Ingredients: 1 1/2 pounds large shrimp, shelled/n1/2 cup olive oil, divided/n2 cloves garlic, minced/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, divided/n1 small onion, minced/n1 tablespoon chopped flat-leaf parsley/n1 1/2 tablespoons chopped fresh sage leaves, or 1 1/2 teaspoons dried sage/n1 tablespoon wine vinegar/n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper/n3 1/3 cups drained and rinsed cannellini beans (two 15-ounce cans)
Steps: Step 1: Light the grill or heat the broiler. Thread the shrimp onto four skewers. In a shallow glass dish, combine 1/4 cup of the oil with the garlic and 1/4 teaspoon of the salt. Add the skewers and turn to coat the shrimp. Set aside./nStep 2: In a medium bowl, combine the onion with the remaining 1/4 cup oil and 1/4 teaspoon salt, the parsley, sage, vinegar, and pepper. Gently stir in the beans./nStep 3: Grill or broil the shrimp, turning once, until just done, about 5 minutes in all. Serve the shrimp with the bean salad./nStep 4: Test kitchen tip: We put the shrimp on skewers before grilling so that they don't fall through the grate. If you don't have metal skewers, the disposable wooden ones work just fine. Soak them in water for 10 or 15 minutes before using them so that they don't burn up. Or you could use a grilling basket./nStep 5: The beans and the shrimp require a white with good body and full flavor. Tocai Friulano gives you both, while at the same time contributing a lively acidity that refreshes the palate.

Ingredients: 1 pound very fresh fava beans in the pods, rinsed/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 scallion, thinly sliced crosswise/n1/2 teaspoon crushed red pepper or Chinese chile sauce/nKosher salt/nLemon wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Light a grill. In a large bowl, toss the fava bean pods with the olive oil. Grill the favas over high heat for about 5 minutes, turning occasionally, until softened and charred in spots. Return the beans to the bowl and toss with the scallion, crushed red pepper and salt. Transfer to a platter and serve with lemon wedges.

Ingredients: 1/4 pound sliced bacon, cut crosswise into 1/4-inch strips/n1 onion, chopped/n1 tablespoon chili powder/n1/2 teaspoon unsweetened cocoa powder/n1/4 teaspoon Tabasco sauce/n2 teaspoons dried oregano/n2 teaspoons salt/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n1 3/4 cups canned crushed tomatoes in thick puree (one 15-ounce can)/n1 quart canned low-sodium chicken broth or homemade stock/n1 2/3 cups drained and rinsed canned black beans (one 15-ounce can)/n1 1-pound piece cooked deli turkey, cut into 1/2-by-1/2-by-1/4-inch slices/n10 ounces spinach, stems removed, leaves washed and cut crosswise into 1-inch strips
Steps: Step 1: In a large stainless-steel pot, cook the bacon until crisp. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Pour off all but 1 tablespoon of fat from the pot./nStep 2: Reduce the heat to moderately low. Add the onion to the pot and cook, stirring, until translucent, about 5 minutes. Stir in the chili powder, cocoa, Tabasco sauce, oregano, salt, pepper, tomatoes, and broth. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 15 minutes./nStep 3: Add the black beans and turkey to the pot. Simmer for 5 minutes. Stir in the spinach and the bacon. Cook until the spinach just wilts, about 1 minute./nStep 4: VariationsUse smoked turkey in place of plain./nStep 5: Substitute 12/3 cups drained and rinsed kidney, pinto, or cannellini beans for the black beans./nStep 6: You need a lusty red wine with plenty of spiciness and fruit flavor to stand up to this powerful soup. That describes Zinfandel to a T, so try one here.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, divided/n3 garlic cloves, very finely chopped/n1 teaspoon finely chopped sage/n1/2 teaspoon finely chopped rosemary/n2 1/2 (15-ounce) cans cannellini beans, drained/n2 tablespoons water/nKosher salt/nCayenne pepper/nPita chips, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a medium skillet, heat 1/4 cup of the olive oil until shimmering. Add the garlic, sage, and rosemary; cook over moderately high heat, stirring, until fragrant and the garlic is just beginning to brown, about 1 minute. Add the beans and toss to coat./nStep 2: Transfer the cannellini beans to a food processor. Add the water, season with salt and cayenne, and process to a fairly smooth puree. Transfer the dip to a small serving bowl, drizzle the remaining 2 tablespoons of olive oil on top, and serve with pita chips./nStep 3: Drizzling a high-quality olive oil over this dip will add depth and complexity, but stick with a less-expensive supermarket brand when sautéing the garlic and herbs in Step 1./nStep 4: Any canned white beans can be used in place of the cannellini.

Ingredients: 3 cups vegetable oil (for frying)/n15 ounce cans chickpeas (drained, rinsed and patted dry)/n1 ½ tablespoons ground coriander/n1 tablespoon ground cumin/n1 cup all-purpose flour/nSalt
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, heat the oil to 350°. Line a baking sheet with paper towels. In a medium bowl, toss the chickpeas with the coriander and cumin. Add the flour and toss until the chickpeas are coated; transfer to a sieve and tap off the excess flour./nStep 2: Add one-third of the chickpeas at a time to the hot oil and fry, stirring occasionally, until they are browned and crispy, about 8 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the chickpeas to the paper towels to drain and sprinkle liberally with salt. Let the vegetable oil return to 350° between batches. Let the chickpeas cool, then transfer them to a bowl and serve./nStep 3: The fried chickpeas can kept at room temperature for up to 4 hours.

Ingredients: 2 teaspoons ground anardana (dried pomegranate arils)/n1 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more to taste/n1 teaspoon granulated sugar/n¼ teaspoon black salt/n4 cups thin poha (flattened rice flakes) (about 7 ounces)/n3 tablespoons corn oil, peanut oil, or untoasted sesame oil/n.50 cup raw skin-on peanuts (about 2 1/2 ounces)/n.50 cup raw cashews (about 2 1/2 ounces)/n.50 cup unsweetened shaved dried coconut (about 3/4 ounce)/n1 teaspoon black mustard seeds/n1 tablespoon fennel seeds/n1 tablespoon white poppy seeds/n1 tablespoon white sesame seeds/n1 - 4  fresh Indian green chiles or Thai green chiles, to taste, thinly sliced/n12 - 15  fresh curry leaves, to taste/n¼ teaspoon asafoetida (hing) powder/n.50 cup dalia (roasted split chickpeas) (about 1 3/4 ounces)/n.3333 cup black raisins (about 1 3/4 ounces)/n1 teaspoon Kashmiri red chile powder (optional)/n.50 teaspoon ground turmeric
Steps: Step 1: Stir together anardana, kosher salt, sugar, and black salt in a small bowl; set masala mixture aside./nStep 2: Place poha in a large (12-inch) heavy-bottomed high-sided skillet; place a large bowl nearby. Cook poha over medium, stirring constantly, until it starts to dry out and crisp but doesn't pick up any color, 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer to large bowl. Wipe out any dust from skillet. Return skillet to heat over medium, and add oil. Add peanuts; cook, stirring constantly, until lightly browned and fragrant, 2 to 3 minutes, reducing heat if peanuts brown too quickly. Remove peanuts using a slotted spoon, and add to poha in bowl. Add cashews to skillet; cook, stirring constantly, until lightly browned, 30 seconds to 1 minute. Transfer to poha mixture in bowl. Add dried coconut to skillet; cook, stirring constantly, until lightly browned, 30 seconds to 1 minute. Transfer to poha mixture in bowl. Add mustard seeds to skillet. (They will foam up and may pop.) Cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, 30 to 40 seconds. Add fennel seeds, poppy seeds, and sesame seeds to skillet. Cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, 30 to 40 seconds. Add chiles and curry leaves. (These will crackle, and some seeds will pop out of skillet.) Cook, stirring constantly, until chiles are just softened and leaves are wilted, 30 to 45 seconds. Add asafoetida; cook, stirring constantly, 15 seconds. Add dalia; cook, stirring constantly, 15 seconds. Add raisins; cook, stirring constantly, 15 seconds. Add chile powder (if using) and turmeric; cook, stirring constantly, 20 seconds. Add reserved masala mixture; cook, stirring constantly, 5 seconds. Immediately add chile mixture to poha mixture in bowl; stir until well combined. Season with additional kosher salt to taste./nStep 3: Find anardana, thin poha, asafoetida, dalia, and Kashmiri chile powder at South Asian grocery stores or online at desiclik.com./nStep 4: Store in an airtight container at room temperature up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n3 pounds ground turkey/n1 medium onion, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n3 garlic cloves, minced/n1 1/2 tablespoons chile powder/n1 teaspoon ground cumin/n1 teaspoon dried oregano/n3/4 teaspoon chipotle powder/n1 large carrot, cut into 1/4-inch dice/n1 red bell pepper, cut into 1/2-inch dice/nOne 28-ounce can tomato puree/nThree 15-ounce cans pinto beans, drained/n3/4 cup lager/n1 cup chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n1 tablespoon cider vinegar/n1 teaspoon chopped thyme/nSalt and freshly ground black pepper/nChopped chives, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a large Dutch oven, heat 1 tablespoon of the oil until shimmering. Add half of the turkey and cook over high heat, undisturbed, until browned on the bottom, about 3 minutes. Stir the turkey and cook until no pink remains, about 2 minutes longer. Transfer the cooked turkey to a bowl and repeat with 1 more tablespoon of oil and the remaining turkey./nStep 2: Add the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil and the onion to the pot. Cook over moderate heat until softened, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic, chile powder, cumin, oregano and chipotle powder and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Return the turkey to the pot. Stir in the carrot, bell pepper, tomato puree, beans and lager and bring to a boil. Stir in the stock and vinegar, cover and simmer over low heat for 45 minutes. Add the thyme, season with salt and pepper and serve, garnished with chives./nStep 3: Crisp, malty lager: Blue Point Brewing Company Toasted Lager.

Ingredients: 2 teaspoons fennel seeds/n2 teaspoons cumin seeds/n2 teaspoons coriander seeds/n1/4 cup peanut oil/n3 medium carrots, coarsely shredded/n2 medium red onions, halved lengthwise and thinly sliced crosswise/n1 medium leek, white and tender green parts only, thinly sliced/n4 garlic cloves, minced/n2 teaspoons minced fresh ginger/n1 small fresh red chile, seeded and minced/n5 cups water/n2 3/4 cups unsweetened coconut milk/n6 makrut lime leaves or six 1-inch strips of lime zest/n3/4 cup red lentils/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n2 small garlic cloves, smashed/n1/4 cup cilantro leaves/n1/4 cup mint leaves/n1 pound large shrimp, shelled and deveined/n1 tablespoon cornstarch/n1 tablespoon plus 2 teaspoons fish sauce, plus more for serving/n1/2 teaspoon sesame oil/n1/4 cup fresh lime juice/n1/2 cup finely chopped cilantro
Steps: Step 1: In a small skillet, toast the fennel, cumin and coriander seeds over moderate heat until fragrant, about 2 minutes; let cool. Transfer to a spice grinder and finely grind the spices./nStep 2: In a medium casserole, heat the oil until shimmering. Add the carrots, onions, leek, garlic, ginger and chile and cook over moderately high heat until softened and lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Add the ground spices and cook until fragrant, about 2 minutes longer. Add the water, coconut milk and lime leaves and bring to a boil. Stir in the lentils and simmer over low heat, stirring occasionally, until tender, about 20 minutes. Season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: In a food processor, combine the garlic with the cilantro and mint and pulse until finely chopped. Add the shrimp and pulse until coarsely chopped. Transfer the mixture to a bowl and stir in the cornstarch, 1 tablespoon of fish sauce and the sesame oil. Refrigerate for 30 minutes./nStep 4: Using slightly moistened hands, roll teaspoons of the shrimp mixture into balls and arrange on a plastic wrap-lined plate./nStep 5: Add the shrimp dumplings and the 2 teaspoons of fish sauce to the casserole and simmer just until the dumplings are slightly pink and cooked, about 5 minutes. Remove the lime leaves. Stir in the lime juice and cilantro and serve, passing the fish sauce at the table./nStep 6: The soup can be prepared through Step 2 and refrigerated overnight. The shrimp balls can be refrigerated overnight./nStep 7: This rich, spicy soup demands a dry and fruity white such as a Sauvignon Blanc.

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n2 ounces pancetta (finely diced)/n1  large onion (finely chopped)/n2  celery ribs (thinly sliced)/n4  garlic cloves (thinly sliced)/n1  leek (white and tender green parts thinly sliced,)/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n½ pound Savoy or other green cabbage (coarsely shredded)/n14 ounce can diced tomatoes/n1 cup dried black-eyed peas/n2 quarts water/n3  parsley sprigs/n1  bay leaf/n3  thyme sprigs/n15 ounce can red kidney beans (drained and rinsed)/n2 ounces penne/n½ cup shredded basil/n¼ cup plus 2 tablespoons grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese
Steps: Step 1: In a pot, heat 2 tablespoons of the oil. Add the pancetta, onion, celery, garlic and sliced leek and season with salt and pepper. Cook over moderate heat, until the vegetables are softened, 10 minutes. Add the cabbage and cook until slightly wilted, 1 minute. Add the tomatoes and cook for about 5 minutes. Add the black-eyed peas and water; bring to a boil. Wrap the parsley, bay leaf and thyme in the reserved leek top and secure with kitchen twine. Add to the pot./nStep 2: Cover the pot and simmer over low heat until the black-eyed peas are tender, 45 minutes. Discard the herbs. Add the kidney beans and simmer for 10 minutes longer./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a pot of boiling salted water, cook the penne until al dente. Drain and cool under running water. Slice the penne crosswise into 1/4-inch rings./nStep 4: In a nonstick skillet, heat the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil. Add the penne in a single layer and cook over moderately high heat, turning once, until golden, 5 minutes. Drain the penne rings on paper towels./nStep 5: Stir the pasta and basil into the soup. Ladle the soup into bowls, sprinkle each with 1 tablespoon of the cheese and serve./nStep 6: One Serving 361 cal, 14 gm fat, 3.5 gm sat fat, 43 gm carb, 11 gm fiber.

Ingredients: 14 ounces medium tofu/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil, divided/n1/4 cup water/n2 tablespoons black bean sauce/n1 teaspoon chili-garlic sauce/n1 teaspoon honey/n1 teaspoon corn starch/n1/4 teaspoon white vinegar/n1 clove of garlic, finely minced/n2 eggplants, cut in half lengthwise then cut into 1-inch slices/n6 kale leaves, ribs removed and torn into bite-sized pieces/nRice or noodles, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Place the tofu on a large plate with a small lip to catch water. Put a small plate on top of the tofu and something heavy (like a can of beans) on top of the plate. After 15 minutes discard the water that has drained from the tofu and cut it into 2-inch cubes./nStep 2: Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a well-seasoned cast iron pan or non-stick pan over medium high heat. Add the tofu and give the pan a shake so it doesn't stick. Cook for 5-7 minutes, or until the tofu is crispy and brown. Turn each piece over and continue cooking until lightly browned, about 5 more minutes. Add more oil if sticking./nStep 3: In a small bowl whisk together the water, black bean sauce, chili-garlic sauce, honey, white vinegar and garlic. Set aside./nStep 4: Add the remaining tablespoon of oil to a large frying pan or wok over medium high heat. Add the eggplant and cook, stirring frequently, until it is soft, about 8-10 minutes. Add the kale and cook until it just starts to wilt, about 1 minute. Add the crispy tofu and the sauce and cook until the sauce is thick and coats the vegetables, about 30 seconds./nStep 5: Remove from the heat and serve with rice or noodles.

Ingredients: ¼ cup vegetable oil/n¾ pound zucchini (about 2 small cut into 3/4-inch pieces)/n½ pound okra (tops trimmed)/n4  scallions (cut into 1/2 -inch pieces)/n1  serrano chile (seeded and thinly sliced)/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n15 ounce can chickpeas (drained)/n1 ½ tablespoons Madras curry powder/n1  large tomato (coarsely chopped)/n4 ounces baby spinach ( cups)/n2 tablespoons water/n¼ cup plain whole-milk yogurt/n4  large pita breads (warmed)/nCilantro sprigs (for garnish)
Steps: Step 1: In a large, deep skillet, heat the oil. Add the zucchini, okra, scallions and chile and season with salt and pepper. Cook over high heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are crisp-tender and lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Add the chickpeas and curry and cook over moderate heat, stirring, for 3 minutes. Add the tomato and spinach and cook, stirring occasionally, until the spinach is wilted and the tomato is just beginning to soften, about 3 minutes. Add the water and scrape up any browned bits stuck to the skillet. Season the vegetables with salt and pepper and stir in the yogurt. Stuff the pitas with the vegetables, garnish with the cilantro sprigs and serve./nStep 2: Plummy, medium-bodied Rosso di Montalcino.

Ingredients: 1 clove garlic/n1/4 teaspoon ground cumin/nOne 15-ounce can black beans, rinsed and drained/n1 can chipotle chile in adobo sauce/n1/4 cup tightly packed cilantro leaves/n2 tablespoons lime juice/n1 teaspoon salt/n2 tablespoons finely grated cotija cheese
Steps: Step 1: Combine the garlic, cumin, beans, chipotle, cilantro, lime juice and salt in a small food processor. Add 1/4 cup warm water and puree until smooth. Taste for seasoning.

Ingredients: 1 cup quinoa/n1 (15-ounce) can chickpeas, rinsed and drained/n4 ounces baby spinach (about 4 cups), coarsely chopped/n2 ripe tomatoes, cored, seeded and chopped/n3 scallions, chopped/n2 ounces feta cheese, crumbled (about 1/2 cup)/n3 tablespoons freshly squeezed lemon juice/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper
Steps: Step 1: Rinse the quinoa in 3 changes of water in a bowl, rubbing the grains and letting them settle each time before pouring off the water (if the quinoa does not settle, drain in a large fine-mesh sieve after each rinse)./nStep 2: Cook the quinoa in a medium saucepan of boiling well-salted water until tender, about 15 minutes. Drain well in a sieve and let cool./nStep 3: Combine the chickpeas, spinach, tomatoes, scallions and cooled quinoa in a large bowl. Add the feta, lemon juice and olive oil and toss gently but thoroughly to combine. Season to taste with salt and pepper./nStep 4: The salad can be made 2 hours ahead.

Ingredients: 2 cups dried zolfini or cannellini beans, picked over and rinsed/n1 sage sprig, plus 1/2 teaspoon chopped sage/n2 garlic cloves, 1 minced/n1 small bay leaf/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nSalt/n1 cup canned tomato sauce/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: Cover the beans with 2 inches of water and bring to a boil. Cover and remove from the heat. Let stand for 1 hour, then drain./nStep 2: Cover the beans with 4 inches of fresh water. Add the sage sprig, whole garlic clove, bay leaf and 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Bring to a boil and cook over moderately low heat for 30 minutes. Season the beans with salt and cook for about 15 minutes longer, until the beans are tender; drain and discard the sage, garlic and bay leaf./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a medium, deep skillet, heat the remaining 1/4 cup of oil. Add the chopped sage and minced garlic and cook over moderate heat for 1 minute. Add the tomato sauce and bring to a simmer./nStep 4: Add the beans to the skillet and cook, stirring, until saucy and thick, 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper and serve.

Ingredients: 1 cup dried red kidney beans (6 ounces)—picked over, soaked overnight and drained, or 2 1/2 cups canned red kidney beans, rinsed and drained/n1/2 small white onion, minced/n1 bay leaf/n6 cups water/n3/4 cup walnuts (3 ounces)/n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened/n1/4 teaspoon minced garlic/n1 tablespoon minced dill/n1 tablespoon minced basil/n1 tablespoon minced flat-leaf parsley/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/nArmenian string cheese and baguette slices or torn pita, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, combine the dried beans, onion and bay leaf. Add the water and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to moderate and simmer until the beans are tender, 1 1/4 to 1 1/2 hours. Drain the beans in a colander and discard the bay leaf. Let cool completely./nStep 2: Preheat the oven to 350°. Spread the walnuts in a pie plate and bake for about 7 minutes, or until lightly toasted. Transfer the walnuts to a food processor and let them cool completely. Add the cooked dried or drained canned kidney beans, butter and garlic and pulse until smooth. Add the dill, basil and parsley, season with salt and pepper and pulse the bean pâté just until blended./nStep 3: Scrape the bean pâté onto a long sheet of plastic wrap and pat it into a 12-by-2-inch log. Wrap and refrigerate until chilled, at least 1 hour. Slice the pâté 1/2 inch thick and serve with the string cheese and bread./nStep 4: The pâté can be refrigerated for up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 tablespoons cooking oil/n1 onion, chopped/n1 green bell pepper, chopped/n3 cloves garlic, minced/n1 1/2 pounds ground beef/n3 1/3 cups canned whole tomatoes with their juice (one 28-ounce can), broken up/n2 tablespoons tomato paste/n1 tablespoon ground cumin/n1 teaspoon dried oregano/n1 teaspoon salt/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n1 1/3 cups drained and rinsed canned pinto or kidney beans (one 15-ounce can)
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, heat the oil over moderately low heat. Add the onion, bell pepper, and garlic and cook, stirring, until the vegetables start to soften, about 10 minutes. Increase the heat to moderate. Add the ground beef and cook, stirring, until the meat is no longer pink, about 5 minutes./nStep 2: Stir in the tomatoes, tomato paste, cumin, oregano, salt, and black pepper and bring to a simmer. Reduce the heat and simmer, partially covered, for 10 minutes. Add the beans and simmer, partially covered, until the vegetables are tender and the chili thickened, about 5 minutes longer./nStep 3: Variation Add one ten-ounce package of frozen corn, thawed, to the chili along with the beans./nStep 4: Red Zinfandel is just made for chili because it's as flavorful and fun as chili is. If you choose to make the dish spicy with cayenne, the ripe fruity character of Zinfandel can even cool the heat.

Ingredients: 9 cups water/n1 cup dried mung beans/n⅓ cup uncooked Turkish baldo rice/n¼ cup sunflower oil/n1  medium-size yellow onion, chopped (about 1 3/4 cups)/n1  large carrot, cut into 1/4-inch cubes (about 1/2 cup)/n2 tablespoons tomato sauce/n4  fresh or dried bay leaves/n2 teaspoons table salt, divided/n2 ½ cups chopped fresh cilantro leaves and tender stems, divided/n1 ¾ cups chopped fresh tender dill fronds, divided/n¾ cup dried Turkish apricots (preferably unsulfured or organic) (about 5 ounces)/n½ cup plus 1 tablespoon labneh or Greek-style yogurt/n½ teaspoon black pepper
Steps: Step 1: Bring 9 cups water to a boil in a large saucepan over medium-high. Reduce heat to maintain a simmer./nStep 2: Place mung beans in a small saucepan; add enough cold water to cover. Bring to a boil over high. Reduce heat to medium, and simmer about 6 minutes to remove any small particles and dirt. Drain beans in a colander, and transfer to a fine wire-mesh strainer. Rinse under cool water. Set aside./nStep 3: Place rice in a separate fine wire-mesh strainer, and rinse under cold water until water runs clear. Set aside./nStep 4: Pour oil into a large saucepan; heat over medium-high until shimmering, about 1 minute. Add onion, and cook, stirring occasionally, until onion starts to soften, 1 to 2 minutes. Add carrot, and cook, stirring occasionally, until carrot starts to soften, about 2 minutes. Add tomato sauce, and cook, stirring constantly, until vegetables are well coated and sauce thickens slightly, about 2 minutes. Add 1 1/2 cups of the hot water, and cook, stirring occasionally, until mixture comes to a boil, about 30 seconds. Add 1 1/2 cups hot water, rinsed beans, bay leaves, and 1 teaspoon salt, and return to a boil over medium-high. Reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer, covered, stirring occasionally, 10 minutes./nStep 5: If beans are barely covered with water, add 1/2 cup hot water. Cover and cook over medium-low, stirring occasionally, until beans have fully softened and are starting to break apart, 10 to 25 minutes, adding hot water, 1/2 cup at a time, as needed so that water barely covers beans./nStep 6: Add rice, 2 cups cilantro, 1 1/2 cups dill, 2 1/2 cups hot water, and remaining 1 teaspoon salt to bean mixture. Increase heat to medium-high, and cook, stirring constantly, until mixture comes to a boil. Cover and reduce heat to medium-low. Cook, stirring often and adjusting heat as needed to make sure nothing sticks on bottom of pan, until rice is soft and tender, 18 to 20 minutes./nStep 7: Check water level in bean mixture; add 1/2 cup to 1 cup hot water, if needed, until mixture resembles a thick soup but not quite a stew. Add apricots, and cook over low, stirring often, until apricots have softened but are not completely broken down, about 5 minutes. Cover pan, and remove from heat. Let stand 10 minutes for flavors to meld./nStep 8: Uncover soup. Remove and discard bay leaves. Ladle soup evenly into 6 bowls, and mound about 1 tablespoon cilantro and about 2 teaspoons dill into middle of each bowl. Dollop servings with yogurt, and sprinkle with pepper./nStep 9: This soup is best served the day it's made; to reheat, add a little water, and cook very gently to avoid overcooking the apricots./nStep 10: Find Turkish apricots and baldo rice at kalustyans.com./nStep 11: Full-bodied, lightly peppery white: Rousset Crozes-Hermitage

Ingredients: 2 15-ounce cans of chickpeas, drained, rinsed, and dried/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n4 teaspoons curry powder/n2 teaspoons kosher salt/n2 teaspoons garlic powder/n1 teaspoon coriander/n1 teaspoon turmeric/n1 teaspoon cayenne pepper/n1 teaspoon onion powder
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 400º. Toss the chickpeas with oil and 2 tablespoons of the Curry seasoning. Spread on a large baking sheet and bake, uncovered, for 45 minutes, or until golden brown and crunchy./nStep 2: The chickpeas can be roasted up to 1 day ahead. Cool completely and store in an air-tight container. Can be served at room temperature or briefly reheated, about 5 minutes at 400º./nStep 3: Water is the enemy of crunch, so make sure you remove as much moisture as possible after rinsing the chickpeas. Use paper towels to remove any surface moisture, and if you have time, let them air-dry for 30 minutes before tossing with oil and baking.

Ingredients: One 14-ounce package extra-firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes/n3 tablespoons Korean chile powder or hot paprika/n1 tablespoon Korean pepper paste (kochujang)/n1 tablespoon finely grated garlic/n1 tablespoon finely grated ginger/n1 tablespoon toasted-sesame oil/nKosher salt/n1 cup cornstarch/n2 cups vegetable oil, for frying/n12 corn or 5-inch flour tortillas, warmed/nHoisin sauce, kimchi, Asian pear, scallions and chopped honey-roasted peanuts, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Place the tofu on a rack lined with paper towels and drain for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, in a large bowl, combine 1 tablespoon of the chile powder with the pepper paste, garlic, ginger and sesame oil and season with salt. In another large bowl, whisk the cornstarch with the remaining 2 tablespoons of chile powder and 1 tablespoon of salt./nStep 2: In a medium, deep skillet, heat the oil until it reaches 365°. Add the tofu to the chile sauce and stir gently to coat. Scrape the tofu into the cornstarch mixture and toss to coat. Transfer the coated tofu to a colander to tap out the excess cornstarch. Fry the tofu in one batch, stirring occasionally, until golden and crunchy, 3 to 3 1/2 minutes; maintain the heat near 360°. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the crunchy tofu to a paper towel–lined rack and sprinkle with salt. Serve the tofu right away with the tortillas, hoisin sauce, kimchi, Asian pear, scallions and peanuts./nStep 3: Strawberry-scented dry rosé from California.

Ingredients: 1 pound merguez sausage/n1 medium onion, halved/n8 garlic cloves, peeled, 3 finely chopped/n1 carrot, cut into chunks/n1 pound French green (Le Puy) lentils (2 1/4 cups), picked over and rinsed/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt/n1 pound butternut squash, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch chunks/n2 teaspoons ground cumin/n1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon sweet paprika/n1 teaspoon Marash or Aleppo pepper (see Note)/n1 teaspoon harissa/n2 cups vegetable stock or water/nOne 14-ounce can crushed tomatoes/n1 jalapeño, seeded and finely chopped/n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice, plus lemon wedges for serving/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375°. Place the merguez on a rimmed baking sheet and bake until cooked through, about 25 minutes./nStep 2: In a medium saucepan, combine 1 onion half with the whole garlic cloves, the carrot and the lentils. Add enough cold water to cover the lentils by 2 inches. Bring to a boil over high heat, then cover and simmer over moderately low heat until the lentils are just tender, 25 to 30 minutes. Drain; discard the onion, carrot and garlic./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a large enameled cast-iron casserole or Dutch oven, heat the olive oil over moderately high heat. Finely chop the remaining onion half and add it to the casserole along with the chopped garlicand a pinch of salt. Cook, stirring frequently, until the onion is softened. Add the squash, season with salt and cook, stirring frequently, until golden. Add the cumin, paprika, Marash pepper and harissa and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Stir in the vegetable stock and tomatoes andbring to a boil. Reduce the heat, cover and simmer until the squash is tender, about 15 minutes./nStep 4: Stir the lentils, jalapeño and lemon juice into the casserole and season with salt and pepper. Transfer to a platter and top with the sausage. Serve with lemon wedges./nStep 5: Marash and Aleppo pepper are available at Middle Eastern markets and online at vannsspices.com.

Ingredients: 8 cups hot water/n4 smoked ham hocks (2 1/2 pounds)/n1 1/2 cups dried chickpeas, soaked overnight and drained/n3 large carrots, cut into 2-inch lengths/n1 medium onion, cut into 1-inch dice/n2 bay leaves/n2 thyme sprigs/nThree medium (6-ounce) red-skinned potatoes, peeled and quartered/n1/2 cup chopped flat-leaf parsley/nSalt and freshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a slow cooker, combine the water, ham hocks, chickpeas, carrots, bay leaves and thyme sprigs. Cover and cook on high for 1 hour and 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, Add the potatoes, cover and cook on low for 1 hour and 45 minutes, until the chickpeas, ham hocks and potatoes are tender./nStep 2: Transfer the ham hocks to a large plate. Discard the bay leaves and thyme sprigs. When the hocks are cool enough to handle, remove the meat and coarsely chop it. Return the ham to the soup. Using a paring knife, cut the carrots in the cooker into bite-size pieces. Transfer the potatoes to a bowl and mash to a puree. Stir the mashed potatoes into the soup along with the parsley. Season with salt and pepper and serve./nStep 3: The soup can be refrigerated for up to 3 days. Reheat gently./nStep 4: Rich white Rhône blend.

Ingredients: 16  small cebollitas (spring onions) (about 4 bunches) or 1 large white onion, sliced into 1/2-inch rings/n4  medium nopales (cactus paddles) (about 5 ounces each)/n2  large red or green jalapeños (about 1 1/2 ounces each)/n2 tablespoons sunflower oil or other neutral cooking oil (such as canola)/n1 teaspoon fine Himalayan pink salt, plus more to taste/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice/nBlack beans, rice, corn tortillas, avocado slices, and lime wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: If using cebollitas, trim and discard top third of stalks. Peel off and discard outer layer of bulbs. Remove and discard any dry, papery skin from pale green and dark green stalks. Trim and discard any roots. If any bulbs are 3/4 inch round or larger, cut bulb in half lengthwise, cutting into the pale green stalk just a little bit and keeping the stalk intact. (If using a white onion, peel onion, halve it lengthwise, and thinly slice with the grain, following the curve of the onion to keep the slices similar in size.) Set aside./nStep 2: Working with 1 nopal at a time, place nopal flat on a work surface. Hold the base of the paddle with a clean kitchen towel. Using a sharp paring knife, trim about 1/4 inch off the entire perimeter of the paddle; discard. If base of paddle is tough, cut off and discard. Using a sharp knife, scrape off any thorny spines on each side of paddle, being careful not to shave off too much cactus skin. Rinse paddle under cold water, and pat dry with paper towels. Starting about 1 inch from base of each cleaned paddle, make 3 or 4 lengthwise cuts through paddle and toward top of paddle, spacing cuts 1 inch apart. Halve jalapeños lengthwise, keeping stems intact. (Do not remove seeds.)/nStep 3: Heat a large cast-iron comal or a 2-burner cast-iron griddle over high heat until comal is smoking, 5 to 7 minutes. Toss together cebollitas, nopales, jalapeños, oil, and salt on a large rimmed baking sheet./nStep 4: Working in 2 batches, arrange cebollitas and jalapeños in a single layer on hot comal. Cook cebollitas, turning occasionally, until charred in spots and bulbs are tender when pierced with a paring knife, 9 to 14 minutes. Cook jalapeños, turning occasionally, until charred in spots and softened, 12 to 15 minutes. As cebollitas and jalapeños finish cooking, transfer to a serving platter, and cover with aluminum foil to keep warm. (If using white onion, cook on hot comal, stirring occasionally, until softened and lightly charred around edges, about 12 minutes.)/nStep 5: Add nopales to comal. Cook, turning occasionally, until nopales turn a dull green color, are charred in spots, and are tender all the way through, about 8 minutes. Transfer to serving platter. Sprinkle nopales, cebollitas, and jalapeños with additional salt to taste, and drizzle with lime juice. Serve with beans, rice, tortillas, avocado, and lime wedges./nStep 6: Many Mexican grocers sell cleaned and trimmed nopales. If using these prepared nopales, skip the cleaning in the beginning of step 2 and proceed with cutting the paddles at the end of step 2./nStep 7: Lightly malty beer: Saint Arnold H-Town Pils

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon olive oil/n1 pound mild Italian sausage (casings removed)/n1  onion (chopped)/n1  carrot (chopped)/n1  rib celery (chopped)/n1 clove garlic (minced)/n½ teaspoon dried thyme/n1  bay leaf/n4 cups drained and rinsed canned white beans, preferably cannellini (from two 19-ounce cans)/n10 cups water/n1 cup canned diced tomatoes with their juice/n2 teaspoons salt/n1 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n⅔ pound spinach (about 1 1/2 quarts stems removed and leaves washed well)/nGrated Parmesan (for serving)
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, heat the oil over moderately high heat. Add the sausage and cook, stirring frequently, until browned, about 5 minutes. Remove the sausage with a slotted spoon./nStep 2: Reduce the heat to moderate. Add the onion, carrot, celery, garlic, thyme, and bay leaf to the pot and cook, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables soften, about 10 minutes./nStep 3: Meanwhile, combine 2 cups of the beans and 2 cups of the water in a blender and puree until smooth./nStep 4: Add the tomatoes, the bean puree, the remaining 8 cups water, the salt, and the pepper to the pot. Bring to a boil, skimming any foam that rises to the surface. Stir in the sausage, the remaining 2 cups beans, and the spinach. Simmer until the spinach wilts, about 3 minutes. Serve the soup topped with grated Parmesan, and pass more Parmesan at the table./nStep 5: It's only natural to partner this traditional Italian soup with a classic Italian red wine. Either a Tuscan Chianti or a Dolcetto from the hills of Piedmont will be splendid.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup pine nuts/n2 cups flat-leaf parsley leaves/n1 garlic clove, crushed/n1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground pepper/n4 pounds green beans, trimmed/nLemon wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small skillet, toast the pine nuts over moderate heat, tossing, until golden, about 5 minutes; transfer to a food processor and let cool completely./nStep 2: Add the parsley, garlic, lemon zest and lemon juice to the food processor and pulse until the parsley is very finely chopped. With the machine on, gradually add the olive oil and process until the pesto is nearly smooth. Season with salt and pepper and scrape into a large bowl./nStep 3: Put a steamer basket in the bottom of a pot. Fill the pot with 1 inch of water, add salt and bring to a boil. Add the green beans, cover and steam until bright green and crisp-tender, 8 to 10 minutes. Drain the beans and transfer to the large bowl. Toss with the pesto and season with salt and pepper; serve with lemon wedges./nStep 4: The pesto can be refrigerated overnight. Bring to room temperature before tossing with the beans.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup brown or green lentils/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 pound shiitake mushrooms, stems discarded and caps sliced 1/4 inch thick/nSalt/n1 garlic clove, minced/n1/4 teaspoon ground cumin/n1/4 teaspoon ground coriander/n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper/n1/8 teaspoon turmeric/n1 tablespoon chopped parsley/n1/2 pound Swiss chard or other tender greens, large stems discarded and leaves coarsely chopped
Steps: Step 1: In a small saucepan, cover the lentils with 2 1/2 cups of water and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over low heat until the lentils are tender, about 30 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a medium saucepan, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Add the shiitake and season with salt. Cover and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until the mushrooms are tender and starting to brown, 5 minutes. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon of olive oil along with the garlic, cumin, coriander, pepper and turmeric and cook, stirring, until fragrant, 1 minute. Add the greens and cook, stirring, until wilted, 2 minutes./nStep 3: Add the lentils and their cooking liquid to the mushrooms and simmer for 3 minutes. Add up to 1/4 cup of water if the lentils are too dry. Season with salt. Ladle the lentils into bowls, garnish with the parsley and serve./nStep 4: The lentils can be refrigerated for up to 3 days. Reheat gently./nStep 5: One serving 208 cal, 11 gm fat, 1.5 gm sat fat, 24 gm carb, 6 gm fiber./nStep 6: Earthy, spicy Italian Isola dei Nuraghi.

Ingredients: ½ cup toor dal (split yellow pigeon peas)/n1 teaspoon turmeric powder, divided/n2 teaspoons cumin seeds/n2 teaspoons coriander seeds/n1 tablespoon freshly cracked black pepper/n1  (2-inch) piece fresh ginger, peeled and finely chopped/n1  Serrano chile, chopped/n4 large cloves garlic, chopped/n1 teaspoon vegetable oil/n1 teaspoon yellow mustard seeds/n15  curry leaves, torn into pieces/n1  (14.5-oz.) can chopped tomatoes/n¼ teaspoon asafoetida/n½ teaspoon kosher salt/n¼ cup fresh lemon juice (from 1 lemon)/n½ cup chopped cilantro
Steps: Step 1: Rinse pigeon peas, then place in a medium pot with 1/2 teaspoon turmeric and 1 cup water over medium heat. Bring to a boil, then cover and simmer for 15 minutes. Stir, then simmer for another 10 minutes if needed, or until pigeon peas are soft./nStep 2: While dal cooks, combine cumin seeds, coriander seeds, pepper, ginger, chile, and garlic in a blender and blend into a thick paste. Set aside./nStep 3: Mash cooked pigeon peas, then scoop them out of the pot and transfer to a bowl. Wipe pot clean with a paper towel. Heat oil in pot until shimmering, about 1 minute. Add mustard seeds, curry leaves and remaining 1/2 teaspoon turmeric and cook until curry leaves sizzle and mustard seeds begin to pop, about 90 seconds./nStep 4: Add tomatoes with their juices, ginger-garlic spice paste and asafoetida to the pot, and stir until combined. Add cooked pigeon peas, 3 cups water and salt. Stir, then simmer 10 minutes. Stir in lemon juice, taste for seasoning, and top with chopped cilantro.

Ingredients: 1 pound lentils (about 2 1/3 cups)/n1 small onion, halved/n1 carrot, halved/n1 clove garlic/n1 bay leaf/n1/3 cup pecans/n4 tablespoons red- or white-wine vinegar/n1 teaspoon salt/n1/2 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n1/2 cup olive oil/n1 1/2 pounds spinach, stems removed, leaves washed well (about 3 1/2 quarts)/n1/4 pound aged cheddar cheese
Steps: Step 1: In a medium pot, combine the lentils, onion, carrot, garlic, bay leaf, and enough water to cover by 2 inches. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer, partially covered, until the lentils are tender, about 30 minutes. Drain; discard the onion, carrot, garlic, and bay leaf./nStep 2: In a small frying pan, toast the pecans over moderately low heat, stirring frequently, until golden brown, about 5 minutes. Or toast them in a 350° oven for 5 to 10 minutes. Chop them./nStep 3: In a large glass or stainless-steel bowl, whisk together 2 tablespoons of the vinegar, 1/2 teaspoon of the salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of the pepper. Add the oil slowly, whisking./nStep 4: Shred half the spinach and put in a large glass or stainless-steel bowl. Add the hot lentils and toss with half the dressing, the remaining 2 tablespoons vinegar, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Toss the mixture gently until the spinach wilts./nStep 5: Toss the remaining spinach into the remaining dressing and put on plates. Top with the lentil mixture and the toasted pecans. Using a vegetable peeler, shave the cheese over the top./nStep 6: This salad, with its lentils and rich cheddar, can easily stand up to a fruity red wine. A Petite Sirah's roasted-berry flavors make it just right for the part.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons olive oil/n2 cups chopped yellow onion (from 1 large onion)/n1 cup chopped poblano chile (from 1 chile)/n8 garlic cloves, minced/n3 pounds 90/10 lean ground chuck/n1 (6-ounce) can tomato paste/n1/3 cup ancho chile powder/n2 tablespoons ground cumin/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n1 teaspoon black pepper/n1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves/n1 teaspoon chopped fresh oregano/n2 (15-ounce) cans dark red kidney beans, drained and rinsed/n1 (15-ounce) can black beans, drained and rinsed/n1 (28-ounce) can crushed tomatoes/n2 cups lower-sodium chicken broth/n1 (12-ounce) bottle of beer/nShredded cheddar cheese, sliced jalapeño chiles, sliced radishes, and sour cream, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Molly Bolton/nStep 2: Ingredients./nStep 3: Molly Bolton/nStep 4: Heat oil in a large Dutch oven over medium-high. Add onion, poblano, and garlic and cook, stirring often, until tender, about 5 minutes./nStep 5: Molly Bolton/nStep 6: Add ground chuck and cook, stirring occasionally, until beef crumbles and is no longer pink, 8 to 10 minutes./nStep 7: Molly Bolton/nStep 8: Drain beef mixture well and return to Dutch oven over medium-high./nStep 9: Molly Bolton/nStep 10: Add tomato paste, ancho chile powder, cumin, salt, pepper, thyme, and oregano and cook, stirring often, 2 minutes./nStep 11: Molly Bolton/nStep 12: Increase heat to high. Stir in beans, tomatoes, chicken broth, and beer and bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer, stirring occasionally, until heated through, about 30 minutes./nStep 13: Molly Bolton/nStep 14: Serve chili with desired toppings./nStep 15: Molly Bolton

Ingredients: 1 1/4 pounds thick-sliced bacon, cut crosswise into 1/4-inch strips/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 Spanish onion, finely chopped/n1 large carrot, finely diced/n2 celery ribs, finely diced/n4 garlic cloves, minced/n1 fresh bay leaf/n2 teaspoons chopped fresh thyme, divided/n2 teaspoons chopped fresh rosemary, divided/n1 pound dried Great Northern beans, soaked overnight and drained/n10 cups chicken stock/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a large soup pot, cook the bacon over moderate heat, stirring, until browned and crisp, about 7 minutes. Drain, reserving the fat and bacon separately./nStep 2: Heat the olive oil in the soup pot. Add the onion, carrot, and celery and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are softened, about 8 minutes. Stir in the garlic, bay leaf, and 1 teaspoon each of the chopped thyme and rosemary and cook until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Add the drained beans, stock, and 3 tablespoons of the reserved bacon fat and bring to a boil. Simmer the soup over moderately low heat until the beans are tender, about 1 1/2 hours./nStep 3: Discard the bay leaf and stir in the remaining thyme and rosemary. Season the soup with salt and pepper and transfer to shallow bowls. Garnish the soup with the bacon and serve./nStep 4: The soup and bacon can be refrigerated separately for up to 3 days. Recrisp the bacon before serving./nStep 5: Bright, citrusy Albariño.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons honey/n1 tablespoon lime juice/n1 small garlic clove, minced/n2 teaspoons pumpkin seed oil/n2 teaspoons walnut oil/n3 tablespoons olive oil/n4 pounds fresh fava beans, shelled (3 cups)/n1 tablespoon olive oil/n1/2 cup pine nuts/n1/2 cup shelled pistachios/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper/n2 lemons/n5 medium fennel bulbs—trimmed, halved lengthwise, cored and very thinly sliced crosswise/n1 medium jalapeño, seeded and minced/nPinch of cayenne pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a very large bowl, whisk the honey with the lime juice, garlic and pumpkin seed, walnut and olive oils./nStep 2: In a large saucepan of salted boiling water, blanch the fava beans until just tender, 3 to 5 minutes. Drain and rinse under cold water. Squeeze the favas from their skins; discard the skins./nStep 3: In a medium skillet, heat the olive oil until shimmering. Add the pine nuts and pistachios and cook over moderate heat, shaking the pan frequently, until the nuts are golden, about 5 minutes. Season the nuts with salt and black pepper and transfer them to paper towels to drain and cool completely./nStep 4: Using a very sharp knife, peel the lemons, being sure to remove all of the bitter white pith. Thinly slice the lemons crosswise. Pick out and discard any seeds, then cut the lemon slices into thin strips./nStep 5: Stir the lemon strips into the dressing. Add the fava beans, fennel, jalapeño, cayenne and toasted pine nuts and pistachios and toss. Season the salad with salt and black pepper and toss again. Serve the salad right away./nStep 6: A fresh and zesty unoaked Chardonnay.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon vegetable oil, plus more for the ramps/n2 pounds boneless chuck roast/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper/n1 large onion, thinly sliced/n4 cloves garlic, smashed/nOne 12-ounce bottle Negra Modelo beer/nOne 15-ounce can pinto beans, drained/n1 bunch ramps (about 8 ramps) or scallions, root ends trimmed/n8 to 10 ounces tortilla chips (1 medium bag)/n8 ounces Monterey Jack cheese, grated (2 cups)/n1⁄2 cup sliced pickled Fresno or jalapeño peppers/n1 cup Homemade Crema (see Note) or sour cream
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. Heat the oil in a large heavy-bottomed saucepan or Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Season the beef all over with salt and pepper and sear it on all sides until well browned, about 3 minutes a side. Transfer the meat to a plate. Add the onion and garlic to the pan and cook over medium-low heat, stirring occasionally, until the onion has caramelized and is very soft, about 20 minutes. Add the beer and, using a wooden spoon, scrape up any browned bits on the bottom of the pan. Return the beef to the pan, cover and roast, checking every 30 minutes, until the beef shreds easily with a fork, 2 to 3 hours. When the meat is cool enough to handle, shred it into its braising liquid, then stir in the beans./nStep 2: Meanwhile, preheat the broiler. Place the ramps on a rimmed baking sheet, brush with oil and season with salt. Broil the ramps, turning every 30 seconds or so, until charred all over, 2 to 3 minutes total. Transfer to a cutting board and chop coarsely./nStep 3: Scatter half of the chips on a rimmed baking sheet. Scatter half of the cheese over the chips. Repeat to make a second layer. Broil the chips until the cheese has melted, about 2 minutes. Top the chips with the shredded beef–bean mixture and broil again to heat the meat through, about 1 minute. Top with the charred ramps and pickled peppers. Drizzle the crema over the top and serve./nStep 4: Homemade Crema

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons coconut oil/n1 teaspoon cumin seeds/n1 teaspoon fennel seeds/n1 teaspoon ground turmeric/n2 onions, halved and thinly sliced/n3 garlic cloves, finely chopped/n2 tablespoons finely chopped fresh ginger/n2 small fresh red chiles, thinly sliced/n1 quart chicken stock or broth/nOne 14-ounce can unsweetened coconut milk/n2 cups red lentils, picked over (13 ounces)/n2 tablespoons chopped cilantro stems, plus chopped leaves for garnish/n1/2 pound kale, stemmed and leaves coarsely chopped (4 cups)/n1 1/2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice, plus lemon wedges for serving/nSea salt/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, heat 1 tablespoon of the coconut oil. Add the cumin, fennel and turmeric and cook over moderate heat, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Stir in the remaining 2 tablespoons of coconut oil and the onions and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, 6 to 7 minutes. Add the garlic, ginger and half of the sliced chiles and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Spoon half of the spiced onion mixture into a small bowl and reserve./nStep 2: Add the chicken stock, coconut milk, red lentils and cilantro stems to the saucepan and bring to a simmer. Cook over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until the lentils are tender, about 20 minutes. Add the kale and cook until tender, about 5 minutes. Stir in the lemon juice and season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: Spoon the dal into bowls. Top with the reserved onion mixture and the remaining sliced chiles. Garnish with chopped cilantro and serve with lemon wedges./nStep 4: The dal can be refrigerated for 2 days. Reheat gently, adding more water if necessary to help thin it out./nStep 5: Juicy Chenin Blanc from the Loire Valley is a good pick for dishes that have a lot of varied flavors, like this coconutty, spicy dal.

Ingredients: One 14 ounce (396g) package firm tofu, drained and rinsed/n2 tablespoons grapeseed or canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil)
Steps: Step 1: Pat the tofu dry with paper towels to remove excess water. Cut into 1-inch slices./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the oil and after the oil is hot, carefully add the tofu into a single layer (hot oil may splatter). Sear each side for 1-2 minutes, or until at least 2-3 sides are golden and crisped./nStep 3: Drain on paper towels.

Ingredients: 4 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature/n9 squash blossoms, stems and pistils removed and petals finely chopped (1/2 cup), plus whole petals for garnish/n8 ounces green beans, trimmed/n6 ounces wax beans, trimmed/n1/2 pound spaghetti/n1/4 cup snipped chives/n2 tablespoons chopped basil leaves, plus small leaves for garnish/n2 tablespoons finely grated Pecorino Toscano or Romano cheese, plus more for serving/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zestplus 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/nKosher salt/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, mix the butter with the chopped squash blossom petals./nStep 2: Prepare an ice bath. In a large pot of salted boiling water, blanch the green and wax beans until crisp-tender, about 3 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the beans to the ice bath to cool completely. Drain, pat dry and halve the beans lengthwise./nStep 3: Meanwhile, return the water to a boil. Cook the pasta until al dente. Drain, reserving 1 1/2 cups of the cooking water./nStep 4: In a large skillet, melt the squash blossom butter. Add the pasta and pasta water and bring to a boil over moderately high heat. Add the beans and cook, stirring, until the sauce is thickened and the beans are heated through, about 2 minutes. Add the chives, the chopped basil, the 2 tablespoons of cheese, and the lemon zest and lemon juice; season with salt and pepper. Transfer the pasta to shallow bowls and garnish with more cheese, squash blossom petals and basil leaves; serve.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n3 garlic cloves, peeled/n2 celery ribs, finely chopped/n2 carrots, finely chopped/n1 onion, finely chopped/nOne 16-ounce can whole tomatoes, chopped and juices reserved/n1 bay leaf/n1 cup green or brown lentils/n3/4 pound smoked turkey wing and thigh/n4 small red potatoes, peeled and sliced 1/4 inch thick/n1/4 cup chopped flat-leaf parsley/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/nFreshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, heat the oil. Add the garlic, celery, carrots and onion and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until softened, 7 minutes. Add the tomatoes, bay leaf, lentils, smoked turkey and 2 quarts of water and bring to a boil. Cover partially and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the lentils are very tender, 1 hour. Add the potatoes and simmer until tender, 10 minutes./nStep 2: Remove the turkey meat from the bones and return it to the soup; discard the skin, bones and bay leaf. Add the parsley and season the soup with salt and pepper. Ladle the soup into bowls and serve, passing the cheese at the table./nStep 3: The lentil soup can be refrigerated for up to 3 days./nStep 4: Earthy and smoky, this soup could go with a full-bodied white or a lighter red. If guests prefer white, try a Vouvray; for a red, consider an Oregon Pinot Noir.

Ingredients: 1 16-ounce package extra firm tofu/n3 tablespoon canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil), divided/n1/2 medium onion, sliced/n1 tablespoon hoisin sauce/n1 tablespoon fish sauce/n2 ears of corn, shucked (about 2 cups)/nKosher or sea salt, to taste/nFresh cracked black pepper, to taste/nChopped cilantro, to garnish/nSoy sauce, drizzled to finish (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Drain the tofu and slice into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Pat slices dry with paper towels. Season both sides with salt and pepper./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over heat. Add 2 tablespoons of oil, and then carefully add the tofu (hot oil may splatter). Sear both sides of the tofu until golden brown, 2-3 minutes each side. Remove the tofu from the pan and drain on paper towel towels./nStep 3: Turn the heat down to medium heat. Add the final tablespoon of oil to the pan. Stir in the onions and cook until caramelized and golden brown, about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally./nStep 4: Stir in the hoisin and fish sauce. Stir in the corn. Cook for 2-3 minutes or until the corn is tender./nStep 5: Layer several pieces of tofu on each plate. Add a couple spoonfuls of corn mixture over tofu. Garnish with cilantro and drizzle with soy sauce if desired. Serve warm.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons cooking oil/n1 onion, chopped/n2 carrots, diced/n2 ribs celery, diced/n1 red bell pepper, diced/n1 1/2 teaspoons salt/n3 cups water/n3 cups canned low-sodium chicken broth or homemade stock/n2 cups drained and rinsed canned black beans (one 19-ounce can)/n1 jalapeÑo pepper, seeds and ribs removed, minced/n1/2 pound sliced deli corned beef, cut crosswise into thin strips/n1 1/2 tablespoons red- or white-wine vinegar/n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, heat the oil over moderate heat. Add the onion, carrots, celery, bell pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt and cook, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables start to soften, about 10 minutes./nStep 2: Add the water, broth, and the remaining teaspoon of salt to the pot. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer until the vegetables are tender, about 10 minutes. Stir the beans and jalapeño into the soup and simmer for 5 minutes more./nStep 3: Remove the pot from the heat and stir in the corned beef, vinegar, and parsley./nStep 4: If you make the soup ahead of time, wait to stir in the last three ingredients until you're ready to serve. Otherwise, the flavor of the corned beef will leach out into the broth, the vinegar will lose its bite, and the parsley will turn brown./nStep 5: This hearty soup calls for an equally hearty wine. Look for Australia's unique Cabernet Sauvignon/Shiraz blend, a red wine redolent of blackberries, cassis, herbs, and eucalyptus. Its full body and frank fruitiness are just what you want.

Ingredients: Two 15-ounce cans of chickpeas—rinsed, drained and patted dry/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 teaspoon ground cumin/n1 teaspoon ground coriander/n1 teaspoon chile powder/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. In a medium bowl, toss the chickpeas with the olive oil, cumin, coriander and chile powder and season with salt and pepper. Spread the chickpeas on a rimmed baking sheet and roast for 30 minutes, or until slightly crisp and golden brown. Serve warm or at room temperature.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 large white onions, whole onion cut in half/n4 habanero chiles, stemmed/n7 plum tomatoes, divided/n1 cup packed cilantro leaves and thin stems/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n2 garlic cloves, smashed/nKosher salt/nPepper/n1/4 cup finely chopped cilantro/n3 tablespoons fresh orange juice/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice/n2 1/2 pounds boneless pork shoulder roast, cut into 1/2-inch pieces/n1/4 cup pork lard/n6 garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n10 cups water/n1 (16-ounce) package dried black beans, soaked overnight, drained/n1 tablespoon dried epazote/nDiced radish, diced avocado, finely chopped white onion, cilantro leaves, lime wedges, steamed white rice, and warm corn tortillas, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Heat a large cast-iron skillet over high heat. Add onion halves, cut side down, and habaneros. Cook, turning occasionally, until charred all over, about 10 minutes. Transfer onions and habaneros to a plate, and let cool slightly. Core and thinly slice 2 of the charred onion halves. Mince enough of the thinly sliced onion to equal 1/4 cup minced onion. Place sliced onion and minced onion in separate small bowls./nStep 2: Roughly chop remaining charred onion half, 1 habanero, and 6 tomatoes, and place in a blender. Add cilantro leaves and stems, olive oil, and smashed garlic cloves, and puree until smooth. Season with salt. Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve./nStep 3: Finely chop remaining 3 charred habaneros and remaining tomato, and scrape into a medium bowl. Stir in minced charred onion, chopped cilantro, orange juice, and lime juice. Season with salt. Cover and refrigerate until ready to serve./nStep 4: Season pork generously with salt and pepper. Heat lard in a large Dutch oven or heavy pot. Add pork and cook over moderately high heat, turning occasionally, until browned all over, about 10 minutes. Transfer pork to a plate./nStep 5: Add thinly sliced charred onion and thinly sliced garlic to pot, and cook, stirring occasionally, until slightly softened, about 3 minutes. Return pork and any accumulated juices to pot, and add 10 cups water, beans, and epazote. Bring to a boil. Reduce heat to low, and simmer, partially covered, until pork and beans are very tender, about 2 hours. Season with salt, and let stand 15 minutes./nStep 6: Using a slotted spoon, remove pork and beans from the broth to a platter. Using two forks, shred pork. Serve with salsas, radish, avocado, chopped onion, cilantro leaves, lime wedges, rice, and tortillas.

Ingredients: 1 pound green split peas/n3 quarts water/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n2 celery ribs, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n2 carrots, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n1 onion, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n1 teaspoon marjoram leaves/n1 teaspoon thyme leaves/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/nParsley Pistou, Onion Rings and crispy bacon (optional), for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, combine the split peas and water and bring to a boil. Simmer for 2 minutes, cover and let stand for 1 hour./nStep 2: In a medium skillet, heat the oil. Add the celery, carrots, onion, marjoram and thyme and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are softened, 8 minutes. Scrape the mixture into the split peas and simmer over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until the peas have dissolved and the soup is thickened, about 2 hours. Season with salt and pepper. Serve with Parsley Pistou, Onion Rings and crispy bacon./nStep 3: The soup can be refrigerated for up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 1 can chickpeas (5-ounce rinsed)/n2 tablespoons mayonnaise/n2 tablespoons red onion (minced)/n1 tablespoon lemon juice (fresh)/n1 tablespoon dill (chopped)/nSalt/nPepper/n4 slices multigrain bread (toasted)/nSliced avocado and radish or alfalfa sprouts (for topping)
Steps: Step 1: In a large bowl, gently mash the chickpeas with a fork. Stir in the mayonnaise, onion, lemon juice and dill. Season with salt and pepper. Spoon the chickpea salad onto 4 toasts and top with sliced avocado and sprouts. Serve.

Ingredients: 14 ounces feta cheese/n2 large eggs, beaten/n1/2 cup finely chopped mixed herbs, such as mint, flat-leaf parsley and dill/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n16 sheets phyllo dough/n6 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a medium bowl, blend the feta with the eggs and the mixed herbs and season with salt and pepper./nStep 2: Have 2 large baking sheets ready. Work with 2 sheets of phyllo at a time, keeping the remaining sheets under a damp towel. Set 1 sheet of phyllo on a work surface and brush with some of the melted butter. Press a second sheet of phyllo on top. Cut the phyllo lengthwise into 4 even rectangles./nStep 3: Spread 1 tablespoon of the feta cheese and herb filling along the short end of one of the phyllo rectangles, leaving about 1/2 inch on each side. Roll up the phyllo, neatly tucking in the ends one-third of the way up to enclose the filling, then continue to roll up the phyllo with the sides open. Transfer the rolled-up cigar, seam side down, to a large baking sheet and brush with more of the melted butter. Repeat with the remaining phyllo dough and feta cheese and herb filling./nStep 4: Bake the cigars for about 30 minutes, or until they are golden brown and crisp; switch the baking sheets halfway through for even browning. Serve the cigars hot or at room temperature./nStep 5: The cigars can be assembled up to 4 hours ahead. Cover them with plastic wrap and refrigerate. Bake the cigars just before serving.

Ingredients: Two 19-ounce cans chickpeas, drained/nOne 13.5-ounce can light coconut milk/nOne 14.4-ounce can whole tomatoes, drained and chopped (1/2 cup)/n1/4 cup naturally sweetened apple juice/n1/4 cup cilantro leaves/n1/2 teaspoon garam masala/n1/2 teaspoon ground ginger/n1 cup chicken stock or low-sodium broth/nSalt and freshly ground black pepper/n1/4 cup plain low-fat yogurt/n2 scallions, green parts only, thinly sliced
Steps: Step 1: In a blender, combine the drained chickpeas with the coconut milk, chopped tomatoes, apple juice, cilantro leaves, garam masala and ground ginger and puree the mixture until smooth./nStep 2: Transfer the puree to a medium saucepan. Stir in the chicken stock and bring to a simmer over moderately high heat. Season with salt and black pepper. Ladle the soup into bowls, top with the yogurt and scallion greens and serve./nStep 3: The soup can be refrigerated overnight. Reheat gently./nStep 4: One Serving 288 cal, 6 gm fat, 3.7 gm sat fat, 49 gm carb, 8.7 gm fiber.

Ingredients: 2 cups Fuji apple juice (see Note)/n3 tablespoons shiro dashi (see Note)/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n1/2 tablespoon sherry vinegar/n1/2 tablespoon untoasted sesame oil/nOne 12-ounce package soft silken tofu, drained and cut into 4 slices/n2 cooked chestnuts, thinly sliced/nLight green frisée leaves, for garnish/nWasabi oil, for garnish (see Note)
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk together the apple juice, shiro dashi, soy sauce, sherry vinegar and sesame oil. Set the tofu in 4 shallow bowls. Top with the chestnuts and frisée. Pour the apple dashi around the tofu (reserve any remaining dashi for another use). Drizzle with a few drops of wasabi oil and serve./nStep 2: Fuji apple juice is available at supermarkets and juice bars, or you can make your own. Shiro dashi is a stock made with soy sauce, white soy, bonito (a type of fish)and seaweed. Shiro dashi and wasabi oil are both available at Asian markets.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons pure olive oil/n1 yellow onion, quartered/n2 carrots, halved/n1 celery rib, halved crosswise, plus 4 small celery ribs, finely diced/n1 pound dried chickpeas, soaked overnight and drained/n4 rosemary sprigs and 4 thyme sprigs, tied together with string/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper/n1 medium red onion, finely chopped/n1/2 cup red wine vinegar/nFinely shredded zest and juice of 1 lemon/n2 garlic cloves, very finely chopped/n1 teaspoon finely chopped rosemary/n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano/n1 1/2 teaspoons finely chopped peperoncini/n1 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n3/4 cup finely chopped flat-leaf parsley
Steps: Step 1: In a large soup pot, heat the pure olive oil. Add the quartered yellow onion, carrots and halved celery rib and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are golden, about 10 minutes. Add the drained chickpeas, the herb sprig bundle and enough water to cover by 2 inches and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer over moderately low until the chickpeas are tender, about 1 1/2 hours. Add a large pinch of salt and pepper and cook the chickpeas for 10 minutes longer. Remove from the heat and cool for 15 minutes, then drain the chickpeas. Discard the herb sprigs, onion, carrots and celery./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large bowl, soak the red onion in the vinegar for 15 minutes. Drain, discarding the vinegar. Return the onion to the bowl and add the diced celery, lemon zest, lemon juice, garlic, chopped rosemary, oregano and peperoncini. Add the chickpeas and olive oil; season with salt and pepper. Fold in the parsley and serve./nStep 3: The chickpea salad can be refrigerated overnight. Add the parsley just before serving.

Ingredients: 6 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for brushing/n1 very large onion, finely chopped/n1 very large carrot, finely chopped/n5 garlic cloves—4 minced, 1 whole/n1 pound dried black-eyed peas (about 2 1/4 cups), soaked overnight and drained/nTwo 1-pound smoked ham hocks/n2 quarts chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n2 bay leaves/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n1 small baguette, sliced diagonally 3/4 inch thick/nFreshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large, enameled cast-iron casserole, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Add the onion, carrot and minced garlic and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 6 minutes. Add the drained black-eyed peas, ham hocks, chicken stock and bay leaves and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to very low, cover partially and cook until the beans are tender, about 1 1/2 hours. Season generously with salt and pepper and let stand for 30 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, preheat the oven to 350°. Toast the bread slices in the oven for about 8 minutes, until golden. Brush lightly with olive oil and rub lightly with the garlic clove./nStep 3: Drain the black-eyed peas; discard the ham hocks and bay leaves. Transfer the peas to a serving bowl. Stir in the remaining 1/4 cup of olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Serve the black-eyed peas with the garlic toasts, passing grated cheese at the table./nStep 4: The black-eyed peas can be refrigerated for up to 4 days.

Ingredients: 1 cup dried chickpeas, soaked overnight and drained/n14 garlic cloves, 4 cloves halved/n1 ounce pancetta or prosciutto, diced/n1/2 medium yellow onion, halved lengthwise/n1/2 medium carrot, halved lengthwise/n1/2 celery rib, halved lengthwise/n3 sage leaves/n1 small rosemary sprig, plus 1/2 teaspoon finely chopped leaves/n1 bay leaf/n1 dried chile de árbol/n2 tablespoons kosher salt/n3/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for brushing and drizzling/nAbout 30 baguette slices (1/2 inch thick)/n1/2 teaspoon minced thyme leaves/nFlaky sea salt, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a medium Dutch oven, combine the soaked chickpeas with the 10 whole garlic cloves, the pancetta, onion, carrot, celery, sage, rosemary sprig, bay leaf, chile, salt, 1/4 cup of the olive oil and 8 cups of water. Bring to a boil over high heat and stir. Cover and bake for about 2 hours, until the chickpeas are tender. Remove from the oven, uncover and let the chickpeas cool in the liquid for 1 hour./nStep 2: Meanwhile, lightly brush the baguette slices with olive oil and arrange on a rimmed baking sheet. Bake until lightly toasted, about 15 minutes. Rub the cut halves of garlic on one side of each toast./nStep 3: Drain the chickpeas, reserving 1/2 cup of the cooking liquid; discard all the aromatics except the garlic. Transfer the chickpeas and garlic to a blender. Add the remaining 1/2 cup of olive oil and the reserved cooking liquid and puree until smooth./nStep 4: Arrange the toasts on a platter. Dollop the chickpea puree on top and use a small spoon to form a little well in each dollop. Drizzle the bruschetta with olive oil, sprinkle with the chopped rosemary, minced thyme and sea salt and serve./nStep 5: The chickpea puree can be refrigerated for 1 week. Rewarm before serving.

Ingredients: 1 large (12-ounce) unripe green mango/n½ cup white vinegar/n¼ cup water/n1 ½ tablespoons agave/n2 teaspoons Dijon mustard/n1 ½ teaspoons kosher salt/n1 ½ teaspoons ground fenugreek/n1 teaspoon ground sumac/n½ teaspoon ground cumin/n½ teaspoon ground turmeric/n¼ teaspoon cayenne pepper/n1 medium garlic clove, grated (about 1/4 teaspoon)/nRoasted meats or vegetables, for serving (optional)/n1 cup labneh (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Peel mango. Cut mango in half lengthwise; remove and discard pit. Chop 1 mango half into 1/4-inch pieces; set aside. Bring vinegar, 1/4 cup water, agave, mustard, salt, fenugreek, sumac, cumin, turmeric, cayenne, and garlic to a boil in a small saucepan over medium, stirring occasionally. Add chopped mango; return mixture to a simmer over medium. Simmer, stirring occasionally, 2 minutes. Remove from heat; let cool until some of the mango pieces are translucent, about 10 minutes. Meanwhile, chop remaining mango half into 1/2-inch pieces; set aside./nStep 2: Transfer cooled mango-vinegar mixture to a blender; do not wipe saucepan clean. Process mixture until smooth, about 30 seconds. Add 1/2-inch mango pieces; using short pulses, pulse until sauce is a chunky consistency with a mix of small and large mango pieces, 1 to 2 pulses./nStep 3: Scrape mango mixture into reserved saucepan. Bring to a gentle simmer over medium. Simmer, stirring often, until amba turns 1 or 2 shades darker, about 3 minutes. Remove from heat; let cool 30 minutes. Serve alongside roasted meats or vegetables, or stir in labneh for a tangy and creamy version of the condiment./nStep 4: Amba may be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 2 weeks.

Ingredients: 2 ½ cups water, divided/n2 tablespoons plus 1 teaspoon kosher salt, divided, plus more to taste/n2 medium-size jalapeños (about 2 1/2 ounces), seeded and ribs removed/n3 small dried chiles de árbol (about 1/8 ounce), seeded/n2 large tomatoes (about 1 pound)/n3  fresh tomatillos (about 12 ounces), husks removed/n½ cup thinly sliced white onion (from 1 small onion)/n1 large garlic clove, thinly sliced (about 1 teaspoon)/n3  cilantro sprigs (about 1/4 ounce)/n½ teaspoon ground cumin/n½ teaspoon dried oregano/n¼ cup extra-virgin olive oil/n1 teaspoon white wine vinegar, plus more to taste/n¼ teaspoon black pepper
Steps: Step 1: Combine 2 cups water and 2 tablespoons salt in a small saucepan; bring to a boil over medium-high. Stir until salt is fully dissolved. Remove from heat. Let cool about 15 minutes. Add jalapeños and chiles de árbol; soak 1 hour./nStep 2: Meanwhile, heat a comal or cast-iron skillet over medium-high. Add tomatoes and tomatillos; cook, turning occasionally, until charred in spots and starting to soften, about 15 minutes. Remove from heat, and set aside until ready to use./nStep 3: Drain chile mixture, and transfer to a large pot. Add charred tomatoes and tomatillos, onion, garlic, cilantro, cumin, oregano, and remaining 1/2 cup water. Bring to a boil over medium-high; boil, stirring occasionally and breaking down tomatoes using the back of a wooden spoon, until tomatoes and tomatillos are soft and falling apart, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat./nStep 4: Transfer mixture to a blender. Secure lid on blender, and remove center piece to allow steam to escape. Place a clean towel over opening. Process until smooth, about 30 seconds./nStep 5: Wipe large pot clean. Add oil to pot; heat over medium-high. Carefully add pureed tomato mixture. (Sauce will splatter.) Using a long-handled wooden spoon, stir in vinegar, black pepper, and remaining 1 teaspoon salt. Bring to a boil, and boil, stirring often, until salsa thickens slightly and you can see bottom of pot when stirring, 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from heat. Season with additional salt and vinegar to taste. Serve hot or at room temperature.

Ingredients: 1 medium head garlic, cloves separated and peeled (about 2 ounces)/n1 cup sunflower oil, divided/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice (from 1 lime), divided/n1 large egg white/n2 teeaspoons kosher salt, plus more to taste/n1 to 2 tablespoons cold water, if needed
Steps: Step 1: Crush garlic cloves using mortar and pestle until smashed and softened, about 20 seconds. Transfer to food processor, and process until finely chopped, about 10 seconds, stopping to scrape down sides as needed. With processor running, slowly pour in 1/4 cup oil, pouring in a thin, even stream, processing until well blended, about 2 minutes, stopping to scrape down sides as needed./nStep 2: With processor running, gradually add 1 tablespoon lime juice to garlic mixture, processing until incorporated, about 20 seconds. With processor running, add egg white, processing until well combined, about 30 seconds. With processor running, gradually stream in remaining 3/4 cup oil, processing until mixture is thick and fluffy, about 2 minutes. With processor running, gradually add remaining 1 tablespoon lime juice, processing until incorporated, about 20 seconds. Add salt and, if toum is very thick, add cold water, 1 teaspoon at a time, to thin into a smooth and spreadable consistency, pulsing 3 to 6 times after each addition. Add additional salt to taste./nStep 3: Toum may be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup mayonnaise/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice (from 2 small limes)/n1 large bunch fresh cilantro, trimmed, leaves and stems coarsely chopped (about 2 packed cups)/n1 medium garlic clove, coarsely chopped/n5 scallions, coarsely chopped/n1/4 cup chopped fresh mint/n1 tablespoon ajî Amarillo (Peruvian yellow chile) paste or 1 tablespoon seeded and coarsely chopped serrano or jalapeño chile/n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt
Steps: Step 1: Place all ingredients in a blender. Process on low, gradually increasing speed, until smooth, about 1 minute. Cover and chill sauce at least 1 hour before serving. (This allows flavors to meld and mellow out.) Sauce can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 1 pound Honeycrisp apples, cored, unpeeled, and finely chopped (about 3 cups)/n1 cup toasted walnuts, chopped/n.3333 cup Concord grape kosher wine (such as Manischewitz)/n2 tablespoons honey/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice (from 1 lemon)/n¾ teaspoon ground cinnamon/n⅛ teaspoon kosher salt
Steps: Step 1: Stir together apples, walnuts, wine, honey, lemon juice, cinnamon, and salt in a medium bowl until evenly distributed. Let stand at room temperature for 30 minutes. Stir before serving./nStep 2: Alternatively: Pulse all ingredients in a food processor until finely chopped, about 8 pulses./nStep 3: Refrigerate in an airtight container up to 3 days.

Yield: Makes 75 to 100 pearls, depending on size
Ingredients: ½ cup tapioca starch/n¼ cup boiling water/nFood coloring (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Place the tapioca flour in a heat-resistant bowl, add the boiling water and stir until a dough is formed. To keep dough from drying out, cover dough with a damp towel./nStep 2: Using about 1/8 teaspoon of dough to form a little ball./nStep 3: Place the pearls on a sheet pan that has been lined with parchment paper. Allow them to dry for at least 2 hours./nStep 4: To cook the pearls, fill a medium saucepan with water and bring it to a boil. Add the pearls. When they are half way cooked through they will float to the top. Continue cooking for another 15 to 20 minutes, then drain./nStep 5: If you are not using the tapioca pearls immediately, cover the drained boboas, as the pearls are called, with a simple syrup. This way will keep in the refrigerator for several days.

Ingredients: 2 cups pineapple juice/n1/4 cup soy sauce/n2 tablespoons distilled white vinegar/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n2 garlic cloves, finely grated/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 teaspoon pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a medium bowl, whisk all of the ingredients until combined.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup ketchup/n1/3 cup dark brown sugar/n1/4 cup unsulfured blackstrap molasses/n1/4 cup apricot preserves/n2 tablespoons yellow mustard/n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1 garlic clove, minced/n1 1/2 teaspoons chile powder/n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper/n1/2 teaspoon hot sauce/nPinch of ground cloves/nPinch of ground allspice/nSalt
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, combine all of the ingredients except the salt with 1/2 cup of water and bring to a boil, stirring well. Let cool and season with salt./nStep 2: The barbecue sauce can be refrigerated for up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 teaspoons cumin seeds/n1 1/2 teaspoons coriander seeds/n1 1/2 cups coarsely chopped cilantro/n1 cup coarsely chopped parsley/n1 tablespoon coarsely chopped mint/n1/4 preserved lemon, pulp discarded and rind coarsely chopped/n3 garlic cloves/n1 teaspoon sweet paprika/n1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice/n1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper/n3 saffron threads (optional)/n1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a small skillet, toast the cumin and coriander seeds over low heat, shaking the pan occasionally, until fragrant, about 2 minutes. Transfer to a spice grinder and let cool. Pulse until finely ground./nStep 2: In a food processor, combine the ground seeds with the cilantro, parsley, mint, preserved lemon, garlic, paprika, lemon juice, crushed red pepper and saffron, if desired. Pulse until a coarse paste forms. With the processor running, drizzle in the olive oil in a slow, steady stream. Scrape the chermoula into a medium bowl and season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: The chermoula can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup soy sauce/n3 tablespoons sake/n3 tablespoons mirin/n1 (3-inch) kombu square/n1/4 ounce katsuobushi/n1/4 cup fresh yuzu or Meyer lemon juice
Steps: Step 1: Combine soy sauce, sake, and mirin in a small saucepan. Bring to a simmer over medium. Add kombu and katsuobushi and remove from heat. Add yuzu juice. Cover and let mixture stand at room temperature overnight. Strain before using.
