Ingredients: 1/2 cup mayonnaise/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/n1 tablespoon chopped capers/n2 teaspoons chopped fresh tarragon/n1 garlic clove, minced/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nSalt/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk the mayonnaise with the lemon juice, capers, tarragon and garlic. Whisk in the olive oil in a steady stream and season with salt and pepper. Use on grilled chicken, pork, fish and shellfish./nStep 2: The aïoli can be refrigerated overnight.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 large red bell pepper, seeded and finely chopped/n1/2 onion, finely chopped/n3 fresh red chiles, such as cayenne—stemmed, seeded and finely chopped/n3 Thai chiles, finely chopped/n3 garlic cloves, minced/n1 tablespoon sweet smoked paprika/n2 tablespoons red wine vinegar/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/n1/4 cup water/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a large skillet, heat the olive oil until shimmering. Add the bell pepper, onion, cayenne chiles, Thai chiles, garlic and paprika and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the vegetables are softened, about 12 minutes./nStep 2: Scrape the mixture into a blender and let cool slightly. Add the vinegar, lemon juice and water and puree until almost smooth. Season the sauce with salt and pepper and transfer to a bowl. Let stand at room temperature for about 1 hour before serving./nStep 3: The sauce can be refrigerated for up to 4 days. Let return to room temperature before serving.

Ingredients: 4 cups stemmed and sliced lacinato kale leaves/n3 cups fresh basil leaves/n1/2 cup toasted walnuts/n3/4 cup mild extra-virgin olive oil, divided/n2 medium garlic cloves, smashed/n1 teaspoon coarse sea salt/n1 teaspoon grated lemon zest plus 1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/nToasted baguette slices, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Combine kale, basil, walnuts, 1/4 cup oil, garlic, and salt in a food processor; process until a finely chopped paste forms, about 30 seconds, stopping to scrape down sides as needed. Transfer to a medium bowl. Stir in lemon zest and juice and remaining 1/2 cup oil until combined. Serve with baguette slices./nStep 2: Pesto may be refrigerated in an airtight container up to 3 days.

Ingredients: ¾ cup packed mint leaves/n¼ cup flat-leaf parsley leaves/n2  scallions (thickly sliced)/n2  medium garlic cloves/n½ teaspoon finely grated lemon zest/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nSalt
Steps: Step 1: In a food processor, combine the mint leaves with the parsley, scallions, garlic and lemon zest and pulse until chopped. With the machine on, add the olive oil in a thin stream and process until smooth. Season the pesto with salt./nStep 2: The mint pesto can be refrigerated overnight./nStep 3: Best Uses Toss the pesto with pasta or mix it with soft, fresh goat cheese and spread it on crostini. Brush on lamb chops, chicken, fish, pork, seafood or vegetables after grilling, or serve alongside burgers, sausages or grilled bread.

Ingredients: 3 salt-packed anchovies—rinsed, soaked and filleted/n1 tablespoon drained capers/n1/2 small garlic clove/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n3 tablespoons red wine vinegar/n1 tablespoon Dijon mustard/n2 cups packed mint leaves/n1 1/2 cups packed parsley leaves/nFlaky sea salt/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a food processor, pulse the anchovies with the capers and garlic until a fine paste forms. Add the olive oil, vinegar and mustard and pulse to combine. Add the herbs and pulse until finely chopped. Scrape the mixture into a small bowl. Season with salt and pepper and serve./nStep 2: The salsa verde can be refrigerated overnight./nStep 3: Salt-packed anchovies can be purchased on amazon.com. We use Agostino Recca brand salted anchovies.

Ingredients: 3/4 cup raw pistachios (about 4 ounces), coarsely chopped/n2 garlic cloves, chopped/n1 anchovy fillet, chopped/n1/2 cup oregano leaves, coarsely chopped/n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n3/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/nSalt/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. Spread the pistachios in a pie plate and toast until lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Let cool completely./nStep 2: In a food processor, combine the pistachios with the garlic, anchovy, oregano and lemon juice. Pulse to chop. Add the olive oil and pulse to form a coarse sauce. Season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: The pesto can be refrigerated for up to 4 days.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup warm water, plus more as needed/n3 tablespoons fresh lime juice (from 2 limes), plus more to taste/n2 tablespoons granulated sugar or 3 to 4 tablespoons pure maple syrup, plus more to taste/n2 teaspoons rice vinegar (optional)/n3 tablespoons fish sauce (such as Three Crabs), plus more to taste/n1/2 small carrot, matchstick-cut or coarsely grated (2 tablespoons)/n1 (1-ounce) Thai chile or serrano chile, unseeded and thinly sliced, or 2 to 3 teaspoon Asian chile-garlic sauce or sambal oelek (ground fresh chile paste)/n1 large garlic clove, minced (1 1/2 teaspoons)
Steps: Step 1: Stir together 1/2 cup water, lime juice, and sugar in a small bowl until sugar dissolves. Add additional lime juice and/or sugar to taste; dilute with water if flavors are too strong. If there’s an unpleasant tart-bitter edge, add rice vinegar to fix flavor./nStep 2: Stir in fish sauce; add additional fish sauce to taste. (How much you use depends on the brand and your own taste.) Aim for a bold, forward finish that’s a little gutsy. Keep in mind that this sauce typically dresses dishes that include unsalted ingredients such as lettuce and herbs, which will need an extra flavor lift./nStep 3: If using, stir in carrot, chile, and/or garlic. (Offer chile on the side if diners are sensitive to its heat.) Serve sauce in a bowl on the table so diners may help themselves, or divide among small individual bowls in advance./nStep 4: The sauce can stand at room temperature up to 8 hours until serving. Lime juice dulls and can make the sauce slightly bitter if left longer; combine water, sugar, and fish sauce to make a base, then refrigerate, covered, up to 2 weeks. (Prep a double batch if you use it a lot.) To finish, add lime juice, vinegar (if using), and any desired add-ins./nStep 5: VARIATIONS: For a vegetarian nuoc cham: Stir together 3 tablespoons light brown sugar (or 4 to 5 tablespoons pure maple syrup), 3 tablespoons fresh lime juice, and a rounded 1/2 teasopon finely ground sea salt in a small bowl until sugar dissolves. Taste and add additional sugar or up to 1 teaspoon rice vinegar to round out the lime juice. Stir in 2/3 cup lukewarm water and 1 1/2 teaspoons soy sauce. Finish with any add-ins before serving.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 pounds tomatillos (about 11 medium tomatillos), husks removed, tomatillos cored and quartered/n3/4 cup roasted, peeled, and chopped Hatch chiles (from fresh or thawed frozen chiles)/n1/2 cup chopped fresh cilantro leaves and tender stems/n1/4 cup chopped sweet onion/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice/n1 tablespoon chopped garlic/n2 teaspoons kosher salt/n1 teaspoon agave nectar
Steps: Step 1: Bring a large pot of water to a boil over high. Add tomatillos, and return to a boil; cook until softened, about 4 minutes. Drain well, and let cool 10 minutes. Transfer to a food processor. Add chiles, cilantro, onion, lime juice, garlic, salt, and agave, and process until mostly smooth, about 30 seconds. Refrigerate in an airtight container up to 2 weeks.

Ingredients: 50 pounds ripe plum tomatoes, rinsed/n1/2 cup kosher salt, divided/n6 (1-quart) glass preserving jars (such as Ball) with bands and new lids, washed/n1 tablespoon citric acid (such as Ball)/n6 (5-inch) basil sprigs, divided
Steps: Step 1: Pour water to a depth of 3 inches into 2 large stockpots. Divide tomatoes evenly between pots, and sprinkle 1/4 cup salt in each pot. Partially cover, and bring each pot to a boil over high. Boil, stirring occasionally, until tomatoes are very tender, 20 to 30 minutes. Remove from heat./nStep 2: Meanwhile, line several large strainers (about six strainers) or large colander food pans with several layers of cheesecloth, and set them over appropriately sized bowls or pans. Remove tomatoes using a medium saucepan, and pour into prepared strainers. Let cool 30 minutes, stirring occasionally with a wooden spoon to press out as much water as possible./nStep 3: While tomatoes cool, line bottom of a large, deep stockpot with folded clean kitchen towels or burlap, and place 6 preserving jars in pot. Add water to cover jars by 1 inch (filling jars with water to prevent flotation). Bring to a simmer over medium-high, keeping jars hot until ready to use./nStep 4: Working in batches, process tomatoes using an electric sauce maker or tomato press strainer. Return pureed tomatoes to a medium stockpot, and bring to a simmer over medium-high. Stir in citric acid, and remove tomato passata from heat./nStep 5: Place a kitchen towel on a work surface. Using a jar lifter, remove jars from pot, letting water drain back into pot, and place on towel. Working with 1 jar at a time, add 1 basil sprig to each jar. Ladle hot tomato passata into hot jar, using a jar funnel to keep jar rim clean and leaving 1/2 inch of headspace. Release air bubbles in filled jar by running a bubble remover or nonmetallic spatula between passata and sides of jar; repeat a few times. Wipe rim of jar with a clean kitchen towel or paper towel. Top with lid, and screw on jar band until tight. Repeat with remaining jars and passata./nStep 6: Using a jar lifter, carefully lower filled jars into simmering water, and make sure jars are covered by 1 inch of water (add hot water if needed). Bring to a boil over high. Cover and boil 45 minutes Uncover and turn off heat. Let stand 5 minutes. Place a kitchen towel on a work surface. Using a jar lifter, carefully remove jars from pot and place on towel. Let stand, undisturbed, at least 12 and up to 24 hours. Check seals (lids should be curved inward), and label. Store in a cool, dark place up to 1 year.

Ingredients: 3 quarts Turkey Stock/n2 cups dry red wine/n2  shallots (coarsely chopped)/n1 stick unsalted butter/n½ cup all-purpose flour/n¼ cup reserved turkey pan drippings/n1 teaspoon Asian fish sauce (plus more for seasoning)/n¼ teaspoon Worcestershire sauce (plus more for seasoning)/nKosher salt/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, combine the turkey stock, wine and shallots and bring to a simmer. Cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until reduced by half, about 45 minutes. Strain the stock into a large bowl. Wipe out the saucepan./nStep 2: Melt the butter in the saucepan. Add the flour and cook over moderate heat, whisking frequently, until deep golden, 4 to 5 minutes. Whisk in the strained stock and the reserved turkey pan drippings and bring to a simmer. Cook over moderately high heat, whisking occasionally, until the gravy is thickened, about 5 minutes. Stir in the 1 teaspoon of fish sauce and 1/4 teaspoon of Worcestershire sauce and season with salt and pepper. Add more fish sauce and Worcestershire sauce to taste. Serve hot./nStep 3: The gravy can be refrigerated for 3 days or frozen for up to 1 month.

Ingredients: 1 cup frozen mango chunks/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice/n1 teaspoon granulated sugar/n1 teaspoon smoked paprika/n1 teaspoon curry powder/n1 teaspoon smoked salt (such as hickory)/n1/2 teaspoon cayenne pepper/n1/2 teaspoon black pepper/n1 small habanero chile, seeded and chopped (about 1/4 teaspoon)/n1 cup mayonnaise (such as Duke’s)
Steps: Step 1: Process frozen mango chunks, lime juice, sugar, smoked paprika, curry powder, smoked salt, cayenne pepper, black pepper, and chopped habanero in a food processor until smooth, about 1 minute. Stir together mango mixture and mayonnaise in a medium bowl. Cover and refrigerate until ready to use./nStep 2: Aioli can be prepared and stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 2 1/2 tablespoons yellow mustard seeds/n3/4 cup dry white wine/n1 small cinnamon stick/nOne 1/2-inch slice of fresh ginger/n5 whole cloves/n1 1/2 cups sugar/n1 cup Champagne vinegar/n3/4 cup pure cranberry juice/n1 tablespoon mustard powder/n2 cups dried cranberries (1/2 pound)/n1 teaspoon finely grated orange zest/nSalt
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, soak the mustard seeds in the wine at room temperature overnight./nStep 2: Wrap the cinnamon stick, ginger and cloves in a piece of cheesecloth and tie closed. In a saucepan, whisk the mustard seeds, wine, sugar, vinegar, cranberry juice and mustard powder and bring to a boil. Add the spice bundle and cook over moderate heat, without stirring, until the syrup coats the back of a spoon, 25 minutes. Discard the spice bundle. Stir in the cranberries and orange zest and let the mostarda cool completely. Season with salt and serve; stir in water by the tablespoon if it seems too thick./nStep 3: The mostarda can be refrigerated for up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 6 dried guajillo chiles, stemmed and seeded/n4 dried ancho chiles, stemmed and seeded/n4 dried cascabel chiles, stemmed and seeded/n1 large white onion, cut into 1-inch wedges/n10 garlic cloves/n2 tablespoons roughly chopped peeled fresh ginger/n8 cups water, divided/n2 tablespoons white vinegar/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n1 1/2 teaspoons black pepper/n1 1/2 teaspoons dried oregano/n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin/n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon/n1/4 teaspoon ground cloves/n6 thyme sprigs/n3 dried bay leaves
Steps: Step 1: Heat a large cast-iron skillet over medium. Add chiles to skillet; cook, stirring occasionally, until fragrant, 4 to 5 minutes. Transfer chiles to a large saucepan; add onion, garlic, ginger, and 6 cups water. Bring to a boil over medium-high. Cook, uncovered, stirring occasionally, until chiles are softened, about 8 minutes. Drain chile mixture; discard cooking liquid./nStep 2: Combine chile mixture, vinegar, salt, black pepper, oregano, cumin, cinnamon, cloves, thyme, bay leaves, and remaining 2 cups water in a blender. Secure lid on blender, and remove center piece to allow steam to escape. Place a clean towel over opening. Process until smooth, about 45 seconds. Let cool to room temperature, about 1 hour. Cover and chill until ready to use./nStep 3: Adobo can be chilled in an airtight container up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/4 pound thick-cut bacon, finely chopped/n1 cup minced shallots (2 large)/n1 large thyme sprig/nKosher salt/n1/3 cup all-purpose flour/n1/2 cup dry white wine/n4 cups turkey or chicken stock/n1/4 teaspoon sweet paprika/n2 tablespoons unsalted butter/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a large skillet, heat the olive oil. Add the bacon, shallots, thyme and a generous pinch of salt and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the shallots are browned and the bacon is nearly crisp, about 10 minutes./nStep 2: Sift the flour into the skillet and stir it in until completely absorbed. Stir in the wine and cook until thick, 1 minute. Gradually stir in the stock, then stir in the paprika and bring to a boil. Simmer the gravy over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until no floury taste remains and the gravy is reduced to 3 1/2 cups, 10 minutes. Discard the thyme sprig. Remove from the heat and stir in the butter. Season the gravy generously with salt and pepper and serve hot./nStep 3: The gravy can be refrigerated for 3 days. Reheat gently; stir in a few tablespoons of water if the gravy is too thick.

Ingredients: ¼ cup gochujang/n2 tablespoons water/n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n1 tablespoon rice vinegar/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n1 tablespoon granulated sugar/n1 ½ teaspoons grated garlic (from 2 large garlic cloves)/n1 teaspoon grated ginger (from a 1-in. piece ginger)
Steps: Step 1: Stir together all ingredients in a small saucepan, and bring to a simmer over medium. Cook, stirring constantly, until sugar has dissolved, about 1 minute. Remove from heat. Transfer to a small bowl. Refrigerate, covered, up to 7 days.

Ingredients: One 12-ounce bag fresh cranberries/n1 large Fuji apple, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice/n1 cup sugar/n3/4 cup water
Steps: Step 1: Line an 8-by-4-inch loaf pan with plastic wrap and spray the plastic wrap with nonstick cooking spray./nStep 2: In a medium saucepan, combine the cranberries with the apple, sugar and water. Bring to a boil and cook over moderately high heat, stirring frequently until the cranberries are completely broken down and the sauce is very thick, about 15 minutes. Scrape the cranberry sauce into the prepared pan and refrigerate until chilled, about 3 hours. Invert the jelly onto a serving plate and remove the plastic wrap. Garnish with fresh cranberries and rosemary sprigs. Slice with a serrated knife before serving./nStep 3: The cranberry sauce can be covered in plastic wrap and refrigerated for up to 2 weeks. Serve chilled./nStep 4: Leftover cranberry sauce is always great as a spread on sandwiches.

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 onion, finely chopped/n2 garlic cloves, finely chopped/n2 tablespoons raisins/n1 tablespoon gochujang (Korean red pepper paste)/n3/4 teaspoon smoked paprika/n1/2 teaspoon black peppercorns/n1/8 teaspoon celery seeds/n2 tablespoons fresh orange juice/n1/3 cup balsamic vinegar/n1/4 cup Worcestershire/n3 tablespoons ketchup/n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n1 tablespoon light brown sugar/nKosher salt
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, heat the olive oil. Add the onion, garlic and raisins and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the onion is softened, 6 to 8 minutes. Add the gochujang, paprika, peppercorns and celery seeds and cook, stirring, until the gochujang deepens in color, about 1 minute. Add the orange juice and scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan. Add all of the remaining ingredients, except the salt, along with 3/4 cup of waterand simmer over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until thickened slightly, about 30 minutes. Season with salt and scrape the sauce into a blender; let cool slightly. Wipe out the saucepan./nStep 2: Puree the steak sauce until very smooth, about 2 minutes. Pass it through a mesh sieve set over the saucepan, pressing on the solids. Simmer the steak sauce over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until thickened, about 30 minutes. Let cool to room temperature before serving./nStep 3: The steak sauce can be refrigerated for up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 1/3 cup finely chopped toasted pistachios/n1/4 cup chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley/n2 tablespoons lemon zest (from 2 lemons)/n1 small garlic clove, minced
Steps: Step 1: Stir together all ingredients until well blended.

Ingredients: 2/3 cup mayonnaise (preferably Duke’s)/n1/4 cup apple cider vinegar/n2 teaspoons light brown sugar/n3/4 teaspoon coarsely ground black pepper/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt/n1/4 teaspoon garlic powder/n1/4 teaspoon onion powder
Steps: Step 1: Whisk together all ingredients in a medium bowl. Cover and chill 30 minutes./nStep 2: Dressing can be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 3 days.

Yield: MAKES 3 CUPS JUS AND 4 CUPS STOCK
Ingredients: 2 tablespoons olive oil, divided/n2 garlic heads, halved crosswise/n1 small yellow onion, roughly chopped/n2 medium carrots, roughly chopped/n2 medium celery stalks, roughly chopped/n5 pounds turkey necks and wings/n16 1/2  cups plus 2 1/2 tablespoons cold water, divided/n6 flat-leaf parsley sprigs/n2 fresh or dried bay leaves/n1 cup (8 ounces) dry white wine/nKosher salt, to taste/n2 1/2 tablespoons cornstarch
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 475°F. Grease a heavy-duty rimmed baking sheet with 1 tablespoon oil, using cut sides of garlic heads to help distribute the oil. Arrange garlic, onion, carrots, and celery in an even layer on baking sheet. Toss together turkey parts and remaining 1 tablespoon oil in a large bowl, and arrange in an even layer over vegetable mixture. Roast in preheated oven until turkey begins to brown, about 20 minutes./nStep 2: Reduce oven temperature to 350°F. Roast, without stirring, until wings are deep golden brown, 50 minutes to 1 hour and 10 minutes, checking vegetables every 20 minutes and adding up to 1/2 cup cold water and gently shaking baking sheet to prevent scorching./nStep 3: Transfer baking sheet to stovetop. Place turkey parts in a 6-quart Dutch oven; add parsley sprigs and bay leaves. Pour wine over vegetables on baking sheet, and heat baking sheet over 2 burners over medium-low. Using a flat wooden spatula or spoon, scrape up any browned bits on baking sheet. Push garlic halves around mixture to help scrape up more of the browned bits, and gently smash garlic and vegetables while wine reduces. Cook, stirring often, until wine mixture has reduced to about 1/4 cup and is thick, opaque, and sticky, 10 to 12 minutes. Scrape vegetables and wine mixture into Dutch oven with turkey parts. Return baking sheet to 2 burners on stovetop over medium-high, and pour 1 cup cold water onto baking sheet. Cook, scraping up any stubborn browned bits, until baking sheet is mostly clean and water has reduced slightly, 2 to 3 minutes. Pour mixture from baking sheet into Dutch oven./nStep 4: Add 7 cups cold water to Dutch oven; bring to a boil over medium-high. Reduce heat to medium-low; simmer, uncovered, until liquid has reduced by about half and turkey begins to fall apart, 1 hour and 30 minutes to 2 hours, pressing down turkey parts often so they remain submerged. Set a fine wire-mesh strainer over a medium-size heatproof bowl. Working in batches, pour mixture in Dutch oven through strainer, mashing turkey parts and vegetables with the back of a spoon to extract as much of their juices as possible; reserve liquid (the jus) and solids separately./nStep 5: Let turkey jus cool at room temperature 30 minutes. Cover and refrigerate until congealed, at least 8 hours or up to 4 days. Meanwhile, return strained turkey parts and vegetables to Dutch oven; add 8 cups cold water. Bring to a boil over medium-high. Reduce heat to medium-low; simmer, uncovered, until liquid is reduced to about 4 cups, about 1 hour. Strain turkey stock as with turkey jus in step 4; discard solids. Let turkey stock cool at room temperature 30 minutes. Cover and store in refrigerator up to 5 days, reserving for another use (like dressing or mashed potatoes)./nStep 6: Remove turkey jus from refrigerator. Scrape congealed turkey fat off top of jus; reserve for another use, such as frying potatoes. Transfer jus to a medium saucepan, and bring to a boil over medium. Boil until reduced to about 3 cups, 8 to 12 minutes. Season to taste with salt./nStep 7: Whisk together cornstarch and remaining 2 1/2 tablespoons cold water in a small heatproof bowl until well dissolved. Whisk 1/3 cup hot jus into cornstarch mixture. While constantly whisking the boiling jus in saucepan, gradually add about half of cornstarch mixture. Bring to a full boil over medium, whisking constantly, 30 seconds to 1 minute. For a thicker jus, continue adding cornstarch mixture, whisking constantly, until desired consistency is reached, ensuring jus comes to a full boil after each addition. Serve hot./nStep 8: Turkey stock can be refrigerated up to 5 days or frozen up to 2 months. Freeze turkey jus after step 5. Thaw in refrigerator overnight, and proceed with step 6.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons mirin/n2 tablespoons sake/n1/4 cup ají amarillo paste (see Note)/n2 tablespoons shiro (white) miso/n3 tablespoons fresh orange juice/n1 teaspoon fresh lime juice/nFour 6-ounce skinless center-cut salmon fillets/nSalt/nFreshly ground pepper/n1/2 cup cooked quinoa/n3 tablespoons canola oil/n1 small cucumber—peeled, seeded and diced
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. In a small saucepan, bring the mirin and sake to a boil. Whisk in the ají amarillo paste, miso and orange and lime juices and simmer gently, stirring occasionally, until thickened, about 20 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, season the salmon with salt and pepper. Press 2 tablespoons of the quinoa onto the skinned side of each fillet./nStep 3: In a large ovenproof nonstick skillet, heat the canola oil. Add the salmon fillets, quinoa side down, and cook over high heat until the quinoa is browned, about 2 minutes. Transfer the skillet to the oven and roast the salmon until almost opaque throughout, about 4 minutes./nStep 4: Using a spatula, carefully transfer the fillets to plates, quinoa side up. Spoon the diced cucumber alongside and serve with the orange-miso sauce./nStep 5: Ají amarillo paste is a spicy Peruvian yellow chile paste. It’s available in many supermarkets and online at amazon.com.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup dried sour cherries/n1 cup whole milk or cream/n1 cup unsweetened, unflavored almond milk/n1 cup steel-cut oats/n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon/n1 teaspoon ground ginger/n1/4 teaspoon ground allspice/n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more for seasoning/n1 tablespoon pure maple syrup, plus more for drizzling/n1/4 cup sliced almonds, plus more for topping
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, cover the dried sour cherries with warm water and let stand until plumped and softened, about 15 minutes. Drain the cherries and discard the soaking water./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a medium saucepan, combine the whole milk, almond milk and 1 cup of water and bring to a boil. Stir in the oats, cinnamon, ginger, allspice and the 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Cover and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the oats are al dente and the porridge is creamy, 20 minutes./nStep 3: Stir in the cherries, maple syrup and almonds and season with salt. Serve topped with more maple syrup and almonds./nStep 4: The porridge can be refrigerated for up to 2 days. Reheat gently with more milk or cream to loosen as necessary.

Ingredients: 1  chicken breast (6-ounce)/n¼ cup olive oil (plus 1 tablespoon extra-virgin)/n¼ teaspoon sea salt/n¼ teaspoon pepper (freshly ground)/n6 ounces fettuccine/n1  onion (medium diced)/n¼ cup dry white wine/n¼ teaspoon chile flakes/n¼ cup lemon juice (freshly squeezed)/n2 tablespoons Greek yogurt (plain)/n2 tablespoons heavy cream/n2 tablespoons dill (plus more for garnish chopped, fresh)/nLemon slices (for serving)
Steps: Step 1: Season the chicken breast with sea salt and freshly ground pepper. In a small pan, heat 1 tablespoon of the extra-virgin olive oil over medium high heat. Add the chicken and cook for 1 minute. Turn the chicken, reduce the heat, cover the pan and cook for 8 minutes. Remove from the heat and leave covered for 10 minutes, then shred the chicken with a fork./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large pot of boiling salted water, cook the pasta according to package directions./nStep 3: In a large frying pan, heat the remaining 1/4 cup of extra-virgin olive oil over medium high heat. Add the onion and cook for 5 minutes, or until it starts to brown. Add the garlic and cook for 30 seconds. Add the white wine, scraping the pan to remove any browned bits. Add the pasta and the chicken, chili flakes and lemon to the pan and toss well to coat./nStep 4: Remove the pan from the heat and stir in the Greek yogurt, heavy cream and dill. Serve with lemon slices and extra dill on top.

Ingredients: 1  egg/n¼ cup plain Greek yogurt/n3 teaspoons maple syrup/n1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice/n1 pinch kosher salt/n2 slices brioche or another soft bread/n1 cup blueberries and/or blackberries/n¼ cup slivered almonds/n½ teaspoon sugar/n1 teaspoon honey
Steps: Step 1: Preheat air fryer to 350°F./nStep 2: In a small bowl, whisk together egg, yogurt, maple syrup, lemon juice, and salt until completely smooth and fully blended./nStep 3: Using a small glass or the back of a spoon, firmly press a divot into the center of each slice of bread, leaving a border around the edges to contain the custard. Spoon custard into each divot and top with berries and nuts. Sprinkle sugar on top./nStep 4: Cook yogurt toast in air fryer for 5 minutes, until custard is caramelized and the bread is toasted around the edges. Drizzle with honey and serve.

Ingredients: 7 ounces frozen all-butter puff pastry from one 14-ounce package, thawed in the refrigerator/n1/4 cup sugar/n1/4 cup water/n1 pound blackberries and raspberries (about 4 cups)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375°. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper. Unfold the puff pastry on the baking sheet and cut it into two 5-by-6-inch rectangles. Cut each rectangle on the diagonal to form 2 triangles. Refrigerate until the pastry is chilled, about 10 minutes./nStep 2: Separate the triangles so they’re evenly spaced. Bake the pastry for 25 minutes, or until nicely browned and crisp./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a saucepan, bring the sugar and water to a simmer over moderate heat. Add the blackberries and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Add the raspberries and cook for 10 seconds. Stir a few times; transfer to a bowl./nStep 4: Place the pastry on plates, top with the berries and serve./nStep 5: Lightly sweet, sparkling Brachetto d'Acqui.

Ingredients: ¾ cup water/n¾ cup sugar/n½ teaspoon kosher salt/n2  firm lemons (very thinly sliced crosswise on a mandoline and seeded)/n¼ cup extra-virgin olive oil/n½  onion (medium minced)/nKosher salt/n1 cup peas (thawed if frozen)/n2 tablespoons mint (finely chopped)/n2 tablespoons parsley (finely chopped)/n½ cup fresh ricotta/n2 tablespoons freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese/n1 ½ tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil (plus more for brushing)/n12 cloves black garlic (small peeled (See Note))/n1 cup English peas (/4 pound freshly shelled)/n¼ pound sugar snap peas (trimmed)/n¼ pound snow peas (trimmed)/nKosher salt/nPea shoots, thinly sliced radishes, small mint leaves, finely chopped chives, chopped marcona almonds and edible flowers (for garnish)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a small saucepan, combine the water, sugar and salt and bring to a boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Transfer to a small baking dish and add the lemon slices in an even layer. Bake for 20 to 25 minutes, until the rinds are translucent and the lemons are tender. Let cool completely./nStep 2: In a medium skillet, heat the olive oil. Add the onion, season with salt and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until just starting to brown, about 7 minutes. Add the peas and cook, stirring, until warmed through, about 3 minutes. Stir in the mint and parsley until just wilted, 1 minute. Transfer the mixture to a mini food processor and let cool completely, then puree until smooth. Scrape the pea puree into a medium bowl and fold in the ricotta and Parmigiano-Reggiano. Season with salt./nStep 3: Lightly brush a large square of wax paper with olive oil. Arrange the black garlic cloves 3 inches apart and put another piece of wax paper on top. Using a rolling pin, gently roll the cloves until very flat. Slide the paper onto a plate and freeze until slightly firm, about 15 minutes./nStep 4: Meanwhile, in a large saucepan of salted boiling water, blanch the English peas, sugar snaps and snow peas until crisp tender, about 3 minutes. Drain, transfer to a large bowl and stir in the 1 1/2 tablespoons of olive oil. Coarsely chop 8 of the lemon slices and fold them in. Season with salt./nStep 5: Scoop 1/3-cup mounds of the pea puree onto plates and spoon the warm peas alongside. Peel the top sheet of wax paper off the smashed black garlic and, using a small offset spatula, lay 2 garlic cloves on each mound of pea puree. Arrange 1 slice of lemon confiture on the garlic and garnish the salads with pea shoots, radishes, small mint leaves, chives, marcona almonds and edible flowers. Serve right away./nStep 6: The ricotta-pea puree can be refrigerated overnight. The lemon confiture can be refrigerated for up to 1 week./nStep 7: Black garlic is fermented and has a sweet, molasses-like flavor. It's available at specialty food shops and at blackgarlic.com./nStep 8: Zippy, green apple–scented northern Italian Pinot Grigio.

Ingredients: 3 cups mixed berries, such as blueberries, raspberries and halved strawberries/n1/4 cup plus 3 tablespoons granulated sugar/n1 1/2 cups whole milk/n2 large eggs/n3 tablespoons melted unsalted butter, plus more for brushing/n1 cup all-purpose flour/n3/4 cup whole-wheat flour/n2 teaspoons baking powder/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/nWhipped cream and confectioners' sugar, for topping
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. On a rimmed baking sheet, toss the berries with 1/4 cup of the granulated sugar. Bake for about 10 minutes, until the berries are just softened./nStep 2: Meanwhile, set a large resealable plastic bag in a tall bowl to hold it upright. In the bag, whisk the milk with the eggs and the melted butter, then add both flours, the remaining 3 tablespoons of granulated sugar, the baking powder and salt; stir until incorporated./nStep 3: Preheat a griddle and brush lightly with melted butter. Gently twist the bag and hold it upright. Using scissors, snip off 1/4 inch from a bottom corner. For each batch of pancakes, pipe 4-inch rounds of batter onto the griddle. Cook over moderate heat until bubbles appear on the surface of the pancakes, 2 to 3 minutes; flip and cook until risen and golden brown, 2 minutes longer. Transfer to plates and top with the berries, whipped cream and confectioners’ sugar.

Ingredients: 3/4 cup unsweetened coconut milk/n1/4 cup raw coconut vinegar (see Note)/n1/2 small red onion—thinly sliced, rinsed under cold water and patted dry/n3 Thai chiles, thinly sliced/n4 teaspoons grated peeled ginger/n1 tablespoon minced cilantro stems and leaves, plus small leaves for garnish/n1 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more for seasoning/n1/4 teaspoon pepper, plus more for seasoning/n3/4 pound sashimi-grade tuna or hamachi, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nLime wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a bowl, add all of the ingredients except the olive oil and lime wedges. Stir in 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Cover the bowl with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 20 minutes./nStep 2: Stir in the remaining 1 tablespoon of olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Transfer the ceviche to a bowl, garnish with cilantro leaves and serve with lime wedges./nStep 3: Raw coconut vinegar is available at health food shops and from amazon.com./nStep 4: Brisk, zesty Albariño.

Ingredients: 1 ⅓ cups finely chopped walnuts (4 1/2 ounces)/n½ pound cream cheese (softened)/n1  large egg yolk/n¾ cup granulated sugar (plus more for sprinkling)/n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract/n¼ teaspoon cinnamon/n2 ounces bittersweet or semisweet chocolate (finely chopped)/n4  sheets phyllo dough/n1 stick unsalted butter (4 ounces melted)/n4  medium bananas (peeled)/nConfectioners' sugar (for dusting)/n1 pint vanilla ice cream
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375°. Spread the walnuts on a rimmed baking sheet and toast for 6 minutes, or until browned. Transfer the walnuts to a plate to cool./nStep 2: In a bowl, using a handheld mixer, beat the cream cheese until smooth. Beat in the egg yolk. Add 1/4 cup of granulated sugar, the vanilla and cinnamon and beat until blended. Stir the chocolate into the cream cheese mixture and refrigerate for at least 10 minutes./nStep 3: Line a large rimmed baking sheet with parchment paper. Lay 1 sheet of phyllo on the parchment paper. Brush the phyllo with melted butter and sprinkle with 1/3 cup of the walnuts and 2 tablespoons of the granulated sugar. Cover with another phyllo sheet, butter it and sprinkle with walnuts and granulated sugar as before; repeat 2 more times to make 4 layers./nStep 4: Turn the baking sheet so that a long side is facing you. Spoon half the cream cheese mixture in a long strip along the length of the phyllo, leaving a 2-inch border of phyllo below and on each side. Lay 2 bananas end to end on the cream cheese. Set the 2 remaining bananas next to them, so you have a double row. Trim the bananas if needed. Spoon the remaining cream cheese mixture in a strip on the bananas./nStep 5: Starting with the long edge closest to you and using the parchment paper as a guide, lift the phyllo up and over the bananas and roll into a neat, compact log; fold in the sides to enclose the filling. Discard the parchment paper. Slide the strudel to the center of the baking sheet, making sure the seam is down. Brush the strudel with melted butter and sprinkle with granulated sugar./nStep 6: Bake the strudel for 40 minutes, or until crisp and brown. Let it stand for about 25 minutes, then transfer to a cutting board. Dust with confectioners' sugar. Using a serrated knife, thickly slice the strudel crosswise and serve warm with vanilla ice cream.

Ingredients: 5 tablespoons fresh lime juice/n2 1/2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n2 1/2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1 tablespoon very finely chopped jalapeño/n1 tablespoon chopped cilantro, plus cilantro leaves for garnish/n1/2 tablespoon honey/n1/2 teaspoon minced garlic/nSalt and freshly ground black pepper/n1/2 pound lump crabmeat, picked over/n1 1/2 Hass avocados, diced ( 1/2 inch)/n1/3 cup minced red onion/n1 large heirloom tomato, cut into four 1/2-inch-thick slices/nTortilla chips, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, combine the lime juice with the olive oil, vegetable oil, jalapeño, chopped cilantro, honey and garlic. Season the dressing with salt and pepper./nStep 2: In a small bowl, toss the crab with 3 tablespoons of the dressing and season with salt and pepper. In a medium bowl, gently toss the avocado with the red onion and 2 tablespoons of the dressing; season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: Place a tomato slice on each plate and season with salt. Top with the avocado and the crab and garnish with the cilantro. Drizzle the remaining dressing on top and serve with tortilla chips./nStep 4: Variation: To replicate our cover recipe, spoon chopped cherry tomatoes into glasses; top with the crab, avocado and remaining dressing and serve./nStep 5: Rich crab and avocado demand a white wine with substantial body; at the same time, only a white with good acidity will stand up to Zemanick's sweet-spicy-tart dressing. The cool temperatures in Sonoma's Russian River Valley and Sonoma Coast appellations result in Chardonnays with a firm line of acidity under their rich fruit.

Ingredients: 8 large eggs/n1 cup granulated sugar/n1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, sifted/n1 stick unsalted butter, melted and cooled/nYuzu syrup/n3/4 cup granulated sugar/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons fresh orange juice/n2 tablespoons yuzu juice (see Note)/n1 teaspoon unflavored powdered gelatin/n4 large egg yolks/n4 large eggs/n1 cup granulated sugar/n3/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lime zest/nPinch of kosher salt/n1 stick unsalted butter, cubed and softened/n2 cups whole milk/n1/2 vanilla bean, split lengthwise and seeds scraped/n2 large eggs/n1/2 cup granulated sugar/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons cornstarch/nPinch of kosher salt/n1 cup blueberries/n1 cup raspberries/n2 tablespoons yuzu juice/n1 tablespoon granulated sugar/n1 cup cold heavy cream/n2 tablespoons confectioners’ sugar/n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract/n4 kiwi, peeled and sliced/n1 pint blackberries, halved/n3 cups strawberries, sliced
Steps: Step 1: Make the cake layers Preheat the oven to 350°. Line two 8-inch round cake pans with parchment paper. In a stand mixer fitted with the whisk, beat the eggs with the granulated sugar at high speed until thickened, about 10 minutes. Reduce the speed to medium and beat until more than doubled in bulk, about 10 minutes. Using a rubber spatula, gently fold in the flour until nearly smooth. In a small bowl, mix the melted butter with a large dollop of the batter, then fold this mixture into the remaining batter until no streaks remain./nStep 2: Divide the batter between the prepared pans and bake for 25 to 30 minutes, until the cakes are golden and a toothpick inserted in the centers comes out clean. Let cool in the pans for 15 minutes. Unmold the cakes, peel off the parchment and let cool completely. Using a large serrated knife, cut both cakes in half horizontally to make 4 layers./nStep 3: Meanwhile, make the yuzu syrup In a small saucepan, combine the granulated sugar, orange juice and yuzu juice with 1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons of water and bring to a boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Let cool completely./nStep 4: Make the lemon curd In a small bowl, sprinkle the gelatin over 2 tablespoons of cold water until softened. In a medium saucepan, whisk the egg yolks with the whole eggs, granulated sugar, lemon juice and both zests. Cook over moderate heat, whisking occasionally, until simmering, about 8 minutes. Remove from the heat and whisk in the softened gelatin and salt until incorporated. Whisk in the butter 1 cube at a time. Transfer to a medium bowl and let cool completely. Press a piece of plastic wrap directly onto the surface and refrigerate until well chilled, about 1 hour./nStep 5: Make the pastry cream In a medium saucepan, bring the milk and vanilla bean and seeds just to a simmer over moderate heat; discard the vanilla bean. In a stand mixer fitted with the paddle, beat the eggs with the granulated sugar, cornstarch and salt at high speed until very thick and pale, about 2 minutes. Gradually whisk in 1 cup of the hot milk. Scrape this mixture into the saucepan and cook over moderately high heat, whisking, until thickened, 3 to 5 minutes. Scrape into a medium bowl and let cool completely. Press a piece of plastic wrap directly onto the surface and refrigerate, whisking occasionally, until chilled, about 1 hour./nStep 6: Macerate the berries In a medium bowl, toss the berries with the yuzu juice and granulated sugar and let stand at room temperature for 45 minutes./nStep 7: Make the whipped cream In a large bowl, using a hand mixer, beat the cream with the confectioners’ sugar and vanilla extract until stiff; cover and refrigerate until ready to use./nStep 8: Assemble the trifle Arrange half of the kiwi slices and blackberry halves decoratively around the edge of a trifle bowl. Fit 1 cake layer in the bottom of the bowl and brush generously with some of the yuzu syrup. Spread half of the lemon curd on the cake and top with half of the macerated berries. Set another cake layer on top and brush generously with more of the yuzu syrup. Arrange some of the strawberry slices decoratively around the edge of the bowl. Spread half of the pastry cream on the cake, then top with more strawberry slices and half of the whipped cream. Repeat the layering to finish the trifle. Serve./nStep 9: The yuzu syrup, lemon curd and pastry cream can be refrigerated separately overnight. The cooled cake layers can be wrapped in plastic and refrigerated overnight. Beat the lemon curd and pastry cream until smooth before using./nStep 10: If fresh yuzu isn’t available, look for bottled yuzu juice at Japanese markets.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup ketchup/n1/3 cup dark brown sugar/n1/4 cup unsulfured blackstrap molasses/n1/4 cup apricot preserves/n2 tablespoons yellow mustard/n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1 garlic clove, minced/n1 1/2 teaspoons chile powder/n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper/n1/2 teaspoon hot sauce/nPinch of ground cloves/nPinch of ground allspice/nSalt
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, combine all of the ingredients except the salt with 1/2 cup of water and bring to a boil, stirring well. Let cool and season with salt./nStep 2: The barbecue sauce can be refrigerated for up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 1 cup sugar/n1/2 cup water/n1/3 cup light corn syrup/nPinch of salt/n4 cups fresh orange juice/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/n3/4 cup sugar/n1 teaspoon powdered plain gelatin/n8 large egg yolks/n1 cup heavy cream/n1 teaspoon grated orange zest/n3/4 cup finely chopped salted roasted almonds
Steps: Step 1: In a saucepan, bring the sugar, water, light corn syrup and salt to a boil, stirring until the sugar is dissolved; cool. Stir in the orange and lemon juices, transfer to a large glass baking dish and freeze until ice crystals form around the edge, 1 hour. Stir the ice crystals into the center and continue to freeze for 4 1/2 hours, stirring every 30 minutes, until fairly solid./nStep 2: In a saucepan, combine the sugar with 1/2 cup of water and boil until the sugar syrup reaches 220° on a candy thermometer, about 10 minutes. In a small bowl, sprinkle the gelatin over 2 tablespoons of water and let stand until softened, 5 minutes. Whisk the softened gelatin into the sugar syrup./nStep 3: In the bowl of a standing electric mixer fitted with the whisk, beat the egg yolks until smooth. With the machine at medium-high speed, carefully drizzle in the hot sugar syrup, then beat at high speed until the mousse base is thick, fluffy and cool, about 5 minutes./nStep 4: In a bowl, beat the cream until firm. Add the whipped cream and zest to the mousse base; fold in until no white streaks remain./nStep 5: Scrape the granita with a fork until fluffy and spoon half of it into 8 dessert glasses. Top with half of the orange mousse and almonds. Repeat with the remaining granita, mousse and almonds. Freeze the parfaits until firm, at least 2 hours or overnight./nStep 6: The assembled parfaits can be frozen for up to 2 days. Let stand in the refrigerator for 30 minutes to soften slightly before serving./nStep 7: It's delicious with a bright, lively Cuvée Brut, an Italian sparkling wine made in the same manner as Champagne.

Ingredients: 2 ripe bananas, cut into 1-inch chunks/n1/2 cup plain yogurt/n1 cup fresh orange juice/n2 tablespoons honey/n2 tablespoons wheat germ/n2 cups crushed ice
Steps: Step 1: Combine the bananas with the yogurt, orange juice, honey, wheat germ and crushed ice in a blender. Blend at high speed until smooth and frothy. Adjust the sweetness with more honey or orange juice and serve./nStep 2: One Serving Calories 290 kcal, Total Fat 3.4 gm, Saturated Fat 1.5 gm, Protein 6 gm, Carbohydrates 63 gm.

Ingredients: 3 fennel bulbs, cut into 3/4-inch wedges/n1/4 cup plus 1 1/2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 1/2 teaspoons chopped thyme/n1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper/nKosher salt/nBlack pepper/nTwo 12-ounce red snapper fillets/n2 teaspoons crushed fennel seeds/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated grapefruit zest/n1 pink grapefruit, peeled and supremed
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. On a rimmed baking sheet, toss the fennel, 1/4 cup of oil, the thyme and crushed red pepper. Season with salt and black pepper. Roast for about 20 minutes, until just tender./nStep 2: Gently curl 1 snapper fillet over the edge of a ceramic baking dish, skin side up. Make 5 or 6 slashes in the fillet. Repeat with the remaining fillet./nStep 3: In a bowl, whisk the remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons of oil, the fennel seeds and zest and rub all over the fillets and in the slashes; season with salt and pepper. Arrange the snapper skin side up on the fennel. Roast for about 8 minutes, until the fish is just cooked through. Serve the fish and fennel with the grapefruit sections./nStep 4: Wine: Citrusy, medium-bodied white Bordeaux.

Ingredients: 4 cinnamon sticks/n2 teaspoons green cardamom pods/nOne 2-inch piece peeled fresh ginger, chopped/n4 teaspoons finely grated orange zest/n12 whole cloves/n1 cup vodka/nTwo 750-ml bottles dry white wine/n2 cups dry rosé/n2 cups sugar/n2 tablespoons vanilla sugar/n1/2 cup blanched whole almonds/n1/2 cup raisins
Steps: Step 1: In a mortar, crush the cinnamon and cardamom. Transfer to a 1-quart jar. Add the ginger, orange zest, cloves and vodka. Cover; let stand for 24 hours./nStep 2: Strain the vodka into a large saucepan; discard the solids. Add the remaining ingredients and stir over moderate heat until bubbles form around the edges; do not boil. Serve hot./nStep 3: The glögg can be refrigerated for 1 week and rewarmed before serving.

Ingredients: 2 1/2 pounds medium beets, scrubbed/n1 navel orange, halved/nOne 3-inch piece of fresh ginger, sliced and smashed/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt/nPepper/n1/3 cup macadamia nuts/n1/2 cup wakame seaweed/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons unseasoned rice vinegar/n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n1/2 cup very thinly sliced sweet onion/n1/4 cup thinly sliced scallions/n2 Hass avocados—peeled, pitted and cut into large chunks/n2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice/n2 teaspoons wasabi powder/n1 golden beet, peeled and sliced paper-thin, for garnish (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. Set the beets in a baking dish. Squeeze the juice from the orange halves over the beets; add the orange halves and ginger to the dish. Drizzle the beets with the oil and season with salt and pepper. Cover tightly with foil and bake for 1 hour and 15 minutes, until the beets are tender. Let cool, then peel and cut into 1-inch pieces. Leave the oven on./nStep 2: Meanwhile, toast the nuts in a pie plate until golden, about 10 minutes. Let cool, then coarsely chop. In a bowl, cover the wakame with cold water and let stand until rehydrated, about 5 minutes; drain. Rinse under cold water, then drain again./nStep 3: In a large bowl, toss the beets with the wakame, toasted nuts, vinegar, sesame oil, onion and scallions. Season the poke with salt and pepper. Refrigerate until slightly chilled, about 15 minutes./nStep 4: In another bowl, mash the avocados with the lemon juice, wasabi powder and 1 tablespoon of water. Season the avocado with salt and pepper. Refrigerate until chilled, about 15 minutes./nStep 5: To serve, mound the poke on plates and garnish with the golden beet, if using. Pass the avocado-wasabi mash at the table./nStep 6: The beet poke can be refrigerated overnight. Add the nuts, then serve.

Ingredients: 1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest/n3/4 cup sugar/n3/4 cup fresh lemon juice (4 lemons)/n4 large eggs plus 1 large egg yolk/nSalt/n1 1/2 sticks unsalted butter, cubed/nMixed fresh berries, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, bring 2 inches of water to a boil; keep the water at a simmer over low heat. In a large stainless steel or glass bowl, using your fingers, rub the lemon zest into the sugar. Whisk in the lemon juice, eggs, egg yolk and a pinch of salt. Set the bowl over the simmering water and cook the mixture, stirring, until very thick, 5 to 7 minutes. Scrape the cream into a medium bowl./nStep 2: Add 3 tablespoons of the butter to the cream. Using an immersion blender, puree until the cream is smooth. Add the remaining butter and puree until incorporated. Press a sheet of plastic wrap directly onto the surface of the cream and refrigerate until well chilled, about 4 hours. Spoon over fresh berries and serve./nStep 3: The lemon cream can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.

Ingredients: 6 medium-size ripe yellow guavas, unpeeled, stemmed, and halved/n3 cups water/n1 ounce edible dried hibiscus flowers (about 1 cup)/n3/4 cup granulated sugar/n2 (2-inch) cinnamon sticks/n1 cup (8 ounces) sweet red vermouth (such as Bèrto)/n1 small Granny Smith apple, finely chopped (about 1 cup)/n1/2 cup fresh lemon juice, plus lemon slices, for garnish/n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt/n1/4 cup (2 ounces) Fernet-Vallet or Fernet-Branca (optional)/nTopo Chico, for serving/nMint sprigs, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Combine guavas, 3 cups water, hibiscus flowers, sugar, and cinnamon sticks in a large saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium-high. Reduce heat to medium-low, and simmer, uncovered, until guavas are slightly softened, about 15 minutes. Let cool to room temperature, about 1 hour. Proceed immediately to step 2, or, for a more intense guava flavor, transfer to a medium bowl, cover, and refrigerate overnight./nStep 2: Pour guava mixture through a fine wire-mesh strainer set over a medium bowl. Using the back of a spoon, lightly mash guava mixture to release all of the juices; discard solids./nStep 3: Stir together guava mixture, vermouth, apple, lemon juice, salt, and, if desired, Fernet in an ice-filled pitcher or bowl. Garnish with lemon slices. Serve in chilled cocktail glasses. Top each glass with a splash of Topo Chico, and garnish with mint./nStep 4: Dried hibiscus flowers can be purchased at Mexican grocery stores or online.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 small yellow onion, chopped/n2 cloves garlic, minced/n1 jalapeño, seeded and chopped/n1 tablespoon chili powder/n1 teaspoon cumin/nPinch of crushed red pepper/n1 teaspoon smoked paprika/n1/2 teaspoon dried Mexican oregano/n1 teaspoon sugar/nKosher salt/nFresh ground black pepper/nOne 28-ounce can diced tomatoes/n1 pound boneless skinless chicken breast/n1 14-ounce can chopped pineapple/n8 eight-inch corn or flour tortillas/n4 ounces shredded sharp cheddar or Monterey jack cheese (about 1 cup)
Steps: Step 1: reheat oven to 350º. In a large saucepan, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Cook the onion over moderate heat until soft and translucent, about 5 to 7 minutes. Add the garlic, jalapeño, chili powder, cumin, crushed red pepper, paprika, oregano, sugar, salt and pepper and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Stir in the tomatoes and remove from heat. Blend in a food processor or blender until smooth. Return the tomato mixture to heat, and bring to a simmer. Add the chicken breasts and cook, stirring occasionally, until the chicken is no longer pink and cooked through, about 20 to 25 minutes./nStep 2: Transfer the chicken to a cutting board and use two forks to shred it. Place the chicken in a large bowl and add the pineapple. Stir in 1 cup of the sauce./nStep 3: Wrap the tortillas in a damp paper towel and warm them in a microwave oven until soft and pliable, about 1 minute./nStep 4: Spread a thin layer of sauce on the bottom of a 9-by-13-inch glass baking dish. Arrange the tortillas on a work surface. Spoon the chicken mixture onto the tortillas. Roll up the tortillas and arrange in the baking dish. Top evenly with the remaining sauce. Sprinkle the top of the enchiladas with the cheese. Bake for 15 to 20 minutes, until the enchiladas are hot and the cheese is melted./nStep 5: Serve warm with sour cream, jalapeños, lime wedges and minced green onions.

Ingredients: 2 pounds large shrimp, shelled and deveined, tails left on/n3 garlic cloves, minced/nJuice of 1 lime/nKosher salt/n2 tablespoons Annatto Oil or corn oil/n1 small onion, minced/n6 scallions, white and light green parts, minced/n1/2 medium red bell pepper, minced/n1/2 medium green bell pepper, minced/n6 plum tomatoes, minced/n1/4 cup tomato sauce/n1/2 cup unsweetened coconut milk/n1 Scotch bonnet or habanero chile, halved and seeded/n1 tablespoon minced cilantro leaves and stems/nLime wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large bowl, toss the shrimp with the garlic, lime juice and 1 teaspoon of salt. Let marinate at room temperature for 30 minutes./nStep 2: In a large skillet, heat the Annatto Oil until shimmering. Add the onion, scallions and red and green bell peppers and cook over moderately high heat, stirring, until softened, about 4 minutes. Add the minced tomatoes and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. Reduce the heat to moderately low and add the tomato sauce, coconut milk, chile and 1 teaspoon of salt. Simmer until the sauce is reduced by one-fourth, about 10 minutes. Increase the heat to moderately high. Add the shrimp and cook, stirring, until they're pink and opaque, about 5 minutes. Transfer to a serving dish and discard the chile. Sprinkle with the cilantro and serve with lime wedges./nStep 3: White rice./nStep 4: To complement the sauce here, look for a fruity, lightly spicy and aromatic white, such as an Argentinean Torrontés.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon canola oil/n5 garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n1/4 cup pine nuts/n1/2 cup sherry, preferably Amontillado/n2 tablespoons sherry vinegar/n6 tablespoons fresh blood-orange juice or plain orange juice/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated blood-orange zest or plain orange zest/n1 tablespoon unsalted butter/n2 tablespoons chopped tarragon/nKosher salt/nPepper/nPan-seared scallops, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a medium skillet, heat the oil. Add the garlic and pine nuts and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until golden, 2 minutes. Stir in the sherry, sherry vinegar and blood-orange juice and cook over high heat until reduced by half, 5 minutes. Remove the saucepan from the heat and whisk in the orange zest, butter and tarragon. Season with salt and pepper. Serve the agrodolce over seared scallops.

Ingredients: ¼ cup (2 ounces) spiced rum/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice (1 ounce)/n1 ½ tablespoons Herb-Infused Simple Syrup (3/4 ounce) (see Note)/n10 to 12 fresh mint leaves/n⅓ cup club soda/nFresh herb sprigs (such as sage, rosemary, and mint)
Steps: Step 1: Combine rum, lime juice, syrup, and mint leaves in a cocktail shaker filled halfway with ice. Cover and shake vigorously until chilled, about 20 seconds. Strain into a 12-ounce Collins glass filled with ice. Top with club soda. Garnish with herb sprigs./nStep 2: ACTIVE 5 MIN; TOTAL 35 MIN; MAKES ABOUT 1 1/2 CUPS/nStep 3: This twist on classic simple syrup infuses the sweetener with fresh, piney rosemary and sage to add an aromatic depth./nStep 4: Stir together 1 cup granulated sugar and 1 cup boiling water in a heatproof measuring cup until dissolved. Add 5 rosemary sprigs and 5 sage leaves; press with a spoon until submerged. Steep, uncovered, 30 minutes. Pour through a fine wire- mesh strainer into a 2-cup glass jar; discard solids. Cover and refrigerate up to 2 weeks. —ANH NGO, KATA ROBATA, HOUSTON

Ingredients: 8 pounds baby back ribs, membranes removed, cut into 4-rib sections/nFinely grated zest of 2 lemons/n1/4 cup finely chopped flat-leaf parsley/n2 tablespoons minced chives/n1 tablespoon minced tarragon/n1 tablespoon minced thyme/n1 1/2 cups Ham Hock Stock/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n3 tablespoons grapeseed oil/n2 tablespoons cider vinegar/n1 pound Napa cabbage, finely shredded (4 cups)/n2 large Granny Smith apples, julienned
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the broiler. Peel the membrane from the underside of the ribs and place them, skinned side up, on 2 rimmed baking sheets. Broil the ribs 6 inches from the heat, turning once, until browned on both sides, 8 to 10 minutes per sheet./nStep 2: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a small bowl, mix the lemon zest with 2 tablespoons of the parsley and the chives, tarragon and thyme. Brush the ribs with some of the Ham Hock Stock over the ribs and sprinkle with half of the herb mixture. Season the ribs with salt and pepper and bake for about 1 hour, without turning, until very tender; baste the ribs with the stock and sprinkle with the herb mixture several times while baking. Transfer the ribs to a cutting board and cut into individual ribs./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a large bowl, whisk the oil with the vinegar and season with salt and pepper. Add the cabbage, apples and the remaining 2 tablespoons of chopped parsley and toss to coat. Serve with the ribs./nStep 4: The baked ribs can be refrigerated overnight. Reheat before serving./nStep 5: These delectable ribs would be ideal with a fruity Norton, Missouri's most famous wine grape, because Norton has a firm acidity that pairs well with tangy foods. A good alternative is Argentine Malbec.

Ingredients: One 15-ounce can unsweetened coconut milk/n1 tablespoon coconut sugar/n2 teaspoons kosher salt/n2 teaspoons ground turmeric/n6 ears of corn, shucked
Steps: Step 1: In a small saucepan, combine the coconut milk, coconut sugar, salt and turmeric. Bring to a boil, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Cook until slightly thickened, about 10 minutes./nStep 2: Light a grill or heat a grill pan over moderate heat. Brush the corn with some of the coconut glaze and grill, turning and basting occasionally, until slightly charred and crisp-tender, about 20 minutes. Brush the corn with more glaze and serve warm./nStep 3: The glaze can be refrigerated overnight.

Ingredients: 1 pound fresh apricots, halved and pitted/n1 pound fresh nectarines, halved and pitted/n⅓ cup granulated sugar/n15  fresh mint leaves (about 1/4 loosely packed cup)/n25 cup (2 ounces) bourbon/nFinely crushed or pebbled ice/n1  mint sprig, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 400°F. Toss together apricots, nectarines, and sugar on a large rimmed baking sheet until fully coated; spread in an even layer. Roast in preheated oven until fruit is soft and juicy, about 20 minutes, stirring halfway through roasting time. Let cool 5 minutes. Scrape fruit and any liquid on baking sheet into a food processor or blender; pulse until smooth, 5 to 8 pulses. Pour through a fine wire-mesh strainer into a medium bowl. Refrigerate, uncovered, until completely cool, about 20 minutes. (You should have about 2 cups apricot-nectarine puree, enough for 8 cocktails.)/nStep 2: Muddle mint leaves and 1/4 cup apricot-nectarine puree in bottom of a julep cup. Add bourbon and crushed or pebbled ice to cover; stir until chilled, about 20 seconds. Fill cup with additional ice, adding enough to form a small mound on top. Pour 2 to 4 tablespoons apricot-nectarine puree over ice. Garnish with a mint sprig, and serve with a short julep straw./nStep 3: Muddle 2 cups loosely packed fresh mint leaves and 2 cups apricot-nectarine puree in a pitcher. Add 2 cups bourbon and crushed or pebbled ice to cover, and stir until chilled, about 20 seconds. Serve drinks over ice, and garnish with mint sprigs./nStep 4: Apricot-nectarine puree may be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 3/4 cup (6 1/2 ounces) whole milk/n1 teaspoon honey/n1  (1/4-ounce) envelope active dry yeast (about 2 1/4 teaspoons)/n4 ¼ cups (about 18 ounces) all-purpose flour, plus more for work surface and as needed/n½ cup (3 1/2 ounces) granulated sugar/n1 ½ teaspoons kosher salt/n1 cup (8 ounces) cold unsalted butter, cut into cubes/n4 large eggs, beaten/n1 teaspoon vanilla extract/nCooking spray/n½ cup (4 ounces) unsalted butter/n½ cup (4 ounces) honey/n3 tablespoons grated orange zest (from 6 medium oranges)/n1 tablespoon ground cinnamon/n2 teaspoons ground cardamom
Steps: Step 1: Heat milk in a small saucepan over medium-low until just warm (105°F to 110°F), about 1 minute. Remove pan from heat; stir in honey. Stir in yeast; let stand until yeast is dissolved and mixture is foamy, about 5 minutes. Stir mixture until no clumps remain./nStep 2: Beat flour, sugar, and salt with a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment on low speed until combined, about 30 seconds. Add butter cubes a few at a time, beating on low speed until cubes are broken down into pea-sized pieces, about 2 minutes per addition. Remove paddle attachment from mixer; attach dough hook attachment. With stand mixer running on low speed, drizzle in milk mixture, eggs, and vanilla; beat until combined, about 1 minute. Increase mixer speed to medium; beat until a soft, smooth, shiny Dough forms, 10 to 15 minutes. If Dough remains too sticky, beat in additional flour 1 tablespoon at a time./nStep 3: Transfer Dough to a lightly floured work surface, and shape into a ball. Transfer Dough to a bowl coated with cooking spray, and cover with plastic wrap. Refrigerate at least 8 hours or up to 20 hours./nStep 4: Cook butter, honey, orange zest, cinnamon, and cardamom in a small saucepan over medium, stirring often, until butter is melted, about 3 minutes. Remove pan from heat; stir mixture until smooth. Let cool slightly, about 15 minutes./nStep 5: Coat a 13- x -9-inch baking dish with cooking spray; set aside. Remove Dough from refrigerator. Place on a lightly floured work surface, and roll into a 16- x 12-inch rectangle aout 1/4 inch thick, with 1 long edge of Dough facing you./nStep 6: Brush half of the Filling over surface of Dough. Starting with long edge nearest to you, roll Dough up into a log, using a bench scraper to help move the Dough if necessary (Dough will be soft and somewhat sticky). Using a sharp serrated knife, cut Dough evenly into 12 pieces (about 1 1/4 inches wide). Transfer each piece of Dough to prepared baking dish. Cover baking dish with plastic wrap, and let buns rise until puffy and almost doubled in size, 45 minutes to 1 hour. Meanwhile, preheat oven to 375°F./nStep 7: Remove plastic wrap. Transfer buns to preheated oven. Bake until golden brown, about 25 minutes. Remove buns from oven, and immediately brush remaining Filling on top. Let buns cool to just warm, about 10 minutes. Serve.

Ingredients: Four 1 1/2-inch-thick slices of brioche/n1/4 cup strawberry jam, plus more for serving/n3 large eggs/n1/4 cup heavy cream/n1 1/2 teaspoons granulated sugar/nFleur de sel/n4 tablespoons unsalted butter/nConfectioners’ sugar/nCrème fraîche, for serving/n1/2 lemon
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. Cut a 2-inch pocket in the side of each brioche slice; spoon 1 tablespoon of jam in each one./nStep 2: In a shallow bowl, whisk the eggs with the cream, granulated sugar and 1/2 teaspoon of fleur de sel./nStep 3: In a large skillet, melt 2 tablespoons of the butter. Dip 2 slices of the stuffed brioche in the egg mixture and soak until saturated. Add to the skillet and cook over moderate heat until nicely browned on both sides, about 2 minutes. Transfer the French toast to a baking sheet. Repeat with the remaining butter, brioche and egg mixture./nStep 4: Bake the French toast for about 5 minutes, until cooked through. Transfer to plates and sift confectioners’ sugar evenly on top. Dollop crème fraîche and strawberry jam on the French toast. Squeeze a little lemon juice over each slice and sprinkle with fleur de sel. Serve right away.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons sugar/n2 tablespoons hot water/n2 cups lightly packed mint leaves, plus small sprigs for garnish/n1 1/2 cups lightly packed basil leaves, plus small sprigs for garnish/n1 cup thinly sliced English cucumber, plus 8 spears for garnish/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons yuzu juice/n2 cups chilled vodka/n2 1/4 cups chilled sparkling water/nIce
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk the sugar with the hot water until dissolved. In a pitcher, muddle the mint and basil leaves with the sliced cucumber and the sugar syrup. Stir in the yuzu juice, vodka and sparkling water. Serve in ice-filled collins glasses garnished with small sprigs of mint and basil and a cucumber spear.

Ingredients: 4 pounds stone fruit (peaches, nectarines and apricots) cut into large wedges/n3/4 cup granulated sugar/n2 tablespoons cornstarch/n1 1/3 cups all-purpose flour/n2/3 cup light brown sugar/n1 teaspoon baking soda/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 stick plus 2 tablespoons cold unsalted butter, cubed/n1 cup thick-cut rolled oats
Steps: Step 1: In a bowl, toss the fruit with the granulated sugar and cornstarch and let stand for 10 minutes./nStep 2: Preheat the oven to 375°. In a food processor, pulse the flour with the brown sugar, baking soda and salt. Add the butter and pulse until crumbly. Add the oats and pulse until incorporated. Transfer the topping to a bowl and press it into clumps./nStep 3: Spread the filling in a 9-by-13-inch baking dish. Scatter the topping over the filling. Bake in the center of the oven for 1 hour, until the fruit is bubbling and the topping is golden and crisp. Let cool for 1 hour before serving.

Ingredients: Ice/n1 1/2 ounces aged rum/n1/2 ounce triple sec/n3/4 ounce passion fruit nectar or juice/n1 1/2 teaspoons sambuca/nSplash of chilled Sprite/n1 organic rose petal (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Fill a cocktail shaker with ice. Add all of the ingredients except the Sprite and rose petal and shake well. Strain into a chilled martini glass and top with the Sprite. If desired, garnish with the rose petal.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons kosher salt/n1 tablespoon smoked hot paprika/n1 tablespoon onion powder/n1 tablespoon garlic powder/nOne 7-pound trimmed boneless pork shoulder, at room temperature/n1/4 cup Sriracha/nOne 2-pound ripe pineapple—peeled, cored and cut into 1-inch pieces/n1 cup light brown sugar/n1 cup apple cider vinegar
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, combine the salt, paprika and onion and garlic powders. Set the pork fat side down on a work surface. Using a boning knife, cut between the natural separations in the meat in about 4 places. Sprinkle the spice mixture all over the pork, then rub all over with the Sriracha. Roll up the roast and tie it at 1-inch intervals with kitchen twine; let marinate at room temperature for 2 hours./nStep 2: Preheat the oven to 325°. In a roasting pan, toss the pineapple with the brown sugar and vinegar. Spread the pineapple in the pan and set the pork roast on top, fat side up. Roast for 4 hours, basting every 30 minutes, until an instant-read thermometer inserted in the thickest part of the meat registers 165°. Transfer to a carving board to rest for 20 minutes./nStep 3: Set the roasting pan with the pineapple over high heat and boil the pan juices until slightly thickened, 2 minutes. Remove the strings from the pork, carve into 1/2-inch-thick slices and arrange on a platter. Add carving juices to the pan and season with salt. Serve the pork with the pineapple and pan juices./nStep 4: Sweet-and-sour dishes can prove tricky to pair with wine. Generous, juicy Grenache tends to be a good choice, especially for substantial pork dishes.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup red wine vinegar/n2 tablespoons honey/n2 tablespoons light brown sugar/n1/4 teaspoon ground coriander/nOne 2-inch cinnamon stick/nPinch of ground cloves/n1 small bay leaf/n1 1/2 cups finely diced pineapple ( 1/2 inch)/n1 1/2 cups finely diced mango ( 1/2 inch)/n1 cup finely diced papaya ( 1/2 inch)/n1 small garlic clove, minced/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated fresh ginger/n1/2 small Scotch bonnet or habanero chile, minced/nSalt and freshly ground white pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, combine the vinegar, honey, brown sugar, coriander, cinnamon stick, cloves and bay leaf and bring to a simmer. Add the pineapple, mango, papaya, garlic, ginger and Scotch bonnet and season lightly with salt and white pepper. Simmer over low heat for 30 minutes. Let cool. Discard the cinnamon and bay leaf. Serve at room temperature or chilled./nStep 2: The chutney can be refrigerated for up to 2 weeks.

Ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour (about 8 1/2 ounces), plus more for pan/n2 tablespoons grated orange zest plus 1 1/4 cups fresh orange juice (from 3 oranges), divided/n1 1/2 tablespoons baking powder/n1 1/2 cups granulated sugar/n1/2 cup vegetable oil, plus more for greasing pan/n3 large eggs
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F. Stir together flour, orange zest, and baking powder in a medium bowl. Set aside./nStep 2: Beat sugar, vegetable oil, and eggs with an electric mixer on high speed until almost white, about 1 minute and 30 seconds. Add orange juice; beat on low speed until combined, about 20 seconds. With mixer running on low speed, gradually add flour mixture. Beat until just combined, about 1 minute (do not overmix)./nStep 3: Transfer batter to a greased (with vegetable oil) and floured 9-inch tube or Bundt pan. Bake in preheated oven until a wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean, 40 to 45 minutes. Let cool in pan 10 minutes. Invert cake onto a wire rack; let cool completely, about 1 hour./nStep 4: Cake can be made up to 3 days in advance and stored in an airtight container at room temperature.

Ingredients: 2 cups all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting/n1/2 cup vegetable shortening/n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, cubed and chilled/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 stick unsalted butter/n1 cup dark raisins/n1 cup currants/n1/2 cup golden raisins/n1/2 cup dried cranberries/n1/2 cup packed dark brown sugar/n1 teaspoon finely grated orange zest/n1/4 cup fresh orange juice/n1/4 cup unsulfured molasses/n1 Granny Smith apple—unpeeled, cored and cut into 1/4-inch pieces/n1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest/n1/2 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg/n1/2 teaspoon ground cinnamon/n1/2 teaspoon ground cloves/n1/2 teaspoon ground allspice/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt/n1/4 cup dark rum/n1/4 cup brandy/n2 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted/n1 tablespoon whole milk/n2 tablespoons sugar
Steps: Step 1: Make the crust In a small bowl, mix 1/2 cup of the flour with 1/4 cup of ice water until a paste forms. In a medium bowl, combine the remaining 1 1/2 cups of flour with the shortening, butter and salt, cutting in the shortening and butter until pea-size pieces form. Add the flour paste and gently knead until the dough just comes together. Pat into a 1-inch-thick disk, wrap in plastic and refrigerate for at least 1 hour or overnight./nStep 2: Meanwhile, make the filling In a large saucepan, combine all of the ingredients except the rum and brandy. Cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the mixture thickens and the apples are tender, about 15 minutes. Stir in the rum and brandy and let cool to room temperature./nStep 3: Preheat the oven to 375°. Cut the dough in half. On a lightly floured work surface, using a lightly floured rolling pin, roll out each half into a 12-inch round about 1/8 inch thick. Fit 1 round into a 9-inch pie plate. Spread the filling in the pie shell, then top with the remaining dough round. Trim the overhang to 1/2 inch, then tuck the top edge under the bottom edge and crimp decoratively./nStep 4: Glaze and bake the pie Brush the pie with the melted butter and drizzle over the milk. Sprinkle with the sugar and make 8 small slits in the top. Set the pie on a baking sheet and bake for about 1 hour and 45 minutes, until the crust is golden. Transfer the pie to a rack to cool completely./nStep 5: The filling can be refrigerated for up to 2 days. The baked pie can be stored at room temperature overnight.

Ingredients: ¾ cup whole milk/n2 large pitted dried Medjool dates, chopped (3 tablespoons)/n2 tablespoons water/n1 ½ teaspoons  matcha powder
Steps: Step 1: Process all ingredients in a blender until almost all dates are broken down, about 1 minute. Pour through a fine mesh strainer into a glass; discard solids. Top latte with ice.

Ingredients: 1 1/3 cups simple syrup/n10 dried figs, halved/n1 (4-inch) piece fresh ginger, peeled and thinly sliced (about 1/3 cup)/n1 (750-ml) bottle mezcal/n1 1/4 cups fresh lemon juice (from 8 large lemons)/n3/4 cup water/nWhole nutmeg
Steps: Step 1: Combine simple syrup, figs, and ginger in a small saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium. Reduce heat to low, and simmer until figs are softened, about 5 minutes. Remove from heat, and let cool 30 minutes. Refrigerate mixture, covered, 8 hours or overnight. Pour mixture through a fine wire-mesh strainer into a bowl; discard solids. Store in an airtight container up to 1 week./nStep 2: Place mezcal in a pitcher. Pour 11/4 cups fig-ginger syrup through a fine-mesh sieve into pitcher, followed by lemon juice and 3/4 cup water. Refrigerate until chilled, 2 hours or up to overnight. Stir before serving. Pour over large ice cubes into rocks glasses. Garnish servings with freshly grated nutmeg./nStep 3: Fig-ginger syrup can be made up to 1 week ahead of time.

Ingredients: 1/2 vanilla bean pod, split lengthwise/n2 cups well-shaken and stirred unsweetened canned coconut milk/n1 cup creamy peanut butter/n1/2 cup sweetened condensed milk/n1/4 cup (2 ounces) Jamaican dark rum (such as Cruzan Aged Dark Rum)/n1 teaspoon grated cinnamon (from 1 cinnamon stick)/n9 cups shaved or crushed ice/nGrated fresh nutmeg
Steps: Step 1: Scrape vanilla bean seeds into a blender; add coconut milk, peanut butter, condensed milk, rum, and cinnamon. Process until smooth, about 45 seconds. (Mixture will be the consistency of a milkshake.) Cover and chill until ready to serve, up to 3 days./nStep 2: Fill 6 lowball glasses with shaved ice (about 1 1/2 cups each), heaping into a mound. Slowly pour peanut mixture over ice (about 1/2 cup each). Garnish with nutmeg, and serve with spoons.

Ingredients: 3 ½ cups all-purpose flour (about 14 7/8 ounces), plus more for work surface and kneading/n¾ cup granulated sugar/n½ cup coconut sugar/n1 teaspoon ground nutmeg/n½ teaspoon kosher salt/n¼ teaspoon baking powder/n¼ cup unsalted butter, cubed, at room temperature/n¾ cup heavy cream/n¼ cup unsweetened coconut cream (such as Thai Kitchen)/n1 large egg/nVegetable oil, for frying
Steps: Step 1: Whisk together flour, granulated sugar, coconut sugar, nutmeg, salt, and baking powder in a large bowl. Add butter; rub butter into flour mixture using your fingers until well incorporated. (Mixture should look like sand.) Whisk in heavy cream, coconut cream, and egg until a sticky dough ball forms, eventually switching from a whisk to using your hands when mixture becomes too thick to whisk./nStep 2: Turn dough out onto a lightly floured work surface. Knead until smooth, elastic, even in color, and no longer sticky, 2 to 3 minutes, adding up to 1/4 cup additional flour, 1 tablespoon at a time, as needed./nStep 3: Divide dough in half. Roll 1 dough piece into a 1/6-inch-thick rectangle about 12 x 9 inches. (Feel free to use a pasta roller if you have one.) Trim away any uneven edges. Cut dough rectangle into 1/2-inch squares, occasionally flouring knife blade to prevent dough from sticking. Repeat process with remaining dough piece. (At this point, you can freeze dough squares for later, if you like: Place cut dough squares in a single layer on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper, and freeze until solid; transfer dough squares to a ziplock plastic freezer bag, and freeze up to 3 months. To cook, let thaw in a single layer at room temperature, and then fry as instructed below.)/nStep 4: Pour oil to a depth of 3 inches in a large Dutch oven. Heat over medium to 350°F. Working in 6 to 8 batches, add chin chin squares to hot oil. (Don't worry if the chin chin squares are a little stuck together; they'll separate once they hit the oil.) Cook, stirring often using a slotted spoon, until golden, puffed, and crisp, about 1 minute. (This goes quickly, so watch carefully.) Using a spider, transfer chin chin squares to a baking sheet lined with paper towels. Let cool slightly, about 5 minutes. Serve./nStep 5: Chin chin can be stored in an airtight container at room temperature up to 1 month. Dough can be frozen after being cut up to 3 months.

Ingredients: 6 large basil leaves/n2 large limes, quartered/n2 navel oranges, quartered/n2 cups fresh orange juice/n3/4 cup sugar/n1/4 teaspoon minced Thai chile, with some seeds/n1/4 teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg, plus more for garnish/n1 1/2 cups dark rum/n4 cups crushed ice
Steps: Step 1: In a large bowl, combine 2 of the basil leaves with the limes, oranges, orange juice, sugar, chile and 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg. Using a potato masher or a large wooden pestle, pound the limes and oranges until the sugar is dissolved and a rich syrup forms. Squeeze and discard the lime and orange quarters. Stir in the rum./nStep 2: Fill 4 large wineglasses or highball glasses with the crushed ice and bury a basil leaf in each. Fill with the rum drink, garnish each drink with grated nutmeg and serve./nStep 3: The recipe can be prepared through Step 1 and refrigerated overnight.

Ingredients: 1 cup amaranth/n3 cups unsweetened coconut milk/n1 cup unsweetened shredded coconut/n1/2 cup honey/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract/n1 cinnamon stick/nOne 1-inch piece of peeled fresh ginger/n1/4 cup raisins
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350º. In a large saucepan, bring all of the ingredients to a boil. Remove from the heat and pour into an oiled 3-quart casserole dish./nStep 2: Bake for one hour, or until amaranth has absorbed the liquid and is tender. Serve warm or chilled.
