Cover the saucepan and simmer over low heat until the quinoa is tender and all of the water has been absorbed, 20 minutes./nStep 3: In a large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the oil. Add the onion and cook over moderate heat until translucent, about 4 minutes. Add the carrot and cook until starting to soften, about 3 minutes. Add the shiitake, cover and cook until tender, about 4 minutes. Add the zucchini, season with salt and cook, stirring a few times, until tender, about 3 minutes. Transfer to a bowl./nStep 4: Add the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil to the skillet. Add the broccoli, cover and cook over moderate heat, stirring a few times, until deep green, 5 minutes. Add the kale, cover and cook, stirring a few times, until the broccoli and kale are just tender, 4 minutes. Season with salt. Stir in the other vegetables./nStep 5: In a small bowl, whisk the tahini with the lemon juice, garlic, warm water and crushed red pepper. Season with salt./nStep 6: Transfer the brown rice and quinoa to bowls. Top with the cooked vegetables, diced avocado and bean sprouts. Serve, passing the tahini sauce at the table./nStep 7: One Serving 500 cal, 22 gm fat, 2.9 gm sat fat, 69 gm carb, 10 gm fiber, 15 gm protein./nStep 8: Fresh, zesty Sauvignon Blanc.

Ingredients: 1 cup uncooked short-grain brown rice/n2 cups water/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 medium onion, diced/n3 cloves garlic, minced/n2 cups (8 ounces) shelled edamame/n1 medium carrot, grated or diced/n1 large egg, beaten/n2 tablespoons fish sauce/nFresh cracked black pepper, to taste
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, combine the rice and water and bring to a simmer. Cover, reduce the heat to low, and gently simmer for 30-40 minutes or until the water is fully absorbed. Remove from heat, fluff the rice and set allow to cool to room temperature. (You can chill the rice to expedite the cooling.)/nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over medium heat. Add the oil, onions and garlic. Cook until soft, about 2 minutes./nStep 3: Stir in the rice, breaking apart any clumps. Cook for about 3 minutes, or until rice is completely heated through, stirring constantly as it cooks./nStep 4: Stir in the edamame and carrots. Cook for 2 minutes, or until heated through. Stir in the egg and fish sauce until well mixed. Cook for another 2 minutes, or until egg is fully cooked, stirring occasionally. Season with black pepper. Serve warm./nStep 5: Using day-old rice is the best option when making fried rice.

Ingredients: 1 1/4 cups pearled barley (9 ounces)/n1 cup walnut halves (4 ounces)/n3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n1 garlic clove, minced/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n1 cup packed flat-leaf parsley leaves/n4 ounces ricotta salata, crumbled (about 1 cup)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a large saucepan of boiling salted water, cook the barley over high heat until tender, about 25 minutes. Drain the barley and rinse under cold water to cool thoroughly. Drain again, shaking out the excess water./nStep 2: Meanwhile, spread the walnuts in a pie plate and toast for 10 to 12 minutes, until golden and fragrant. Transfer to a cutting board and let cool. Coarsely chop the nuts./nStep 3: In a large bowl, whisk the lemon juice with the olive oil, garlic and lemon zest and season with salt and pepper. Add the barley, parsley and ricotta salata and toss gently. Add the toasted walnuts, toss again and serve./nStep 4: The salad can be refrigerated overnight.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons chopped garlic/n100 milliliters (3 1/2 fluid ounces) extra-virgin olive oil/n200 grams (7 ounces) brown onions, chopped/n1 kilogram (2 pounds 3 ounces) cuttlefish/n1 tablespoon tomato paste (concentrated purée)/n100 milliliters (3 1/2 fluid ounces) white wine/n600 milliliters (20 1/2 fluid ounces / 2 1/2 cups) fish stock or water/n1/2 tablespoon cuttlefish ink (see method)/n300 grams (10 1/2 ounces) risotto rice (arborio or carnaroli)/nSea salt/nFreshly ground black pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a frying pan over high heat, sauté the chopped garlic in a little olive oil for a few seconds, making sure it does not burn. Add the onion, reduce the heat to low, and sauté until golden and transparent, approximately 10–15 minutes. (It’s important to sauté the garlic before the onion as this will help to release its aroma.)/nStep 2: Before cleaning out the inside and bones of the cuttlefish, carefully remove the silver sac of ink from the middle of the cuttlefish, making sure not to break it, and set it aside. Cut the cuttlefish into 1 centimeter (1/2 inch) cubes./nStep 3: Add the diced cuttlefish to the sautéed garlic and onion and season well with salt and pepper. Sauté the cuttlefish until all the liquid that has been released has evaporated and the cuttlefish starts to stick to the bottom of the pan, caramelising slightly. Add the tomato paste and cook for a few seconds, then add the white wine and cook until the liquid has almost completely evaporated. Add the fish stock or water, 1/2 tablespoon of the cuttlefish ink, and adjust the seasoning. Leave to simmer on low heat for 10 minutes./nStep 4: Add the rice and cook for 16 minutes, stirring the risotto constantly until it is done (the rice should be cooked but still slightly firm). If the risotto is too thick, you can add some more fish stock and olive oil at the end. Add more seasoning if needed and serve immediately.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 pound hot Italian chicken or turkey sausage, casings removed/n1 small yellow onion, diced/n1 leek, white and light green parts only, thinly sliced/n2 garlic cloves, minced/n1 cup uncooked long-grain white rice/n1 teaspoon sea salt/n1 pound broccoli, cut into bite-size pieces/n2 cups chicken broth/n2 cups shredded extra-sharp cheddar cheese
Steps: Step 1: In a medium skillet or saucepan, heat the olive oil. Add the sausage and cook over moderately high heat, breaking it up with your spatula, until nicely browned, 5 to 7 minutes. Transfer to a plate./nStep 2: Add the onion and leek to the pan and sauté until translucent, 5 minutes. Stir in the garlic and rice and cook until the garlic is fragrant and the rice is coated with the vegetable mixture , about 2 minutes. Stir in the cooked sausage along with the salt and chicken broth and bring to a boil./nStep 3: Cover the pan, turn the heat to low and cook for 10 minutes./nStep 4: Uncover and fold in the broccoli and half of the cheese. Cover and cook until the broccoli and rice are tender, 10 to 12 minutes longer. Sprinkle with the remaining cheese cover and let stand off the heat until the cheese is melted. For a crisp top, broil briefly. Serve hot.

Ingredients: 2 cups almond milk/n2 cups water/n1 cup amaranth/n4 tablespoons unsalted butter/n½ cup brown sugar/n1 tablespoon ground cinnamon
Steps: Step 1: Bring the milk and water to a boil in a medium saucepan. Whisk in the amaranth, reduce the heat to low and cover. Simmer for 30 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the liquid is absorbed and the amaranth is tender. Remove the amaranth from the heat and stir in the butter, brown sugar and cinnamon. Serve warm.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup uncooked medium-grain white rice (such as Bomba) or 2 cups cooked medium-grain white rice/n1 1/2 cups water/n1/2 cup plain whole-milk yogurt/n1/4 cup whole milk/nKosher salt, to taste/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n2 teaspoons dried split white urad dal/n1/2 teaspoon brown mustard seeds/n2 small dried whole red chiles (such as chiles de árbol)/n12 small fresh curry leaves (optional)
Steps: Step 1: If using cooked rice, skip step 1, and proceed to step 2.) Place uncooked rice in a small colander. Rinse under cold water, using your fingers to move rice around in colander, until water runs clear, about 1 minute. Drain well. Transfer rice to a small saucepan, and add 1 1/2 cups water; bring to a boil over high. Stir once; cover and reduce heat to low. Gently simmer until water is absorbed, about 15 minutes. Remove from heat; let stand, covered, 10 minutes. Spread rice evenly on a rimmed baking sheet; let cool to just slightly warmer than room temperature, about 20 minutes./nStep 2: Divide rice evenly between 2 shallow bowls. Add 1/4 cup yogurt and 2 tablespoons milk to each bowl; gently stir until combined. Stir in salt to taste, and set aside./nStep 3: Heat oil in small saucepan over medium until shimmering, about 3 minutes. Add urad dal and mustard seeds; cook, stirring constantly, 15 seconds (mixture will sizzle). Add chiles and, if using, curry leaves; cook, stirring constantly, until dal turns light brown and curry leaves become almost translucent, about 45 seconds. Immediately pour hot mixture (tadka) evenly over prepared yogurt rice./nStep 4: Rice can be cooked up to 1 day ahead and stored in an airtight container in refrigerator./nStep 5: Urad dal may be purchased online.

Ingredients: 5 tablespoons olive oil/n2 cloves garlic, minced/n1 1/3 cups couscous/n1 teaspoon ground cumin/n1/4 teaspoon cayenne/n3/4 teaspoon salt/n1 cup tomato juice/n1 cup water/n1 pound mild or hot Italian sausages or a combination/n1 tablespoon lemon juice/n1 tomato, diced/n1/2 cup chopped cilantro (optional)
Steps: Step 1: In a large frying pan with a lid, heat 1 tablespoon of the oil over moderately low heat. Add the garlic, couscous, cumin, cayenne, and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt to the pan. Cook, stirring occasionally, until the couscous starts to brown, about 3 minutes. Stir in the tomato juice and water. Bring to a simmer. Cover, remove from the heat, and let stand 5 minutes. Transfer the couscous to a platter or a large glass or stainless-steel bowl to cool./nStep 2: Meanwhile, light the grill or heat the broiler. Coat the sausages with 1/2 tablespoon of the oil. Grill or broil the sausages, turning occasionally, until completely cooked through, about 10 minutes. Remove from the heat. When the sausages are cool enough to handle, cut them into thin slices./nStep 3: Toss the cooled couscous with the lemon juice, the remaining 3 1/2 tablespoons oil and 1/4 teaspoon salt, and the tomato. Top with the sliced sausages and the cilantro./nStep 4: Australian Shiraz is an all-purpose red that marries particularly well with anything from the grill. It offers lots of ripe blackberry flavor, pepper nuances, and a soft, lush texture.

Ingredients: 1 pound mixed wild mushrooms, such as oyster, hen-of-the-woods, and chanterelle, torn into small pieces/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt/nPepper/n7 cups low-sodium chicken or vegetable broth/n1/4 cup unsalted butter, divided/n4 shallots, minced (about 3/4 cup)/n1 1/2 cups arborio rice/n1 cup dry vermouth/n1/2 cup freshly grated Parmesan cheese, plus more for serving
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 425°. On a rimmed baking sheet, toss the mushrooms with the olive oil, and season with salt and pepper. Spread the mushrooms in an even layer, and roast until golden and crisp, about 15 minutes, tossing halfway through./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a medium saucepan, bring the broth to a simmer. Keep warm./nStep 3: In a large, deep skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the butter. Add the shallots; cook over moderate heat, stirring, until softened, about 4 minutes. Add the rice, and cook, stirring, until lightly toasted, about 1 minute. Add the vermouth and cook, stirring until the vermouth is absorbed, about 2 minutes. Add 1 cup of the warm broth; cook over moderate heat, stirring constantly, until nearly absorbed. Continue adding the broth 1 cup at a time, stirring constantly, until it’s nearly absorbed between additions, for 15 minutes./nStep 4: Add half of the roasted mushrooms to the risotto. Cook the risotto, adding more broth as needed, until the rice is just tender and suspended in a thick, creamy sauce, about 5 minutes. Stir in the remaining 2 tablespoons of butter and the Parmesan. Season with salt and pepper. Serve immediately, topped with the remaining half of the roasted mushrooms and more Parmesan.

Ingredients: 1 cup salted dried baby shrimp (about 1 ounce), rinsed/n1/2 cup thinly sliced scallions/n1/2 cup soy sauce/n1/4 cup water/n1 large jalapeño, stemmed and finely chopped/n2 tablespoons finely chopped garlic/n4 teaspoons gochugaru/n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n3 tablespoons canola oil/n3 1/2 cups cooled cooked short-grain rice (day-old rice is best)/n1 cup chopped kimchi (about 6 ounces)/n1/4 cup low-sodium chicken broth/n2 tablespoons unsalted butter
Steps: Step 1: Stir together all sauce ingredients in a medium bowl. Set aside./nStep 2: Heat oil in a large skillet over high until shimmering. Add rice to hot oil, and spread in an even layer. Cook, without stirring, until rice is crispy and a light golden brown, about 4 minutes. Stir in kimchi, broth, and 3 tablespoons sauce. Cook, stirring often, until crispy, about 3 minutes. Add butter, and stir until melted. Remove from heat. Divide rice mixture between 2 bowls, and serve with remaining sauce.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon unsalted butter/n1/4 cup finely chopped onion/n1 cup jasmine rice/n1 1/2 cups water/nKosher salt
Steps: Step 1: Melt the butter in a medium saucepan. Add the onion and cook over moderately high heat until softened, about 5 minutes. Stir in the rice. Add the water and a pinch of salt and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over low heat for 18 minutes, until the rice is tender and the water is absorbed. Fluff the rice with a fork, cover and let stand for 5 minutes before serving./nStep 2: The rice can be refrigerated overnight. Rewarm before serving.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups short grain brown rice/n3 1/2 cups vegetable stock/n1/8 teaspoon saffron threads/nKosher salt/n1 bay leaf/n1 cinnamon stick
Steps: Step 1: In a medium sauce pan, combine rice with the water, saffron, 1 teaspoon kosher salt, bay leaf, and cinnamon stick. Bring to a boil, reduce the heat to low, and simmer, covered, for 45 minutes, or until the moisture has been absorbed./nStep 2: Remove from heat and leave, covered, for 10 more minutes. Discard cinnamon stick, fluff with a fork, and serve.

Ingredients: 2 1/2 cups water/n1 cup black rice (see Note)/n1 small onion, finely diced/n1 large garlic clove, minced/n2 tablespoons unsalted butter/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n2 1/2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n3/4 pound medium shrimp, shelled and deveined/n1 teaspoon chopped rosemary/n3/4 pound cleaned small squid, bodies sliced crosswise 1/4 inch thick/n1/3 cup dry white wine/n1/2 cup tomato sauce
Steps: Step 1: In a saucepan, bring the water to a boil with the rice. Cover and simmer over moderately low heat until tender, 45 minutes./nStep 2: In a medium skillet, cook the onion and garlic in the butter over moderate heat until softened. Stir in the rice, season with salt and pepper, cover and keep warm./nStep 3: In a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of the oil. Add the shrimp and 1/2 teaspoon of the rosemary; season with salt and pepper. Cook over moderate heat, turning once, until just white throughout; transfer to a plate./nStep 4: Add 1 tablespoon of the oil to the skillet; increase the heat to moderately high. Add half of the squid and 1/4 teaspoon of the rosemary; season with salt and pepper. Cook, turning once, until the squid is just firm, 1 minute; transfer to the plate. Repeat with the remaining squid, 1/2 tablespoon of oil and 1/4 teaspoon of rosemary./nStep 5: Add the wine to the skillet and cook for 1 minute, scraping up any browned bits from the bottom. Stir in the tomato sauce and the seafood; cook just until heated through. Season with salt and pepper. Mound the rice on plates, top with the seafood and sauce and serve right away./nStep 6: Black rice, not to be confused with black sticky rice, is available at supermarkets and online at amazon.com./nStep 7: Bold, berry-rich Spanish rosé.

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons canola oil/n1 shallot, sliced/n1 tablespoon minced peeled fresh ginger/n1 teaspoon cumin seeds/n4 cups cooked basmati rice/nOne 14.5-ounces can chickpeas, drained and rinsed/n4 cups curly spinach/nKosher salt/nPepper/nLemon wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large nonstick skillet, heat the oil. Add the shallot and ginger and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the shallot is golden, about 3 minutes. Add the cumin, rice, chickpeas and spinach and cook, stirring, until the spinach is wilted, about 3 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Serve with lemon wedges.

Ingredients: 2 pounds farro (4 1/2 cups)/n2 bay leaves/nSalt/n2 1/2 pounds turnips, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice/n3 pounds turnip greens, mustard greens or Swiss chard, stems discarded and leaves chopped/n3/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n2 tablespoons chopped thyme/nFreshly ground pepper/n1/4 cup red wine vinegar/n1 cup chopped flat-leaf parsley
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375°. Spread the farro in a roasting pan and toast for 15 minutes, shaking the pan occasionally, until fragrant./nStep 2: In a large pot, combine the farro with the bay leaves and 12 cups of water and bring to a boil. Simmer the farro over moderately low heat until al dente, about 25 minutes; season the water generously with salt about 10 minutes before the farro is done. Let cool slightly. Drain the farro, discard the bay leaves and transfer the farro to a large serving bowl./nStep 3: In the same roasting pan, toss the turnips with 1/2 cup of the olive oil and the thyme. Set the pan over 2 burners and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the turnips are browned and nearly tender, about 10 minutes. Add the chopped greens, season with salt and pepper and cook, tossing, until just wilted, about 5 minutes. Cover with foil and cook until tender, about 5 minutes longer. Stir in the vinegar and parsley./nStep 4: Scrape the turnips and turnip greens into the farro. Add the remaining 1/4 cup of olive oil and season with salt and pepper; toss well. Serve warm or at room temperature./nStep 5: The farro salad can be refrigerated overnight. Return to room temperature before serving.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups long-grain rice, rinsed and drained/nKosher salt/n7 tablespoons vegetable oil, divided/n12 raw medium shrimp, peeled, deveined, and chopped/n5 medium eggs, beaten/n1/2 teaspoon sugar/n1/4 teaspoon black pepper/n1 cup frozen peas, thawed/n3 tablespoons light soy sauce
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, bring 2 1/4 cups of water to a boil. Add the rice and a generous pinch of salt, and return to a boil. Stir once; cover and simmer over low heat until the rice is tender and the water is absorbed, about 20 minutes. Remove from heat, and let steam for 20 minutes. Fluff with a fork, and spread on a large baking sheet to cool completely, about 30 minutes./nStep 2: In a very large skillet or wok, heat 2 tablespoons of the oil until shimmering. Add the shrimp, and stir-fry over moderately high heat until nearly cooked through, about 3 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a plate./nStep 3: In the same skillet, heat the remaining 5 tablespoons of the oil until shimmering. Add the eggs, and stir-fry over moderately high heat until small curds form and the eggs are nearly cooked, about 2 minutes. Add the rice, sugar, pepper, and a generous pinch of salt, and stir-fry until the rice is hot, about 3 minutes. Add the shrimp, peas, and soy sauce, and stir-fry until the shrimp are cooked through and the peas are hot, 2 to 3 minutes. Season with salt and serve immediately.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup dried sour cherries/n1 cup whole milk or cream/n1 cup unsweetened, unflavored almond milk/n1 cup steel-cut oats/n1 teaspoon ground cinnamon/n1 teaspoon ground ginger/n1/4 teaspoon ground allspice/n1/4 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more for seasoning/n1 tablespoon pure maple syrup, plus more for drizzling/n1/4 cup sliced almonds, plus more for topping
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, cover the dried sour cherries with warm water and let stand until plumped and softened, about 15 minutes. Drain the cherries and discard the soaking water./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a medium saucepan, combine the whole milk, almond milk and 1 cup of water and bring to a boil. Stir in the oats, cinnamon, ginger, allspice and the 1/4 teaspoon of salt. Cover and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the oats are al dente and the porridge is creamy, 20 minutes./nStep 3: Stir in the cherries, maple syrup and almonds and season with salt. Serve topped with more maple syrup and almonds./nStep 4: The porridge can be refrigerated for up to 2 days. Reheat gently with more milk or cream to loosen as necessary.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1 1/2 cups (10 ounces) pearled barley/n1 small onion, finely diced/n2 thyme sprigs/n3 cups water/nKosher salt/n1/3 cup (2 ounces) pine nuts, preferably from Italy/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n3 tablespoons white wine vinegar/n1 small shallot, minced (2 tablespoons)/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper/n4 cups Thyme-Scented Pearled Barley/n1 large tart apple, such as Honeycrisp, cored and cut into 1/2-inch pieces/n1/2 cup pomegranate seeds (from 1 pomegranate)/n1/2 cup chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, heat the olive oil. Add the pearled barley and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until lightly toasted; the grains will turn slightly opaque just before browning. Add the onion and thyme and cook over low heat, stirring, until the onion is softened, about 5 minutes./nStep 2: Add the water and 1 teaspoon of kosher salt and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over very low heat until the water is absorbed and the grains are tender. Fluff the grains and discard the thyme sprigs. Season the grains with salt to taste and serve./nStep 3: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Spread the pine nuts in a pie plate and toast until golden, about 5 minutes. Let cool./nStep 4: In a bowl, whisk the oil with the vinegar and shallot and season with salt and pepper to taste. Add the thyme-scented pearled barley, pine nuts, apple, pomegranate seeds, and parsley; toss before serving./nStep 5: The cooked barley can be refrigerated for up to 5 days or frozen for up to 1 month. The salad without the pine nuts can be refrigerated overnight; bring the salad to room temperature and add the nuts before serving.

Ingredients: 2 cups lightly packed parsley leaves (8 ounces), 1 cup chopped/n1/3 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nSalt/n1 1/2 cups buckwheat groats (kasha)/n1/2 pound each of shiitake and oyster mushrooms, stemmed, large caps quartered/nFreshly ground pepper/n2 tablespoons balsamic vinegar/n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice, plus lemon wedges, for serving/n1 garlic clove, minced/n1 tablespoon dark soy sauce/n2 large scallions, thinly sliced/n1 medium fennel bulb, diced
Steps: Step 1: Bring a saucepan of water to a boil. Prepare a bowl of ice water. Blanch the 1 cup of parsley leaves in the boiling water for 20 seconds. With a slotted spoon, transfer the parsley to the ice water. Drain the parsley, squeeze out the excess water and pat thoroughly dry. In a blender, puree the blanched parsley with 1/3 cup of the olive oil. Transfer to a bowl and season with salt./nStep 2: Bring a medium saucepan of water to a boil. In a large skillet, toast the buckwheat groats over moderately high heat, shaking the pan often, until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Let cool slightly, then transfer to the boiling water and simmer over low heat, stirring often, until just tender but still holding its shape, about 5 minutes. Drain the buckwheat, spread it out on a large rimmed baking sheet and let cool to room temperature./nStep 3: Meanwhile, heat the remaining 2 tablespoons of olive oil in the large skillet. Add the shiitake and oyster mushrooms and season generously with salt and pepper. Cover and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the mushrooms have released their liquid, about 5 minutes. Uncover and cook, stirring occasionally, until the mushrooms are golden brown, about 5 minutes longer./nStep 4: In a small bowl, mix all but 1 tablespoon of the parsley oil with the balsamic vinegar, lemon juice, garlic and soy sauce./nStep 5: In a large bowl, toss the cooked buckwheat groats, sliced scallions, diced fennel and the 1 cup of chopped parsley with the dressing; season with salt and pepper and transfer to a platter. Top the salad with the sautéed mushrooms and drizzle with the remaining 1 tablespoon of parsley oil. Serve with the lemon wedges./nStep 6: One Serving 341 cal, 26 gm fat, 3.8 gm sat fat, 24 gm carb, 5 gm fiber.

Ingredients: 2 cups basmati rice/n1/2 teaspoon salt/n1 bunch flat-leaf parsley, chopped/n1 bunch cilantro, chopped (about 1 cup)/n1 bunch dill, chopped (about 1 cup)/n1 bunch fenugreek, chopped (about 1 cup)/n1 leek or 10 green onions, chopped (about 1/2 cup)/n2 tablespoons coconut oil/n1 potato, cut into 1/4-inch slices (optional)/n2 tablespoons butter or ghee, melted/n5 strands saffron, crushed/n2 tablespoons ghee or coconut oil/n1/4 cup tapioca starch/n1/2 teaspoon salt/n1/2 teaspoon black pepper/n1/4 teaspoon turmeric/n4 filets white fish, such as tilapia, halibut, or flounder
Steps: Step 1: Soak the rice in lukewarm water for at least 1 hour and up to 6 hours; the longer the rice soaks, the fluffier it will be. After soaking, drain, rinse and add to a stockpot. Fill the stockpot with water and 1/2 teaspoon salt, bring to a boil over high heat, then reduce heat to medium once it starts boiling. Simmer until the rice softens and starts to freely float to the top of the water, about 8 minutes. Drain the rice and set aside./nStep 2: In the stockpot (which should still be warm), add the 2 tablespoons coconut oil and line the bottom of the pot with potato slices. These will prevent the rice from drying and will also be delicious and crispy when the rice is done cooking. Alternatively, omit the potato, which will give the bottom rice a nice golden crunchy layer (called tahdig)./nStep 3: Scoop 1/3 of the rice into the pot, being careful not to shake the pot so that the rice doesn’t compact. Cover the rice with 1/3 of the chopped herbs. Spoon in another 1/3 of the rice, then another 1/3 of the herbs. Finally, add the remaining rice. Mix the melted butter (or ghee) with the crushed saffron, then pour over the rice in a circular pattern./nStep 4: Wrap the stockpot lid in a kitchen towel, then cover. Cook on medium-high heat for 5 minutes, then reduce heat to low and simmer for 40 minutes. Uncover and carefully stir together with a spatula, then stir in the final 1/3 of the fresh herbs./nStep 5: In a skillet, warm the ghee or coconut oil over medium-high heat for 1 minute. Combine the tapioca starch, salt, pepper and turmeric in a shallow pan. Dredge the fish fillets in the tapioca starch mixture one at a time, shaking off any excess starch. Add the fillets to the skillet (cook in batches if needed; don’t overcrowd the skillet). Cook for 3 minutes, carefully flip the fish, then continue to cook until the fish is done, about 3 more minutes, depending on the thickness of the fillets./nStep 6: The fish is done when it just starts to flake (it will finish cooking when removed from the heat). If cooking the fish in batches, add more ghee/oil with each batch. Serve over the herbed rice.

Ingredients: 6 small cubanelle peppers (1 pound)—stemmed, cored and seeded/n3 medium zucchini (1 1/2 pounds), halved crosswise and seedy flesh scooped out with a melon baller/nKosher salt/nPepper/n12 ounces ground beef chuck/n1 medium onion, finely chopped (1 cup)/n1 medium tomato, finely chopped (1 cup)/n1/2 cup long grain white rice/n1/4 cup finely chopped parsley/n2 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n2 teaspoons fresh thyme leaves/n2 tablespoons tomato paste/n3/4 cup Greek yogurt/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated garlic/nAleppo pepper, for sprinkling
Steps: Step 1: Season the peppers and zucchini inside and out with salt and pepper and arrange them snugly, hollow side up, in a medium saucepan./nStep 2: In a medium bowl, combine the beef, onion, tomato, rice, parsley, olive oil, thyme, 2 teaspoons of salt and 1 teaspoon of pepper and mix well. Spoon the filling into the peppers and zucchini./nStep 3: In a small bowl, whisk the tomato paste with 1 cup of water; pour the mixture around the vegetables in the saucepan and bring to a simmer. Cover and cook over moderately low heat until the vegetables are tender and the filling is cooked through, about 25 minutes./nStep 4: In another small bowl, stir the yogurt with the garlic. Transfer the stuffed vegetables to a platter and drizzle with some of the sauce from the pan. Spoon the yogurt on top, sprinkle with Aleppo pepper and serve./nStep 5: The cooked vegetables can be refrigerated overnight./nStep 6: Robustly fruity rosés are terrific with dishes that have varied flavors, like these stuffed vegetables. Try one from southern Italy.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 onion, finely chopped/n1 cup quinoa, rinsed and drained/n2 tablespoons dry white wine/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n2 tablespoons each finely chopped basil, parsley, scallion and dill/nBaking spray/n2 large eggs/n1/2 tablespoon whole milk/n1/2 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1 cup plus 2 tablespoons fine dried breadcrumbs/n1 cup finely grated Parmigiano-Reggiano, plus more for garnish/n1/4 cup fine semolina/n2 teaspoons onion powder/n1 teaspoon garlic powder/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt/n1/2 teaspoon pepper/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 onion, finely chopped/n5 garlic cloves, minced/n3/4 cup dry white wine/nOne 28-ounce can whole tomatoes in juice (preferably San Marzano), tomatoes chopped and juices reserved/nPinch each of dried oregano and crushed red pepper/n3 tablespoons chopped basil, plus more for garnish/nKosher salt/nPepper/n1 small bunch of Tuscan kale (8 ounces), stemmed and chopped
Steps: Step 1: Make the pilaf In a medium saucepan, heat the olive oil. Add the onion and cook over moderate heat until softened, about 8 minutes. Add the quinoa and cook, stirring, until toasted, about 2 minutes. Add 2 cups of water along with the wine and salt and bring to a boil. Cover and simmer over low heat until the quinoa is tender and the water is absorbed, about 20 minutes. Spread the quinoa onto a large rimmed baking sheet to cool, then transfer to a medium bowl and stir in the herbs. Set aside 1 cup of the quinoa pilaf./nStep 2: Make the quinoa meatballs Preheat the oven to 375°. Line a large rimmed baking sheet with foil and coat with baking spray. In a medium bowl, beat the eggs with the milk, olive oil and 2/3 cup of water. Add the reserved 1 cup of quinoa pilaf along with the breadcrumbs, the 1 cup of Parmigiano, the semolina, onion powder, garlic powder, salt and pepper and mix well. Form the mixture into twenty-six 1 1/2-inch meatballs, using about 1 tablespoon of the mixture for each. Transfer to the baking sheet. Bake the meatballs for 10 to 12 minutes, until browned on the bottoms, then turn and bake for 10 to 12 minutes longer, until browned all over./nStep 3: Make the tomato sauce Meanwhile, in a medium enameled cast-iron casserole, heat the olive oil over moderate heat. Add the onion and garlic and cook until softened, about 6 minutes. Add the wine and tomato juices and cook until the liquid is reduced by one-third, about 8 minutes. Add the chopped tomatoes, oregano and crushed red pepper and simmer over moderately low heat for 20 minutes. Stir in the 3 tablespoons of chopped basil and season with salt and black pepper. Add the kale, cover and cook over moderately low heat until it begins to wilt, about 5 minutes. Add the meatballs to the casserole and simmer until the kale is tender and the meatballs are heated through, 10 to 15 minutes./nStep 4: Spoon the quinoa pilaf into shallow bowls and top with the meatballs and sauce. Garnish with chopped basil and grated Parmigiano and serve.

Ingredients: 6 cups shrimp or seafood stock/n1 bunch fresh flat-leaf parsley, stems and leaves separated/n6 tablespoons olive oil, divided/n1/2 cup finely chopped yellow onion/n1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon finely chopped garlic (about 4 garlic cloves), divided/n2 cups uncooked Arborio rice (about 15 ounces)/n1 cup dry white wine (preferably Croatian Pošip, or substitute off-dry Riesling)/n8 unpeeled medium langoustines (about 2 pounds)/n8 littleneck clams, scrubbed/n1/2 pound cleaned baby squid (tubes and tentacles), rinsed, tubes sliced into thin rings (about 2/3 cup)/n1 tablespoon jarred cuttlefish ink (such as Alma Gourmet)/n1 teaspoon lemon zest plus 1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice, divided/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more to taste/n2 tablespoons cold unsalted butter, cut into pieces/n4 lemon wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Bring stock and 5 parsley stems to a simmer in a medium saucepan over medium; reduce heat to low, and keep warm. Chop parsley leaves to equal 5 tablespoons; reserve remaining leaves for another use. Place chopped parsley leaves in a small bowl, and set aside./nStep 2: Heat 3 tablespoons oil in a large saucepan over medium. Add onion and 1 tablespoon garlic; cook, stirring often, until onion is softened, about 3 minutes. Stir in rice, and cook, stirring often, until grains are almost translucent and have a nutty aroma, about 3 minutes. Increase heat to medium-high. Add wine, and cook, stirring constantly, until wine is absorbed, 2 to 3 minutes./nStep 3: Remove and discard parsley stems from warm stock. Add 1/4 cup stock to rice mixture, and cook, stirring often, until almost absorbed. Continue adding 2 to 3 cups stock, 1/4 cup at a time, stirring often, until stock is almost absorbed after each addition and rice is just beginning to soften, about 15 minutes total. Remove from heat, and set aside./nStep 4: Heat remaining 3 tablespoons oil in a large skillet over medium-high. Add langoustines and clams; cook, turning occasionally, until langoustines are pink and just cooked, 5 to 7 minutes. Remove and set aside. Continue cooking clams until they open, about 10 minutes, stirring in squid and remaining 1 teaspoon garlic during last minute of cooking time. Remove from heat; discard any unopened clams. Return langoustines to skillet./nStep 5: Return rice mixture to heat over medium. Stir in cuttlefish ink, lemon zest, and salt. Continue adding stock, 1/4 cup at a time, stirring often, until stock is almost absorbed after each addition, rice is al dente, and mixture is creamy, 5 to 7 minutes longer. (You may not need all remaining stock.) Remove from heat. Stir in butter, lemon juice, and 3 tablespoons reserved chopped parsley. Season to taste with salt. Divide risotto among 4 bowls, and top evenly with langoustines, clams, squid, and remaining 2 tablespoons chopped parsley. Serve immediately with lemon wedges./nStep 6: Complex Friulian (or Croatian) white.

Ingredients: 2  (15-ounce) cans chickpeas, drained, rinsed, and patted dry/n¼ cup olive oil, divided/n1 teaspoon kosher salt, divided/n4 cups broccoli florets and chopped peeled stems (about 2 medium-size heads)/n1 ½ cups baby kale (from a (5-ounce) package)/n1 ½ cups cooked quinoa/n2  soft-cooked eggs, half lengthwise/n2  nori (dried toasted seaweed) sheets, crumbled/nThinly sliced scallion/n¼ cup tahini (sesame paste)/n2 tablespoons riced vinegar/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n1 teaspoon fresh lime juice (from 1 lime)/n½ teaspoon honey/n1  (2-inch) piece fresh ginger, peeled and minced (about 1/2 teaspoon)/nWater, to taste
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 400ºF. Toss together chickpeas, 2 tablespoons of the oil, 1/2 teaspoon of the salt, and 1/4 teaspoon of the pepper on a rimmed baking sheet lined with aluminum foil; spread in an even layer. Bake until chickpeas start to brown, about 10 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, toss together broccoli and remaining 2 tablespoons oil, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper in a large bowl./nStep 3: Remove chickpeas from oven. Add broccoli to chickpeas on baking sheet in an even layer. Bake at 400ºF until chickpeas are browned and broccoli is charred in spots, about 20 minutes. Remove from oven./nStep 4: Prepare the Dressing: Whisk together tahini, vinegar, soy sauce, lime juice, honey, and ginger in a bowl. Whisk in water (about a tablespoon) until desired consistency./nStep 5: Divide kale, quinoa, and 2 cups chickpea-broccoli mixture among two serving bowls. Top with egg halves and nori; drizzle with desired amount of dressing and garnish with scallions./nStep 6: Leftover chickpea-broccoli mixture and dressing may be stored in separate airtight containers in refrigerator up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons canola oil/n1 onion, chopped/n2 garlic cloves, finely chopped/n1 bird chile, stemmed and thinly sliced/n1 medium carrot, halved lengthwise and thinly sliced crosswise/n1 cup stemmed and coarsely chopped mustard greens/n3 cups cooked black rice (see Note)/n1 cup bean sprouts/n1 cup thawed frozen edamame/n4 ounces cored pineapple, cut into 1/4-inch pieces (about 1 cup)/n3 tablespoons soy sauce/n2 scallions, thinly sliced/n1 teaspoon sweet chili sauce
Steps: Step 1: In a large cast-iron skillet, heat the oil over moderately high heat. Add the onion and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 6 minutes. Add the garlic and chile, and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute./nStep 2: Increase heat to high. Add the carrot and mustard greens, and stir-fry until crisp-tender, 2 to 3 minutes. Stir in the rice until hot, about 2 minutes. Add the bean sprouts, edamame, pineapple, and soy sauce, and stir-fry until the bean sprouts are crisp-tender and the pineapple and edamame are heated through, about 2 minutes. Fold in the scallions and chili sauce./nStep 3: To cook black rice (also called “forbidden rice”), in a medium saucepan, bring 1 2/3 cups water and 1 cup black rice to a boil over moderate heat. Simmer, covered, over moderately low heat until tender, about 20 minutes. Remove from heat, and let stand 5 minutes. Scrape the rice onto a large rimmed baking sheet to cool completely.

Ingredients: 1 pound butternut squash—peeled, seeded and cut into 1-inch pieces/n1 sage sprig/n3 tablespoons unsalted butter/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground pepper/n6 cups chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for drizzling/n1/2 medium onion, minced/n1 1/2 cups Venere black rice (see Note)/n1/4 cup dry white wine/n2 tablespoons freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, plus more for serving/n1/2 pound burrata or fresh buffalo mozzarella, cut into 6 pieces/nFlaky sea salt, such as Maldon, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a 9-by-13-inch baking dish, combine the squash with the sage sprig, 2 tablespoons of the butter and 1/4 cup of water; season with kosher salt and pepper. Roast for about 25 minutes, until the squash is tender and most of the liquid has evaporated. Discard the sage./nStep 2: Transfer the squash to a food processor and let cool slightly. Puree until smooth and season with kosher salt and pepper. Scrape the squash puree into a medium saucepan and keep warm over very low heat./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in another medium saucepan, bring the stock to a simmer. Keep warm over very low heat./nStep 4: In a large saucepan, heat the 1/4 cup of olive oil. Add the onion and a generous pinch of kosher salt and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until softened, about 3 minutes. Add the rice and cook, stirring, until well coated with oil, about 1 minute. Add the wine and cook, stirring, until absorbed. Add 1 cup of the warm stock and cook over moderate heat, stirring constantly, until nearly absorbed. Continue adding the stock 1/2 cup at a time, stirring constantly and allowing the stock to be nearly absorbed between additions. The risotto is done when the rice is al dente and suspended in a creamy sauce, 35 to 40 minutes total. Stir in the 2 tablespoons of Parmigiano and the remaining 1 tablespoon of butter and season with kosher salt and pepper./nStep 5: Spoon the squash puree into shallow bowls, then spoon the risotto on top and garnish with the burrata. Top with a sprinkle of flaky sea salt and a drizzle of olive oil and serve. Pass additional cheese at the table./nStep 6: Venere black rice (riso Venere) is a short-grain rice that is less milled and more nutritious than other types of rice. It is available at specialty stores and amazon.com./nStep 7: Fruit-forward South African Chenin Blanc.

Ingredients: 1 cup uncooked jasmine rice (6 1/2 ounces) (such as Three Ladies Thai Hom Mali Rice)/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 1/3 cups cold water/n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n2 (2-ounce) pieces boneless, skinless salmon belly (about 1/2-inch thick)/n3 ounces baby bok choy, yu choy, or broccoli florets (about 1 1/2 cups)/n1/4 cup fresh or frozen yellow corn kernels/n2 scallions/nGinger-Scallion Sauce/nMirin-Soy Sauce
Steps: Step 1: Rinse rice in a strainer until water runs clear. Shake rice dry in strainer. Stir together rice, salt, and 1 1/3 cups cold water in a 1-quart Chinese clay pot. Let stand at room temperature 1 hour./nStep 2: Heat rice mixture, uncovered and undisturbed, on a gas stovetop over medium-high until water along edges of clay pot begins to simmer in spots, 8 to 10 minutes. Continue simmering, uncovered and undisturbed, over medium-high until water is completely absorbed and rice makes a faint crackling sound, 5 to 6 minutes. Drizzle sesame oil evenly around inside edges of pot. Reduce heat to low; cover and cook until rice is just tender, about 10 minutes./nStep 3: Working quickly, turn off heat, uncover, and arrange salmon belly, baby bok choy, and corn in an even layer on top of rice. Increase heat to medium-high. Cook, covered, until rice smells nutty and makes a constant crackling sound, 4 to 5 minutes. Turn off heat, and let stand, covered, on unlit burner 15 minutes. Slice green parts of scallions to equal 3 tablespoons, and sprinkle over salmon, baby bok choy, and corn. (Reserve remaining scallion for another use.) Serve with ginger-scallion sauce and mirin-soy sauce./nStep 4: Apple-scented, complex Chenin Blanc.

Ingredients: 1 garlic head/nOlive oil/nSea salt, to taste/nPepper, to taste/n1 eggplant, sliced/n1 red, yellow or orange bell pepper, seeded and cut into chunks/nChile powder, to taste/n1 1/4 cup raw (untoasted) buckwheat groats, soaked for 1 hour or overnight/n1/3 cup water/n1 tablespoon olive oil, plus more for the cake pans/nSea salt, to taste/nFreshly ground black pepper, to taste/nGarlic, onion powder or fresh garlic (optional)/nThyme, fresh or dried (optional)/nOregano, fresh or dried (optional)/nFeta cheese (optional)/nLeafy greens, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 400°. Cut the very top of the garlic head off to expose the insides. Drizzle with olive oil, salt and pepper and wrap in foil or parchment paper./nStep 2: Mix olive oil and chile powder to taste. Place eggplant slices and pepper chunks into a large baking dish and brush with the chile oil./nStep 3: Place both the garlic and vegetables into the oven, roast for about 20 minutes or until soft. Set aside./nStep 4: Preheat oven to 450°. Rinse the buckwheat groats very well; they become very slimy during soaking. Combine groats, water, olive oil, salt, pepper, garlic and other spices/herbs, if using, in a blender. Blend until smooth./nStep 5: Place two 8-9-inch cake pans into the hot oven for 5 minutes. Remove them from the oven and add 1 to 2 tablespoons of olive oil to each (use cooking spray if your cake pans stick). Place back into the oven for 3 to 5 minutes./nStep 6: Working quickly, pour the batter into the pans, spreading evenly. Bake for 15 minutes, then flip the crusts and bake for 10 more minutes. Remove from the oven and reduce temperature to 400°./nStep 7: Place crusts onto a parchment paper-covered baking sheet. Smear most of the roasted garlic over the crust./nStep 8: Slice the bell pepper chunks into smaller pieces if you wish. Arrange the eggplant and pepper slices on the crusts snuggly, to cover most of the surface./nStep 9: Place pizzas back in the oven and bake for 10 to 15 more minutes. Sprinkle with feta cheese (if using) and finely chopped kale or other greens. Let cool slightly before slicing.

Ingredients: 3/4 cup farro/n1 tablespoon tahini/n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1 tablespoon vegetable oil/n2 packed cups baby turnip greens or spinach, chopped/n1/2 cup parsley leaves/n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/nSalt/nPomegranate molasses, for drizzling (optional)
Steps: Step 1: In a saucepan, cover the farro with water and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over moderate heat until just tender, 12 minutes. Drain and transfer to a medium bowl. Refrigerate for about 30 minutes, until chilled./nStep 2: In a small bowl, whisk 2 tablespoons of water with the tahini and olive oil./nStep 3: In a skillet, heat the vegetable oil. Add the farro in an even layer and cook over high heat, stirring once, until toasted, about 5 minutes. Add 1/4 cup of water and the greens and cook over moderate heat, stirring a few times, until the greens are just tender, about 2 minutes. Stir in the parsley and the tahini mixture and remove from the heat. Stir in the lemon juice and season with salt. Transfer the farro to a bowl, drizzle with pomegranate molasses and serve./nStep 4: One Serving 159 cal, 17 gm carb, 9 gm fat, 1.4 gm sat fat, 4 gm protein, 3 gm fiber./nStep 5: Lively, refreshing Grüner Veltliner from Austria.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups short-grain sushi rice/n1 cup unsweetened coconut milk/n1/4 cup sugar/n1 tablespoon Massaman or red curry paste/nThree 2-by-1/2-inch strips of lime zest/nOne 2-by-1-inch piece of peeled fresh ginger, chopped/n1/2 fresh Thai bird chile/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt/n2 tablespoons chopped cilantro leaves and stems/n2 teaspoons grapeseed or canola oil
Steps: Step 1: Put the rice in a large bowl and add enough warm water to cover by 2 inches. Let soak at room temperature for 2 hours, swirling occasionally. Drain well./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a medium saucepan, combine the coconut milk with the sugar, curry paste, lime zest, ginger, chile and salt and bring to a simmer over moderate heat, whisking to dissolve the curry paste and sugar. Strain through a fine sieve into a small bowl; discard the solids. Clean the saucepan./nStep 3: In the saucepan, combine the drained rice with 2 1/4 cups of water and bring to a boil. Cover and simmer over low heat until the rice is tender and the water is absorbed, about 15 minutes. Transfer the rice to a large bowl and slowly drizzle the infused coconut milk on top. Fold the rice until the liquid is absorbed, then let stand for 15 minutes. Stir in the cilantro./nStep 4: In a large nonstick skillet, heat the oil. Scrape the rice into the skillet, press it into an even layer and cook over moderate heat until the edge and bottom are golden and crisp, 12 to 15 minutes. Invert the rice onto a platter and serve.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups uncooked basmati rice/n1 tablespoon sesame seeds/n3 tablespoons coconut or canola oil/n10 fresh curry leaves (optional)/n2 red onions, halved and thinly sliced/n1 1/2 teaspoons cumin seeds/n2 teaspoons tamarind paste (or to taste)/n1 1/4 teaspoons kosher salt/n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper/nPinch of cayenne pepper
Steps: Step 1: Place rice in a deep saucepan and rinse rice with cold water until water runs clear. Let rice soak in cold water 20 minutes. Drain rice, and add cold water to cover by 2 inches. Bring to a boil over medium-high. Reduce heat and simmer until rice is tender, about 10 minutes. Pour rice through a fine wire-mesh strainer, and discard cooking liquid. Return rice to saucepan, and cover with a clean kitchen towel. Let rice steam until fluffy, about 5 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, heat a large skillet over medium. Add sesame seeds and toast, stirring, until golden brown, about 30 seconds. Tip seeds into a small bowl; set aside. Add oil to pan and, when hot, add curry leaves, if using. When the curry leaves crackle, add the red onions and cumin, and cook, stirring often, until the onions are soft, golden, and sweet, about 15 minutes. Stir in the tamarind paste, salt, black pepper, and cayenne. Remove pan from heat./nStep 3: Using a fork, add rice to onion mixture. Return pan to heat over medium, and fold rice into onion mixture until fully incorporated and hot, about 5 minutes. Stir in the sesame seeds. Remove from heat, and serve immediately.

Ingredients: 2 cups pearled barley (5 cups cooked)/n1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n2 pounds mixed mushrooms, stemmed and cut into bite-size pieces/n2 teaspoons chopped sage/n1/4 cup fresh lemon juice/nKosher salt/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan of boiling water, cook the barley until tender, about 30 minutes. Drain and transfer to a large bowl./nStep 2: In a large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Add one-third of the mushrooms and cook over high heat, stirring, until golden brown, about 5 minutes. Transfer to the large bowl. Repeat in 2 more batches with 4 tablespoons of the oil and the remaining mushrooms. Add the sage, lemon juice and the remaining 1/4 cup of oil to the bowl; season with salt and pepper and toss to coat./nStep 3: The salad can be made 3 hours ahead and kept at room temperature.

Ingredients: 2 cups water/n1 cup bulgur/n1/4 teaspoon kosher or sea salt/n2 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 medium onion diced/n2 cloves garlic, minced/n1 pound boneless, skinless chicken breasts, cut into 1/2-inch cubes/n1/2 medium red bell pepper, seeded and diced/n1 tablespoon Worcestershire sauce/n1/2 teaspoon paprika/nAdditional kosher or sea salt, to taste/nFresh cracked black pepper, to taste/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/n3 green onions, sliced
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan bring the water to a boil. Stir in the bulgur and salt, remove from the heat and allow to sit for 25 minutes, or until the bulgur is tender. Drain excess water. Set aside to cool./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add the oil, and then stir in the onion and garlic. Cook for 2 minutes, or until soft./nStep 3: Add the chicken, stirring occasionally, and cook for 5 minutes, or until lightly browned./nStep 4: Stir in the bell peppers, Worcestershire sauce, and paprika. Cook for an additional 2 minutes, or until the peppers are tender and the chicken is cooked through. Season with salt and pepper, to taste. Remove from heat and set aside to cool./nStep 5: In a large bowl, combine the bulgur and chicken mixture. Stir in the lemon juice and green onions. Serve at room temperature or chilled.

Ingredients: 2 cups uncooked basmati rice/n3 tablespoons ghee, divided/n2 green cardamom pods/n4 whole cloves/n2 bay leaves/n1 1/2 teaspoons cumin seeds/n1 1/2 cups fresh or frozen peas/n4 cups water/n2 teaspoons kosher salt/n1/4 cup fresh cilantro leaves, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Pick through the rice for any stones or dirt. Place rice in a fine wire-mesh strainer, and rinse under cool tap water until water is no longer cloudy. Transfer rice to a medium bowl; add water to cover, and soak 30 minutes./nStep 2: Heat 2 tablespoons ghee in a medium saucepan over medium-high. Crack cardamom pods with the flat edge of a knife, and add them to the ghee with the cloves, bay leaves, and cumin seeds. Cook, stirring often, until spices are fragrant, 30 to 45 seconds. Add peas, and cook, stirring often, 1 minute. Drain rice completely, and add it to saucepan. Cook, stirring often, until rice grains are completely coated with ghee, 1 minute to 1 minute and 30 seconds./nStep 3: Add 4 cups water and salt, and bring to a rolling boil over high. Reduce heat to low; cover pan with a lid, and cook until most of the water has evaporated, 10 to 12 minutes. Remove from heat, and let stand 5 minutes. Remove and discard cardamom pods, cloves, and bay leaves. Add remaining 1 tablespoon ghee, and fluff rice mixture with a fork. Garnish with cilantro.

Ingredients: 1 cup extra-thick rolled oats/n3 cups whole milk/n2 tablespoons turbinado sugar/nPinch of kosher salt/n3 large eggs, separated/n2 cups mixed raspberries and blueberries/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest/nConfectioners’ sugar, for dusting/nPure maple syrup, for serving (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. Butter a 2-quart baking dish./nStep 2: In a large saucepan, combine the oats, milk, turbinado sugar and salt and bring to a simmer. Cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until thickened to a porridge consistency, about 15 minutes. Remove from the heat; let cool slightly./nStep 3: Working quickly, stir the egg yolks into the oatmeal until well blended. Fold in 1 cup of the berries and the lemon zest./nStep 4: In a large bowl, using a hand mixer, beat the egg whites at medium speed until medium-stiff peaks form, about 3 minutes. Gently fold the whites into the oatmeal just until combined. Scrape the mixture into the prepared dish and bake for about 30 minutes, until golden and puffed. Dust with confectioners’ sugar and serve hot with the remaining 1 cup of berries and maple syrup, if desired./nStep 5: The oatmeal can be prepared through Step 2 and refrigerated for 3 days. Rewarm with some milk to loosen the oatmeal to a porridge consistency before proceeding.

Ingredients: 5 liters tap water/n1 cup warm water/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n2 1/2 cups coarse semolina (about 14 ounces) (provided with couscoussier)/n2 tablespoons canola oil, divided, plus more for greasing pan
Steps: Step 1: Place 5 liters tap water in the base of a couscoussier (couscous steamer pot), and bring to a boil over high./nStep 2: While water comes to a boil, stir together 1 cup warm water and salt in a bowl until salt dissolves. Pour into the glass spray bottle provided with couscoussier. Place semolina in the flat-bottomed bowl provided with couscoussier, and spray with about 12 spritzes salt water. Using a circular motion, rub semolina with your fingers until small (1/16- to 1/8-inch) clumps form, spritzing with up to 1/2 cup salt water, as needed./nStep 3: Place rolled semolina into the sieve provided with the couscoussier. Using a clawing motion with your fingers, move rolled semolina aound until it passes through sieve into a large bowl. Sprinkle semolina with 4 teaspoons oil, and toss gently to coat. Lightly grease (with oil) bottom and sides of the perforated couscoussier steamer insert. Place rolled semolina in an even layer in steamer insert. Place insert over boiling water, reduce heat to medium, and wait until the first wisp of steam passes through the semolina. Cover and cook 20 minutes./nStep 4: Wipe flat-bottomed bowl clean, and add partially cooked couscous. Using a wooden spoon, gently stir, breaking up any large clumps. Spray with about 12 spritzes salt water, and toss gently to incorporate. Sprinkle with 1 teaspoon oil, and toss gently to coat. Return couscous to steamer insert over medium heat, and wait until the first wisp of steam passes through semolina. Cover and cook 20 minutes./nStep 5: Repeat step 4 with another 12 spritzes salt water and remaining 1 teaspoon oil, cooking until desired texture is reached, about 20 minutes. Pass couscous through sieve a second time, and transfer to a serving bowl.

Ingredients: 2 medium tomatoes, chopped/n1 medium onion, coarsely chopped/n2 garlic cloves/nKosher salt/nPepper/n1/3 cup grapeseed oil/n2 cups long-grain white rice/n1 cup chicken stock or low-sodium broth
Steps: Step 1: In a blender or food processor, puree the tomatoes with the onion, garlic and 1 teaspoon of salt until smooth./nStep 2: In a large saucepan, heat the oil. Add the rice and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until lightly toasted, about 5 minutes. Pour in the tomato mixture and stock and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over low heat until the liquid has evaporated and the rice is tender, about 20 minutes. Remove the pan from the heat and let stand, covered, for 15 minutes. Fluff with a fork, season with salt and pepper and serve./nStep 3: The cooked rice can stand, covered, for up to 30 minutes.

Ingredients: 8 stalks asparagus, trimmed/n3 cups cooked day-old white rice/n3 large eggs, yolks and whites separated/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1/2 small yellow onion, diced/n2 scallions, chopped/n1 (one-inch) knob ginger, peeled and minced/n4 garlic cloves, minced/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 1/2 teaspoons sugar/n1 tablespoon XO sauce
Steps: Step 1: Cut off the tips of the asparagus and slice the remainder of the stalks into rounds. In a medium pot of boiling salted water, blanch the tips and sliced stalks separately until bright green and crisp-tender, about 30 seconds each. Drain and rinse under cold running water; pat dry and set aside./nStep 2: In a medium bowl, toss rice with egg yolks, breaking up the rice with your hands to separate and coat each and every grain./nStep 3: Heat oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium-high heat. Add ginger and onion and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 1 minute./nStep 4: Add the rice, gently mixing and pressing into the pan until the egg yolks are cooked though and the rice grains are fully separated, 3 to 5 minutes. Add asparagus stalks, garlic, and scallions. Stir in salt and sugar./nStep 5: Briefly beat the egg whites, push the cooked rice mixture to the side of the skillet, and add the egg whites to the pan. Stir-fry until whites are cooked and scrambled, about 1 minute. Mix the cooked egg whites into the rice in the pan. Add XO sauce and stir-fry until incorporated and fragrant, about 1 minute more. Serve golden fried rice topped with asparagus tips and more XO sauce, if desired.

Ingredients: 1 cup pearled barley (about 8 ounces)/n2 tablespoons pine nuts/n1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 cup currants/n1 tablespoon minced shallot/n6 ounces kale, stems discarded and leaves torn into small pieces (4 cups)/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/nKosher salt/n2 tablespoons chopped preserved lemon (optional)
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, cook the barley in salted boiling water until al dente, 30 minutes. Drain well and transfer to a large bowl. Let cool slightly./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a small skillet, toast the pine nuts over low heat, stirring, until lightly golden, 3 to 5 minutes./nStep 3: In a small skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the olive oil. Add the currants and shallot and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until the shallot is golden, about 3 minutes. Scrape into the barley and add the pine nuts./nStep 4: In a food processor, pulse two-thirds of the kale with the lemon juice until chopped. With the machine on, slowly drizzle in the remaining 1/2 cup of olive oil until smooth. Season with salt. Scrape the pesto into the barley. Add the preserved lemon, if using, and the remaining kale leaves, season with salt and toss well. Serve.

Ingredients: 2 cups wild rice (12 ounces), rinsed and drained/nKosher salt/nPepper/n12 baby golden beets/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for rubbing/n1 1/2 cups pecans/n1/4 cup plus 1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar/n1 small shallot, minced/n2 cups seedless green grapes (10 ounces), halved/n5 ounces arugula (not baby), thick stems discarded, leaves chopped
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. In a large saucepan, cover the rice with at least 3 inches of water and bring to a boil. Add a generous pinch of salt and simmer over moderate heat until the rice is tender, about 45 minutes. Drain well, then spread on a large â€¨baking sheet to cool; stir occasionally./nStep 2: Meanwhile, rub the beets with olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Roast for about 30 minutes, until just tender. Let cool, then rub off the skins and cut into 1/2-inch wedges./nStep 3: Spread the pecans in a pie plate. Bake for about 10 minutes, until fragrant and browned. Let cool, then coarsely chop./nStep 4: In a large serving bowl, whisk the vinegar with the shallot and let stand for 5 minutes. Whisk in the 1/4 cup of olive oil. Add the rice, beets and grapes and toss well. Season with salt and pepper; toss again. Fold in the arugula and pecans and serve./nStep 5: The rice salad can be refrigerated overnight. Bring to room temperature and fold in the arugula and toasted pecans before serving.

Ingredients: 1/2 pound ground pork/n2 tablespoons Asian fish sauce, plus more for serving/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/nFreshly ground white pepper/n8 cups chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n1 cup jasmine rice/n1 lemongrass stalk, cut into three 3-inch pieces and crushed/n5 dried Thai bird chiles, stemmed, or 1 tablespoon crushed dried Thai chile/n1/4 cup vegetable oil/n5 garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n1 serrano chile, seeded and minced/n1/4 cup distilled white vinegar/n1/2 teaspoon sugar/nLime wedges, sliced scallions, and chopped cilantro, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a bowl, combine the pork with the 2 tablespoons of fish sauce, the soy sauce and a pinch of white pepper. Let sit for 10 to 30 minutes./nStep 2: In an enameled cast-iron casserole, combine the chicken stock, rice and lemongrass and bring to a boil over moderately high heat. Reduce the heat to low, cover partially and simmer until the rice is soft, about 25 minutes. Discard the lemongrass./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a small skillet, toast the dried chiles over moderate heat until lightly browned and fragrant, about 3 minutes. Transfer to a spice grinder and grind to a coarse powder; some seeds will remain. Transfer to a bowl and wipe out the skillet./nStep 4: Heat the oil in the skillet. Add the garlic and cook over low heat until caramelized, about 10 minutes. Scrape the garlic oil into a small bowl. In another small bowl, combine the serrano, vinegar and sugar and stir until the sugar is dissolved./nStep 5: Using a small ice cream scoop, make generous 1-inch meatballs with the ground pork. Drop into the rice and broth in the casserole. Cover and simmer over moderately high heat, stirring occasionally, until the meatballs are cooked through, about 10 minutes./nStep 6: Ladle the congee into bowls. Serve with little bowls of the toasted chiles, fried garlic oil, chile vinegar, lime wedges, scallions, cilantro, white pepper and fish sauce./nStep 7: The uncooked meatballs can be refrigerated overnight./nStep 8: Vibrant South African Chenin Blanc.

Ingredients: 6 pounds chicken carcasses, backs, legs, or wings/n3 large celery ribs, cut into 2-inch lengths/n2 large carrots, cut into 2-inch lengths/n2 unpeeled medium onions, quartered/n3 quarts water/n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1 small onion, finely chopped/n1 tomatillo, husked, rinsed, and finely chopped/n1 garlic clove, minced/nKosher salt/n1 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin/nOne 15-ounce can diced tomatoes/n1/4 cup (2 ounces) canned diced green Hatch chiles/nJasmine Rice or 3 cups warm cooked white rice/nChopped cilantro, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Combine all of the ingredients in a stockpot and bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce the heat and simmer for 20 minutes, skimming frequently. Cover partially, leaving only a small opening, and simmer over low heat for 2 1/2 hours./nStep 2: Strain the stock into a large bowl, pressing on the solids. Wipe out the stockpot, return the stock to it and boil until reduced to 2 quarts. Let cool slightly and refrigerate. Remove the solidified fat from the stock before using./nStep 3: In a large, deep skillet, heat the olive oil until shimmering. Add the onion, tomatillo, garlic, and a generous pinch of salt. Cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until softened and just starting to brown, about 7 minutes. Stir in the cumin and cook until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add the tomatoes, chiles, and 1/4 cup of the stock and bring to a boil (Reserve the remaining stock for another use). Simmer over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the liquid is reduced by half, about 20 minutes. Transfer the sofrito to a blender or food processor and let cool slightly, then puree until smooth./nStep 4: Wipe out the skillet and cook the sofrito in it over moderate heat, stirring, until hot, about 5 minutes. Gradually fold in the rice and cook just until it is hot and coated in the sofrito, about 5 minutes. Season with salt, garnish with cilantro, and serve./nStep 5: The stock can be refrigerated for 3 days or frozen up to 2 months./nStep 6: The sofrito can be refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 10 days./nStep 7: You can use low-sodium broth in place of the Basic Chicken Stock.

Ingredients: 3/4 cup farro/n2 1/2 pounds large sunchokes, peeled and cut into 2-inch pieces/nSalt/n1 pound Tuscan kale, tough stems discarded/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil blended with 3 tablespoons of vegetable oil/n1 small red onion, sliced 1/4 inch thick/n1 tablespoon unsalted butter/n1/2 pound oyster mushrooms, halved if large/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, cover the farro with 2 inches of water. Bring to a boil, cover and cook over low heat until the farro is tender, about 25 minutes. Drain the farro./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large saucepan, cover the sunchokes with water and add a pinch of salt. Boil until the sunchokes are tender, 10 minutes; drain. Slice the sunchokes 1/4 inch thick./nStep 3: Fill the large saucepan with water and bring to a boil. Add the Tuscan kale and cook until just tender, about 3 minutes. Drain the kale and let cool slightly. Squeeze out any excess liquid from the kale leaves and then coarsely chop them./nStep 4: In a small skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the blended oil. Add the red onion and a pinch of salt and cook over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until browned, about 12 minutes./nStep 5: In a nonstick skillet, melt the butter in 2 tablespoons of the blended oil. Add the sunchokes in an even layer and cook over high heat until browned on the bottom, about 3 minutes. Turn the sunchokes, reduce the heat to moderately high and continue cooking until starting to brown, about 2 minutes. Push the sunchokes to the side of the skillet./nStep 6: Add 1 more tablespoon of the oil and the oyster mushrooms. Season with salt and pepper and cook over moderately high heat until browned, 3 minutes. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil along with the farro, kale and onion and cook, stirring, until hot. Season with salt and pepper and serve./nStep 7: The recipe can be prepared through Step 4 one day ahead; refrigerate the components separately./nStep 8: Melon-scented, full-bodied Chenin Blanc.

Ingredients: 5 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, divided/n12 ounces squash (such as yellow squash or zucchini), quartered lengthwise and cut into 1/2-inch slices/n1 cup stemmed fresh hen-of-the-woods mushrooms/n1 cup chopped yellow onion/n1 cup chopped red bell pepper/n1 1/2 teaspoons kosher salt, divided/n2 medium garlic cloves, finely chopped/n1/2 cup undrained canned diced tomatoes, or chopped very ripe tomatoes/n2 tablespoons tomato paste/n1 quart vegetable stock or water/nPinch of saffron threads/n1/4 cup thinly sliced Swiss chard/n1 cup uncooked Bomba rice (such as Santo Tomas), see Note/nHot water, as needed/n1/2 medium lemon/n1/4 cup Lemon Aioli/nGrilled lemon wedges and cherry tomatoes, for serving/n1/2 cup mayonnaise/n1/2 teaspoon lemon zest/n1/4 teaspoon fresh lemon juice/n1/4 teaspoon grated garlic
Steps: Step 1: Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a 15-inch carbon steel paella pan over high until shimmering. Add squash and mushrooms; cook, undisturbed, until browned on 1 side, about 3 minutes. Continue cooking, stirring occasionally, until browned all over, about 3 minutes. Transfer to a small bowl and set aside./nStep 2: Reduce heat to medium-low; add onion, bell pepper, 1/2 teaspoon salt, and remaining 3 tablespoons oil. Cook, stirring often, until onion darkens around edges, about 15 minutes, stirring in garlic during final 1 minute of cook time./nStep 3: Stir diced tomatoes and tomato paste into mixture, scraping up browned bits on bottom of pan with a wooden spoon. Cook, stirring often, until liquid in pan evaporates and tomato paste sizzles, 3 to 5 minutes. Stir in vegetable stock, saffron, and remaining 1 teaspoon salt. Increase heat to high and bring to a boil. Stir in chard and squash mixture. Sprinkle rice over mixture, stirring gently to disperse evenly./nStep 4: Return mixture to a boil over medium-high heat. Boil until rice grains are just above top of stock, about 10 minutes./nStep 5: Reduce heat to medium-low; simmer, repositioning pan over heat every few minutes by turning pan about 90 degrees to redistribute heat, until rice is tender, has absorbed all liquid, and begins to brown on bottom, about 20 minutes. (Use a small spoon to gently lift rice from bottom of pan to check for brownness on crust.) If the liquid is cooking off quickly and rice is still al dente, add hot water as needed (1/4 cup at a time) until rice is tender./nStep 6: Remove pan from heat; loosely cover with aluminum foil or a clean kitchen towel, and let stand 10 minutes./nStep 7: Stir together all ingredients in a small bowl. Store in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 1 week./nStep 8: Uncover and squeeze juice from lemon half over paella; top with dollops of lemon aioli, grilled lemon wedges, and tomatoes./nStep 9: Bomba rice is a short-grain rice that can absorb a large amount of liquid without bursting or becoming mushy. Find it at specialty stores or on amazon.com./nStep 10: Robust, stone-fruited, Chenin Blanc.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon gochujang (Korean chile paste)/n2 teaspoons soy sauce/n3 tablespoons sesame oil/n1 cup chopped kale leaves/n1/2 cup kimchi, chopped, plus more for serving/n2 cups cooked white rice/n2 large eggs/nKosher salt/nPepper/nThinly sliced scallions and toasted sesame seeds, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk the gochujang with the soy sauce./nStep 2: In a large nonstick skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the sesame oil. Add the kale and the 1/2 cup of kimchi and stir-fry over moderately high heat until the kale is softened, about 2 minutes. Fold in the cooked rice. Add the gochujang sauce and stir-fry until the rice is starting to brown, about 2 minutes more. Divide the fried rice between 2 bowls and wipe out the skillet./nStep 3: In the skillet, heat the remaining 1 tablespoon of sesame oil. Crack the eggs into the skillet and cook over moderate heat until the whites are firm and the yolks are still runny, about 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Top the rice with the fried eggs and garnish with sliced scallions and toasted sesame seeds. Serve with additional kimchi.

Ingredients: 1 cup amaranth/n3 cups unsweetened coconut milk/n1 cup unsweetened shredded coconut/n1/2 cup honey/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract/n1 cinnamon stick/nOne 1-inch piece of peeled fresh ginger/n1/4 cup raisins
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350º. In a large saucepan, bring all of the ingredients to a boil. Remove from the heat and pour into an oiled 3-quart casserole dish./nStep 2: Bake for one hour, or until amaranth has absorbed the liquid and is tender. Serve warm or chilled.

Ingredients: 4 teaspoons canola oil/n1/2 pound ground pork/n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger/n1 scallion, minced/n1 tablespoon unseasoned rice vinegar/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n1/2 teaspoon toasted sesame oil/nKosher salt/nPepper/n6 cups prepared sushi rice/n2 cups baby spinach, chopped/n4 large eggs/n1 cup julienned carrots/nSliced cucumber, gochujang and toasted sesame seeds, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Light a grill. Arrange four 18-inch sheets of heavy-duty foil on a work surface. Put a 14-inch sheet of nonstick foil on each sheet and drizzle 1 teaspoon of canola oil in the center of each./nStep 2: In a bowl, mix the pork, ginger, scallion, vinegar, soy sauce, sesame oil and a generous pinch each of salt and pepper./nStep 3: Mound the rice in the center of the foil sheets and, using damp hands, press into 3/4-inch-thick rounds. Top each mound with one-fourth of the spinach, then crack an egg on top of each mound. Crumble one-fourth of the pork around each mound, then pile the carrots alongside; season with salt and pepper. Bring 2 sides of the foil up over the filling to form a seam across the top, leaving space for the egg. Fold the remaining 2 sides to seal./nStep 4: Slide the foil packets onto the grill and cook over medium heat until the rice is crisp on the bottom and the egg whites are firm but the yolks are runny, 8 to 12 minutes; open once to check the eggs. Open the packets and, using a thin spatula, slide the bibimbaps onto 4 plates. Serve with cucumber, gochujang and sesame seeds./nStep 5: The uncooked bibimbap packets can be refrigerated for a few hours.

Ingredients: 1 cup dried split chickpeas (chana dal)/n¾ cup  olive oil, divided/n1.66667 cups uncooked fine bulgur/n1 small yellow onion, chopped/n3 medium garlic cloves, smashed/n2 teaspoons grated lemon zest/n2 teaspoons ground allspice/n2 teaspoons ground cumin/n1 teaspoon black pepper/n¼ teaspoon cayenne pepper/n1 cup finely chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley/n1 tablespoon plus 1 ¼ teaspoons kosher salt
Steps: Step 1: Place chickpeas in a colander; rinse under cold water, stirring chickpeas with your fingers, until water runs clear, about 2 minutes. Transfer chickpeas to a large bowl or container; add water to cover by 4 inches. Cover and refrigerate 12 hours. Drain and set aside./nStep 2: Pour 3 tablespoons oil into a 12-inch round cake pan; swirl and tilt pan to coat in oil. Set aside./nStep 3: Line a colander with a double layer of cheesecloth or a clean cotton or linen kitchen towel. Add bulgur; rinse under cold water, stirring bulgur with your fingers, until it begins to soften slightly, about 4 minutes. Transfer bulgur to a large bowl; add lukewarm water to cover by 2 inches. Let stand at room temperature 30 minutes./nStep 4: Preheat oven to 350°F. Line colander with a fresh double layer of cheesecloth. Add bulgur and soaking water; drain. Gather cheesecloth up around bulgur; twist and squeeze to wring out water./nStep 5: Combine onion, garlic, lemon zest, allspice, cumin, black pepper, cayenne pepper, and drained bulgur in a food processor. Pulse until bulgur is tinted brown and mixture is thoroughly combined, about 10 pulses, stopping to scrape down sides as needed. Transfer mixture to a large bowl. Add parsley, salt, and drained chickpeas; stir until thoroughly combined./nStep 6: Transfer mixture to a clean work surface. Using both hands, fold mixture over itself, firmly pressing down while mashing mixture together with your hands, until mixture is the consistency of a sticky dough, 7 to 9 minutes. (The mixture should come together in a single tacky mass; no need to be gentle here.)/nStep 7: Place kibbeh in prepared cake pan; press firmly into pan to create a compact, even layer. Drizzle with 1/2 cup oil. Using a sharp paring knife, slice kibbeh into 18 wedges in pan. Working from outer edge toward center of kibbeh, cut 2 (1/4-inch-deep) diagonal slits spaced 1 inch apart into each wedge. Brush remaining 1 tablespoon oil over kibbeh./nStep 8: Bake in preheated oven until outer edges of kibbeh are brown and mixture is set, 55 minutes to 1 hour and 10 minutes. Let cool 10 minutes./nStep 9: Kibbeh may be refrigerated in an airtight container up to 2 days./nStep 10: Find bulgur and split chickpeas at Middle Eastern and Indian grocery stores.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups short-grain Asian rice/n2 cups water/nSalt/n1/4 cup peanut oil/n1 cup sliced roast pork/n1 cup sliced Chinese-style sausage/nOne 1-inch piece of fresh ginger, peeled and thinly sliced/n1 dried red chile/n1 garlic clove, crushed/n2 ounces mung bean sprouts/n1 large egg, beaten/n1 1/2 cups kimchi, coarsly chopped and drained, liquid reserved/n1/2 cup thinly sliced scallions, plus more for garnish/n3 tablespoons soy sauce/n2 teaspoons toasted sesame oil
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, cover the rice with the water and bring to a boil. Add a pinch of salt, cover and cook over low heat until the water is absorbed and the rice is just tender, about 20 minutes. Remove from the heat and let stand, covered, for 20 minutes. Spread the rice on a large rimmed baking sheet and let cool, then cover and refrigerate until cold, about 30 minutes./nStep 2: In a very large skillet, heat the peanut oil until shimmering. Add the sliced pork and sausage and stir-fry over high heat for 2 minutes. Add the ginger, chile and garlic and stir-fry until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add the bean sprouts and stir-fry for 30 seconds, then push the mixture to one side of the skillet. Add the egg to the other side of the skillet and scramble just until set, about 1 minute./nStep 3: Add the cold rice to the skillet and stir-fry over high heat until coated and hot, about 2 minutes. Add the kimchi, scallions, soy sauce and sesame oil and stir-fry until hot, 1 to 2 minutes. Spoon the fried rice into bowls, garnish with thinly sliced scallions and serve./nStep 4: The cooked rice can be refrigerated overnight.

Ingredients: 1/4 pound bacon, chopped/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n1/2 pound medium shrimp, shelled and deveined/n6 scallions, white parts minced, green parts thinly sliced on the bias/n2 garlic cloves, minced/nJasmine Rice (see Note) or 3 cups cooked white rice, cooled/n2 large eggs, beaten/n1/2 cup thawed frozen English peas/n3 tablespoons unseasoned rice vinegar/n1 teaspoon toasted sesame oil/n2 cups sliced tatsoi or leaf spinach/nKosher salt
Steps: Step 1: In a large nonstick skillet, cook the bacon in the canola oil over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until browned and crisp, about 8 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a paper towel–lined plate to drain. Do not wipe out the skillet./nStep 2: Heat the fat in the skillet until shimmering. Add the shrimp and cook over moderately high heat, turning once, until just cooked through, about 3 minutes. Transfer to a plate./nStep 3: Add the scallion whites and garlic to the skillet and stir-fry over moderately high heat until softened, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the rice and stir-fry until hot, about 3 minutes. Using a wooden spoon, make a well in the center of the rice. Add the eggs to the well and cook, slowly stirring them into the rice, until just set, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the bacon, shrimp, peas, vinegar and sesame oil and stir-fry until hot, 2 minutes. Stir in the tatsoi until just wilted. Season the rice with salt. Garnish with the scallion greens./nStep 4: Jasmine Rice

Ingredients: 1 cup red quinoa/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 red onion, chopped/n2 ears corn/n1 teaspoon dried oregano, crumbled/n1 tablespoon lime juice/n1/2 cup torn basil leaves
Steps: Step 1: Cook the quinoa in a pot of boiling salted water until it is tender, 10 to 15 minutes. Drain the quinoa in a sieve and let it cool to room temperature./nStep 2: In a large heavy skillet, heat the olive oil over medium high heat until hot. Stir in the onion, 1/2 teaspoon each salt and pepper, and cook until golden, about 6 minutes. Stir in the corn and continue to cook until tender, about 4 minutes. Transfer the corn mixture to a mixing bowl and let cool./nStep 3: Stir in the quinoa, lime juice, oregano and basil into the corn mixture. Season the salad with salt and pepper to taste then serve.

Ingredients: 1 pound farro, rinsed and drained/n2 carrots, halved crosswise/n1 small onion, halved/n1 celery rib, halved crosswise/n2 garlic cloves, crushed/n1 bay leaf/nCanola oil, for frying/n2 large heads of cauliflower (2 1/2 pounds each), cut into 1-inch florets/n1/2 pound prosciutto, sliced 1/4 inch thick and cut into 1/4-inch dice/n1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n5 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1/4 cup chopped flat-leaf parsley/n2 teaspoons chopped marjoram/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper
