Pour pan drippings into a fat separator or a measuring cup; skim and discard fat. Season pernil to taste with skimmed pan drippings. Divide mac and cheese among bowls; top with pernil./nStep 6: Find sazón at Latin markets or online at amigofoods.com./nStep 7: Mac and cheese can be made up to 1 day ahead, covered, and refrigerated up to 12 hours. Let come to room temperature before baking./nStep 8: Crisp Puerto Rican lager: Medalla Light

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n4 ounces meaty bacon, minced/n1 medium onion, minced/n4 garlic cloves, minced/n1 large bunch Swiss chard, stems minced and leaves reserved/n32 ounces (4 cups) prepared tomato sauce/n1 teaspoon dried basil/nPinch of crushed red pepper/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper/n8 large eggs/n3 tablespoons freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese/n1/4 cup thinly sliced basil leaves
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a large ovenproof skillet, heat the olive oil. Add the bacon, onion, garlic and chard stems and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the stems are softened, about 5 minutes. Add the tomato sauce, dried basil and crushed red pepper and simmer until the sauce is thickened, about 15 minutes. Season with salt and pepper./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large pot of salted boiling water, blanch the chard leaves for 3 minutes. Drain and let cool slightly. Squeeze out the excess water. Form the chard leaves into 8 small piles and arrange them in the sauce around the side the skillet./nStep 3: Crack the eggs into the skillet between the piles of chard. Transfer the pan to the oven and bake the eggs for 12 to 15 minutes, until the egg whites are just set and the yolks are still runny./nStep 4: Transfer the skillet to a rack and sprinkle the cheese on top. Let stand for 5 minutes. Garnish the shakshuka with the sliced basil and serve immediately./nStep 5: Crusty bread./nStep 6: Lively, light-bodied red wine.

Ingredients: 2 ½ cups all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting/n½ teaspoon salt/n1 ½  cold unsalted butter (cubed)/n1  large egg yolk/n¼ cup plus 3 tablespoons ice water/n1 pound thickly sliced bacon (cut into /2-inch dice)/n3  large leeks, white and tender green parts only (thinly sliced)/n1 teaspoon chopped thyme leaves/nSalt and freshly ground white pepper/n8 ounces cave-aged Gruyère cheese (shredded)/n4  large eggs/n2  large egg yolks/n2 ½ cups heavy cream (or half-and-half)
Steps: Step 1: In a food processor, pulse the 2 1/2 cups of flour with the salt. Add the butter and pulse until it is the size of small peas. Add the egg yolk and ice water and pulse until the pastry is moistened. Turn the pastry out onto a floured work surface and knead 2 or 3 times, just until smooth. Pat the pastry into 2 disks, wrap in plastic and refrigerate until firm, about 20 minutes./nStep 2: Preheat the oven to 375°. On a floured surface, roll 1 disk of the pastry to a 12-inch round. Ease the pastry into a 10-inch fluted tart pan with a removable bottom without stretching. Trim the excess and use it to patch any holes. Refrigerate the tart shell for 10 minutes. Repeat with the remaining pastry./nStep 3: Line the tart shells with foil and fill with pie weights or dried beans. Bake the tart shells for 30 minutes, just until dry. Remove the foil and pie weights and bake the crusts for about 15 minutes longer, until they are dry and golden. Transfer the tart pans to 2 sturdy baking sheets./nStep 4: In a large skillet, cook the bacon over moderately high heat, stirring, until browned and crisp, about 7 minutes. Drain the bacon, leaving 1 tablespoon of the fat in the pan. Add the leeks and thyme to the skillet, season with salt and white pepper and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the leeks are softened but not browned, about 5 minutes. Transfer to a bowl and let cool. Stir in the bacon and cheese./nStep 5: Divide the bacon-and-leek filling between the tart shells. In a bowl, whisk the eggs with the egg yolks and heavy cream. Season lightly with salt and white pepper. Pour the custard into the tart shells and bake for about 30 minutes, rotating the sheet halfway through for even baking, until puffed and lightly browned. Transfer the quiches to a rack and let cool for 15 minutes. Remove the rings, cut the quiches into wedges and serve./nStep 6: The quiches can be covered and refrigerated overnight. Reheat the quiches gently before serving./nStep 7: Winemakers in Bordeaux often blend Sémillon and Sauvignon Blanc to produce lightly honeyed, citrusy whites that go very well with rich quiches like the bacon-and-leek one here.

Ingredients: 6 ounces thickly sliced bacon, cut into 1-inch strips/n1/2 medium sweet onion, finely chopped/n2 garlic cloves, finely chopped/n2 tablespoons tomato paste/n1 tablespoon pure maple syrup/nTwo 15-ounce cans pink beans with their liquid/n3 cups chicken stock or low-sodium broth/nSalt/nCayenne pepper/n1 jumbo corn muffin (about 5 ounces), cut into 3/4-inch cubes/nChopped scallions, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. In a medium saucepan, cook the bacon strips over moderately high heat, stirring occasionally, until they are browned and crisp, about 7 minutes. Transfer the crispy bacon to a plate and pour off all but 2 tablespoons of the fat from the saucepan./nStep 2: Add the onion and garlic to the fat in the saucepan and cook, stirring, until they are softened, about 5 minutes. Add the tomato paste and maple syrup and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until thick, about 3 minutes. Add the pink beans and their liquid and cook until slightly thickened, 2 to 3 minutes. Add the chicken stock and bacon strips, season lightly with salt and cayenne pepper and simmer the soup over moderate heat until thickened slightly, about 15 minutes./nStep 3: Meanwhile, spread the corn muffin cubes on a small baking sheet and bake for 7 to 8 minutes, until they are golden and crisp. Let the corn muffin croutons cool slightly./nStep 4: Ladle the soup into deep bowls, garnish with the corn muffin croutons and chopped scallions and serve./nStep 5: Spicy red blend.

Ingredients: 3 pounds butternut squash—peeled, seeded and cut into 1/2-inch dice/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n2 tablespoons finely chopped thyme leaves/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper/n1 tablespoon unsalted butter/n3 leeks—white and light green parts only, halved lengthwise and thinly sliced crosswise (about 4 cups)/n6 large eggs/n2 1/2 cups half-and-half/n1/4 cup freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese/n8 ounces baguette, crusts removed and bread cut into 1/2-inch dice/n4 ounces thinly-sliced prosciutto, cut into thin strips
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400° and butter a 9-by-13-inch baking ceramic baking dish. In a large bowl, toss the butternut squash with 1 tablespoon of the olive oil and the thyme. Season with salt and pepper. Spread the squash on a baking sheet in a single layer and roast for about 25 minutes, until tender, tossing once halfway through. Let cool./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a medium skillet, melt the butter in the remaining 1 tablespoon of olive oil. Add the leeks and season with salt and pepper. Cook over moderate heat, stirring, until tender, about 20 minutes. Let cool slightly./nStep 3: In a large bowl, beat the eggs with the half-and-half, cheese, 1 teaspoon of salt and a 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Stir in the bread and let stand for 10 minutes. Fold in the squash, prosciutto and the cooled leeks. Transfer the mixture to the prepared baking dish and bake for about 1 hour, until lightly golden on top. Let stand for 15 minutes before serving.

Ingredients: Eight 1/4-inch-thick pork loin cutlets (about 2 pounds)/n1 large sweet onion, such as Vidalia, cut crosswise into 1/2-inch-thick rounds/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper/n2 teaspoons chile powder/nEight 6-inch flour or corn tortillas, warmed/n1 Hass avocado, halved and sliced lengthwise/n1/2 cup cilantro leaves/nSour cream and lime wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Light a grill or preheat a grill pan. Arrange the cutlets and onion on a large baking sheet. Brush all over with the oil and season with salt and pepper. Season the cutlets with the chile powder./nStep 2: Grill the onions over moderately high heat, turning once, until charred and tender, about 8 minutes. Transfer to a cutting board and cover with foil to keep warm. Grill the cutlets, turning once, until just cooked through, about 2 minutes./nStep 3: Transfer the pork to the cutting board. Coarsely chop the onions and cut the pork into 1/2-inch strips; transfer to a platter. Serve with the tortillas, avocado, cilantro, sour cream and lime wedges./nStep 4: Berry-rich Zinfandel.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter/n1 ham hock, split by the butcher/n2 medium onions, chopped/n5 garlic cloves, minced/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper/n3 pounds baking potatoes/n8 cups chicken stock
Steps: Step 1: In a large heavy pot, heat the butter over medium heat until hot, then brown the ham hock, turning occasionally, about 6 minutes./nStep 2: Stir the onions, garlic, 3/4 teaspoon salt, and 1/2 teaspoon pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until golden, 8 to 10 minutes. Peel and dice the potatoes. Stir in the potatoes and stock bring to a gentle boil. Cook the soup, stirring occasionally, until the potatoes are very soft and starting to fall apart, 45 minutes to 1 hour. Remove the ham hock and let cool slightly. Remove the meat from the ham hock and cut into pieces, the return the meat to the soup. Season the soup with salt and pepper to taste and serve.

Ingredients: 1 cup uncooked jasmine rice/n6 cups water/nKosher salt or fish sauce, to taste/n6 (1-ounce) thick-cut maple bacon slices, cut into 2-inch pieces/nFermented mustard greens (such as Pigeon Brand)/nSliced scallions and sliced fresh red Thai chiles, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Place rice in a large saucepan; add enough water to just cover rice. Swirl water in pan to rinse rice, and drain. Repeat rinsing and draining process until water runs clear, 8 to 10 times. Add 6cups water to drained rice in saucepan; bring to a boil over high. Stir in salt or fish sauce to taste. Reduce heat to medium-low; cover and cook, undisturbed, until rice is tender and creamy, 30 minutes. Remove from heat; let rice stand, covered, until thickened, about 10 minutes./nStep 2: While rice cooks, cook bacon in a large skillet over medium-high, turning occasionally, until crispy, 8 to 10 minutes. Drain on a paper towel–lined plate./nStep 3: Divide porridge evenly among 6 shallow bowls. Sprinkle evenly with cooked bacon; garnish with fermented mustard greens, scallions, and red Thai chiles./nStep 4: Porridge can be refrigerated in an airtight container up to 2 days./nStep 5: Find canned fermented mustard greens at Asian markets or online.

Ingredients: 3 pounds sugar pumpkin, seeded and halved/n4 ounces thick-cut smoked bacon, cut into 1/4-inch pieces/n1 small white onion, chopped/n1 clove garlic, minced/n1 tablespoon minced fresh thyme/n1 tablespoon firmly packed light brown sugar/n1/4 teaspoon white pepper/n1/2 teaspoon freshly ground cinnamon/n1/4 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg/n1/8 teaspoon cayenne pepper/n3 cups low-sodium vegetable broth/n1/2 cup heavy whipping cream/nKosher salt/nRoasted pumpkin seeds, for garnish (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400º. Oil the inside of the pumpkin halves and season each with salt. Place the pumpkin halves cut side down on a baking sheet and bake in the oven for 30 minutes, or until the pumpkin meat is fork-tender. Remove from the oven. When it's cool enough to handle, use a spoon to scoop out the roasted pumpkin and set aside./nStep 2: In a large pot, sauté the bacon over moderate heat, until it's crispy on all sides. Move the bacon pieces to a paper towel and set aside. To the bacon fat, add onion, garlic, thyme, sugar, pepper, cinnamon, nutmeg and cayenne pepper and cook for 3 minutes. Add the roasted pumpkin and broth, stirring to incorporate, then season with salt, and bring the soup to a boil. Reduce the heat to low and simmer for 20 minutes. Stir in the cream and let cool for 10 minutes./nStep 3: Transfer the soup to a blender (or use an immersion blender in the pot) and puree until smooth. If needed, add additional water or broth to reach the desired consistency. Return the mixture to the saucepan and warm. Serve and garnish with roasted pumpkin seeds./nStep 4: Like most soups, this one is even better made the day before. Reheat before serving.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup small dried shrimp (see Note)/n1/3 cup dried scallops (see Note)/n2 cups boiling water/n1/4 cup diced country ham or prosciutto (1/2 ounce)/n8 garlic cloves/n1 medium shallot, coarsely chopped/nOne 1/2-inch piece of fresh ginger, peeled and sliced/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n1 1/2 teaspoons crushed red pepper/n1 1/2 teaspoons sugar/n1 1/4 cups rice bran, grapeseed or canola oil/n1 pound green beans/nSalt/nBlack pepper/nLemon wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, cover the dried shrimp and scallops with the boiling water and let stand until softened, about 15 minutes. Drain well./nStep 2: In a mini food processor, combine the shrimp, scallops and ham with the garlic, shallot, ginger, soy sauce, crushed red pepper and sugar. Pulse until minced. Scrape the mixture into a small saucepan and stir in 1 cup of the oil. Bring to a boil over moderately high heat; reduce the heat to a simmer and cook until the solids are dark golden and fragrant, about 30 minutes. Remove the XO sauce from the heat and let cool to room temperature./nStep 3: Heat a large wok or skillet over high heat for 5 minutes. Drizzle in the remaining 1/4 cup of oil, add the green beans and cook for 2 to 3 minutes, tossing every 30 seconds; the beans are done when they're tender and blistered in spots. Drain off the oil. Stir in 1/4 cup of the XO sauce; toss until the beans are evenly coated. Season with salt and pepper and transfer to a platter. Serve with lemon wedges./nStep 4: The XO sauce can be refrigerated for up to 2 weeks./nStep 5: Dried shrimp and dried scallops are both available at Asian markets.

Ingredients: 1 cup apple cider/n3 cups low-sodium chicken broth/nOne 4-by-6-inch piece of kombu (see Note)/n4 tablespoons unsalted butter/n2 onions, thinly sliced/nKosher salt/n2 ounces cooked smoked ham, chopped (1/2 cup)/n2 cups pearled barley/n2 tablespoons low-sodium soy sauce/n4 large eggs, poached/nThinly sliced scallions, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, combine the cider, broth, kombu and 2 cups of water. Bring just to a boil, then remove from the heat. Let steep for 40 minutes. Discard the kombu and transfer the cider broth to a bowl./nStep 2: Wipe out the saucepan and melt the butter in it. Add the onions, season with salt and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until golden, about 20 minutes. Add the ham and cook for 3 minutes. Stir in the barley, soy sauce and cider broth and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the barley is porridge-like, about 1 hour. Season with salt./nStep 3: Spoon the porridge into bowls and top with the eggs. Garnish with scallions; serve./nStep 4: Kombu is edible kelp. It's available at natural food stores and Asian markets.

Ingredients: Cooking spray/n¾ cup (about 4 1/4 ounces) yellow cornmeal/n¾ cup (about 3 1/4 ounces) all-purpose flour/n¼ cup granulated sugar/n1 ½ teaspoons baking powder/n½ teaspoon baking soda/n½ teaspoon kosher salt/n2 large eggs/n1 cup whole buttermilk/n5 tablespoons (2 1/2 ounces) unsalted butter, melted/n8  (3/4-ounce each) thick-cut applewood-smoked bacon slices/n1 cup dry red wine/n½ cup red wine vinegar/n¼ cup heavy whipping cream/n1 tablespoon finely chopped shallot (from 1 small shallot)/n2 cups (1 pound) cold unsalted butter, divided/n8 cups water/n¼ cup, plus 1 teaspoon kosher salt, divided/n4  (6-ounce) fresh or thawed frozen lobster tails/n1 ounce (about 2 tablespoons) canned or frozen black truffle shavings (from 1 [1.74-ounce] can), well drained/n¼ teaspoon ground white pepper/n2 tablespoons thinly sliced fresh chives
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 325°F. Coat an 8-inch square baking pan with cooking spray. Whisk together cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, and salt in a large bowl. Whisk together eggs, buttermilk, and melted butter in a medium bowl. Stir egg mixture into cornmeal mixture just until combined. Pour batter into prepared baking pan; smooth top./nStep 2: Bake in preheated oven until Cornbread is light brown around edges and a wooden pick inserted in center comes out clean, 25 to 30 minutes. Let cool in pan 5 minutes. Invert Cornbread onto a wire rack, and let cool completely, about 30 minutes. Slice evenly into 8 pieces. Cover and set aside until ready to use./nStep 3: Preheat oven to 325°F. Line a baking sheet with aluminum foil, and line with a piece of parchment paper on top. Arrange bacon in a single layer on parchment paper. Bake in preheated oven until bacon is crisp, 35 to 40 minutes. Remove from oven. Transfer bacon to a paper towel-lined plate; set aside./nStep 4: Bring wine, vinegar, cream, and shallot to a boil in a small saucepan. Reduce heat to medium; simmer, undisturbed, until liquid has reduced to 2 tablespoons, 30 to 35 minutes./nStep 5: Meanwhile, cut 1 1/2 cups of the butter into 1/2-inch cubes, and place in refrigerator until ready to use. Place 8 cups water and 1/4 cup of the salt in a large pot; bring to boil over high. Fill a large bowl with ice water; set aside. Remove pot of boiling water from heat, and add lobster tails. Let steep for 3 minutes. Using tongs, transfer lobster tails to ice water; let cool 3 to 5 minutes. Discard water in pot. Remove lobster tails from ice water. Stretch 1 curled-up tail flat on a cutting board. Rest the blade of a large knife down lengthwise center of tail to hold it flat, then press knife down to cut tail in half lengthwise. Gently remove lobster meat from shell, and discard shell. Return lobster meat to bowl of ice water to rinse off any bits of shell. Repeat process with remaining lobster tails./nStep 6: Melt remaining 1/2 cup butter in a medium saucepan over low. Add lobster tail meat; cook, basting often with melted butter in pan, until lobster is warm and cooked through (turns bright orange-red and opaque), about 2 minutes. Transfer lobster to a paper towel-lined plate./nStep 7: Once wine mixture has reduced to 2 tablespoons, reduce heat to low, and start adding chilled butter cubes to pot, adding 1 or 2 cubes at a time and whisking rapidly with a wire whisk, fully incorporating butter between additions. Continue adding more butter, whisking constantly, until only 2 or 3 cubes remain. Remove pan from heat; add remaining butter cubes, and whisk until fully incorporated. Whisk in truffle pieces. Stir white pepper and remaining 1 teaspoon salt into beurre rouge sauce. The sauce should be thick and smooth./nStep 8: Place 1 cornbread slice on each of 8 plates. Break bacon slices in half crosswise, and top each cornbread slice with 2 bacon halves. Arrange lobster tails evenly on top of bacon, and cover lobster with beurre rouge. Sprinkle evenly with chives, and serve immediately.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons butter/n1 onion, chopped/n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger, plus one 2-inch piece, peeled, halved lengthwise, and smashed/n3/4 pound green cabbage (about 1/4 head), shredded (about 3 cups)/n1 1/2 quarts canned low-sodium chicken broth or homemade stock/n1 pound boiling potatoes (about 3), peeled and cut into 1/2-inch cubes/n2 teaspoons salt/n1 pound pork tenderloin, cut into approximately 1 1/2-inch-long-by-1/4-inch-wide strips/n2 teaspoons lemon juice/n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, melt the butter over moderately low heat. Add the onion and cook, stirring occasionally, until starting to soften, about 3 minutes. Stir in the minced ginger and the cabbage and cook for 1 minute longer./nStep 2: Add the broth, potatoes, smashed ginger, and 1 teaspoon of the salt. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer until the potatoes are tender, about 10 minutes./nStep 3: Stir in the pork and the remaining 1 teaspoon salt. Cook until the pork is just done, about 3 minutes. Stir in the lemon juice and parsley. Remove the pieces of smashed ginger before serving./nStep 4: Fresh GingerYou'll want to use really fresh ginger here; it's integral to the flavoring of the soup. Look for a piece that has taut skin and is firm to the touch. After the ginger is peeled (the easiest way is to scrape the peel off with a spoon), its color should be pale yellow. If the ginger is blueish green instead, chances are the piece is old and won't have the vibrant flavor you're looking for./nStep 5: Tokay Pinot Gris is full and very rich, with gentle acidity and a nutty flavor. You'll be surprised how well it performs here.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon olive oil/n1 pound mild or hot Italian sausage/n1  onion (chopped)/n2  red bell peppers (cut into 1-inch pieces)/n1 ¾ teaspoons salt/n3 cloves garlic (minced)/n1 cup canned crushed tomatoes in thick puree/n1 cup canned low-sodium chicken broth or homemade stock/n2 tablespoons dry vermouth or dry white wine/n3 tablespoons chopped flat-leaf parsley/n¾ pound whole-wheat spaghetti/n2 tablespoons grated Parmesan cheese (plus more for serving)
Steps: Step 1: In a large frying pan, heat the oil over moderate heat. Add the sausage and cook, turning, until browned and cooked through, about 8 minutes. Remove. When the sausage is cool enough to handle, cut it into 1/2-inch slices./nStep 2: Add the onion, peppers, and 3/4 teaspoon of the salt to the pan. Cook, stirring frequently, until the vegetables begin to brown, about 5 minutes. Cover and cook, stirring occasionally until the vegetables are soft, about 3 minutes longer. Add the garlic and cook, stirring, for about 30 seconds. Add the tomatoes, broth, vermouth, the reserved sausage and any accumulated juices, the parsley, and the remaining 1 teaspoon salt and bring to a simmer./nStep 3: In a large pot of boiling, salted water, cook the spaghetti until just done, about 12 minutes. Drain and toss with the sausage-and-pepper mixture and the Parmesan. Serve with additional Parmesan./nStep 4: The earthy Italian feel of this dish and the acidity from the tomatoes make a Nebbiolo-based wine from the Piedmont region of Italy a nice choice. Look for a lighter version such as Nebbiolo d'Alba.

Ingredients: Canola oil/n1 small onion, finely chopped/n2 large garlic cloves, minced/n1/2 pound ground pork/n1/2 pound ground beef/n1 teaspoon ground cumin/n1 teaspoon ground coriander/n1/4 teaspoon dried oregano/nPinch of cayenne/nSalt/n1/4 cup toasted sunflower seeds/n1/4 cup freshly grated Cotija or Pecorino Romano cheese/n3 tablespoons raisins, chopped/n4 large poblanos (1 1/2 pounds)/n1/2 cup shredded Cheddar cheese/n1/4 cup sour cream/n2 tablespoons milk/n1 tablespoon chopped cilantro/n1/2 tablespoon fresh lime juice
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the broiler. Position a rack 8 inches from the heat. In a skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of oil until shimmering. Add the onion and garlic; cook over high heat until softened. Add the pork, beef, cumin, coriander, oregano and cayenne and stir until the meat is no longer pink, 7 minutes. Season with salt. Stir in the sunflower seeds, Cotija and raisins./nStep 2: Rub the poblanos with oil and broil, turning occasionally, until charred all over, 7 minutes. Transfer to a plate, let cool slightly, then peel. Slit the chiles along 1 side. Using scissors, snip out the cores. Scoop out the seeds. Fill the chiles with the meat mixture, sprinkle with the Cheddar and broil until the cheese is golden. Transfer to plates./nStep 3: In a bowl, blend the sour cream, milk, cilantro and lime juice. Season with salt, spoon over the poblanos and serve.

Ingredients: 6 slices of thick-cut applewood-smoked bacon/n1/2 cup hazelnuts/n1 tablespoon hazelnut or canola oil/nKosher salt/nPepper/n1/4 cup sherry vinegar/n1/4 cup minced shallots/n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1 teaspoon sugar/n1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil/nLight green leaves from 2 small heads of Bibb lettuce/n1/2 cup Concord grapes, halved and seeded/n4 ounces Gorgonzola dolce, crumbled/nSnipped chives, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 325°. On a foil-lined rimmed baking sheet, bake the bacon for about 17 minutes, turning once, until browned but still chewy. Transfer the bacon to paper towels to drain, then cut into 1-inch pieces. Leave the oven on./nStep 2: Meanwhile, spread the hazelnuts in a pie plate and bake for about 12 minutes, until lightly browned and the skins start to crack. Transfer the hazelnuts to a clean kitchen towel and rub them together to remove the skins; let cool. Coarsely chop the hazelnuts and transfer to a small bowl. Stir in the hazelnut oil and season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: In a medium bowl, whisk the sherry vinegar with the minced shallots, lemon juice and sugar. Gradually whisk in the olive oil until incorporated. Season the shallot vinaigrette with salt and pepper./nStep 4: In a large bowl, toss the lettuce leaves with 1/4 cup of the shallot vinaigrette and season lightly with salt and pepper. On a serving platter or plates, layer the lettuce leaves with the bacon pieces, chopped hazelnuts, Concord grapes and Gorgonzola dolce. Garnish with snipped chives and serve, passing the remaining shallot vinaigrette at the table./nStep 5: Fragrant, medium-bodied Piedmontese white.

Ingredients: 4  (1/2-inch-thick) good-quality firm white sandwich bread slices/n3 tablespoons unsalted butter, softened, divided/n1 tablespoon all-purpose flour/n¾ cup whole milk/n4 ounces Gruyère cheese, grated on small holes of box grater (about 1 cup), divided/n½ teaspoon kosher salt/n¼ teaspoon black pepper, plus more for garnish/n¼ teaspoon ground nutmeg/n4 slices cooked unsmoked ham (3 ounces total; such as Jamon de Paris)/n1 tablespoon Dijon mustard/n2  large eggs/nChopped fresh chives/nFlaky sea salt
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to broil with rack about 8 inches from heat source. Heat a large nonstick skillet over medium-high. Spread 1 side of bread slices evenly with 1 tablespoon of the butter. Place bread slices, buttered side down, in skillet; cook until toasted and golden, 2 to 4 minutes. Transfer bread to a work surface. Wipe skillet clean./nStep 2: Melt 1 tablespoon of the butter in a small saucepan over medium until foamy. Whisk in flour; cook, whisking constantly, until light golden, about 1 minute, 30 seconds. Gradually whisk in milk; bring to a simmer over medium, whisking constantly. Reduce heat to low; cook, whisking often, until thickened, about 3 minutes. Remove from heat. Add 1/4 cup of the grated Gruyère and whisk until melted. Stir salt, pepper, and nutmeg into the Mornay sauce. (If not using immediately, cover surface of sauce directly with plastic wrap for up to 1 hour.)/nStep 3: Arrange 2 of the bread slices on a work surface, toasted side down. On each slice, spread 2 tablespoons Mornay sauce to evenly to cover the surface. Sprinkle with 1/4 cup grated Gruyère, and top with 2 ham slices. Spread mustard evenly on untoasted sides of remaining 2 bread slices; place, mustard side down, on top of ham-topped slices. Spread remaining Mornay sauce evenly on top of sandwiches, then top with remaining 1/4 cup grated Gruyère./nStep 4: Transfer sandwiches to a rimmed baking sheet, and broil in preheated oven until cheese has melted and top is bubbly and browning in spots, 5 to 7 minutes./nStep 5: Meanwhile, melt remaining 1 tablespoon butter in cleaned nonstick skillet over medium-high. Crack eggs into skillet; cook, undisturbed, until whites are set but yolks are runny, about 3 minutes./nStep 6: Top each sandwich with a fried egg; garnish with chives, flaky sea salt, and additional pepper.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter/n1 ham hock, split by the butcher/n2 medium onions, chopped/n5 garlic cloves, minced/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper/n3 pounds baking potatoes/n8 cups chicken stock
Steps: Step 1: Heat a slow cooker on high until hot. Stir in the butter until melted, then add the ham hock and brown, turning once, until golden, about 5 minutes. Stir in the onions, garlic, 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until golden, about 6 minutes. Peel the potatoes and cut into bite-sized cubes. Reduce the heat to low and stir in the potatoes and stock. Cook the soup until the potatoes are starting to fall apart, about 6 hours. Remove the ham hock and let cool to warm. Remove the meat, discarding the bones and return the meat to the slow cooker. Season the soup with salt and pepper to taste then serve.

Ingredients: 4 3/4-inch-thick slices country bread or sourdough bread/n1/4 pound sliced bacon, cut crosswise into 1/2-inch strips/n2 red onions, sliced thin/n3 tablespoons wine vinegar/n4 cups drained and rinsed canned cannellini beans (two 19-ounce cans)/n1 1/4 teaspoons salt/n1 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n4 pounds spinach, stems removed, leaves washed well/n2 tablespoons olive oil
Steps: Step 1: Heat the oven to 450°. Put the bread on a baking sheet and toast until lightly browned, turning once, about 5 minutes./nStep 2: In a large frying pan, cook the bacon over moderate heat until crisp. Remove the bacon with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels./nStep 3: Add the onions to the bacon fat and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until translucent, about 5 minutes. Add 2 tablespoons of the vinegar, the beans, 3/4 teaspoon of the salt, and 1/2 teaspoon of the pepper. Mix gently and remove from the heat./nStep 4: Put the spinach in a large glass or stainless-steel bowl. Add the remaining tablespoon of vinegar and 1/2 teaspoon each of salt and pepper, the oil, and the bacon to the bowl and toss. Stir half of the bean mixture into the spinach and put the salad on plates. Top each slice of toasted bread with the remaining bean mixture and serve with the salad./nStep 5: The complex combination of flavors and textures in this salad is best accompanied by a simple, crisp, and fruity red wine for contrast. Beaujolais would be our first choice, but Valpolicella, Bardolino, or even a Provençal rosé will work as well.

Ingredients: 2  (10-ounce) smoked ham hocks/n3 quarts plus 3 cups water, divided/n1 tablespoon olive oil, plus more for drizzling/n1 cup finely chopped Spanish onion/n1 cup sliced okra (1/8-inch-thick slices)/n1  (1/2-ounce) lemongrass stalk, finely chopped (about 2 tablespoons)/n1  small fresh habanero chile, finely chopped (about 1 tablespoon)/n1 tablespoon finely chopped peeled fresh ginger/n2 teaspoons kosher salt, plus more to taste/n2 cups uncooked dried red or yellow lentils/n.50 cup thinly sliced scallions/n1.50 teaspoons chopped fresh thyme, plus thyme leaves, for garnish/nMicrogreens and croutons, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Bring ham hocks and 3 quarts water to a boil in a large stockpot over high. Reduce heat to low to maintain a gentle boil; partially cover, and cook, undisturbed, until meat is tender, about 2 hours. Remove hocks; remove and discard skin from hocks. Remove meat from bones, and roughly chop; set aside. Skim and discard fat from surface of stock. Set stock aside./nStep 2: Heat oil in a large stockpot over medium. Add onion, okra, lemongrass, habanero, and ginger; cook, stirring often, until onion is translucent, 4 to 6 minutes. Stir in salt. Add lentils, remaining 3 cups water, and 3 cups reserved stock; bring to a boil over medium-high, stirring occasionally. Reduce heat to medium, and cook, stirring occasionally, until lentils are tender, 7 to 14 minutes, adding additional stock to thin, if needed. Remove 1 cup soup, and place in blender. Secure lid on blender, and remove center piece from lid. Cover opening with a kitchen towel. Process until smooth, about 20 seconds. Stir into soup. Stir in scallions, chopped thyme, and reserved chopped ham. Season with additional salt to taste. Top servings with oil, thyme leaves, microgreens, and croutons./nStep 3: Stock can be frozen up to 1 month./nStep 4: Bacony, rich California Syrah: Tensley Santa Barbara County

Ingredients: ½ cup unsalted butter (4 ounces), divided, plus more for greasing dishes/n1 medium-size yellow onion (about 8 ounces), finely chopped (about 1 3/4 cups)/n1 medium carrot (about 3 ounces), finely chopped (about 1/2 cup)/n2 teaspoons kosher salt, divided/n½ teaspoon black pepper, divided/n1 pound grass-fed 93% extra-lean ground beef/n1 (5 1/2-ounce) link fresh Mexican chorizo, casing removed/n6 tablespoons all-purpose flour/n2 cups beef stock/n2 tablespoons Worcestershire sauce/n¾ teaspoon smoked paprika/n½ teaspoon dried oregano/n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard/n1 pound, 4 ounces medium-size russet potatoes, peeled and thinly sliced/nFinely chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 450°F. Grease 6 (12- to 16-ounce) individual pie dishes with butter; set aside. Melt 1/4 cup butter in a large skillet over medium-high. Add onion, carrot, 1 teaspoon salt, and 1/4 teaspoon pepper, and cook, stirring often, until onion is soft but not browned, about 5 minutes. Add ground beef and chorizo; cook, stirring often, until meat is browned and cooked through, about 5 minutes. Sprinkle flour over mixture, and cook, stirring constantly, 2 minutes. Stir in stock, Worcestershire sauce, paprika, and oregano; bring to a boil over medium-high. Reduce heat to low; simmer, stirring often, until flavors meld and vegetables soften, about 10 minutes. Remove from heat; stir in mustard and 1/2 teaspoon salt./nStep 2: Spoon filling evenly into prepared dishes (a heaping 2/3 cup filling each). Top evenly with sliced potatoes. Sprinkle potatoes with remaining 1/2 teaspoon salt and remaining 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Microwave remaining 1/4 cup butter in a small microwavable bowl on high until melted, about 1 minute. Brush melted butter evenly over potatoes. Transfer dishes to preheated oven. Bake until pies are golden brown, 25 to 35 minutes. Remove from oven; garnish with parsley./nStep 3: Filling can be prepared through step 1 up to 2 days ahead. Let cool, and then cover and refrigerate./nStep 4: Robust, peppery Zinfandel: 2019 Foxglove Paso Robles

Ingredients: 1/4 pound bacon, chopped/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n1/2 pound medium shrimp, shelled and deveined/n6 scallions, white parts minced, green parts thinly sliced on the bias/n2 garlic cloves, minced/nJasmine Rice (see Note) or 3 cups cooked white rice, cooled/n2 large eggs, beaten/n1/2 cup thawed frozen English peas/n3 tablespoons unseasoned rice vinegar/n1 teaspoon toasted sesame oil/n2 cups sliced tatsoi or leaf spinach/nKosher salt
Steps: Step 1: In a large nonstick skillet, cook the bacon in the canola oil over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until browned and crisp, about 8 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a paper towel–lined plate to drain. Do not wipe out the skillet./nStep 2: Heat the fat in the skillet until shimmering. Add the shrimp and cook over moderately high heat, turning once, until just cooked through, about 3 minutes. Transfer to a plate./nStep 3: Add the scallion whites and garlic to the skillet and stir-fry over moderately high heat until softened, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the rice and stir-fry until hot, about 3 minutes. Using a wooden spoon, make a well in the center of the rice. Add the eggs to the well and cook, slowly stirring them into the rice, until just set, 1 to 2 minutes. Add the bacon, shrimp, peas, vinegar and sesame oil and stir-fry until hot, 2 minutes. Stir in the tatsoi until just wilted. Season the rice with salt. Garnish with the scallion greens./nStep 4: Jasmine Rice

Ingredients: 1 cup rice/n2 tablespoons cooking oil/n1 pound boneless pork chops, cut into approximately 1 1/2-by-1/4-by-1/4-inch strips/n3 scallions, white bulbs and green tops chopped and reserved separately/n3 cloves garlic, minced/n1/4 teaspoon cayenne/n1/2 teaspoon paprika/n5 cups water/n2 ribs celery, sliced thin/n1 zucchini, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n3/4 teaspoon salt/n4 teaspoons soy sauce/n4 teaspoons Asian sesame oil/n1 teaspoon white- or rice-wine vinegar/n1 pound firm tofu, cut into 1/2-inch cubes/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper
Steps: Step 1: Bring a medium pot of salted water to a boil. Stir in the rice and boil until just done, 10 to 12 minutes. Drain./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large pot, heat the oil over moderately high heat. Add the pork, the scallion bulbs, the garlic, cayenne, and paprika and cook, stirring frequently, until the pork starts to brown, about 2 minutes./nStep 3: Add the water, celery, zucchini, and salt. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer, partially covered, until the vegetables and pork are tender, 15 to 20 minutes. Stir in the soy sauce, sesame oil, vinegar, tofu, and pepper and cook for 5 minutes more./nStep 4: Stir the scallion tops into the soup. Put a mound of rice in the center of each of four bowls. Ladle the soup around the rice./nStep 5: Riesling wines and Asian flavors are truly a match made in heaven. Pay attention, however, to the degree of heat in the food; the more fire, the sweeter the wine should be to cool the burn. Here, a Spätlese, preferably from Germany's Pfalz, is in order.

Ingredients: 5 dried ancho chiles/n3 dried pasilla negre chiles/n1 poblano pepper/n2 jalapeño peppers/n1 habanero pepper/n1 red bell pepper/n6 Roma tomatoes, halved lengthwise/n1 teaspoon canola oil/n3 dried arbol chiles/n1 tablespoon cumin seed, toasted and ground/n3 garlic cloves, finely chopped/nJuice of 1 lime/nKosher salt/n1⁄2 cup finely chopped cilantro/n1 large Hass avocado, halved and pitted/n6 small tomatillos (about 9 ounces), husks removed, rinsed, and quartered/n2 jalapeños, seeded/n1 cup cilantro leaves, packed/n2 green onions/n1 small garlic clove/n1/4 cup freshly squeezed lime juice/n1 tablespoon freshly squeezed orange juice/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground black pepper/n1 pound fresh Mexican chorizo, casings removed/n1 large yellow onion, finely chopped/n2 cups Seven-Pepper Salsa/n8 ounces queso Oaxaca or fresh mozzarella, grated (2 cups)/n8 ounces (2 cups) grated Monterey Jack cheese/n8 to 10 ounces tortilla chips (1 medium bag)/n1 cup Avocado-Tomatillo Salsa, or more as needed/n1⁄2 cup cilantro leaves/n1 cup diced fresh tomatoes/n1⁄2 cup finely chopped red onion/n1 cup sliced canned black olives/n1⁄2 cup grated cotija cheese/n2 limes, quartered, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Bring a medium saucepan of water to a boil. Turn off the heat and add the ancho and pasilla negre chiles. Leave the chiles in the water for 10 minutes, then transfer them to a cutting board. When the chiles are cool enough to handle, remove the stems and seeds./nStep 2: Meanwhile, preheat the broiler and line a rimmed baking sheet with foil. Arrange the poblano, jalapeño, habanero, and red peppers on the baking sheet and broil about 4 inches from the heat, turning frequently, until charred all over (remove the peppers as they are blackened and transfer to a bowl; the smaller ones will be done first). When all of the peppers are charred, cover the bowl with plastic wrap and let steam for 10 minutes. When the peppers are cool enough to handle, peel and seed them./nStep 3: While the peppers steam, place the tomatoes, cut-side down, on the same baking sheet and broil until charred all over, about 5 to 7 minutes. When the tomatoes are cool enough to handle, peel and core them./nStep 4: In a small saucepan, heat the oil over medium-high heat. Add the arbol chiles and toast until fragrant, about 10 to 15 seconds. Transfer to a cutting board and when the chiles are cool enough to handle, remove the stems and seeds./nStep 5: In a food processor, combine the roasted peppers, reconstituted chiles, toasted arbol chiles, cumin, garlic, and lime juice. Pulse until smooth. Season to taste with salt, add the cilantro, and pulse until combined. Set aside 2 cups and refrigerate the remainder until ready to use./nStep 6: In the bowl of a food processor, combine the avocado, tomatillos, jalapeños, cilantro, green onions, and garlic and process for about 10 seconds, or until creamy but still chunky./nStep 7: Transfer the salsa to a medium bowl, stir in the lime juice, orange juice, and season with salt and pepper. Cover and chill well./nStep 8: Preheat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Crumble the chorizo into the skillet and cook, breaking up the meat with a spoon, until the meat is browned, 5 to 7 minutes. Add the onion and cook until softened, about 4 minutes./nStep 9: Add the Seven-Pepper Salsa, lower the heat to medium, and bring the mixture to a simmer. Cook until any liquid evaporates, 5 to 7 minutes. Add the cheeses and stir for 1 minute. Turn off the heat and continue stirring until all of the cheese has melted./nStep 10: Scatter the chips on a serving platter. Ladle about half of the queso fundido over the chips. Spoon a cup or more of the Avocado-Tomatillo Salsa around the pile wherever the queso didn't land./nStep 11: Sprinkle with the cilantro, tomatoes, onion, and olives. Sprinkle the cotija cheese over the top. Serve with lime wedges./nStep 12: The Seven Pepper Salsa will taste its best after resting for a day or so, so feel free to make it ahead of time./nStep 13: If a spicier Avocado-Tomatillo Salsa is preferred, leave the jalapeño seeds intact. It is best served within 4 hours; it will keep in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Before using, stir to redistribute.

Ingredients: 4 pounds chicken necks and backs/n3 pound rack of pork baby back ribs (cut into 4 sections)/n1  large leek (halved lengthwise)/n2 ounces fresh ginger (1/ cup thinly sliced)/n4 cloves garlic/n4 quarts water/n¼ cup plus 2 tablespoons shoyu or other soy sauce/n1 tablespoon vegetable oil/n3 ½ pound boneless pork shoulder butt (trimmed and tied)/n1 teaspoon Salt/n1  2-by-2-inch piece of kombu (seaweed)/n1 tablespoon Shoyu or other soy sauce (for seasoning and brushing)/n24 ounces fresh or 16 dried chuka soba (curly noodles) (boiled until al dente)/n5 ounces baby spinach (steamed)/n4  large soft-boiled eggs (peeled and soaked for 1 hour in equal parts soy sauce and mirin (sweet rice wine))/n2 sheets 2 thinly sliced scallions, 2 sheets of quartered nori (dried seaweed), rice vinegar and togarashi (Japanese chile powder) (for garnishing and seasoning)
Steps: Step 1: In a large stockpot, combine the chicken, ribs, leek, ginger, garlic, water and shoyu. Bring to a boil./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a skillet, heat the oil. Season the pork butt with salt and brown it well on all sides over high heat, 12 minutes; transfer to the stockpot. Simmer the broth over moderately low heat for 2 hours, until the pork butt and ribs are just tender; skim any scum that rises to the surface. Transfer the pork butt and ribs to a platter and refrigerate. Strain the broth and discard the remaining solids./nStep 3: Return the broth to the pot. Add the kombu and simmer over moderately low heat for 1 hour and 30 minutes. Let cool, then chill and refrigerate the broth overnight./nStep 4: Preheat the broiler. Skim the fat off of the broth and discard the kombu. Bring the broth to a simmer. Season with shoyu and keep hot./nStep 5: Untie the pork butt and slice it across the grain 1/3 inch thick. Cut the ribs between the bones. Arrange the pork slices and ribs on a large baking sheet and brush with shoyu. Broil 8 inches from the heat for 3 minutes, turning once, until the meat is crisp; keep warm./nStep 6: Divide the cooked noodles among 8 bowls and ladle 1 1/2 cups of broth into each one. Add the spinach in piles. Drain the eggs, cut each one in half lengthwise and set a half in each bowl. Arrange 2 slices of pork butt and 1 rib in each bowl and garnish with the scallions and nori. Serve the ramen immediately, passing the rice vinegar and togarashi at the table./nStep 7: The broth can be refrigerated for up to 3 days or frozen for up to 2 months; discard the kombu after 1 day./nStep 8: Variations Stir 1/2 teaspoon white miso, 1/2 teaspoon Madras curry paste or 2 teaspoons coarsely ground toasted sesame seeds into each serving of broth before adding the toppings.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons canola oil/n5 garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n2 tablespoons chopped peeled fresh ginger/n3/4 pound ground pork/n1 pound red kale (2 bunches), stemmed and leaves torn into large pieces (16 cups)/n1 tablespoon Asian fish sauce/n1 cup mixed chopped basil and cilantro/nKosher salt/nPepper/nSteamed rice and Sriracha, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large nonstick skillet, heat the canola oil. Add the garlic, ginger and pork and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until the pork is just cooked through, 3 minutes. In batches, add the kale and stir-fry until tender, about 5 minutes. Stir in the fish sauce and herbs and season with salt and pepper. Serve with rice and Sriracha.

Ingredients: 2 pounds medium Yukon Gold potatoes/n1 1/2 pounds fresh chorizo, casings removed (see Note)/n1 large onion, finely chopped/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n8 large eggs/nToast and hot sauce, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375°. Put the potatoes in a large saucepan and cover with cold water. Bring to a boil and cook over moderate heat until tender, about 25 minutes; drain and let cool. Peel the potatoes and cut them into 3/4-inch pieces./nStep 2: Meanwhile, heat a 12-inch cast-iron skillet. Add the chorizo, break it into chunks with a wooden spoon and cook over moderate heat, turning, until cooked through and lightly browned, about 8 minutes. Add the onion and cook, stirring, until softened, about 5 minutes. Scrape the chorizo mixture into a bowl and wipe out the skillet./nStep 3: Heat the oil in the skillet. Add the potatoes, season with salt and pepper and cook over moderate heat, turning occasionally, until golden and crispy, about 6 minutes. Stir in the chorizo mixture. Remove the skillet from the heat./nStep 4: Using a ladle, make 8 indentations in the potato-chorizo mixture about 1 inch apart; crack an egg into each one. Bake the skillet in the middle of the oven for about 12 minutes, or until the egg whites are just set but the yolks are still runny. Serve at once with toast and hot sauce./nStep 5: The potatoes can be boiled a day ahead and refrigerated./nStep 6: Spicy fresh chorizo, which looks a lot like Italian sausage links, is available at Whole Foods markets and many Latin American food stores.

Ingredients: 1 (1 1/2-pound) bunch collard greens/n1 tablespoon olive oil/n4 bacon slices/n2 large yellow onions, thinly sliced (about 5 cups)/n4 large garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n1 pound smoked ham hocks, at room temperature/n1/4 cup (2 ounces) bourbon or other whiskey/n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar/n8 cups cold water/n4 teaspoons kosher salt/n1/2 teaspoon black pepper/n1/4 cup lower-sodium soy sauce/n12 ounces uncooked instant ramen noodles, cooked/n4 large hard-cooked eggs, peeled and halved/n8 scallions, thinly sliced/n1 lime, cut into wedges/n2 teaspoons shichimi togarashi
Steps: Step 1: Using a sharp knife, remove stems from collard greens. Cut leaves into 2-inch squares (about 14 cups), and rinse in cold water./nStep 2: Heat olive oil in a 4-quart stockpot over medium. Add bacon; cook until crisp, about 10 minutes. Transfer bacon to paper towels to drain, reserving drippings in pot. Crumble bacon, and set aside./nStep 3: Add onions and garlic to hot drippings in pot, and cook over mediumv, stirring often, until golden brown, about 25 minutes. Add ham hocks, and cook until browned on all sides, about 5 minutes, turning ham hocks every 45 seconds. Add bourbon and vinegar, and cook, stirring and scraping up browned bits on bottom of pot, until liquid is reduced by half, about 30 seconds. Add 8 cups cold water; bring to a simmer./nStep 4: Add salt and pepper to soup. Add collards in large handfuls, stirring each addition until wilted, 2 to 3 minutes, before adding next handful. Return to a simmer; cover and cook until collards are tender, about 1 hour./nStep 5: Remove ham hocks; cool slightly. Pull meat from bones, and chop meat. Discard bones and skin./nStep 6: Divide soy sauce evenly among 4 serving bowls. Ladle 1 1/4 cups liquid from cooked collards into each bowl. Divide noodles evenly among 4 bowls, and stir noodles twice in broth to combine./nStep 7: Top bowls evenly with ham hock meat, collards, eggs, bacon, scallions, lime wedges, and shichimi togarashi.

Ingredients: 1 ball Artisan Pizza Dough/nAll-purpose flour, for dusting/nSemolina flour, for dusting/n3 tablespoons crème fraîche/n4  smashed cloves of Garlic Confit (see Note)/n2 ounces thinly sliced potato/n¾ ounce caramelized onions/n¼ ounce cooked crumbled bacon/n6  baby kale leaves/nChopped fresh chives, for garnishing
Steps: Step 1: Let chilled covered dough stand at room temperature until dough is cool (not cold) and a fingerprint remains when dough is pressed, 1 to 2 hours. Transfer 1 dough ball to a heavily floured surface. Using floured fingertips, firmly press all over dough, leaving a 1/2-inch border./nStep 2: If cooking in your home oven, preheat to 500°F with a baking steel or large round cast-iron pizza pan (such as Lodge 15-inch) on middle rack. Let pan preheat in oven for about 30 minutes. If using an outdoor pizza oven, preheat pizza oven and pizza stone according to manufacturer's instructions on high 20 minutes. (Note: Cooking with wood takes more experience to control the heat, so we've only included instructions for gas oven cooking here.)/nStep 3: Form a C-shape with the outer edge of your hand, and press firmly inside dough border to define a 1/2-inch wide ring around edge of dough. Lift dough onto the knuckles of both hands, and gently stretch, rotating dough after each stretch to maintain its round shape. Continue gently stretching dough, allowing gravity to help it expand, until a 10-inch circle of even thickness forms, with a slightly thicker outer ring. Lay dough round on a semolina-dusted pizza peel, reshaping as needed to form a circle. Spread dough round with crème fraîche and 4 smashed garlic confit. Layer with potato, onions, bacon, and baby kale./nStep 4: Gently shake pizza peel with prepared pie to loosen. If pizza feels stuck in any areas, carefully lift pizza edge with a bench scraper, and dust peel with a 1:1 mixture of semolina and bread flour. Unload pizza onto preheated pan in home oven, or into stone in outdoor pizza oven using quick, decisive movements: Set the peel edge on the pan at about a 20-degree angle, and quickly pull back peel to slide half of the pizza onto the pan. Gently shake the peel side to side while pulling it back to slide the rest of the pizza onto the pan, allowing it to stretch slightly./nStep 5: If baking in a home oven, bake at 500°F until edges of crust have puffed slightly, about 3 minutes. Rotate pan 90 degrees, and increase oven temperature to broil. Broil until pizza is cooked through and crust is browned, 3 to 6 minutes. If baking in an outdoor pizza oven, cook pizza, using peel to rotate pizza 90 degrees every 20 to 30 seconds, until cooked through and crust is risen and charred in spots, 2 to 4 minutes./nStep 6: Using peel, transfer pizza to a cutting board. Garnish with chives, and cut into wedges./nStep 7: Get the Recipe: Garlic Confit

Ingredients: 6 cloves garlic (unpeeled)/n2  Vidalia onions (large; 1 1/ pounds peeled and quartered through the core)/n1 ¼ cups vegetable oil (plus more for brushing)/n½ cup apple cider vinegar/n¼ cup lemon juice (freshly squeezed)/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground pepper/n10 cups mixed lettuces (lightly packed; 8 ounces)/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground pepper/n2 cups cooked chicken (shredded)/n1 cup corn kernels (cooked fresh or thawed frozen)/n1 cup buckwheat or radish sprouts/n4 ounces blue cheese (1 cup crumbled)/n½ cup cooked bacon (crumbled)/n1  Hass avocado (peeled and diced)/n1  tomato (medium diced)/n½ cup toasted pecans (chopped)/n2  hard-cooked eggs (peeled and sliced lengthwise)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 425°F. Wrap garlic cloves in foil and set on a rimmed baking sheet. Brush onions with oil and arrange on the baking sheet. Bake for about 1 hour, until onions and garlic are lightly charred and soft. Let cool./nStep 2: Peel garlic and transfer cloves to a blender. Add onions, cider vinegar and lemon juice and puree until smooth. With blender on, gradually add vegetable oil until incorporated. Season dressing with salt and pepper./nStep 3: In a large bowl, toss lettuces with 1/2 cup of the dressing and season with salt and pepper. Transfer to a serving bowl or platter. Arrange remaining ingredients on top and serve, passing remaining dressing at the table./nStep 4: The onion dressing can be refrigerated for up to 4 days./nStep 5: Medium-bodied Sauvignon Blanc has enough heft to go with ingredients like bacon and eggs and enough brightness to stand up to vinegary dressings. Pour a Sancerre.

Ingredients: 8 slices of thick-cut bacon/n1/3 cup packed light brown sugar/nKosher salt/nPepper/n1/3 cup plus 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1 medium fennel bulb—halved, cored and very thinly sliced/n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard/n1 1/2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1 1/2 tablespoons sherry vinegar/n8 ounces baby spinach (12 cups)/n2 cups lightly packed basil leaves/n4 ounces French feta cheese, crumbled
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375°. In a large bowl, coat the bacon with the brown sugar and 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Arrange the bacon in an even layer on a parchment paper–lined baking sheet. Top with another piece of parchment paper and another large baking sheet. Bake for about 25 minutes, until the bacon is lightly browned and the fat is rendered. Remove the top baking sheet and parchment paper. Bake the bacon for about 15 minutes longer, until well browned and nearly crisp. Using tongs, transfer the bacon to a rack to cool and crisp, then coarsely chop./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of the oil. Add the fennel and a generous pinch each of salt and pepper. Cook over moderately high heat, stirring occasionally, until just softened and lightly browned, about 4 minutes. Transfer to a plate and let cool./nStep 3: In a large serving bowl, whisk the mustard with the lemon juice and vinegar. Gradually whisk in the remaining 1/3 cup of oil until emulsified. Season the dressing with salt and pepper. Add the fennel, spinach and basil to the bowl and toss well. Season with salt and pepper and toss again. Sprinkle the feta and candied bacon on top and serve right away./nStep 4: Minerally Chardonnay.

Ingredients: 8 ounces fresh asparagus, trimmed and sliced diagonally into 1-inch pieces (about 2 cups)/n.50 cup shelled fresh fava beans (about 3 ounces)/nAll-purpose flour, for dusting/n1  (14-ounce) package frozen puff pastry (such as Dufour), thawed/n1  large egg, beaten/n1 cup whole-milk ricotta cheese/n3 ounces Parmesan cheese, grated (about 3/4 cup), divided, plus more for garnish/n1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon grated lemon zest/n1 teaspoon fresh thyme leaves/n.50 teaspoon flaky sea salt/n¼ teaspoon black pepper, plus more for garnish/n4  prosciutto slices (about 2 ounces), torn into strip/nFresh mint leaves, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Place an inverted large rimmed baking sheet on middle oven rack, and preheat oven to 425°F. Do not remove baking sheet while oven preheats. Fill a large bowl with ice water; set aside. Bring a large saucepan of salted water to a boil over high. Add asparagus and fava beans; cook 1 minute. Drain in a colander. Place colander in bowl of ice water; set aside./nStep 2: Lightly flour a large sheet of parchment paper. Roll out puff pastry on parchment paper into a 16-x 12-inch rectangle, dusting pastry with flour as needed to prevent sticking. Brush off excess flour from pastry. Using a pizza cutter, cut 1/2-inch-wide strips from perimeter of pastry; set strips aside. Lightly brush some of the beaten egg around pastry perimeter. Gently and loosely twist each pastry strip. Return pastry twists to pastry perimeter, placing on top of brushed egg and pressing gently into pastry base to seal. Trim any overhang from twists. Using a fork, prick the flat pastry surface 40 times; lightly brush with additional beaten egg. Slide parchment with pastry onto an 18-x 13-inch rimmed baking sheet. Using a paring knife, lightly score interior perimeter of pastry just inside twist border. Freeze 10 minutes./nStep 3: Meanwhile, drain asparagus mixture, and pat dry; set aside. Stir together ricotta, 1/4 cup Parmesan, lemon zest, thyme, salt, pepper, and remaining beaten egg in a medium bowl; set aside./nStep 4: Remove baking sheet with pastry from freezer, and place on top of preheated inverted baking sheet in oven. Bake until puffed and lightly browned, 12 to 15 minutes. Remove from oven. Reduce oven temperature to 375°F/nStep 5: Using a small offset spatula, gently spread ricotta mixture over puffed par-baked pastry, pressing gently to slightly flatten; sprinkle with remaining 1/2 cup Parmesan. Top evenly with asparagus and fava beans; drape with prosciutto slices. Immediately return to oven, and bake at 375°F until filling is set, about 10 minutes. Let cool 10 minutes. Garnish with mint, pepper, and Parmesan./nStep 6: Asparagus and fava beans can be blanched 1 day ahead and stored in an airtight container in refrigerator./nStep 7: Crisp, spicy Grüner Veltliner: 2018 Nikolaihof Hefeabzug.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n3 garlic cloves, peeled/n2 celery ribs, finely chopped/n2 carrots, finely chopped/n1 onion, finely chopped/nOne 16-ounce can whole tomatoes, chopped and juices reserved/n1 bay leaf/n1 cup green or brown lentils/n3/4 pound smoked turkey wing and thigh/n4 small red potatoes, peeled and sliced 1/4 inch thick/n1/4 cup chopped flat-leaf parsley/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/nFreshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, heat the oil. Add the garlic, celery, carrots and onion and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until softened, 7 minutes. Add the tomatoes, bay leaf, lentils, smoked turkey and 2 quarts of water and bring to a boil. Cover partially and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the lentils are very tender, 1 hour. Add the potatoes and simmer until tender, 10 minutes./nStep 2: Remove the turkey meat from the bones and return it to the soup; discard the skin, bones and bay leaf. Add the parsley and season the soup with salt and pepper. Ladle the soup into bowls and serve, passing the cheese at the table./nStep 3: The lentil soup can be refrigerated for up to 3 days./nStep 4: Earthy and smoky, this soup could go with a full-bodied white or a lighter red. If guests prefer white, try a Vouvray; for a red, consider an Oregon Pinot Noir.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n5 pounds turkey legs with skin/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n6 large garlic cloves, finely chopped/n2 large onions, finely chopped/n3 tablespoons ancho chile powder/n2 tablespoons chipotle chile powder/n4 teaspoons ground cumin/n1/2 teaspoon ground cloves/nOne 28-ounce can crushed tomatoes/n1 quart water/nOne 2-pound butternut squash, peeled and cut into 1-inch dice/nTwo 15-ounce cans black beans, drained/n4 large poblano chiles—roasted, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch pieces/n1/4 cup tomato paste
Steps: Step 1: In a large enameled cast-iron casserole, heat the oil. Season the turkey with salt and pepper; cook over moderate heat until browned, 15 minutes. Transfer to a plate. Add the garlic and onions to the casserole and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until softened, 10 minutes. Add the ancho and chipotle chile powders, cumin and cloves and cook, stirring, for 5 minutes. Add the tomatoes and water; bring to a simmer./nStep 2: Return the turkey to the casserole; bring to a boil. Cover and simmer over low heat until tender, about 2 hours. Transfer the turkey to a plate and let cool slightly. Discard the bones and skin and cut the meat into bite-size pieces./nStep 3: Skim the fat from the chili. Add the squash and turkey. Simmer over low heat until the squash is tender, 15 minutes. Add the beans and poblanos. Season with salt and pepper. Ladle 1 cup of chili into a bowl. Stir in the tomato paste until dissolved, then stir the chili back into the casserole. Simmer for 5 minutes, then serve in mugs or bowls./nStep 4: One Serving 398 calories, 9.2 gm total fat, 2.0 gm saturated fat, 42 gm carb./nStep 5: Cilantro leaves, low-fat sour cream and corn bread.

Ingredients: 8 garlic cloves, smashed and peeled/n2 tablespoons dried oregano/n1 tablespoon sweet paprika/n1 tablespoon pure ancho chile powder/n3/4 teaspoon curry powder/n1/2 tablespoon kosher salt/n2 tablespoons distilled white vinegar/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n2 pounds turkey cutlets/nVegetable oil, for brushing
Steps: Step 1: In a mini food processor, combine the garlic, oregano, paprika, chile powder, curry and salt and process until the garlic is chopped. Add the vinegar and olive oil and process to a paste./nStep 2: Rub the marinade onto the turkey cutlets and let stand at room temperature for at least 30 minutes or refrigerate for up to 24 hours./nStep 3: Light a grill. Scrape the marinade off of the turkey cutlets. Brush the cutlets with vegetable oil and grill over moderately high heat, turning once, until lightly charred and cooked through, about 5 minutes total. Serve hot./nStep 4: The marinade can be refrigerated for up to 3 days./nStep 5: Variation The marinade is also great for pork chops and pork tenderloin./nStep 6: Black beans and yellow rice./nStep 7: Tropical South African Chenin Blanc.

Ingredients: 1/2 pound thin rice noodles/n6 ounces low-fat firm tofu/n1/2 pound ground turkey/n3 tablespoons finely chopped water chestnuts/n2 scallions, finely chopped/n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger/n1/3 cup plus 1/2 cup chopped cilantro/n2 tablespoons low-sodium soy sauce/nSalt and freshly ground white pepper/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n2 shallots, thinly sliced/n7 cups chicken stock/n1 small red chile, minced/n2 teaspoons fresh lime juice/n1 teaspoon sugar/n1 pound baby bok choy, sliced crosswise into 1/4-inch strips/n1 tomato, cut into 1/2-inch dice
Steps: Step 1: In a large bowl, soak the rice noodles in hot water for 10 minutes, then drain. Cut the noodles into 4-inch lengths./nStep 2: In a medium bowl, mash the tofu until it resembles cottage cheese. Mix in the turkey, water chestnuts, scallions, ginger, 1/3 cup of the cilantro, 1 tablespoon of the soy sauce, 1/2 teaspoon of salt and 1/4 teaspoon of white pepper. Form into 1-inch balls and transfer to a plate. Cover with plastic and refrigerate./nStep 3: Heat the oil in a small skillet. Add the shallots and cook over moderate heat, stirring constantly, until golden, 7 to 8 minutes. Drain on paper towels./nStep 4: In a large saucepan, combine the stock with the chile, lime juice, sugar and the remaining 1 tablespoon of soy sauce. Season with salt and pepper and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to moderately low, add the meatballs and cook for 3 minutes. Stir in the bok choy and tomato and cook for 1 minute. Add the rice noodles and cook over moderate heat until slightly softened, about 2 minutes. Ladle the soup into bowls, garnish with the fried shallots and the remaining 1/2 cup of cilantro and serve./nStep 5: One Serving 440 calories, 9.0 gm total fat, 0.9 gm saturated fat, 57 gm carb.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon long-grain white rice/n1 tablespoon vegetable oil/n1 pound ground turkey/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons chicken stock or low-sodium broth 1 tablespoon plus 1 teaspoon/nAsian fish sauce/nSalt and freshly ground black pepper/n1 tablespoon fresh lime juice/n2 large stalks of lemongrass—tender pale inner core only, minced/n2 scallions, thinly sliced/n1 medium shallot, thinly sliced and separated into rings/n1/2 cup chopped cilantro/n1/2 cup chopped mint/n1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper/nSmall romaine or Belgian endive leaves and lime wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small skillet, toast the rice over high heat, shaking the skillet a few times, until the rice is golden brown, about 3 minutes. Transfer the rice to a spice grinder and let cool completely. Grind the rice to a powder./nStep 2: In a large skillet, heat the oil. Add the turkey and cook over moderately high heat, breaking up the meat evenly, until no pink remains, about 4 minutes. Add the stock and cook, stirring, until bubbling. Remove from the heat and stir in the fish sauce. Season with salt and black pepper and stir in the lime juice. Let stand for 5 minutes, then stir in the lemongrass, scallions, shallot rings, cilantro, mint, crushed red pepper and rice powder./nStep 3: Arrange the lettuce and lime wedges on a platter. Spoon the laap on top and serve./nStep 4: Rieslings from Australia's cool Eden Valley often have a distinctive lime flavor that goes nicely with the herbs and chiles used in this dish.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups kosher salt/n1 cup sugar/nOne 12- to 14-pound turkey—neck, wing tips and giblets reserved, cavity fat removed/n2 medium onions, coarsely chopped/n1 carrot, coarsely chopped/n1 celery rib, coarsely chopped/n3 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted
Steps: Step 1: In a large stockpot or plastic tub, mix 1 1/2 gallons of water with the salt and sugar; stir to dissolve the salt and sugar. Add the turkey to the brine, breast side down and refrigerate for 10 to 12 hours./nStep 2: Remove the turkey from the brine, rinse it in cold water and pat dry with paper towels. Discard the brine./nStep 3: Preheat the oven to 400°. Place half of the onions, carrot and celery in the turkey cavity. Using kitchen string, tie the turkey legs together, then bring the string around the turkey and tie the wings at the breast. Scatter the remaining onions, carrot and celery in a large roasting pan. Oil a V-shaped rack and set it in the pan. Transfer the turkey to the rack, breast side up. Brush the turkey with the melted butter. Pour 1 cup of water into the pan and roast the turkey for 45 minutes./nStep 4: Baste the turkey with the pan juices and add 1 more cup of water to the pan. Roast the turkey for about 1 hour and 45 minutes longer, basting it with the pan juices every 30 minutes or so and adding another 1/2 cup of water to the roasting pan whenever the vegetables begin to brown. (To ensure juicy breast meat, Anderson rotates the turkey a quarter turn each time she bastes it.) The turkey is done when an instant-read thermometer inserted in an inner thigh registers 170°. Transfer the turkey to a carving board, cover loosely with foil and let rest for 20 to 30 minutes before carving. Reserve the juices in the roasting pan for making the gravy./nStep 5: The turkey can be prepared through Step 2 and refrigerated for up to 8 hours.

Ingredients: 1/4 pound sliced bacon, cut crosswise into 1/4-inch strips/n1 onion, chopped/n1 tablespoon chili powder/n1/2 teaspoon unsweetened cocoa powder/n1/4 teaspoon Tabasco sauce/n2 teaspoons dried oregano/n2 teaspoons salt/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n1 3/4 cups canned crushed tomatoes in thick puree (one 15-ounce can)/n1 quart canned low-sodium chicken broth or homemade stock/n1 2/3 cups drained and rinsed canned black beans (one 15-ounce can)/n1 1-pound piece cooked deli turkey, cut into 1/2-by-1/2-by-1/4-inch slices/n10 ounces spinach, stems removed, leaves washed and cut crosswise into 1-inch strips
Steps: Step 1: In a large stainless-steel pot, cook the bacon until crisp. Remove with a slotted spoon and drain on paper towels. Pour off all but 1 tablespoon of fat from the pot./nStep 2: Reduce the heat to moderately low. Add the onion to the pot and cook, stirring, until translucent, about 5 minutes. Stir in the chili powder, cocoa, Tabasco sauce, oregano, salt, pepper, tomatoes, and broth. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer for 15 minutes./nStep 3: Add the black beans and turkey to the pot. Simmer for 5 minutes. Stir in the spinach and the bacon. Cook until the spinach just wilts, about 1 minute./nStep 4: VariationsUse smoked turkey in place of plain./nStep 5: Substitute 12/3 cups drained and rinsed kidney, pinto, or cannellini beans for the black beans./nStep 6: You need a lusty red wine with plenty of spiciness and fruit flavor to stand up to this powerful soup. That describes Zinfandel to a T, so try one here.

Ingredients: 1 stick unsalted butter, softened/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n1/2 cup minced shallots (2 large)/n3 tablespoons coarsely chopped thyme, plus 8 thyme sprigs/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/nOne 12-pound fresh turkey, rinsed and dried, neck and giblets reserved/n1/2 cup dry white wine/nAbout 2 1/2 cups chicken stock/n3 cups water/n1/4 cup Madeira/n2 teaspoons cornstarch mixed with 1 tablespoon water
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a small bowl, blend the butter with the soy sauce, 1/4 cup of the minced shallots, 2 tablespoons of the chopped thyme, 1/2 teaspoon salt and 1/4 teaspoon pepper. Separate the skin from the turkey breast and rub 2/3 of the shallot butter over the meat, then smooth out the breast skin. Rub the outside of the turkey with the remaining shallot butter and season liberally inside and out with salt and pepper. Tuck 5 of the thyme sprigs into the cavity./nStep 2: Pour the wine and 1/2 cup of the chicken stock into a roasting pan fitted with a V-shaped rack. Set the turkey on the rack and roast for 30 minutes. Baste with the pan juices. Roast the turkey for about 1 hour and 45 minutes longer, basting every 30 minutes and adding chicken stock to the pan as necessary; keep the pan moist throughout roasting so the drippings don't burn. If the turkey starts getting too dark, tent it loosely with foil. The turkey is done when an instant-read thermometer inserted in the inner thigh registers 165°. Transfer the turkey to a carving board and let rest for 20 to 30 minutes./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a medium saucepan, cover the turkey neck, heart and gizzard with the 3 cups of water. Add the remaining 3 thyme sprigs, season with salt and pepper and simmer for 20 minutes. Strain the turkey broth and reduce it to 2 1/4 cups./nStep 4: Pour the pan drippings into a fat separator; reserve 2 tablespoons of the fat and all the drippings. Add 1 1/4 cups of the turkey broth and the Madeira to the roasting pan; simmer, stirring to dissolve the browned bits; you should have 1 1/4 cups of jus./nStep 5: In a medium saucepan, heat the reserved turkey fat. Add the remaining 1/4 cup of shallots and cook over moderately high heat, stirring, until softened. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon of chopped thyme and cook for 1 minute longer. Stir in the jus, pan drippings and the remaining 1 cup of turkey broth and bring to a simmer. Stir in the cornstarch slurry and bring to a boil to thicken very lightly, then season with salt and pepper. Transfer to a gravy boat. Carve the turkey and serve with the gravy.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup dried porcini mushrooms (1/2 ounce)/n1 cup boiling water/n1/4 cup olive oil/n4 turkey drumsticks (about 3 pounds)/nSalt/n2 carrots, finely chopped/n1 onion, finely chopped/n2 cups red or white wine/n3 fresh thyme sprigs/n2 bay leaves/n3 bunches scallions, trimmed to 5 inches/n1/2 pound Portobello mushrooms, stems discarded, caps halved and sliced crosswise 1/4 inch thick/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a heatproof bowl, soak the porcini in the boiling water until softened, about 20 minutes. Rub them to loosen any grit and coarsely chop. Let the soaking liquid stand for 5 minutes, then pour it into a bowl, leaving any grit behind./nStep 2: Heat 2 tablespoons of the oil in an enameled cast-iron casserole. Add the drumsticks, season with salt and brown on all sides over moderately high heat, about 10 minutes. Transfer to a plate. Add the carrots and onion to the casserole, season with salt and cook, stirring, until lightly browned, 8 to 10 minutes./nStep 3: Return the drumsticks to the pan. Add the wine, porcini and their soaking liquid, thyme and bay leaves and bring to a boil. Cover and simmer over low heat until the turkey is falling off the bones, about 3 hours; turn them 2 or 3 times during cooking. Discard the thyme and bay leaves./nStep 4: Heat the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil in a medium skillet. Add the scallions, season with salt and cook over moderately high heat until softened and lightly browned, 3 to 5 minutes. Transfer the scallions to a plate. Add the Portobellos to the skillet, season with salt and cook over high heat, turning them once, until softened and golden, 5 to 8 minutes./nStep 5: Cut the turkey meat off the bone into large pieces, and discard the sticklike tendons. Boil the cooking liquid until it lightly coats a spoon, 10 to 15 minutes. Add the Portobellos; season with pepper./nStep 6: Put the turkey into soup plates and spoon the Portobellos and sauce on top. Arrange the scallions alongside and serve./nStep 7: Steamed rice./nStep 8: The richness of this dish points to a full-flavored red of equal intensity, like a Merlot.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup dry bread crumbs/n1 1/2 teaspoons dried sage/n1/4 cup chopped fresh parsley/n3 tablespoons melted butter/n3/4 teaspoon salt/n1 2-pound boneless, skinless turkey breast/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n1 tablespoon Dijon mustard
Steps: Step 1: Heat the oven to 450°. In a small bowl, combine the bread crumbs, sage, parsley, butter, and 1/4 teaspoon of the salt./nStep 2: Season the turkey breast with the remaining 1/2 teaspoon salt and the pepper. Set the turkey breast in a roasting pan and then brush the top and the sides of the breast with the mustard. Pat the seasoned bread crumbs onto the mustard./nStep 3: Roast the turkey for 20 minutes. Reduce the oven temperature to 375° and continue to roast the turkey breast until just done, 15 to 20 minutes longer. Transfer the turkey to a carving board and leave to rest in a warm spot for about 10 minutes. Cut the turkey into slices./nStep 4: Test-Kitchen Tip Sometimes boneless turkey breasts come rolled and tied like a roast. For this preparation, you'll want to unroll the breast and put it flat in the roasting pan, thereby cutting the cooking time significantly./nStep 5: A moist and creamy side dish—mashed potatoes or sweet potatoes, baked squash, or creamed corn or spinach—is the perfect foil for the turkey./nStep 6: The mild flavors of this dish provide an opportunity to explore a full-flavored red wine. Try a bottle of easy-to-like, easy-to-drink Zinfandel from California or a Shiraz from Australia.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons butter/n1 onion, cut into thin slices/n1 1/2 teaspoons dried sage/n1 pound sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch cubes/n1 1/2 quarts canned low-sodium chicken broth or homemade stock/n2 teaspoons salt/n1/4 pound green beans, cut into 1/4-inch pieces/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper/n1 pound turkey cutlets, cut into approximately 1 1/2-by-1/2-inch strips
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, melt the butter over moderately low heat. Add the onion and sage and cook, stirring occasionally, until the onion is translucent, about 5 minutes./nStep 2: Add the sweet potatoes, broth, and 1 teaspoon of the salt. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer until the sweet potatoes are tender, about 10 minutes./nStep 3: Transfer half the soup to a food processor or blender and puree. Return the pureed soup to the pot and add the green beans, the remaining teaspoon salt, and the pepper. Simmer until the beans are just tender, about 8 minutes./nStep 4: Stir in the strips of turkey. Cook until the turkey is just done, about 1 1/2 minutes./nStep 5: Turkey OptionsIf you like, buy a three-quarter-pound piece of cooked turkey breast from the deli to use instead of the turkey cutlets. Cut the turkey into half-inch cubes and heat it in the soup briefly. Another option is to use leftover cooked turkey or chicken. About two cups of cubed leftovers should do it./nStep 6: Sweet wines are said not to work at the table, but when the dish contains sweet elements, the wine often should, too. A cool glass of succulent Auslese Riesling from the Rheingau will prove the point quite elegantly.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 tablespoons unsalted butter/n1 onion, finely chopped/n1 pound ground lamb/n2 garlic cloves, minced/n1/4 teaspoon ground cinnamon/n1/4 teaspoon ground cardamom/n1/4 teaspoon ground allspice/n1 1/2 cups jasmine rice/nOne 15-ounce can chickpeas, drained/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper/n1 cup turkey stock or low-sodium chicken broth/n1 cup water/n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 cup pine nuts
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, melt the butter. Add the onion and cook over moderate heat until softened, about 4 minutes. Add the lamb, garlic, cinnamon, cardamom and allspice and cook, stirring, until the lamb is no longer pink and the liquid has evaporated, about 4 minutes. Add the rice and chickpeas along with 2 teaspoons of salt and a pinch of pepper and cook, stirring, until evenly coated. Add the stock and water and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over low heat until the rice is tender, about 20 minutes. Remove from the heat, cover and let stand for 10 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, heat the oil in a small skillet. Add the pine nuts and cook over moderate heat, stirring constantly, until browned, about 4 minutes. Transfer the pine nuts to a plate and season with salt./nStep 3: Fluff the rice and transfer it to a bowl. Sprinkle the toasted pine nuts over the dressing and serve./nStep 4: The dressing can be refrigerated overnight. Rewarm in a 300° oven before serving.

Ingredients: Three 1-pound squabs/n2 tablespoons grapeseed oil/n1 large onion, chopped/n1 fennel bulb—halved, cored and chopped/n1/4 cup dry red wine/n1 Bosc pear—peeled, halved, cored and coarsely chopped/n1 teaspoon whole black peppercorns/n1 thyme sprig/n1 bay leaf/n1 cup heavy cream/nSalt/n4 cups boiling water/n1/2 cup bulgur/n3/4 cup farro/nFreshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. Using a sharp knife, cut the breasts off the squabs and transfer to a plate, cover with plastic and refrigerate. In a small roasting pan, roast the carcasses for about 30 minutes, until golden. Turn off the oven./nStep 2: In a large pot, heat 1 tablespoon of the grapeseed oil. Add the chopped onion and fennel and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until tender and lightly browned, about 15 minutes. Add the wine and cook until evaporated. Add the pear, peppercorns, thyme sprig, bay leaf and roast squab carcasses, along with any fat in the pan. Add 8 cups of room-temperature water and bring to a boil. Simmer over moderate heat, skimming, until the stock has reduced by half, about 1 1/2 hours. Strain the stock into a large saucepan and simmer over moderate heat until it is reduced to 1 cup, about 30 minutes./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a small saucepan, simmer the cream until reduced to 1/2 cup, about 15 minutes. Whisk the cream into the reduced stock and season with salt; keep warm./nStep 4: In a large heatproof bowl, pour the boiling water over the bulgur; cover and let stand until tender, about 30 minutes. In a large saucepan of salted boiling water, cook the farro until al dente, about 30 minutes. Drain the farro and bulgur, shaking out excess water./nStep 5: Add the farro and bulgur to the cream-stock mixture and cook over moderate heat until thick and porridge-like, about 5 minutes. Season with salt and pepper and keep warm./nStep 6: Reheat the oven to 400°. Season the squab breasts with salt and pepper. In a large ovenproof skillet, heat the remaining 1 tablespoon of grapeseed oil until shimmering. Add the breasts, skin side down, and cook over high heat until lightly browned, about 2 minutes.
