Add the beef, black pepper, and 1/2 teaspoon of the salt; cook, stirring to crumble, until browned, about 5 minutes./nStep 2: Preheat the broiler with the oven rack 3 to 4 inches from the heat. Reduce the stovetop heat to medium and stir in the macaroni. Add the milk, warm water, mustard, paprika, garlic powder, cayenne pepper, and remaining 1/2 teaspoon salt./nStep 3: Bring to a low simmer; cover, reduce the heat to low, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the macaroni is tender, about 12 minutes. Add the cheeses and cook, stirring constantly, until the cheeses melt. Stir in the chives. Sprinkle the panko over the macaroni mixture. Broil until the panko is golden brown, 1 to 2 minutes. Garnish with the scallion and serve immediately./nStep 4: Variation: Add some slices of jalapeño for an extra kick./nStep 5: Excerpted from Valerie’s Home Cooking by Valerie Bertinelli. Ingredients: 2 thick-cut slices of bacon, minced/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 cup minced carrot/n1/2 cup minced celery/n1/2 cup minced onion/n3 large garlic cloves, thinly sliced/nKosher salt/n1 pound ground veal/n1 sage sprig/n1 parsley sprig/n1 bay leaf/n2 teaspoons dried oregano, crumbled/n1 teaspoon dried basil, crumbled/n1 cup dry red wine/nOne 15-ounce can diced tomatoes/n2 1/2 cups chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n1/2 medium butternut squash—peeled, seeded and cut into 1/2-inch dice (3 cups)/n1/4 cup heavy cream/nFreshly ground white pepper/n1 pound rigatoni/nFinely chopped thyme, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a large enameled cast-iron casserole, cook the bacon in the oil over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the bacon is crisp, about 5 minutes. Add the carrot, celery, onion, garlic and a generous pinch of salt and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until just starting to brown, about 5 minutes. Add the ground veal, sage, parsley, bay leaf, oregano and basil and cook, breaking up the meat with a wooden spoon, until no pink remains, about 8 minutes./nStep 2: Add the wine to the casserole and cook, stirring, until nearly evaporated, about 3 minutes. Add the tomatoes with their juices and cook, stirring, until the liquid has reduced by half, about 4 minutes. Add the stock and bring to a simmer. Cook over moderately low heat, stirring occasionally, until slightly reduced, about 8 minutes. Stir in the squash and simmer, stirring occasionally, until the squash is tender, about 25 minutes. Discard the sage, parsley and bay leaf. Stir in the heavy cream and season the sauce with salt and white pepper; keep warm over very low heat./nStep 3: In a large pot of salted boiling water, cook the pasta until al dente. Drain well and transfer the pasta to deep bowls. Spoon the sauce over the pasta, garnish with thyme and serve./nStep 4: The Bolognese sauce can be refrigerated for up to 2 days. Reheat gently before serving.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n2 ounces pancetta, diced/n3 garlic cloves, peeled/n1/4 teaspoon crushed red pepper/n1/4 cup vodka/n1 tablespoon tomato paste/nOne 35-ounce can whole peeled Italian tomatoes with their juices, crushed by hand/nPinch of sugar/n2 basil sprigs/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n1/4 cup heavy cream
Steps: Step 1: In a large saucepan, heat the oil. Sauté the pancetta, garlic and crushed red pepper over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until golden, about 5 minutes. Deglaze with vodka. Add the tomato paste and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Add the canned tomatoes with their juices. Stir in the sugar and basil, season with salt and pepper and bring to a boil. Simmer the sauce over low heat, stirring occasionally, until it thickens and is reduced to 3 cups, about 30 minutes. Season again with salt and pepper. Discard the basil sprigs and garlic. Add heavy cream and simmer for 5 minutes/nStep 2: The sauce can be refrigerated for up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon olive oil/n1 chicken (3 to 3 1/2 pounds), cut into 8 pieces/n1 1/2 teaspoons salt/n1 onion, chopped/n4 cloves garlic, chopped/n1 tablespoon chopped fresh ginger/n1/2 teaspoon paprika/n3/4 teaspoon ground cumin/n1/2 teaspoon dried oregano/n1/4 teaspoon cayenne/n1/4 teaspoon ground turmeric/n1 1/2 cups canned low-sodium chicken broth or homemade stock/n1 cup canned crushed tomatoes in thick puree/n1 cup canned chickpeas, drained and rinsed/n1 zucchini, cut into 1/4-inch slices/n3 tablespoons chopped fresh parsley/n1 tablespoon lemon juice/n4 cups cooked couscous
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, heat the oil over moderately high heat. Season the chicken pieces with 1/4 teaspoon of the salt and add them to the pot. Cook, turning, until browned, about 8 minutes in all. Remove. Pour off all but 1 tablespoon fat from the pot./nStep 2: Reduce the heat to moderately low. Add the onion to the pot and cook, stirring occasionally, until translucent, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic, ginger, paprika, cumin, oregano, cayenne, and turmeric and cook, stirring, for 30 seconds./nStep 3: Add the broth, tomatoes, and the remaining 1 1/4 teaspoons of salt, scraping the bottom of the pot to dislodge any browned bits. Add the chicken thighs and drumsticks. Bring to a simmer and cook, covered, for 10 minutes. Add the chicken breasts with any accumulated juices, the chickpeas, and the zucchini and bring back to a simmer. Cook, covered, until the chicken and zucchini are just done, about 12 minutes longer. Add the parsley and lemon juice and serve over the couscous./nStep 4: The aromatic spices in this dish are best with an assertive, flavorful wine; color is almost secondary. For a red, try a wine from the indigenous South African grape, Pinotage. For white, try a Tokay Pinot Gris from Alsace in France.

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1 pound pork loin, cut into 1 1/2-by-1/4-inch strips/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n3 garlic cloves, minced/nLarge pinch of crushed red pepper/n1 large leek—halved and cut into 1-inch pieces/n1 cup chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n1/2 pound firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes/n1/4 cup hoisin sauce/n2 teaspoons sherry vinegar/n1/2 teaspoon Asian sesame oil
Steps: Step 1: In a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil. Add the pork, season with salt and pepper and stir-fry over high heat until cooked, 2 minutes. Transfer to a plate. Add the remaining vegetable oil to the skillet. Add the garlic and crushed pepper and stir-fry for 1 minute. Add the leek and 1/4 cup of the stock, cover and cook until the leek is softened, 2 minutes. Add the remaining 3/4 cup of stock and bring to a simmer. Add the tofu, then stir in the pork, hoisin, vinegar and sesame oil. Transfer to bowls and serve./nStep 2: Appley Riesling.

Ingredients: 3/4 pound firm tofu, drained/n2 tablespoons sesame seeds/n1 tablespoon sesame oil/n1 tablespoon vegetable oil/n1 head of bok choy (about 3/4 pound), leaves and stalks sliced crosswise 1 inch thick/n4 cups bean sprouts (9 ounces)/n1 teaspoon crushed or grated chicken bouillon cube/nSalt and freshly ground pepper
Steps: Step 1: Wrap the tofu in paper towels and drain in a strainer set over a bowl for 30 minutes. In a skillet, toast the sesame seeds over moderate heat until fragrant, 1 minute. Let cool, then grind to a coarse powder./nStep 2: In a large skillet, heat the sesame oil. Add the drained tofu, breaking it up into chunks with a spoon, and stir-fry over moderately high heat until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Transfer the tofu to a plate./nStep 3: In the same skillet, heat the vegetable oil. Add the bok choy and stir-fry over moderately high heat until tender, 5 minutes. Add the bean sprouts and stir-fry until heated through. Stir in the tofu and season with the bouillon cube, salt and pepper. Transfer to a bowl and garnish with the sesame seeds./nStep 4: This dish's delicate flavors pair nicely with a nuanced sake, such as Chikurin's floral, peachy Karoyaka Junmai Ginjo.

Ingredients: 2 (14-ounce) package soft tofu/n1 cup packed dark brown sugar/n.6666 cup Korean soy sauce (such as Sempio)/n½ cup mirin/n1 cup plus 3 Tbsp. water, divided/n¼ cup rice vinegar/n2 tablespoons gochugaru/n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n1 tablespoon finely chopped garlic/n1 ½ teaspoon finely chopped peeled fresh ginger/n1 ¾ cups plus 2 Tbsp. cornstarch, divided/n2 tablespoons kosher salt/n1 ½ tablespoons baking powder, divided/nVegetable oil, for frying/n¾ cup white rice flour (not sweet)/n½ cup vodka/n½ cup thinly sliced scallions/n2 tablespoons sesame seeds
Steps: Step 1: Slice tofu blocks into 1-inch cubes (about 60 cubes). Arrange tofu in an even layer on a baking sheet lined with paper towels. Let drain at least 15 minutes or upto 1 hour. Place paper towels on top of drained tofu, and press lightly to remove additional moisture./nStep 2: While tofu drains, stir together brown sugar, soy sauce, mirin, 1/2 cup water, vinegar, gochugaru, sesame oil, garlic, and ginger in a medium saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium. While mixture comes to a boil, whisk together 3 tablespoons water and 2 tablespoons cornstarch in a small bowl to make a slurry. When brown sugar mixture comes to a boil, reduce heat to medium-low, and stir in slurry. Simmer, stirring occasionally, until sauce thickens and reaches a maple syrup–like consistency, 2 to 3 minutes. Remove from heat./nStep 3: Stir together 1 cup cornstarch, salt, and 1 tablespoon baking powder in a medium bowl. Using a pastry brush, dust tofu cubes with cornstarch mixture. Place dusted tofu cubes on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper; refrigerate until ready to fry./nStep 4: Place a wire rack on a baking sheet; set aside. Pour vegetable oil to a depth of 4 inches in a heavy saucepan, and heat over medium until oil reaches 350°F. Whisk together rice flour, remaining 3/4 cup cornstarch, and remaining 1/2 tablespoon baking powder in a medium bowl. Whisk vodka and remaining 1/2 cup water into rice flour mixture until batter is completely smooth./nStep 5: Preheat oven to 200°F. Working in batches of about 15 cubes and working with 1 cube at a time, use your hand to gently dip 1 dusted tofu cube into batter to coat. Gently place in hot oil, keeping cubes separated to prevent sticking. When tofu floats to the surface and is golden and crispy, 5 to 6 minutes, use a spider or slotted spoon to transfer to prepared wire rack. Place in preheated oven to keep warm while frying remaining tofu./nStep 6: Rewarm sauce over low. Transfer fried tofu to a large heatproof bowl. Add 1 to 1 1/2 cups of warm sauce to tofu and, using tongs, gently turn tofu to coat, adding more sauce as desired. Using spider, lift glazed tofu from bowl, allowing excess to drip back into bowl, and transfer to a plate. Sprinkle with scallions and sesame seeds, and serve with remaining sauce, if desired. Serve immediately./nStep 7: Sauce can be made up to 1 day ahead and stored in an airtight container in refrigerator./nStep 8: Find Korean soy sauce and gochugaru at Korean grocery stores or online at asianmart.com.

Ingredients: 1 14-ounce package extra-firm tofu, drained/n1 teaspoon garlic powder/n1 teaspoon dried oregano/n1 teaspoon fresh or dried thyme/n5 tablespoons nutritional yeast, divided/n1 tablespoon olive oil/n1/2 yellow onion, cut into medium dice/n1/4 cup unsweetened oat milk/n1/2 cup shredded vegan cheese of your choice/nKosher salt/nGreens: chopped kale/spinach/Swiss chardHalved cherry tomatoesChopped fresh cilantroChopped fresh parsleyPinch of black salt (kala namak)Minced chivesSliced scallionsMicrogreen of your choice (I love pea shoots!)
Steps: Step 1: In a medium bowl, smash the tofu until it’s soft but still a bit chunky. Set aside./nStep 2: In a small bowl, combine the garlic powder, oregano, thyme, and 3 tablespoons of the nutritional yeast. Set the spice blend aside./nStep 3: In a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the onion and sauté for 2 minutes, or until softened. Soak in the heavenly smell!/nStep 4: In a small bowl, mix the remaining 2 tablespoons nutritional yeast with ¼ cup water. Add to the pan and stir to incorporate. Add tofu, the spice blend, salt to taste, the oat milk, and the vegan cheese and stir to combine./nStep 5: Increase the heat to medium-high and cook, stirring occasionally, for 5 minutes to meld the flavors and melt the cheese. Taste and adjust the flavors and salt as needed./nStep 6: Reduce the heat and mix in any additional ingredients, like veggies and fresh herbs. Remove from the heat and serve!/nStep 7: From Living Lively by Haile Thomas. Copyright © 2020 by Haile Thomas. Reprinted by permission of William Morrow, an imprint of HarperCollins Publishers.

Ingredients: 2 1/2 ounces shiitake mushrooms—stemmed, caps thinly sliced/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n1/2 teaspoon toasted sesame oil/n3 cups cooked sushi rice/n5 ounces firm tofu, sliced/n2 teaspoons unagi sauce (optional)/n1/3 cup shelled edamame/n5 ounces Manchego cheese, shredded (about 1 1/2 cups)/n1/2 cup soy bean sprouts/nKosher salt/nTogarashi and toasted white and black sesame seeds, for sprinkling/n1 cup large bonito flakes/n6 shiso leaves, thinly sliced/n1/4 cup cilantro leaves
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375º. In a bowl, toss the mushrooms and soy sauce. Let stand for 5 minutes; drain./nStep 2: In a 9-inch ovenproof nonstick skillet, heat the oils. Press the rice into the skillet, about 1/4 inch thick. Cook over moderately high heat until the bottom is golden, 10 minutes. Top with the tofu in a single layer and drizzle with unagi sauce. Top with the shiitake, edamame, cheese and bean sprouts and season with salt. Sprinkle with togarashi and sesame seeds./nStep 3: Transfer the skillet to the oven and bake on the top shelf for 15 minutes, until the top is golden. Slide the pizza onto a platter; top with the bonito, shiso and cilantro and serve./nStep 4: Sweet-salty unagi sauce is available at Japanese markets./nStep 5: Citrusy Belgian-style wheat: Hitachino Nest White Ale.

Ingredients: 1 cup rice/n2 tablespoons cooking oil/n1 pound boneless pork chops, cut into approximately 1 1/2-by-1/4-by-1/4-inch strips/n3 scallions, white bulbs and green tops chopped and reserved separately/n3 cloves garlic, minced/n1/4 teaspoon cayenne/n1/2 teaspoon paprika/n5 cups water/n2 ribs celery, sliced thin/n1 zucchini, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n3/4 teaspoon salt/n4 teaspoons soy sauce/n4 teaspoons Asian sesame oil/n1 teaspoon white- or rice-wine vinegar/n1 pound firm tofu, cut into 1/2-inch cubes/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper
Steps: Step 1: Bring a medium pot of salted water to a boil. Stir in the rice and boil until just done, 10 to 12 minutes. Drain./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large pot, heat the oil over moderately high heat. Add the pork, the scallion bulbs, the garlic, cayenne, and paprika and cook, stirring frequently, until the pork starts to brown, about 2 minutes./nStep 3: Add the water, celery, zucchini, and salt. Bring to a boil. Reduce the heat and simmer, partially covered, until the vegetables and pork are tender, 15 to 20 minutes. Stir in the soy sauce, sesame oil, vinegar, tofu, and pepper and cook for 5 minutes more./nStep 4: Stir the scallion tops into the soup. Put a mound of rice in the center of each of four bowls. Ladle the soup around the rice./nStep 5: Riesling wines and Asian flavors are truly a match made in heaven. Pay attention, however, to the degree of heat in the food; the more fire, the sweeter the wine should be to cool the burn. Here, a Spätlese, preferably from Germany's Pfalz, is in order.

Ingredients: 12 cups chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n1 pound honshimeji or cremini mushrooms—stems removed and reserved, caps thinly sliced/nOne 2-inch piece of ginger, thinly sliced/n2 large garlic cloves, crushed/nKosher salt/n6 skinless, boneless chicken thighs (about 1 3/4 pounds), trimmed and sliced into 1/4-inch strips/nOne 14-ounce package firm tofu, drained and cut into 1/2-inch dice/n4 scallions, thinly sliced/nAsian sesame oil, for drizzling
Steps: Step 1: In a large soup pot, bring the stock, mushroom stems, ginger and garlic to a simmer. Cook over low heat for 30 minutes. Strain the stock into a large bowl and return it to the pot. Season the broth with salt./nStep 2: Bring the broth to a boil; add the chicken. Cook until the chicken is white throughout, about 4 minutes. Divide the mushroom caps, tofu and scallions among eight soup bowls and serve, passing the broth and sesame oil at the table./nStep 3: The enriched broth can be refrigerated for up to 3 days./nStep 4: Light-bodied, unoaked Chardonnay from Italy.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n1 garlic clove, grated/n2 teaspoons grated peeled fresh ginger/n1 bunch scallions, white parts sliced, green parts thinly diagonally sliced, for garnish/n2 teaspoons chile bean sauce (toban djan) (such as Lee Kum Kee)/n1/4 cup junmai sake (such as Hakushika Junmai Yamadanishiki)/n2 tablespoons white miso/n4 cups warm Shiitake Dashi, divided/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n5 large Napa cabbage leaves, cut into 1 1/2-inch pieces/n3 ounces white beech mushrooms, trimmed and separated into clusters/n2 medium carrots, peeled (using a julienne peeler, if desired) and thinly diagonally sliced/n7 ounces firm silken tofu, drained and cut into 4 (1/2-inch-thick) slabs/nCoarsely ground toasted sesame seeds, chile oil, kurozu (Japanese black vinegar), and pickled shiitakes, for serving/n5 ounce fresh or thawed frozen ramen noodles (such as Sun Noodle), cooked according to package directions
Steps: Step 1: Heat sesame oil in a 3-quart classic-style donabe over medium. Add garlic, ginger, and white scallion pieces. Cook, stirring constantly, until softened and fragrant, about 2 minutes. Push mixture to 1 side of pot, and add chile bean sauce to empty side. Cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Stir in sake, incorporating garlic, ginger, and white scallion pieces; cook 1 minute. Whisk together miso and 1/4 cup shiitake dashi in a small bowl until smooth; set aside. Stir soy sauce and remaining 3 3/4 cups shiitake dashi into pot. Cover and bring to a simmer over medium-low./nStep 2: Uncover and stir in cabbage, mushrooms, and carrots. Add tofu. Cover and cook until tofu is heated through and vegetables are crisp-tender, 4 to 5 minutes. Stir in miso mixture. Using a spider or slotted spoon, divide vegetables and tofu between 2 serving bowls (about 2 cups each). Ladle about 1 cup of broth into each bowl; reserve remaining broth in donabe. Garnish with ground sesame seeds, chile oil, kurozu, pickled shiitakes, and green scallion pieces./nStep 3: Reheat remaining broth (about 1 1/2 cups) in donabe over medium-low until steaming. Add ramen to broth; let stand until heated through. Serve as second course with hot pot./nStep 4: Source chile bean sauce, junmai sake, and kurozu at Japanese grocery stores.

Ingredients: 4 ounces drained silken tofu/n1/2 cup full-fat Greek yogurt/n1 cup parsley leaves/n1/4 cup chopped chives/n3 drained boquerones (white anchovies) or oil-packed anchovies, drained and rinsed/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated fresh garlic/n1/2 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest plus 1 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/nKosher salt/nPepper/nRadishes and cucumber sticks, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a blender, combine the tofu, yogurt and 2 tablespoons of water and puree until smooth, scraping down the side. Add the parsley, chives, boquerones, garlic and lemon zest and juice and puree until smooth and well blended. Season with salt and pepper. Serve the dip with radishes and cucumber sticks./nStep 2: The dip can be refrigerated for 3 days.

Ingredients: 2 1/2 cups all-purpose flour, plus more for sprinkling/n1 cup water/nTwo 5-ounce bunches of watercress, tough stems discarded, leaves coarsely chopped/nOne 14-ounce block firm tofu, drained and finely diced/n2 scallions, minced/n2 garlic cloves, minced/n1/4 cup finely chopped water chestnuts/n1 teaspoon Asian sesame oil/n1 large egg/n1 teaspoon salt/n1/4 teaspoon white pepper/n1/4 cup vegetable oil
Steps: Step 1: Put the flour in a medium bowl. Add the water in a steady stream, stirring until a raggy dough forms. Turn the dough out on a work surface and knead until smooth, about 5 minutes. Sprinkle the dough with flour, cover loosely with plastic wrap and let stand at room temperature for 15 minutes./nStep 2: In a large skillet, cook the watercress over moderately high heat until wilted, about 2 minutes; squeeze out any liquid. Transfer to a large bowl and let cool. Add the tofu, scallions, garlic, water chestnuts, sesame oil, egg, salt and white pepper. Using your hands, knead the mixture to form a coarse paste./nStep 3: Line a baking sheet with wax paper and dust with flour. Quarter the dumpling dough. On a lightly floured work surface, roll each piece of dough into a 12-inch rope. Cut each rope into 12 pieces and roll into balls; sprinkle with flour. Working with 5 or 6 balls at a time, roll to 3 1/2-inch rounds. Brush the excess flour off of the rounds. Spoon 1 tablespoon of the filling onto the center of each round. Bring up the sides of the wrapper; press and pleat the edges to seal in the filling. Lift each dumpling by the pleated edge, transfer to the baking sheet and press down lightly to flatten. Repeat with the remaining dough./nStep 4: In a very large nonstick skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the oil. Arrange half of the dumplings in the pan, pleated edge up. Cook over high heat until the bottoms are lightly browned, about 2 minutes. Add 1/2 cup of water to the skillet, cover and cook until the water is evaporated and the dumplings are cooked through, about 5 minutes longer. Uncover and cook until the bottoms are well browned, about 1 minute longer. Transfer the dumplings to a plate. Cook the remaining dumplings in the remaining oil and serve./nStep 5: The uncooked dumplings can be frozen on a baking sheet, then transferred to a sealable plastic bag for up to 1 month. Cook from frozen./nStep 6: Dumpling Dipping Sauce.

Ingredients: ¼ cup all-purpose flour/n⅓ cup almond flour/n¼ cup bonito flakes (5 grams)/n1 tablespoon sugar/n3 tablespoons unsalted butter/nSalt/n6 ounces extra-firm silken tofu (drained)/n1 ½ tablespoons Dijon mustard/n¼ cup plus 1/2 teaspoon grapeseed or canola oil/n6 ounces shishito peppers (4 cups)/n2 cups baby mustard greens or mixed baby greens
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 325° and line a baking sheet with parchment paper. In a food processor or a blender, combine the flour, almond flour, bonito flakes and sugar and pulse until fine. Add the butter and pulse until the mixture resembles sand. Spread the mixture on the parchment and bake for about 20 minutes, stirring 2 or 3 times, until the sand is toasted and fragrant. Let cool completely, then rub the mixture between your fingers to break up any lumps. Season with salt./nStep 2: In a blender, combine the tofu and mustard and puree until smooth. Season with salt./nStep 3: Heat a large cast-iron skillet until very hot. Add the 1/4 cup of grapeseed oil and swirl to coat the pan. Add the shishito peppers and cook over high heat, turning, until tender and blistered in spots, 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer the peppers to a paper towel–lined plate and sprinkle with salt./nStep 4: In a medium bowl, toss the greens with the remaining 1/2 teaspoon of oil and season with salt./nStep 5: Spoon a tablespoon of the tofu mustard onto each plate and top with the peppers. Sprinkle with some of the bonito sand. Mound the greens on top and serve right away./nStep 6: The tofu mustard can be refrigerated for up to 3 days. The bonito sand can be kept in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

Ingredients: 1/2 pound dried pad Thai rice noodles (banh pho)/n1/4 cup soy sauce/n2 tablespoons light brown sugar/n1 tablespoons tamarind paste (see Note)/n1 tablespoon Sriracha or chile-garlic sauce/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n6 ounces smoked tofu, cut into 1/2-inch slices/n2 garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n2 small shallots, thinly sliced/n2 cups julienned carrots (from about 3/4 pound carrots)/n4 scallions, cut into 1-inch pieces/n2 large eggs, beaten/n1 cup bean sprouts/n1 lime, cut into 8 wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Put the noodles in a large bowl and cover with very hot water. Let soak until just pliable, about 15 minutes (or according to package directions). Drain the noodles in a colander, shaking off any excess water./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a small bowl, whisk the soy sauce with the brown sugar, tamarind paste and Sriracha./nStep 3: In a large nonstick wok or skillet, heat 1 tablespoon oil until shimmering. Add the tofu and cook until lightly browned on both sides. Transfer the tofu to a plate. Heat the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil. Add the garlic, shallots and carrots and cook over high heat, stirring occasionally, until lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Add the noodles and scallions and stir-fry until heated through, about 2 minutes./nStep 4: Scrape the noodles to one side of the pan and add the eggs. Cook, stirring occasionally, until nearly set, about 1 minute. Toss everything together. Add the sauce and tofu and stir-fry until the noodles are evenly coated and the sauce has thickened slightly, 2 to 3 minutes. Transfer the pad Thai to a platter. Garnish with the bean sprouts and serve with the lime wedges./nStep 5: Tamarind paste is available from Indian, Asian and Latin markets.

Ingredients: 1/2 pound firm tofu, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons soy sauce/n3/4 pound Chinese chow mein noodles or thin linguine/n1/2 cup creamy peanut butter/n1/2 cup chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n1 tablespoon rice vinegar/n3/4 teaspoon Chinese chile-garlic sauce/n1 tablespoon chopped fresh ginger/n1 garlic clove/n3/4 teaspoon Asian sesame oil/n2 large red bell peppers, thinly sliced/n3 large scallions, cut into 2-inch lengths and julienned/nCilantro sprigs, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a large bowl, toss the tofu with 2 tablespoons of the soy sauce and let stand for 10 minutes./nStep 2: Bring a large saucepan of water to a boil. Add the chow mein noodles and cook until they are al dente. Drain and rinse the noodles under cold water. Shake out the excess water and add the noodles to the tofu and soy sauce./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a blender, combine the remaining 1/4 cup of soy sauce with the peanut butter, chicken stock, rice vinegar, chile-garlic sauce, ginger, garlic and sesame oil and puree until a smooth sauce forms. Pour the peanut sauce over the noodles, add the sliced red bell peppers and scallions and toss. Garnish with cilantro and serve./nStep 4: Zesty Orvieto Classico.

Ingredients: 10 dried lily buds/n5 dried wood ear mushrooms/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n2 cloves garlic, minced/n2 stalks scallions, minced, plus more for garnish/n1 tablespoon minced ginger/n1 quart vegetable broth/n1 pound firm tofu, diced/n1/2 cup bamboo shoots, thinly sliced/n1/4 cup Chinese black vinegar, plus more to taste/n2 tablespoons soy sauce, plus more to taste/n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/nFresh ground black pepper/n1 teaspoon sugar/n1 tablespoon cornstarch/nChili oil, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, cover the lily buds with boiling water and let stand until softened, about 10 minutes. In another small bowl, cover the dried wood ear mushrooms with boiling water and let stand until softened, about 20 to 30 minutes. Rinse and coarsely chop./nStep 2: In a large pot, heat the oil over moderately high heat. Add the garlic, scallions and ginger and cook, stirring, for 1 minute./nStep 3: Add the vegetable broth and bring to a simmer. Measure out 1/4 cup of the broth and set aside in a small bowl. Add the lily buds, mushrooms, tofu, bamboo shoots, vinegar, soy sauce, sesame oil, pepper and sugar to the pot. Return the soup to a simmer./nStep 4: Stir the cornstarch into the reserved 1/4 cup of broth, then drizzle the mixture into the soup, stirring gently until slightly thickened, about 3 to 4 minutes./nStep 5: Taste and add more of the vinegar and soy sauce if desired. Divide into bowls and garnish with the scallions. Serve with chili oil./nStep 6: This soup can be made the day before./nStep 7: Lily buds, wood ear mushrooms, and Chinese black vinegar are available at Asian grocery stores.

Ingredients: 1/2 pound pork belly, cut into 1/2-inch pieces/nOne 1-pound jar kimchi, drained, 1/4 cup liquid reserved/n1/2 onion, thinly sliced/n4 ounces shiitake mushrooms, thinly sliced/n2 tablespoons gochujang (Korean red pepper paste)/n1 tablespoon gochugaru (Korean red pepper flakes)/nKosher salt/nOne 14-ounce container silken tofu, cut into large pieces/nSteamed short-grain rice, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a medium-size nonreactive pot, cook the pork belly pieces over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the fat is sizzling and the pork is light golden, about 8 minutes. Add the kimchi and the onion, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the onion is softened, about 5 minutes./nStep 2: Add the reserved kimchi liquid, mushrooms, gochujang, gochugaru, and 4 cups of water, and bring to a boil. Reduce to a simmer, and cook over moderately low heat for 10 minutes./nStep 3: Season the stew with salt. Stir in the tofu, breaking it up slightly with the spoon, and bring to a boil; remove from the heat. Serve the stew hot with steamed rice.

Ingredients: 3 ½ cups (500 grams) all-purpose flour/n9 ounces (1 cup plus 2 tablespoons) very cold butter, cut into ½-inch cubes/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n½ cup (or more) cold water/n1  garlic clove/n1 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more to make garlic paste/n3 tablespoons olive oil/n1  onion, finely chopped/n1 ½ pounds fresh mushrooms, such as king oyster, crimini, shimeji, and stemmed shiitake, sliced or coarsely chopped (about 10 cups)/n8 ounces broccoli, chopped (about 2 1/2 cups)/n8 ounces firm tofu, coarsely crumbled/n2 tablespoons tomato paste/n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce/n¾ cup vegetable stock/n2  bay leaves/n1 cup (about) red wine/n1 tablespoon flour/n1  large egg, whisked (for egg wash)
Steps: Step 1: In a food processor, pulse flour, butter, and salt until mixture resembles breadcrumbs. Gradually add 1/2 cup cold water. Pulse until dough comes together, adding another 1 to 2 tablespoons of water if too dry. Transfer to a work surface and knead a few times, just enough for dough to come together. Divide dough in half, form into balls, flatten into disks, and wrap separately in plastic wrap. Refrigerate for at least 20 minutes and up to 2 days./nStep 2: Mash garlic on cutting board with broad side of a chef's knife. Sprinkle with salt, and rub the salt into the garlic with knife, forming a paste. In a large Dutch oven or other heavy pot, heat oil over medium-high heat. Add onion and garlic paste and cook, stirring often, until soft and beginning to turn golden, 3 to 4 minutes. Add mushrooms, broccoli, and tofu. Cook, stirring occasionally, until mushrooms and broccoli are soft and liquid released has evaporated, about 10 minutes./nStep 3: Stir in tomato paste and Worcestershire. Add stock and bay leaves. Stir in wine and 1 teaspoon salt. Sprinkle flour over and stir to incorporate, adding a splash more wine if desired. Let filling simmer uncovered, stirring occasionally, until sauce is thick and mixture is almost dry, 10 to 15 minutes. Let filling cool completely, stirring occasionally. For faster cooling time, filling can be transferred to a plate and refrigerated until cold./nStep 4: Preheat oven to 400°F. On a lightly floured surface, roll out one dough disk to a 12-inch round. Transfer pie dough to a 9-inch deep-dish pie plate, and gently press onto bottom and sides of pan, leaving a 1-inch overhang. Add cold filling to pie dish. On a lightly floured surface, roll out second dough disk into a 12-inch round. Place on top of filling in pie dish. Using a knife or kitchen scissors, trim crust to a 1-inch overhang. Tuck the edges under edge of dish. Crimp edges to seal. Using a sharp knife, slash a few vents in top crust to allow for steam to escape. Brush top with egg wash. Place pie on a rimmed baking sheet and bake until top is golden brown and filling is bubbling, 55 to 60 minutes.

Ingredients: ½ cup olive oil, divided/n6  large (6 ounces total) fresh king trumpet mushrooms, cut into small cubes (about 6 cups)/n4 cups fresh shiitake mushrooms (from 2 [3 1/2-ounce] pkg.), cut into small cubes (about 2 cups)/n18 ounces firm fried tofu (from 2 [12-ounce] pkg.), cut into small cubes (about 4 cups)/n¼ cup plus 2 tablespoons sherry vinegar/n4  pepperoncini salad peppers, sliced into thin rings (1/3 cup), plus more for garnish/n1  (4-inch) piece fresh ginger, peeled and minced (1/4 cup)/n¼ cup light soy sauce/n3 large garlic cloves, minced (2 Tbsp.)/n2 teaspoons granulated sugar/n2 teaspoons kosher salt/n2  fresh Thai red chiles, unseeded and finely chopped (1 teaspoon)/n½ teaspoon black pepper/n2 cups diced red onion (from 2 medium [8-ounce each] onions)/n¼ cup vegan mayonnaise/n¼ cup fresh lime juice (from 2 limes) or calamansi juice (from 1 [10-ounce] container)/n3  scallions, sliced into 1/8- x 1/16- x 2 1/2-inch thin matchsticks (1/4 cup), plus more for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Heat 2 tablespoons of the oil in a large skillet over high. Add trumpet mushrooms, and cook, stirring occasionally, until browned, about 6 minutes. Transfer to a large bowl. Do not wipe skillet clean. Add 2 tablespoons of the oil to skillet; heat over high. Add shiitake mushrooms; cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 4 minutes. Transfer to trumpet mushrooms in bowl. Do not wipe skillet clean. Add 2 tablespoons of the oil to skillet; heat over high. Add tofu; cook, stirring occasionally, until tofu is browned with a nice crust on some pieces, about 4 minutes. Transfer to bowl with mushrooms./nStep 2: Add sherry vinegar, pepperoncini peppers, ginger, soy sauce, garlic, sugar, salt, Thai chiles, black pepper, and 1 3/4 cups of the onion to bowl with mushrooms and tofu; stir to combine./nStep 3: Wipe skillet clean. Add 2 tablespoons of the oil to skillet; heat over high. Add mushroom-tofu mixture; cook, stirring occasionally, until mixture starts caramelizing, 3 to 5 minutes. Remove from heat./nStep 4: Whisk together mayonnaise and lime juice in a small bowl; drizzle evenly on top of Sisig mixture in skillet. Top with remaining 1/4 cup red onions; garnish with additional pepperoncini and scallions. Stir together while the skillet is still sizzling, and enjoy.

Ingredients: 2 1/2 tablespoons soy sauce/n1 tablespoon sugar/n1 tablespoon Korean red pepper flakes or 2 teaspoons crushed red pepper/n1 large garlic clove, very finely chopped/n1/2 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n2 teaspoons finely grated fresh ginger/n1 teaspoon toasted sesame seeds/nOne 14-ounce container firm tofu/nVegetable oil, for frying/n1 scallion, thinly sliced/nSteamed rice, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk the soy sauce with the sugar, red pepper, garlic, sesame oil, ginger and sesame seeds./nStep 2: Slice the tofu crosswise into 8 thin slabs. Dry the tofu with paper towels, pressing until no moisture remains./nStep 3: In a large skillet, heat 1/4 inch of oil until shimmering. Add the tofu and cook over moderate heat, turning once, until browned and crisp, about 8 minutes per side. Drain on paper towels. Spoon the sauce over the fried tofu and sprinkle with the scallion. Serve with steamed rice.

Ingredients: 3 cups vegetable broth/n2 cups water/n2 whole lemongrass stalks, thinly sliced/nSix 1/4-inch-thick slices of fresh ginger, smashed lightly, plus 1 1/2 teaspoons very finely chopped fresh ginger/n1/4 cup low-sodium soy sauce/nFreshly ground white pepper/n4 ounces rice vermicelli/n1/4 cup vegetable oil/n1 pound small eggplant, peeled and cut into 1-inch cubes/n1/4 pound shiitake mushrooms, stemmed and caps quartered/nSalt/n2 garlic cloves, very finely chopped/n1 pound firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes/n1/2 pound napa cabbage, shredded (8 cups)/n1/2 cup bean sprouts/n1/4 cup cilantro leaves/n2 tablespoons mint leaves, torn/nLime wedges and hot sauce, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a medium soup pot, combine the vegetable broth, water, lemongrass, sliced ginger and soy sauce and season generously with white pepper. Bring to a simmer, cover and cook over low heat until flavorful, about 20 minutes. Strain the broth into a heatproof bowl, pressing on the solids. Discard the solids./nStep 2: Meanwhile, bring a medium saucepan of water to a boil. Cook the rice vermicelli until al dente, about 5 minutes. Drain and cool under running water./nStep 3: Wipe out the soup pot and heat the vegetable oil. Add the eggplant and shiitake mushrooms, season with salt and white pepper and cook the vegetables over high heat, stirring occasionally, until softened and browned, about 8 minutes. Stir in the chopped ginger and garlic and cook until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add the tofu and cook, stirring gently once or twice, until lightly browned, about 4 minutes. Add the vegetable broth along with the cabbage and noodles and simmer just until the cabbage is wilted, about 2 minutes longer. Stir in the bean sprouts, cilantro and mint and season the soup with salt and white pepper. Serve the soup in deep bowls, passing lime wedges and hot sauce at the table.

Ingredients: 16 ounces extra-firm tofu, drained and cut into 1-inch cubes (3 cups)/n3/8 teaspoon finely ground sea salt, divided/n3 tablespoons water/n1 1/2 tablespoons Bragg Liquid Aminos, Maggi seasoning sauce, or soy sauce/n1 tablespoon granulated sugar/n1 large garlic clove, pressed or minced (1 1/4 teaspoon)/n1 teaspoon toasted sesame oil/n1/2 teaspoon cornstarch/n1/2 teaspoon black pepper/n1 tablespoons canola oil or other neutral oil (such as grapeseed oil)/n2 tablespoons water/n1 1/2 tablespoons rice vinegar/n1 1/2 teaspoons granulated sugar or honey/n1/4 teaspoon finely ground sea salt/n1/8 teaspoon black pepper/n1/4 cup thinly sliced red onion or shallot, rinsed in cold water and patted dry/n4 cups loosely packed watercress, arugula, or baby lettuce mix (2 ounces)/n1/4 cup torn fresh mint, basil, or other leafy herb (optional)/n8 cherry tomatoes, halved (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Gently toss together tofu and 1/4 teaspoon of the salt in a bowl. Spread tofu in an even layer on a kitchen towel or double layer of paper towels; let drain 10 to 15 minutes. Meanwhile, stir together 3 tablespoons water, Bragg Liquid Aminos, sugar, garlic, sesame oil, cornstarch, pepper, and remaining 1/8 teaspoon salt in a small bowl until sugar dissolves; set aside./nStep 2: Heat canola oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium-high until shimmering. Pat tofu with paper towels to remove excess moisture. Add tofu to hot skillet; cook, stirring occasionally, until browned on 2 to 3 sides, 5 to 6 minutes./nStep 3: Whisk together 2 tablespoons water, vinegar, sugar, salt, and pepper in a large bowl. Add onion; top with watercress, mint, and tomatoes (if using). Do not toss salad; set aside./nStep 4: Reduce heat under tofu in skillet to medium; pour Bragg Liquid Aminos mixture over tofu. Cook, stirring often, until sauce reduces slightly and clings to tofu, 1 to 2 minutes. Remove from heat./nStep 5: Toss together salad ingredients in bowl; transfer to a serving dish. Top with tofu; spoon remaining sauce in skillet over tofu./nStep 6: Fry the tofu, but do not add Bragg Liquid Aminos mixture. Set tofu aside, covered, at room temperature, up to 4 hours. When ready to serve, prepare the salad, then re-warm the tofu in a skillet over medium until gently sizzling. Add Bragg Liquid Aminos mixture as directed in Step 4, and continue as directed.

Ingredients: 1 medium (2 ounces) garlic head/n½ cup, plus 1 tablespoon olive oil, divided/n¾ teaspoon kosher salt, divided/n1  (14-ounce) package extra-firm tofu, drained and patted dry/n¼ cup tahini/n2 tablespoons tamari/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice (from 1 lemon)/nChili crunch (such as This Little Goat Chili Crunch)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F. Cut top 1/2 inch from top of head of garlic; discard top. Place garlic head on an 8-inch square sheet of aluminum foil. Drizzle garlic with 1 tablespoon of the oil, and sprinkle with 1/4 teaspoon of the salt. Wrap in foil. Roast garlic directly on oven rack until tender, about 35 minutes. Remove from oven. Carefully unwrap garlic (steam will be released), and let cool slightly, about 10 minutes./nStep 2: Squeeze garlic cloves from skins into a small bowl. Mash enough garlic cloves to measure 2 tablespoonfuls, and reserve for dip. Cover and refrigerate any remaining garlic cloves for another use./nStep 3: Place tofu, tahini, tamari, lemon juice, reserved 2 tablespoons garlic, and remaining 1/2 teaspoon salt in a food processor. Process until smooth, about 30 seconds, stopping to scrape down sides as needed. With machine running, drizzle in remaining 1/2 cup oil. Process dip until smooth and combined, about 20 seconds. Transfer dip to a bowl. Sprinkle liberally with chili crunch.

Ingredients: 2 ½ ounces dried tofu skin sticks, broken into 3-inch pieces/n2 tablespoons lower-sodium soy sauce/n1 ½ tablespoons  rice vinegar/n1 ½ tablespoons well-stirred fried chile in oil (such as Lao Gan Ma)/n1 tablespoon mirin/n2 teaspoons granulated sugar/n2 tablespoons neutral oil (such as canola), divided/n1  medium-size red bell pepper, thinly sliced (about 1 cup)/nCooked white rice, for serving/nThinly sliced scallions and chopped cucumber, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Bring a large saucepan of water to a boil over high. Remove from heat. Add dried tofu skin sticks; place an inverted heatproof lid on top of tofu sticks to keep them submerged. Let stand until tofu sticks are very pliable and soft, 10 to 15 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, stir together soy sauce, vinegar, fried chile in oil, mirin, and sugar in a small bowl until sugar dissolves. Set aside./nStep 3: Drain tofu sticks, and gently pat dry. Heat 1 1/2 teaspoons oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium-high; swirl to coat. Add bell pepper; cook, stirring occasionally, until crisp-tender, about 3 minutes. Transfer bell pepper to a small bowl. Add remaining 1 1/2 tablespoons oil to skillet over medium-high. Add tofu sticks; cook, turning occasionally, until light golden, about 6 minutes./nStep 4: Add soy sauce mixture and bell pepper to tofu sticks in skillet; cook over medium-high, stirring often, until tofu sticks absorb soy sauce mixture, 4 to 6 minutes. Serve over cooked rice, and garnish with scallions and cucumber./nStep 5: Find dried tofu skin sticks (aka bean curd sticks) at Chinese markets or online at asianmart.com./nStep 6: Light-bodied California red: Field Recordings Freddo Sangiovese

Ingredients: 1 (14-ounce) package firm tofu, drained and rinsed/n2 tablespoons grapeseed or canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil)/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n2 tablespoons sake or dry vermouth/n2 tablespoons brown sugar/n2 teaspoons rice vinegar/n1/2 medium red onion, diced/nChopped cilantro, to garnish
Steps: Step 1: Pat the tofu dry with paper towels to remove excess water. Cut into 1-inch cubes./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the oil; once heated, carefully add the tofu into a single layer (hot oil may splatter). Turning gently and as little as necessary, sear each side for 2 to 3 minutes, or until sides are golden and crisp./nStep 3: Lower the heat to medium and carefully add the soy sauce, sake (or vermouth), brown sugar, and rice vinegar to the pan with the tofu. Stir in the red onion. Cook for 30 seconds and then remove from heat./nStep 4: Garnish with cilantro and serve warm or at room temperature.

Ingredients: One 14 ounce (396g) package firm tofu, drained and rinsed/n2 tablespoons grapeseed or canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil)/n3 cloves garlic, minced/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n2 tablespoons water/n2 tablespoons Sriracha sauce/n1/4 cup chopped fresh mint/n2 tablespoons chopped cilantro/nLime wedges to garnish
Steps: Step 1: Pat the tofu dry with paper towels to remove excess water. Cut into 1-inch cubes./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the oil and after the oil is hot, carefully add the tofu into a single layer (hot oil may splatter). Turning gently and as little as necessary, sear each side for 2-3 minutes, or until at least 2 -3 sides are golden and crisped./nStep 3: Lower the heat to medium and carefully add the garlic, soy sauce, water, and Sriracha to the pan. Cook for 30 seconds or until the sauce is heated through./nStep 4: Toss with the mint and cilantro then serve with lime squeezed over to taste.

Ingredients: 2  (4-ounce) jars sliced pimientos, drained (about 1/2 cup)/n1  (14-ounce) package firm or extra-firm tofu, drained/n¼ cup nutritional yeast/n¼ cup refined coconut oil, melted/n2 tablespoons pickle brine/n2 tablespoons apple cider vinegar/n2 teaspoons white miso/n2 teaspoons hot sauce/n1 ¼ teaspoons kosher salt/n1 teaspoon paprika/n1 small garlic clove, grated (about 1/2 teaspoon)/n4 ounces vegan Cheddar-style shreds (such as Violife or Miyoko's) (about 1 cup)
Steps: Step 1: Blot pimientos dry using paper towels, removing as much moisture as possible. Set 1 tablespoon pimientos aside. Chop remaining pimientos; set aside./nStep 2: Lightly press tofu using paper towels to remove excess moisture. Crumble tofu into bowl of a food processor. Add unchopped pimientos, nutritional yeast, coconut oil, pickle brine, vinegar, miso, hot sauce, salt, paprika, and garlic. Process until very smooth, 2 to 3 minutes, stopping to scrape down sides as needed./nStep 3: Add reserved chopped pimientos and vegan cheese shreds to mixture in food processor. Pulse until combined, about 3 (1-second) pulses. Transfer mixture to a bowl. Cover and chill until cold, at least 2 hours and up to 12 hours.

Ingredients: 1  (19-ounce) package medium-firm tofu, drained/n2 tablespoons neutral oil (such as canola)/n1 teaspoon cumin seeds/n1  small red onion, finely chopped (about 1 cup)/n1  small fresh Thai chile, unseeded and finely chopped (about 1/2 teaspoon)/n1  small tomato, finely chopped (about 1/2 cup)/n1  garlic clove, finely chopped (about 1 teaspoon)/n1  (1/2-inch) piece fresh ginger, peeled and grated (about 1/4 teaspoon)/n½ teaspoon ground turmeric/n¼ teaspoon black pepper/n¼ teaspoon kala namak (black salt)/n¾ teaspoon kosher salt/n¼ cup chopped fresh cilantro/nLime wedges and buttered toast, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Place tofu in a medium bowl. Using a fork or your hands, crumble tofu into small pieces and curds, being careful not to over-mash. Set aside./nStep 2: Heat oil in a large skillet over medium-high. Add cumin seeds; cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add onion and chile; cook, stirring often, until mixture is softened and onion is golden brown around edges, about 6 minutes. Add tomato, garlic, and ginger; cook, stirring often, until tomato breaks down into a chunky paste, about 2 minutes. Stir in turmeric, black pepper, and kala namak until combined. Add tofu and kosher salt; gently fold into tomato mixture until tofu turns light yellow. Cook, stirring occasionally and being careful not to overwork, until liquid has slightly evaporated, about 7 minutes. Stir in cilantro. Serve over toast with lime wedges./nStep 3: Look for kala namak (black salt) at South Asian grocery stores or online at desiclik.com.

Ingredients: One 14-ounce package medium tofu/n4 tablespoons vegetable oil, divided/nOne 1-inch piece of ginger, julienned/n2 cloves of garlic, thinly sliced/n4 scallions, cut into 1-inch pieces and thinly sliced/n1 tablespoon freshly ground black pepper/n1 teaspoon soy sauce/nSea salt/nCooked rice or noodles, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Place the tofu on a large plate with a small lip to catch water. Put a small plate on top of the tofu and something heavy (like a can of beans) on top of the plate. After 15 minutes discard the water that has drained from the tofu and cut it into 2-inch cubes./nStep 2: Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a well-seasoned cast iron pan or non-stick pan over medium high heat. Add the tofu and give the pan a shake so it doesn't stick. Cook for 5-7 minutes, or until the tofu is crispy and brown. Turn each piece over and continue cooking until lightly browned, about 5 more minutes. Add more oil if needed. Remove the tofu from the pan./nStep 3: In the same pan add the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil. Add the ginger and cook for 1 minute. Add the garlic and continue to cook for 30 more seconds. Stir in the crispy tofu, scallions, black pepper and soy sauce. Taste for seasoning and add salt if needed./nStep 4: Serve immediately over rice or noodles.

Ingredients: 2 serrano chiles, thinly sliced/n1/2 cup rice wine vinegar/n1 teaspoon sugar/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt, plus more for seasoning/n1 tablespoon low-sodium soy sauce/n1 tablespoon fresh lime juice/n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger/n1 teaspoon Dijon mustard/n1/2 cup plus 3 tablespoons canola oil/n6 ounces extra-firm tofu, drained well and cubed/n2 heirloom tomatoes, sliced/n2 peaches, cut into wedges/n1 cup arugula or mizuna/n1/2 cup basil leaves
Steps: Step 1: Put the serranos in a small heatproof bowl. In a small saucepan, bring 1/2 cup of water to a boil with the vinegar, sugar and 1/2 teaspoon of salt, stirring to dissolve the sugar. Pour the brine over the serranos and let stand for 15 minutes, until cooled to room temperature./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a small bowl, whisk the soy sauce, lime juice, ginger, mustard and 3 tablespoons of the oil./nStep 3: In a large cast-iron skillet, heat the remaining 1/2 cup of oil until shimmering. Add the tofu and cook over moderate heat, turning, until crisp, 5 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a paper towel–lined plate. Season with salt./nStep 4: Juicy Pinot Noir–based rosé.

Ingredients: 14 ounces medium tofu/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil, divided/n1/4 cup water/n2 tablespoons black bean sauce/n1 teaspoon chili-garlic sauce/n1 teaspoon honey/n1 teaspoon corn starch/n1/4 teaspoon white vinegar/n1 clove of garlic, finely minced/n2 eggplants, cut in half lengthwise then cut into 1-inch slices/n6 kale leaves, ribs removed and torn into bite-sized pieces/nRice or noodles, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Place the tofu on a large plate with a small lip to catch water. Put a small plate on top of the tofu and something heavy (like a can of beans) on top of the plate. After 15 minutes discard the water that has drained from the tofu and cut it into 2-inch cubes./nStep 2: Heat 1 tablespoon of the oil in a well-seasoned cast iron pan or non-stick pan over medium high heat. Add the tofu and give the pan a shake so it doesn't stick. Cook for 5-7 minutes, or until the tofu is crispy and brown. Turn each piece over and continue cooking until lightly browned, about 5 more minutes. Add more oil if sticking./nStep 3: In a small bowl whisk together the water, black bean sauce, chili-garlic sauce, honey, white vinegar and garlic. Set aside./nStep 4: Add the remaining tablespoon of oil to a large frying pan or wok over medium high heat. Add the eggplant and cook, stirring frequently, until it is soft, about 8-10 minutes. Add the kale and cook until it just starts to wilt, about 1 minute. Add the crispy tofu and the sauce and cook until the sauce is thick and coats the vegetables, about 30 seconds./nStep 5: Remove from the heat and serve with rice or noodles.

Ingredients: One 14-ounce package extra-firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes/n3 tablespoons Korean chile powder or hot paprika/n1 tablespoon Korean pepper paste (kochujang)/n1 tablespoon finely grated garlic/n1 tablespoon finely grated ginger/n1 tablespoon toasted-sesame oil/nKosher salt/n1 cup cornstarch/n2 cups vegetable oil, for frying/n12 corn or 5-inch flour tortillas, warmed/nHoisin sauce, kimchi, Asian pear, scallions and chopped honey-roasted peanuts, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Place the tofu on a rack lined with paper towels and drain for 15 minutes. Meanwhile, in a large bowl, combine 1 tablespoon of the chile powder with the pepper paste, garlic, ginger and sesame oil and season with salt. In another large bowl, whisk the cornstarch with the remaining 2 tablespoons of chile powder and 1 tablespoon of salt./nStep 2: In a medium, deep skillet, heat the oil until it reaches 365°. Add the tofu to the chile sauce and stir gently to coat. Scrape the tofu into the cornstarch mixture and toss to coat. Transfer the coated tofu to a colander to tap out the excess cornstarch. Fry the tofu in one batch, stirring occasionally, until golden and crunchy, 3 to 3 1/2 minutes; maintain the heat near 360°. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the crunchy tofu to a paper towel–lined rack and sprinkle with salt. Serve the tofu right away with the tortillas, hoisin sauce, kimchi, Asian pear, scallions and peanuts./nStep 3: Strawberry-scented dry rosé from California.

Ingredients: One 14 ounce (396g) package firm tofu, drained and rinsed/n2 tablespoons grapeseed or canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil)
Steps: Step 1: Pat the tofu dry with paper towels to remove excess water. Cut into 1-inch slices./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the oil and after the oil is hot, carefully add the tofu into a single layer (hot oil may splatter). Sear each side for 1-2 minutes, or until at least 2-3 sides are golden and crisped./nStep 3: Drain on paper towels.

Ingredients: 1 16-ounce package extra firm tofu/n3 tablespoon canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil), divided/n1/2 medium onion, sliced/n1 tablespoon hoisin sauce/n1 tablespoon fish sauce/n2 ears of corn, shucked (about 2 cups)/nKosher or sea salt, to taste/nFresh cracked black pepper, to taste/nChopped cilantro, to garnish/nSoy sauce, drizzled to finish (optional)
Steps: Step 1: Drain the tofu and slice into 1/2-inch-thick slices. Pat slices dry with paper towels. Season both sides with salt and pepper./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over heat. Add 2 tablespoons of oil, and then carefully add the tofu (hot oil may splatter). Sear both sides of the tofu until golden brown, 2-3 minutes each side. Remove the tofu from the pan and drain on paper towel towels./nStep 3: Turn the heat down to medium heat. Add the final tablespoon of oil to the pan. Stir in the onions and cook until caramelized and golden brown, about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally./nStep 4: Stir in the hoisin and fish sauce. Stir in the corn. Cook for 2-3 minutes or until the corn is tender./nStep 5: Layer several pieces of tofu on each plate. Add a couple spoonfuls of corn mixture over tofu. Garnish with cilantro and drizzle with soy sauce if desired. Serve warm.

Ingredients: 2 cups Fuji apple juice (see Note)/n3 tablespoons shiro dashi (see Note)/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n1/2 tablespoon sherry vinegar/n1/2 tablespoon untoasted sesame oil/nOne 12-ounce package soft silken tofu, drained and cut into 4 slices/n2 cooked chestnuts, thinly sliced/nLight green frisée leaves, for garnish/nWasabi oil, for garnish (see Note)
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk together the apple juice, shiro dashi, soy sauce, sherry vinegar and sesame oil. Set the tofu in 4 shallow bowls. Top with the chestnuts and frisée. Pour the apple dashi around the tofu (reserve any remaining dashi for another use). Drizzle with a few drops of wasabi oil and serve./nStep 2: Fuji apple juice is available at supermarkets and juice bars, or you can make your own. Shiro dashi is a stock made with soy sauce, white soy, bonito (a type of fish)and seaweed. Shiro dashi and wasabi oil are both available at Asian markets.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons coriander seeds/n1 1/2 teaspoons fennel seeds/n1 teaspoon whole black peppercorns/n1 teaspoon crushed red pepper/n1 dried bay leaf, crumbled/n1 tablespoon sweet paprika/n1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for the grill/n4 large garlic cloves, minced and mashed to a paste with a pinch of salt/nTwo 14-ounce blocks firm tofu—drained, each one cut crosswise into 4 slabs/nSalt/n8 brioche buns, split/n1/2 cup mayonnaise/n1/4 cup barbecue sauce/nLettuce, for serving/nSliced pickles, for serving/nRed onion, for serving/nTomatoes, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a skillet, combine the coriander and fennel seeds, peppercorns, crushed red pepper and bay leaf and cook over moderate heat, shaking the pan, until fragrant, 1 minute. Transfer the spices to a grinder and let cool. Add the paprika and finely grind the spices, then transfer them to a bowl and stir in the 1/2 cup of olive oil. Stir in the garlic paste./nStep 2: Arrange the tofu in a baking dish. Spread all but 1 tablespoon of the spice paste over the tofu. Cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or up to 48 hours./nStep 3: Light a grill and oil the grates. Season the tofu with salt and grill over moderate heat, turning, until just heated through, 10 minutes./nStep 4: Grill the buns until toasted. In a bowl, mix the mayonnaise and barbecue sauce with the remaining 1 tablespoon of spice paste. Spread the mayonnaise sauce on the buns and top with the tofu, lettuce, pickles, red onion and tomatoes. Close the sandwiches and serve./nStep 5: Fruity, dry Provençal rosé.

Ingredients: 4 cups bulgur/n5 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nOne 14-ounce package firm tofu, drained and cubed/n5 scallions, chopped, plus more for garnish/n1 small tomato, chopped/n1 Kirby cucumber, chopped/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/nKosher salt/nPepper
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan of boiling water, cook the bulgur until tender, about 12 minutes. Drain and return the bulgur to the pan. Cover and let stand for 10 minutes; fluff with a fork. Spread the bulgur on a baking sheet and let cool to room temperature./nStep 2: In a large cast-iron skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the oil. Cook the tofu and 5 chopped scallions over high heat, stirring, until golden and crisp in spots, about 5 minutes. Transfer to a large bowl. Stir in the bulgur, tomato, cucumber, lemon juice and the remaining oil and season with salt and pepper. Garnish with more chopped scallions and serve.

Ingredients: 1/2 pound fingerling potatoes, scrubbed/n3 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/n5 ounces oyster mushrooms, thickly sliced/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n1 pound firm tofu—drained, patted dry and cut into 1/2-inch cubes/nOne 12-ounce jar roasted red bell peppers, drained and thinly sliced/n3 ounces mozzarella-style soy cheese, coarsely shredded (1/2 cup)/n2 tablespoons prepared pesto
Steps: Step 1: Bring a medium saucepan of water to a boil. Add the potatoes and cook over moderately high heat until tender, about 10 minutes. Drain and slice the potatoes crosswise 3/4 inch thick./nStep 2: In a large nonstick skillet, heat the oil until shimmering. Add the potato slices and cook over moderately high heat, turning occasionally, until lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Add the mushrooms, season with salt and pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until browned, about 6 minutes. Add the tofu and roasted red peppers and season lightly with salt and pepper. Cook, stirring and lightly mashing the tofu, until the ingredients are combined and heated through, about 5 minutes. Add the soy cheese and 1 tablespoon of the pesto and stir to melt the cheese. Transfer the scramble to a platter and drizzle with the remaining 1 tablespoon of pesto and serve./nStep 3: Crusty bread.

Ingredients: 1 teaspoon canola oil/n1/2 pound ground beef chuck (85 percent lean)/n1/2 pound ground pork/nKosher salt/n2 tablespoons chile-bean sauce, preferably toban djan/n2 tablespoons hoisin sauce or tenmenjan (soybean paste)/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/nOne 14-ounce package soft tofu, finely diced/n1 1/2 teaspoon cornstarch/n1/2 cup water/n3 scallions, finely chopped/nWhite rice, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Heat a large skillet until hot. Add the oil, followed by the beef and pork. Season with salt and cook over high heat, stirring and breaking up the meat, until crumbly and lightly browned, about 3 minutes./nStep 2: Stir in the chile-bean sauce, hoisin and soy sauce and cook, stirring, for 3 minutes. Gently fold in the tofu. In a small bowl, whisk the cornstarch into the water. Add to the skillet and simmer until the sauce thickens, 2 minutes. Stir in the scallions and serve.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon soy sauce/n1/2 tablespoon finely grated peeled fresh ginger/n1 teaspoon toasted sesame oil/nKosher salt/nOne 12-ounce package silken firm tofu, drained and cut into 4 equal pieces/nThinly sliced scallion, white sesame seeds and togarashi, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk the soy sauce with the ginger and oil; season with salt. In a medium saucepan of gently simmering water, heat the tofu just until warmed through, about 5 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the tofu to paper towels to drain briefly. Arrange the tofu on serving plates and drizzle with the soy-ginger sauce. Garnish with sliced scallion, sesame seeds and togarashi.

Ingredients: 1/4 cup Fuji apple juice/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n1 tablespoon unseasoned rice vinegar/n4 mixed radishes, very thinly sliced/n1 large scallion, cut into 2-inch lengths and julienned/n1/4 cup cilantro stems, very thinly sliced on the bias/n1 pound cold silken tofu, cut into 6 pieces/n1 1/2 teaspoon hot sesame oil/nToasted sesame seeds, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk the apple juice with the soy sauce and vinegar. In another small bowl, toss the radishes with the scallion and cilantro. Refrigerate the sauce and slaw separately until they are nicely chilled, about 15 minutes./nStep 2: Divide the tofu among 6 bowls. Spoon the apple soy sauce on top. Pile the slaw on top of the tofu and drizzle each with 1/4 teaspoon of the hot sesame oil. Garnish with toasted sesame seeds and serve cold.

Ingredients: One 14 ounce (396g) package firm tofu, drained and rinsed/n2 tablespoons grapeseed or canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil)/n1 tablespoon grated or minced fresh ginger/n1 tablespoon soy sauce/n2 tablespoons water/n1 teaspoon brown sugar/n1/2 teaspoon sesame seed oil/nToasted sesame seeds, to garnish/nSliced green onions, to garnish
Steps: Step 1: Pat the tofu block dry with paper towels to remove excess water. Cut into 1/2-inch thick slices./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add the oil and after the oil is hot, carefully add the tofu into a single layer (hot oil may splatter). Sear each side for 2-3 minutes, or until golden and crisped./nStep 3: Lower the heat to medium and carefully add the ginger, soy sauce, water, brown sugar, and sesame seed oil. Simmer for 1 minute and then serve garnished with toasted sesame seeds and green onions.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon rice vinegar/n1 teaspoon sugar/n2 Persian cucumbers, thinly sliced/n2 teaspoons grated peeled fresh ginger/nKosher salt/n1 cup sushi rice/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n2 garlic cloves, minced/n12 ounces shiitake mushrooms, stemmed and caps thickly sliced/nOne 14-ounce box extra-firm tofu, patted dry and cut into 3-by- 1/3-inch sticks/nOne 12-ounce bunch of mustard greens—stems and inner ribs removed, leaves coarsely chopped/n1 tablespoon toasted sesame oil/n1 small zucchini, cubed/n2 tablespoons kecap manis (Indonesian sweet soy sauce) or 2 tablespoons of soy sauce mixed with 1 teaspoon of molasses/n4 scallions, thinly sliced/nGochujang (Korean chile paste, see Note) or Sriracha, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, combine the vinegar with the sugar, cucumbers, 1 teaspoon of the ginger and 1/2 teaspoon of salt. Set aside./nStep 2: In a medium saucepan, combine the rice with 1 1/3 cups of water and bring to a boil. Cover and cook over very low heat until tender, 20 minutes. Remove from the heat and let stand for 5 minutes, then fluff with a fork./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a nonstick skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of the vegetable oil. Add the garlic and shiitake, season with salt and cook over high heat, stirring, until browned, 6 minutes; scrape onto a platter. Heat 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil and add the tofu. Cook over high heat, turning, until browned, 5 minutes. Scrape the tofu onto the platter, keeping it separate from the mushrooms./nStep 4: Heat 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil in the skillet. Add the remaining 1 teaspoon of ginger and stir-fry for 30 seconds. Add the mustard greens and sesame oil, season with salt and cook until the greens are wilted and just tender, 4 minutes. Add the greens to the platter. Wipe out the skillet. Heat the remaining 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil in the skillet. Add the zucchini and cook over high heat until softened, 3 minutes. Add the kecap manis and cook until the zucchini is glazed, 1 minute; scrape onto the platter. Keep warm./nStep 5: Mound the rice in bowls and arrange the cooked vegetables in separate piles. Using a slotted spoon, add the pickled cucumbers to the bowls. Garnish with the scallions and a dollop of gochujang and serve./nStep 6: Gochujang is available at Korean markets or from hmart.com./nStep 7: The tangy, spicy flavors in bibimbap can be tricky with wine, but vibrant Californian Sauvignon Blanc works well.

Ingredients: One 14 ounce (396g) package firm tofu, drained and rinsed/n3 tablespoons grapeseed or canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil), divided/n3 tablespoons sliced shallots/n1/2 pound shiitake mushrooms, sliced/n1 tablespoon miso paste/n1/4 cup water/nFresh cracked black pepper, to taste/nSliced green onions, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Pat the tofu block dry with paper towels to remove excess water. Cut into 1/2-inch thick slices./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of oil and after the oil is hot, carefully add the tofu into a single layer (hot oil may splatter). Sear each side for 2-3 minutes, or until golden and crisped. Remove the tofu from the pan and set aside./nStep 3: Reduce the heat to medium and add the remaining tablespoon of oil. Stir in the shallots and cook for about 1 minute or until soft./nStep 4: Stir in the mushrooms and cook for about 2 minutes or until mushrooms are tender and lightly browned./nStep 5: Add the miso, water and black pepper, and then stir to liquefy the miso paste. Simmer for 30 seconds or until heated through./nStep 6: Toss tofu with the miso and mushrooms and serve garnished with green onions.

Ingredients: One 14 ounce (396g) package firm tofu, drained and rinsed/n3 tablespoons grapeseed or canola oil (or other high flashpoint oil), divided/n1/2 medium onion, sliced/n1/2 cup dry white wine/n1 tablespoon fresh lemon juice/n1 teaspoon spicy brown mustard/n1/2 teaspoon kosher or sea salt/n4 cups lightly packed chopped kale/n1/2 cup halved cherry tomatoes
Steps: Step 1: Pat the tofu block dry with paper towels to remove excess water. Cut into 1-inch cubes./nStep 2: Heat a large skillet over high heat. Add 2 tablespoons of oil and after the oil is hot, carefully add the tofu into a single layer (hot oil may splatter). Sear each side for 2-3 minutes, or until golden and crisped. Remove the tofu from the pan and set aside./nStep 3: Reduce the heat to medium and add the remaining tablespoon of oil. Stir in the onions, and cook for 2-3 minutes or until soft and light golden./nStep 4: Stir in the white wine, lemon juice, mustard, and salt. Simmer for 30 seconds and then stir in the kale and tomatoes. Cover the pan with a lid and simmer for about 1 minutes or until kale is tender./nStep 5: Toss tofu with the kale and serve warm.

Ingredients: 1/2 pound ground bison/n2 large garlic cloves, minced/n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger/n3 tablespoons soy sauce/n1 tablespoon cornstarch/n1 teaspoon sugar/nSalt and freshly ground black pepper/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n1 pound green beans/nOne 12-ounce block silken firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes/n1 cup low-sodium beef or chicken broth, preferably organic/n1 1/2 teaspoons Chinese chile-garlic sauce/n2 scallions, thinly sliced
Steps: Step 1: In a medium bowl, mix the ground bison with the garlic, ginger, 1 tablespoon of the soy sauce, 2 teaspoons of the cornstarch and the sugar. Season the meat lightly with salt and black pepper and let stand for about 20 minutes./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a nonstick skillet or well-seasoned wok, heat 1 teaspoon of the canola oil until shimmering. Add the seasoned meat, breaking it up into small bits with a spoon, and stir-fry over high heat until browned. Transfer the meat to a bowl. Add the remaining 1 tablespoon plus 2 teaspoons of oil to the skillet, and when it is very hot, add the green beans and stir-fry until crisp-tender, about 3 minutes. Add the tofu cubes and stir-fry until the tofu is lightly browned in spots and the beans begin to blister, about 3 minutes longer. Return the meat to the skillet and stir gently to slightly break up the tofu./nStep 3: In a small bowl, whisk the broth with the Chinese chile-garlic sauce and the remaining 2 tablespoons of soy sauce and 1 teaspoon of cornstarch. Add the sauce to the skillet and bring to a boil. Simmer until the beans are tender and the sauce is thickened, about 5 minutes. Stir in the sliced scallions. Transfer the stir-fry to bowls and serve immediately./nStep 4: One Serving 254 cal, 13 gm fat, 2.5 gm sat fat, 15 gm carb, 5 gm fiber, 20 gm protein./nStep 5: Steamed rice./nStep 6: Juicy, fruit-forward Garnacha from Spain.

Ingredients: 1 pound firm tofu—drained, patted dry and cut into 3/4-inch dice/n6 garlic cloves, minced/n1 1/2 teaspoons ground Calabrian chiles or cayenne/n1/4 teaspoon finely chopped thyme/nKosher salt/n1/3 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n3/4 cup finely chopped onion/n3/4 cup dry white wine/nOne 28-ounce can tomato puree/n2 tablespoons finely chopped basil/n1/4 cup canola oil/n1 pound strozzapreti pasta/nChopped pistachios, grated pecorino and dried oregano, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a medium bowl, toss the tofu with half of the garlic, the chiles, thyme and 2 teaspoons of salt. Cover and refrigerate the tofu for at least 30 minutes or overnight./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large saucepan, heat the olive oil until shimmering. Add the onion, the remaining garlic and a generous pinch of salt and cook over moderately high heat, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 7 minutes. Add the wine and simmer until evaporated, about 5 minutes. Add the tomato puree and basil and bring to a boil. Cover partially and simmer over moderately low heat until thickened slightly, 20 to 25 minutes; keep the sauce warm./nStep 3: In a large skillet, heat the canola oil until shimmering. Add the tofu and cook over moderate heat until browned on the bottom, about 2 minutes. Flip the tofu and cook, stirring occasionally, until lightly browned all over, about 3 minutes longer; keep warm./nStep 4: In a pot of salted boiling water, cook the strozzapreti until al dente. Add the pasta to the sauce and cook over moderate heat, stirring, until coated, about 2 minutes. Fold in the tofu and season with salt. Transfer to a platter and garnish with chopped pistachios, grated pecorino and dried oregano. Serve right away./nStep 5: The marinated tofu and cooked tomato sauce can be refrigerated separately overnight./nStep 6: Pair this pasta dish with a spicy, berried Southern Italian red.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon vegetable oil/n1 medium onion, thinly sliced lengthwise/n1 tablespoon finely grated fresh ginger/n1 garlic clove, very thinly sliced/n1 large jalapeño, thinly sliced crosswise with seeds/n1 teaspoon turmeric/n4 large shiitake mushrooms, stems discarded, caps thickly sliced/n2 cups small broccoli florets/n1 medium carrot, thinly sliced crosswise/n3 canned plum tomatoes, chopped/n1 1/4 cups light unsweetened coconut milk/n1 pound firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes/n1/2 cup water/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n1/2 cup coarsely chopped basil leaves/nLime wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a large skillet or wok, heat the vegetable oil. Add the onion along with the ginger, garlic and jalapeño and stir-fry over moderately high heat for 2 minutes. Add the turmeric, then add the shiitake mushrooms, broccoli and carrot and stir-fry for 3 minutes./nStep 2: Add the tomatoes, coconut milk, tofu, water and soy sauce to the skillet and simmer over moderately high heat, stirring a few times, until the vegetables are al dente, about 4 minutes. Stir the chopped basil into the vegetables, transfer to plates and serve immediately with lime wedges./nStep 3: One Serving 223 cal, 12 gm fat, 4.7 gm saturated fat, 16 gm carb, 2 gm fiber./nStep 4: Steamed rice.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n8 ounces smoked tofu, cut into 1/2-inch dice/n1 small yellow onion, cut into 1/4-inch dice/n2 medium carrots, peeled and cut into 1/4-inch dice/n6 scallions, white and green parts separated, both parts thinly sliced/n2 large garlic cloves, minced/n1 tablespoon minced peeled fresh ginger/n4 cups cooked short-grain brown rice (see Note)/n4 large eggs, lightly beaten/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n1/2 cup sweet peas (defrosted, if frozen)
Steps: Step 1: In a nonstick wok or large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil. Add the tofu and stir-fry over high heat until golden brown, about 3 minutes. Transfer to a plate./nStep 2: Add the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil along with the onion, carrots and white parts of the scallions to the wok. Stir-fry until the vegetables are softened, about 5 minutes. Add the garlic and ginger and stir-fry until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add the rice and all but 1 tablespoon of the scallion greens and stir-fry, until the rice is heated through and beginning to brown, about 3 minutes./nStep 3: Push the fried rice to the side of the pan to create a well. Pour the eggs into the well and cook, stirring gently, until nearly set. Toss the eggs with the fried rice and cook for 1 minute. Stir in the smoked tofu, soy sauce and peas and stir-fry for 1 minute longer. Transfer the fried rice to bowls, garnish with the remaining 1 tablespoon of scallion greens and serve./nStep 4: To cook the rice, in a medium saucepan combine 1 1/2 cups raw rice with 3 cups of water and a large pinch of salt and bring to a boil. Cover and simmer over low heat until the rice is cooked and the water is absorbed, about 45 minutes. Remove from the heat and let stand for 10 minutes. Use the rice right away or refrigerate.

Ingredients: 1 cup basmati rice/n1 1/2 cups water/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1 medium onion, minced/n4 large garlic cloves, finely minced/nOne 2-inch piece of ginger, peeled and very finely minced/n1/2 cup diced tomatoes (fresh, if in season, or canned)/n4 green cardamom pods/n1/2 teaspoon ground coriander/n1/2 teaspoon ground cumin/n1/4 teaspoon cinnamon/n1 teaspoon garam masala/n1 teaspoon sea salt/n6 ounces medium firm tofu, diced/n2 tablespoons raisins/n3 tablespoons slivered almonds
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a small pot, combine the basmati rice and water and bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce the heat to the lowest setting, and cook, covered, for 15 minutes. Remove from the heat and let it sit, covered, for 10 minutes./nStep 2: In a large frying pan, heat the oil over medium high heat. Add the onion and cook until it is soft and light brown, about 7 to 8 minutes. Add the garlic and ginger and cook for 1 minute./nStep 3: Add the tomatoes, cardamom pods, coriander, cumin, cinnamon, garam masala and sea salt and cook for 3 minutes. Remove from the heat and stir in the tofu, raisins and slivered almonds./nStep 4: Put half of the rice in the bottom of an ovenproof dish. Next, layer in half of the tofu, the rest of the rice and finally the remaining tofu./nStep 5: Cook, uncovered, in the preheated oven for 30 minutes.

Ingredients: 1 pound silken tofu, drained/n1.3333 cups mochiko (sweet glutinous rice flour) (such as Koda Farms) (about 6 1/8 ounces)/n1.3333 cups bleached cake flour (about 5 ounces)/n¼ cup plus 1 tablespoon granulated sugar/n¼ cup freeze-dried strawberry powder (such as Nature Restore), divided/n1 tablespoon  plus 1 teaspoon baking powder/n¼ teaspoon fine sea salt/nNeutral cooking oil (such as peanut oil), for frying/n1 cup powdered sugar (about 4 ounces)/n5 to 8 teaspoons whole milk (or plant-based alternative), divided
Steps: Step 1: Using the back of a spoon, press drained tofu through a fine wire-mesh strainer set over a medium bowl. Add mochiko, cake flour, sugar, 3 tablespoons strawberry powder, baking powder, and salt. Stir until mixture is smooth and well combined, about 1 minute. (Dough will look dry and crumbly at first, but tofu will hydrate mixture, allowing it to come together into a ball.)/nStep 2: Pour oil into a large Dutch oven to a depth of 2 inches; heat over medium to 350°F. Meanwhile, cut 8 (5-inch) squares of parchment paper; set aside. Divide dough evenly into 8 pieces (about 31/2 ounces each). Cover with a damp paper towel to prevent drying. Working with 1 dough piece at a time and keeping remaining pieces covered, divide dough piece evenly into 7 pieces (about 1/2 ounce each). Roll each piece into a ball, and arrange balls in a 3-inch ring on 1 prepared parchment square, ensuring adjacent balls are touching so that the ring holds together while frying. If dough is sticky, lightly moisten hands with water. Re-cover assembled ring. Repeat process with remaining dough pieces and parchment squares./nStep 3: Carefully place 2 doughnuts with parchment paper squares in preheated oil in Dutch oven. Fry until golden brown and crisp, 3 to 4 minutes, flipping doughnuts halfway through cook time and removing parchment paper using tongs. Using a spider, transfer doughnuts to a baking sheet lined with paper towels. Repeat frying process with remaining doughnuts, returning oil to 350°F in between batches./nStep 4: Whisk together powdered sugar and remaining 1 tablespoon strawberry powder in a medium bowl. Add 5 teaspoons milk; whisk until smooth. Whisk in remaining 3 teaspoons milk, 1 teaspoon at a time, to thin glaze to desired consistency./nStep 5: Dip 1 side of each doughnut into glaze. Let stand until glaze hardens, about 5 minutes. Doughnuts are best served immediately, but will hold at room temperature up to 4 hours. Doughnuts will become bouncier as they cool./nStep 6: To make lemon doughnuts: Omit strawberry powder in dough. Add 2 teaspoons grated lemon zest and an additional 3 tablespoons cake flour. For the glaze, omit strawberry powder and use lemon juice instead of milk, starting with 1 table-spoon and adding an addi-tional 1/2 teaspoon at a time to reach desired consistency. Garnish with lemon zest./nStep 7: Find mochiko at East and Southeast Asian markets or online at asianmart.com.

Ingredients: 5 cups water/n1/4 cup white or red miso/nSalt/n1 cup frozen shelled edamame/n4 ounces baby spinach (4 cups)/n3/4 pound shelled and deveined medium shrimp, cut into 1/2-inch pieces/n7 ounces firm tofu, cut into 1/2-inch cubes/n1 scallion, thinly sliced/nSteamed short-grain rice and toasted sesame seeds, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk 1 cup of the water into the miso. In a medium saucepan, bring the remaining 4 cups of water to a boil with a pinch of salt. Add the edamame, cover and cook until tender, about 5 minutes. Add the spinach in bunches and stir to wilt. Add the shrimp and tofu. Stir the miso mixture and add it to the soup. Simmer just until the shrimp are cooked through, about 1 minute. Season the soup with salt and stir in the sliced scallion. Ladle the soup into deep bowls and serve with steamed rice and toasted sesame seeds./nStep 2: Fragrant, crisp American sake.

Ingredients: 5 ounces raw pepitas (pumpkin seeds; about 1 cup)/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n1/2 cup finely chopped shallots/n1 large jalapeño—stemmed, seeded and finely chopped/n3 garlic cloves, minced/nKosher salt/n1/4 cup lightly packed parsley/n1/4 cup lightly packed cilantro/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice/n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1/4 teaspoon finely grated orange zest/nTortilla chips, for serving
