Ingredients: 1/2 cup crème fraîche/n1 small shallot, minced/n2 tablespoons finely chopped dill/n2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice, plus more for brushing/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper/n3 baking potatoes (1 1/2 pounds), peeled/n4 tablespoons unsalted butter, 2 tablespoons melted/n1/4 pound thinly sliced smoked salmon/n1/4 pound thinly sliced smoked sturgeon/nExtra-virgin olive oil, for brushing/nFreshly snipped chives and caviar, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a bowl, stir the crème fraîche with the shallot, dill and the 2 teaspoons of lemon juice. Season with salt and pepper. Whisk the mixture until thickened, about 30 seconds./nStep 2: Preheat the oven to 425°. On a box grater, coarsely shred the potatoes. Transfer to a clean kitchen towel and squeeze out as much liquid as possible. In a bowl, combine the potatoes with the 2 tablespoons of melted butter and season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: In a small nonstick skillet, melt 1 tablespoon of the butter. Add half of the potatoes and pat them into a disk about 1/2 inch thick. Cook over moderately high heat, turning once, until golden, 3 minutes per side. Transfer the potato galette to a baking sheet. Repeat with the remaining 1 tablespoon of butter and potatoes. Bake the galettes for 10 minutes, until cooked through and crisp; transfer to a platter and let stand for 15 minutes./nStep 4: Spoon the shallot-dill crème onto the galettes and top with the smoked fish. Lightly brush the fish with olive oil and lemon juice and season with salt and pepper. Garnish with chives and caviar. Serve right away./nStep 5: Bright, minerally sparkling wine.

Ingredients: 1 cup dried kamut or spelt berries/n4 ounces haricots verts, cut into thirds/n1 tablespoon unsalted butter/n1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1 large shallot, halved and thinly sliced/nSalt/n2 teaspoons minced fresh red chile/n1 pound medium shrimp, shelled and deveined/n1/4 cup dry white wine or dry vermouth/n1 1/2 tablespoons finely chopped tarragon/nLemon wedges, for serving
Steps: Step 1: In a heavy medium saucepan, toast the kamut over moderately high heat until fragrant, 3 to 4 minutes. Add 4 cups of water and bring to a boil. Cover and simmer over moderately low heat until the grains are tender, 1 hour 10 minutes; drain off any excess water./nStep 2: In a medium, deep skillet, combine the haricots verts with 1/4 cup of water. Cover and steam over moderately high heat, stirring, until crisp-tender, 3 to 4 minutes. Drain./nStep 3: Wipe out the skillet. Melt the butter in the oil over moderately high heat. Add the shallot, season with salt and cook, stirring, until softened, 2 minutes. Add the chile and cook, stirring, until fragrant. Add the shrimp, season with salt and cook, stirring, until just pink, 3 minutes. Add the wine and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Stir in the kamut and haricots verts and cook until hot. Stir in the tarragon, season with salt and serve with lemon wedges./nStep 4: One Serving 330 cal, 6 gm fat, 2.2 gm sat fat, 40 gm carb, 6 gm fiber, 30 gm protein./nStep 5: Provençal rosé.

Ingredients: 8 ounces yellow Chinese egg noodles/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n2 tablespoons oyster sauce/n1 tablespoon hoisin/n1 tablespoon rice vinegar/n1 teaspoon brown sugar/n2 tablespoons water/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n4 cloves garlic, minced/n1/2 medium onion, chopped/n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger/n1 medium carrot, julienned/n1/4 pound broccoli florets, cut into one-inch pieces (about 1 1/2 cups)/n1/2 medium bell pepper, seeded and sliced
Steps: Step 1: Cook the noodles according to the package instructions. Rinse under cold water, drain and set aside./nStep 2: In a medium bowl, combine the soy sauce, oyster sauce, hoisin, rice vinegar, brown sugar and water. Set aside./nStep 3: Heat the oil over high heat. Stir in the garlic, onion, and ginger. Cook for 2 to 3 minutes or until the garlic and onions are soft and fragrant./nStep 4: Stir in carrot, broccoli and bell peppers. Cook for 3 to 5 minutes or until the vegetables are tender./nStep 5: Add the noodles and sauce mixture. Toss everything together until combined and heated through, about 2 minutes. Serve hot.

Ingredients: ¾ cup chopped flat-leaf parsley/n¾ cup black olives (such as Gaeta, Calamata or Niçoise (3 1/2 ounces), pitted and chopped)/n½ cup extra-virgin olive oil/n4  anchovy fillets (minced)/n3  garlic cloves (minced)/n1 ½ tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1 tablespoon chopped thyme/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n6 ounces snow peas/n6 ounce jars or cans of imported olive oil-packed tuna (drained)/n4  crusty rolls or four 6-inch lengths of baguette (halved)/n1  small red onion (thinly sliced)/n2  medium tomatoes (sliced 1/3 inch thick)/n4  hard-cooked eggs (sliced 1/ inch thick)
Steps: Step 1: In a medium bowl, mix the parsley, black olives, olive oil, anchovies, garlic, lemon juice and thyme. Season the dressing with salt and pepper./nStep 2: In a small pot of boiling salted water, blanch the snow peas for 1 minute, or until they are bright green and just tender. Drain the snow peas and refresh them under cold water, then pat dry. Slice the snow peas lengthwise into 1/4-inch strips and toss them with 1 tablespoon of the olive dressing./nStep 3: In a medium bowl, lightly break up the drained tuna with a fork. Add 6 tablespoons of the olive dressing and toss gently./nStep 4: Spread the cut sides of the rolls or baguette pieces with the remaining olive dressing. On the bottom halves of the rolls or baguette pieces, arrange the snow peas, followed by the red onion slices, the tomatoes, tuna and sliced eggs. Close the tuna sandwiches and serve./nStep 5: The tuna sandwiches can be kept at room temperature for up to 3 hours./nStep 6: Even a meal that arrives between two slices of bread deserves to be matched with the right wine. This Italian tuna sandwich merits an equally flavorful Mediterranean bottle. Look for a dry rosé from Sicily with gutsy fruitniness to offset the saltiness of the tuna. Alternatively, look for a Sardinian red with dried-spice character and peppery fruit flavors which meld with the olive, thyme and pepper of the sandwich, while its acidity and firm tannins are a clean counterbalance to the tuna and black–olive dressing.

Ingredients: 4 ounces fresh sea urchin (see Note)/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n1/2 pound linguine/n1 cup ramp greens, coarsely chopped, or 3 tablespoons chopped chives (see Note)
Steps: Step 1: In a blender, puree the sea urchin with 2 tablespoons of the olive oil until smooth./nStep 2: In a pot of heavily salted boiling water, cook the linguine until al dente. Meanwhile, in a deep skillet, heat the remaining 2 tablespoons of oil. Add the ramps and cook over moderately high heat until wilted, 1 minute./nStep 3: Drain the linguine, reserving 5 tablespoons of the cooking water. Add the linguine to the skillet with the sea urchin puree and 2 tablespoons of the cooking water and toss over moderate heat for 30 seconds. Off the heat, add the remaining 3 tablespoons of cooking water and toss. Transfer the linguine to bowls and serve./nStep 4: Look for uni (sea urchin) at Japanese markets. If using chives, toss them with the pasta at the end./nStep 5: Muscadet from France's western Loire Valley is crisp and subtly salty, exquisite with rich, briny sea urchin.

Ingredients: ¼  cup plus 2 tablespoons (3 ounces) unsalted butter/n3  tablespoons capers, drained and rinsed/n2  large egg yolks/n1  teaspoon fresh lemon juice (from 1 lemon)/n¼  teaspoon kosher salt/nPinch of cayenne pepper/nPinch of ground white pepper/n1 to 4 tablespoons boiling water, as needed/n1  tablespoon white vinegar/n8  large eggs/n8  smoked salmon slices (about 6 ounces total)/n4  English muffins, split and toasted/n2  cups packed arugula (about 2 ounces), roughly chopped/nThinly sliced fresh chives
Steps: Step 1: Place butter and capers in a small saucepan; heat over medium-low. Cook butter and capers, stirring occasionally, until butter browns and capers are crispy, about 6 minutes. Transfer capers to a small bowl using a slotted spoon; remove saucepan from heat. Reserve butter in pan. Whisk together egg yolks and lemon juice in a medium-size nonreactive metal bowl or glass bowl until well combined./nStep 2: Add water to a medium saucepan to a depth of 1 inch, and bring to a low simmer over medium-low. Place egg yolk mixture in bowl over pan of simmering water, and whisk continuously (be sure bottom of bowl is not touching water). Slowly drizzle reserved warm butter into mixture, whisking vigorously until thick and creamy, about 6 minutes. Remove from heat, and whisk in salt, cayenne pepper, and white pepper. (If mixture is too thick, slowly add boiling water as needed, 1 tablespoon at a time, until desired consistency.)/nStep 3: Add water to a deep 12-inch skillet to a depth of 2 inches. Add vinegar, and bring to a low simmer over medium-low. Working in 2 batches of 4 eggs each, crack egg into a small heatproof bowl, being careful not to break yolk. Gently lower bowl into water, and carefully pour out egg; quickly repeat with remaining 3 eggs. Cook until egg whites are set, 3 to 4 minutes per batch. Transfer eggs to a paper towel-lined plate using a slotted spoon./nStep 4: Place 1 salmon slice on each toasted muffin half, and top each with 1 egg. Spoon 1 tablespoon warm egg yolk mixture evenly over each egg, and top evenly with crispy capers. Top evenly with arugula, and garnish with chives. Serve immediately./nStep 5: Capers can be crisped the day beforehand and kept in an airtight container in the refrigerator overnight. Butter can also be stored in the fridge and re-melted day of. Hollandaise sauce can be kept warm on the stove for 30 minutes.

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1/2 pound large shrimp, shelled and deveined/n1/4 pound skinless, boneless chicken breast, thinly sliced/n2 1/2 cups chopped Napa cabbage/n1 small onion, thinly sliced/n1 carrot, thinly sliced on the bias/n7 ounces enoki mushrooms/n4 ounces oyster mushrooms/n1/4 cup dried wood ear mushrooms, soaked in warm water for 10 minutes and drained/n1/2 cup chicken stock/n3 tablespoons soy sauce/n1 teaspoon Asian sesame oil/n18 ounces frozen precooked udon noodles, thawed/nKosher salt and freshly ground pepper/nChopped scallions, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of the vegetable oil. Add the shrimp and stir-fry over moderately high heat until curled, 2 minutes; transfer to a plate. Add 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil to the skillet. Add the chicken and stir-fry until white throughout, 3 minutes; transfer to the plate with the shrimp./nStep 2: Add the remaining 1 tablespoon of oil to the skillet. Add the cabbage, onion, carrot and the mushrooms and stir-fry for 4 minutes. Add the stock, soy sauce, sesame oil, shrimp and chicken; remove from the heat./nStep 3: Meanwhile, cook the udon in a pot of boiling salted water for 1 minute. Drain and add to the skillet. Stir-fry over high heat until heated through. Season with salt and pepper, garnish with scallions and serve./nStep 4: Crisp, citrus-inflected Italian Pinot Bianco.

Ingredients: 1 (33.8-ounce) package fish broth (such as Aneto)/n2 medium-size plum tomatoes (about 8 ounces), quartered lengthwise/n1 small (6-ounce) yellow onion, peeled and halved lengthwise/n1 (1-inch) piece fresh ginger, peeled and thinly sliced/n4 medium garlic cloves, smashed/n1 small (11-ounce) red grapefruit/n1 ½ tablespoons fish sauce, plus more to taste/n1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice (from 1 lemon)/nFine sea salt, to taste/n12  deveined unpeeled head-on raw large Argentinean prawns (about 1 1/2 pounds) or 1 1/2 pounds deveined unpeeled head-on raw extra-large shrimp/n1 tablespoon seasoning salt (such as Johnny's Fine Foods)/n1 tablespoon canola oil, divided/n12 medium shishito peppers (about 3 ounces)/nSmall fresh cilantro leaves and thinly sliced watermelon radish, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Bring fish broth, tomatoes, onion, ginger, and garlic to a boil in a medium saucepan over medium. Reduce heat to medium-low; simmer, uncovered, until flavors meld and liquid has reduced to about 3 1/4 cups (about 6 3/4 cups including solids), about 45 minutes./nStep 2: Using a Y-shaped peeler, remove grapefruit peel in 6 to 8 long strips. Cut grapefruit in half crosswise, and squeeze to yield 1/2 cup juice. Discard squeezed grapefruit. Remove broth mixture from heat, and add grapefruit juice and peel strips. Let mixture stand 10 minutes. Pour mixture through a fine wire-mesh strainer set over a medium-size heatproof bowl; discard solids. Return strained broth to saucepan; stir in fish sauce and lemon juice. Add salt and additional fish sauce to taste. Cover and keep warm over low./nStep 3: Preheat grill to medium-high (400°F to 450°F). Toss together prawns, seasoning salt, and 2 teaspoons oil in a medium bowl. Toss together shishito peppers and remaining 1 teaspoon oil in a separate medium bowl. Arrange prawns and shishito peppers on unoiled grates; grill, uncovered, turning occasionally, until prawns are cooked through and peppers are lightly charred and tender, about 4 minutes per side. (Prawn shells will start to release from the meat when they're cooked through.)/nStep 4: Divide sinigang broth evenly among 4 bowls. Arrange 3 prawns and 3 shishito peppers in each bowl. Garnish with cilantro and radish, and serve./nStep 5: The sinigang broth can be prepared through step 1 up to 3 days in advance and stored in an airtight container in refrigerator. Warm broth over low heat before proceeding with step 2./nStep 6: Aneto fish broth is available at specialty grocery stores and online at marianafoods.us.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n2 teaspoons white truffle oil or extra-virgin olive oil/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n1/2 pound celery root, peeled/n1/4 pound arugula (8 cups)/n2 ounces pea shoots (2 packed cups)/n1/4 pound thinly sliced smoked salmon, cut into 1/4-inch-wide strips
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, mix the lemon juice with the truffle oil and season with salt and pepper. Set aside until ready to use./nStep 2: Using a mandoline, slice the celery root very thinly. Stack the slices and cut them into very fine strips./nStep 3: In a large bowl, toss the arugula with the pea shoots, celery root and smoked salmon. Add the dressing and toss well. Mound the salad on plates and serve./nStep 4: One Serving Calories 103 kcal, Total Fat 4.0 gm, Saturated Fat 0.6 gm, Protein 8 gm, Carbohydrates 11 gm.

Ingredients: One 1 1/2-pound lobster/n6 tablespoons unsalted butter/n2 tablespoons finely diced lean salt pork/n2 medium onions, coarsely chopped/n1 pound red potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice/n2 cups bottled clam juice/n1 cup water/n1 bay leaf/n1 quart light cream/n2 one-pound halibut or haddock fillets, without skin/n6 ounces smoked mussels, drained and patted dry/n6 ounces smoked shrimp, drained and patted dry/n1/2 teaspoon sweet paprika/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n3 tablespoons chopped flat-leaf parsley, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: In a medium pot of boiling salted water, cook the lobster until bright red all over, about 9 minutes. Transfer the lobster to a plate and let cool slightly. Twist the tail and claws from the body and crack the claws. Remove the meat from the tail in 1 piece. Make a slit down the center of the tail meat and remove the intestinal tract. Remove the meat from the claws. Cut the lobster meat into 1-inch pieces. Cover and refrigerate./nStep 2: Melt the butter in a large saucepan. Add the salt pork and cook over moderate heat, stirring, for 1 minute. Stir in the onions and cook until softened, about 7 minutes. Add the potatoes, clam juice, water and bay leaf and bring to a simmer. Cook over moderate heat until the potatoes are just tender, about 12 minutes. Add the cream and return to a simmer. Add the fish fillets and simmer gently until they break apart and are cooked through, about 10 minutes./nStep 3: Remove the soup from the heat and stir in the mussels, shrimp and lobster meat. Cook over low heat until the shellfish is just heated through. Add the paprika and season with salt and pepper. Ladle the chowder into mugs or bowls, garnish with the parsley and serve./nStep 4: The chowder can be refrigerated for up to 1 day. Rewarm over moderately low heat./nStep 5: To remove the tail meat from a lobster in one piece, snap off the flipper at the end of the tail. Then place the tail on its side and press gently on it with the heel of your hand until you feel the shell crack; don't push too hard or you'll mangle the meat. You can also use kitchen shears to slice along either side of the soft underside of the tail. For both methods, put the tail on a kitchen towel and pull away the sides of the shell to release the meat.

Ingredients: 12 ounces small to medium radishes, trimmed (and halved, if needed)/n1 tablespoon olive oil/n¼ teaspoon black pepper/n1 teaspoon kosher salt, divided/n.50 cup sour cream/n2 teaspoons grated lemon zest/n¼ cup almond oil/n3.50 tablespoons wildflower honey/n1.50 tablespoons aged sherry vinegar/n3 cups thinly sliced fennel, plus fennel fronds for garnish/n2 cups thinly sliced unpeeled underripe stone fruit (such as peaches or apricots/n2 cups (8-ounce) packages hot-smoked trout fillets (such as Ducktrap River of Maine), skin discarded/nFlaky sea salt, for garnish/nToasted baguette slices, for serving
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 450°F. Toss together radishes, olive oil, pepper, and 1/4 teaspoon kosher salt on a rimmed baking sheet; arrange any halved radishes cut sides down. Roast in preheated oven until radishes are tender and lightly browned, about 15 minutes. Let cool 5 minutes./nStep 2: While radishes cool, stir together sour cream and lemon zest in a small bowl. Whisk together almond oil, honey, vinegar, and 1/2 teaspoon kosher salt in a separate small bowl until creamy; reserve 1/4 cup vinaigrette for drizzling. Combine sliced fennel, stone fruit, remaining vinaigrette, and remaining 1/4 teaspoon kosher salt in a large bowl; toss to coat./nStep 3: Spread 2 tablespoons sour cream mixture along one side of each of 4 plates to form a semicircle. Decoratively pile fennel mixture and radishes on sour cream mixture. Gently break each trout fillet in half crosswise, and place alongside fennel mixture. Garnish fennel mixture with fennel fronds and sea salt. Drizzle reserved 1/4 cup vinaigrette evenly over trout. Serve alongside toasted baguette slices./nStep 4: Savory, lightly honeyed French white: 2018 Clos Lapeyre Jurançon Sec.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for brushing/n5 garlic cloves/n6 ounces rustic Italian bread, torn into 1 1/2-inch pieces/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground pepper/n1 large head of radicchio— quartered through the core/n2 teaspoons honey, plus more for drizzling/n1/4 cup white verjus (see Note)/n1 teaspoon soy sauce/n1 jalapeño, seeded and minced/n1 1/2 tablespoons minced fresh ginger/n1 tablespoon minced preserved lemon rind (optional; see Note) or 1 teaspoon grated lemon zest/n3 plum tomatoes, cut into 3/4-inch dice/n2 roasted red bell peppers, cut into 3/4-inch dice/n1 English cucumber—halved lengthwise, seeded and sliced crosswise 1/4 inch thick/n4 scallions, thinly sliced/n2 celery ribs, thinly sliced crosswise, plus 1/2 cup celery leaves/n3 ounces white anchovy fillets (alici or boquerones), cut into 3/4-inch pieces (see Note)/n1 cup lightly packed flat-leaf parsley
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 350°. In a blender, blend the 1/2 cup of olive oil with the garlic until smooth. On a rimmed baking sheet, toss the bread with the garlic oil and season with salt and pepper. Spread the bread in a single layer and bake for about 15 minutes, stirring once, until golden and barely crisp. Let cool completely./nStep 2: Meanwhile, light a grill or preheat a grill pan. Brush the cut sides of the radicchio with olive oil and drizzle with a little honey. Grill the radicchio cut side down over high heat, turning once, until charred and just starting to soften, about 3 minutes. Let cool completely, then cut into 1-inch pieces; discard the cores./nStep 3: In a large bowl, whisk the 2 teaspoons of honey with the verjus, soy sauce, jalapeño, ginger and preserved lemon, if using. Add the tomatoes, roasted red peppers, cucumber, scallions, sliced celery and celery leaves and toss well. Stir in the croutons, grilled radicchio, anchovies and parsley and season with salt and pepper. Serve right away./nStep 4: Verjus is the juice of unripened grapes. It’s often used as a substitute for vinegar. Preserved lemon is a condiment used primarily in Indian and North African cooking. Both are available at specialty food shops. White anchovy fillets are available in the deli section of specialty food shops./nStep 5: Assertive flavors, like fishy anchovies and bitter radicchio, can be toned down with juicy, fruity wines. Try a robust rosé, like one from Australia or Spain’s Rioja region.

Ingredients: 2 large cucumbers (about 1 1/4 pounds)—peeled, seeded and coarsely chopped/n2 tablespoons sugar/n2 tablespoons rice vinegar/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n2 cups diced (1/2 inch) seedless red watermelon/n2 cups diced (1/2 inch) seedless yellow watermelon/n1 1/2 pounds red tomatoes, seeded and cut into 1/2-inch dice/nOne large cucumber—peeled, seeded and cut into 1/2-inch dice/n1/2 cup minced shallots/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n3 1/2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n2 tablespoons chopped tarragon/n1 pound large shrimp, shelled and deveined/n1/4 cup pure olive oil/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n2 cups baby salad greens
Steps: Step 1: In a blender, puree the cucumbers with the sugar, rice vinegar and salt. Strain the puree through a fine sieve set over a medium bowl. Refrigerate the cucumber water until chilled./nStep 2: In a large bowl, toss the red and yellow watermelon with the tomatoes, cucumber, shallots, extra-virgin olive oil, lemon juice and tarragon. Cover and refrigerate for at least 2 hours and for up to 6 hours./nStep 3: Shortly before serving, light a grill or heat a grill pan. In a large bowl, toss the shrimp with the pure olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Grill the shrimp over high heat until browned and just cooked, about 3 minutes per side./nStep 4: Spoon the watermelon salad into 4 shallow bowls. Arrange the grilled shrimp on top. Ladle the cucumber water into each bowl, top with the baby salad greens and serve./nStep 5: The cucumber water can be made up to 1 day ahead. Stir before adding to the salad.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon canola oil/n1 onion, thinly sliced/n3 garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n1 fennel bulb, thinly sliced/n1 carrot, thinly sliced/n5 pounds red snapper bones, coarsely chopped and rinsed well/n3 ripe tomatoes, coarsely chopped/n4 oil-packed anchovies/n1 orange, zest removed with a vegetable peeler and orange halved/n1/4 Scotch bonnet chile/n3 sprigs each parsley, basil and mint, tied in a bundle with kitchen string/n2 quarts cold water/nSalt and freshly ground black pepper/n2 tablespoons canola oil, plus more for brushing/n4 garlic cloves, thinly sliced/n4 carrots, thinly sliced on the diagonal/n1 bunch of scallions, cut into 3-inch lengths/n18 okra, halved lengthwise/n1/2 Scotch bonnet or habanero chile, seeded and minced/n2 tomatoes, cut into eighths/nPinch of ground allspice/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/nSix 7-ounce red snapper fillets (about 1 1/2 inches thick), skin lightly scored
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot, heat the oil. Add the onion, garlic, fennel and carrot and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 15 minutes. Add the fish bones and cook until just beginning to turn opaque, about 10 minutes. Add the tomatoes, anchovies and orange zest. Squeeze the orange juice into the pot. Add the halves to the pot along with the Scotch bonnet, herb bundle and water and bring to a boil. Simmer over moderately low heat until the broth is very flavorful, about 1 hour. Strain the broth and season with salt and pepper./nStep 2: Preheat the oven to 500°. In a large skillet, heat the 2 tablespoons of canola oil. Add the garlic and carrots and cook over moderately high heat, stirring, until they are barely tender, about 3 minutes. Add the scallions, okra and Scotch bonnet and cook for 2 minutes, stirring occasionally. Add the tomatoes and cook, stirring, for 1 minute. Stir in the allspice and season with salt and pepper. Let cool slightly./nStep 3: Place six 12-inch squares of heavy-duty aluminum foil on a work surface, shiny side down, and brush with oil. Season the snapper fillets with salt and pepper and place one in the center of each piece of foil. Spoon the vegetables over the fillets. Fold up the sides of the foil and seal each packet./nStep 4: Arrange the packets on a sturdy baking sheet and bake for about 18 minutes, until the fish is tender and the vegetables are cooked through. Transfer the packets to plates. Pour the fish tea into cups and serve alongside./nStep 5: The fish tea can be refrigerated overnight. The packets can be assembled and refrigerated for up to 2 hours./nStep 6: Vermentino, a grape that thrives in Italy's coastal vineyard regions, produces minerally, focused white wines that go well with white fish like snapper, partly because Vermentino's lemony acidity works in a similar way to a squeeze of lemon.

Ingredients: 1 1/2 pounds fresh curly spinach, thick stems discarded/n1 cup orzo/n1 pound sweet Italian sausage, casings removed/n2 thyme sprigs/n5 medium shallots, finely chopped (1 cup)/n1 1/2 cups dry white wine/n1 cup chicken stock or low-sodium broth/n3 pounds littleneck or other small hard-shell clams, scrubbed/n4 tablespoons salted butter, sliced/nJuice of 1/2 lemon/n3 tablespoons chopped parsley
Steps: Step 1: In a large pot of boiling water, blanch the spinach, stirring occasionally, until wilted, about 2 minutes. Drain and let cool, then squeeze dry. Coarsely chop the spinach./nStep 2: In a medium pot of boiling salted water, cook the orzo until al dente. Drain and transfer to a large shallow serving bowl./nStep 3: Heat a large enameled cast-iron casserole over high heat until hot. Add the sausage and thyme and cook, breaking up the sausage, until the meat is golden, about 6 minutes. Add the shallots and cook, stirring, until golden, about 4 minutes. Add the wine and boil until reduced by half. Add the stock and bring to a boil. Add the clams, cover and cook until wide open, 6 to 8 minutes. Transfer the clams as they are done to the serving bowl with the orzo. Discard the thyme sprigs./nStep 4: Boil the broth in the casserole until reduced to 1/2 cup. Remove from the heat and stir in the spinach, butter and lemon juice. Pour the sauce over the clams and toss well. Sprinkle the parsley over the ragout and serve.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup crème fraîche or sour cream/n1 teaspoon chopped dill/n1 teaspoon fresh lemon juice/nKosher salt and freshly ground black pepper/n1 tablespoon snipped chives/n2 medium baking potatoes (1 pound), peeled/n1 small onion/n1 large egg, lightly beaten/n2 tablespoons all-purpose flour/n1/2 teaspoon baking powder/n1/2 cup vegetable oil/n1/2 pound thinly sliced smoked salmon/n2 ounces caviar
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, stir the crème fraîche with the dill and lemon juice. Season with salt and black pepper and sprinkle with the chives. Refrigerate until ready to serve./nStep 2: In a food processor or on a box grater, coarsely shred the potatoes and the onion. Transfer to a large, clean kitchen towel and squeeze dry./nStep 3: In a medium bowl, mix the shredded potatoes and onion with the egg, flour, baking powder, 1 teaspoon of salt and 1/4 teaspoon of black pepper./nStep 4: In a large nonstick skillet or on a griddle, heat the vegetable oil until shimmering. Drop 2 tablespoons of the potato mixture into the skillet and flatten with the back of a spoon to make a 3-inch round. Make about 5 more pancakes and cook over moderately high heat until golden on the bottom, about 4 minutes. Flip the pancakes and cook until golden, about 2 minutes longer. Transfer to paper towels to drain. Repeat with the remaining potato mixture; you should have 12 pancakes./nStep 5: Arrange the potato pancakes on a platter. Serve warm, with the dill cream, smoked salmon and caviar./nStep 6: These crisp potato pancakes seem to hark back to Puck's Austrian heritage, so serving them with an Austrian wine feels appropriate—especially since dry Riesling's mineral and apple notes pair so well with the smoked salmon and caviar toppings.

Ingredients: 3 tablespoons pressed caviar (3 ounces)/n2 tablespoons sour cream/n1 tablespoon minced chives/n2 large eggs/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/n1 tablespoon unsalted butter
Steps: Step 1: Roll out the caviar between two sheets of plastic wrap to a 5-by-8-inch rectangle 1/8 inch thick. Cut half of it into 1/2-inch strips. Finely dice the remaining caviar and transfer to a small bowl. Stir in the sour cream and all but a pinch of the chives./nStep 2: In a small bowl, beat the eggs until frothy and season with salt and pepper. In a 6-inch nonstick skillet, melt the butter over high heat until the foam subsides. Add the eggs and stir constantly with a heatproof rubber spatula, while shaking the skillet, until the eggs are set but still moist./nStep 3: Off the heat, dollop the sour cream mixture across the center of the eggs. Shake the skillet to loosen the omelet, then fold one-third of the eggs over the filling. Tilt the skillet and turn the omelet onto a plate, folding it over itself as you tilt. Garnish with the caviar strips, sprinkle with the remaining chives and serve right away.

Ingredients: 8 ounces yellow Chinese egg noodles/n2 tablespoons soy sauce/n2 tablespoons oyster sauce/n1 tablespoon hoisin/n1 tablespoon rice vinegar/n1 teaspoon brown sugar/n2 tablespoons water/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n8 cloves garlic, minced/n1/2 medium onion, chopped/n1 tablespoon minced fresh ginger/n1/2 pound boneless, skinless chicken, cut 1/2-inch thick/n8 ounces mushrooms, sliced/n4 scallions, cut into one-inch pieces
Steps: Step 1: Cook the noodles according to the package instructions. Rinse under cold water, drain and set aside./nStep 2: In medium bowl, combine the soy sauce, oyster sauce, hoisin, rice vinegar, brown sugar and water. Set aside./nStep 3: Heat a large pan or wok on medium-high heat. Add the oil and then stir in the garlic, onion, and ginger. Cook for 2 to 3 minutes or until the garlic and onions are soft and fragrant./nStep 4: Stir in the chicken and mushrooms. Cook for 3 to 5 minutes or until the chicken is browned and nearly cooked through./nStep 5: Stir in the scallions and cook for 2 to 3 minutes or until the scallions are tender. Add noodles and sauce mixture. Toss everything together until combined and heated through, about 2 minutes. Serve hot.

Ingredients: 8  whole Pomfret fish, cleaned and trimmed, or 16 fillets of pomfret, sea bass or tilapia/n1 teaspoon ground turmeric/n1 tablespoon tandoori masala/n1 teaspoon garam masala/n¾ cup strained plain (Greek-style) yogurt/n4 tablespoons mustard oil/n4 tablespoons ginger-garlic paste/n2 tablespoons Kashmiri chile powder (see note)/n2 tablespoons besan (chickpea flour)/n2 tablespoons lemon juice (from 1 lemon)/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/nMelted butter/nChaat masala/nCilantro sprigs/nRed onions cut in rings/nLemon wedges
Steps: Step 1: Make several 2-inch incisions on fish fillets, about 1 inch apart. In a small bowl, whisk turmeric, tandoori masala, garam masala, yogurt, mustard oil, ginger-garlic paste, Kashmiri chile powder, besan, lemon juice, and salt until combined. Cover fish with marinade and refrigerate 30 minutes./nStep 2: Preheat oven to broil, with rack about 6 inches from heat source. Line a broiler-safe baking sheet with foil. Place fish on prepared baking sheet and broil until edges char, about 10 minutes./nStep 3: Brush fish with melted butter, top with chaat masala, and serve with cilantro, onion rings, and lemon wedges./nStep 4: If you can't find Kashmiri chile powder, substitute with a mix of 3 parts paprika and 1 part cayenne pepper.

Ingredients: 1 (12-ounce) skinless salmon fillet/n1/2 cup mezcal/n3 dried chipotle chiles, stemmed, seeded, and torn into small pieces/n1/4 cup kosher salt/n2 ounces cream cheese, at room temperature/n2 tablespoons fresh lime juice/nKosher salt/n4 ounces small sorrel leaves (see note)/n1/4 cup red onion, thinly sliced
Steps: Step 1: Set the salmon fillet in a glass or ceramic baking dish. Brush the fish all over with 1/4 cup of the mezcal, then cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 1 hour./nStep 2: In a spice grinder, combine the dried chipotles with the kosher salt and grind to a fine powder. Sprinkle both sides of the salmon with the chipotle salt, then cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate for 4 hours longer./nStep 3: Brush the salmon with the remaining 1/4 cup of mezcal and tightly wrap the fillet in plastic. Refrigerate for at least 4 hours or overnight./nStep 4: Unwrap the salmon. On a work surface, using a very sharp, thin knife, cut the fish at an angle crosswise into very thin slices. Arrange the slices on a platter./nStep 5: In a blender or food processor, puree the cream cheese with the lime juice and 2 tablespoons of water. Season with salt. In a bowl, toss the sorrel with the red onion and the dressing. Serve the salad alongside the salmon./nStep 6: The salmon can be prepared through Step 3 and refrigerated for up to 4 days./nStep 7: If sorrel is unavailable, use baby spinach./nStep 8: A clean, dry Rosé.

Ingredients: 1 pound small Yukon Gold potatoes, sliced 1/4 inch thick/n2 tablespoons drained capers/n2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil/nKosher salt/nPepper/nFour 5-to 6-ounce skin-on sea bass fillets/n3 tablespoons grapefruit juice/n1 Hass avocado—peeled, pitted and chopped/n2 tablespoons chopped tarragon
Steps: Step 1: In a medium bowl, combine the potatoes, capers and 1 tablespoon of the olive oil, season with salt and pepper and toss to coat. On a heatproof plate that fits inside a large enameled cast-iron casserole, arrange the potatoes in a slightly overlapping layer. Place a small heatproof bowl upside down in the center of the casserole and place the plate with the potatoes on top. Add enough water to reach 1 inch up the side of the casserole. Bring the water to a simmer, cover the casserole and steam the potatoes over moderate heat until almost tender, about 15 minutes./nStep 2: Rub the fish with the remaining 1 tablespoon of olive oil and season with salt and pepper. Arrange the fillets on top of the potatoes, skin side up, in a single layer and drizzle with 2 tablespoons of the grapefruit juice. Cover and steam until the potatoes are tender and the fish is just opaque throughout, about 8 minutes longer./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a small bowl, toss the avocado with the tarragon and the remaining 1 tablespoon of grapefruit juice; season with salt and pepper./nStep 4: Transfer the potatoes and fish to plates. Top with any juices from the plate and the avocado salsa and serve.

Ingredients: 2 medium carrots, cut into 2-inch lengths/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for frying/n2 large shallots, thinly sliced/n4 thyme sprigs/n4 bay leaves/n1 large garlic clove, thinly sliced/n1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons red wine vinegar/nSalt and freshly ground pepper/nFour 6-ounce skin-on Spanish mackerel fillets/n1/4 cup prepared black olive tapenade
Steps: Step 1: Using a mandoline, cut the carrots into thin strips. In a small skillet, heat 1/4 cup of the olive oil. Add the carrots, shallots, thyme sprigs, bay leaves and garlic and cook over moderate heat until the vegetables are softened, about 6 minutes. Remove from the heat. Stir in the vinegar and season with salt and pepper. Let stand for 10 minutes./nStep 2: In a large nonstick skillet, heat 1/4 inch of olive oil until shimmering. Season the mackerel fillets with salt and pepper and add them to the skillet skin-side down. Cook over high heat until the skin is browned and crisp, about 4 minutes. Turn and cook the fillets for 1 minute longer, until almost cooked through. Transfer the fillets to a large, shallow glass or ceramic dish, skin side up. Top with the vegetables and their marinade. Let stand at room temperature for 3 hours, occasionally spooning the marinade over./nStep 3: Discard the thyme sprigs and bay leaves. Arrange the mackerel on plates and spoon the vegetables and their marinade on top. Dollop with the tapenade and serve./nStep 4: The tangy flavors in this dish will pair best with an equally tart white wine, such as an Australian Riesling.

Ingredients: 1  lemon/n2 medium (8-ounce) leeks, rinsed thoroughly/n¾ cup extra-virgin olive oil, divided/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/nBlack pepper, to taste/n1 ½ cups lower-sodium chicken stock/n20  (5-inch) thyme sprigs/n¼ cup finely chopped shallot (from 1 medium [1 1/2 oz.] shallot)/n2 tablespoons grated lemon zest, plus 1/4 cup fresh juice (from 3 lemons), divided/n1 tablespoon Champagne vinegar or white wine vinegar/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n½ teaspoon black pepper/n½ cup extra-virgin olive oil/n1 ¼ ounces Parmesan cheese, grated on a Microplane grater (about 3/4 cup loosely packed)/n1 teaspoon grated garlic (from 3 medium garlic cloves)/n2 teaspoons Champagne vinegar or white wine vinegar/n2 teaspoons fresh lemon juice (from 1 lemon)/n¾ cup canola oil (or another neutral cooking oil)/n¼ cup extra-virgin olive oil/n1  extra-large egg yolk/n1 teaspoon kosher salt/n½ teaspoon grated garlic (from 1 medium garlic clove)/n12  (3-inch) salt-packed anchovies (from 1 [29.9-ounce] jar or can)/n¼ cup olive oil/n1 tablespoon chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley/n1 teaspoon grated lemon zest (from 1 lemon)/n8 cups water/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n7 large eggs/n6  (3/4-inch-thick) sourdough bread slices/n1 medium garlic clove/n¾ cup Aïoli (recipe below)/n6 tablespoons finely chopped fresh chives/n5  (3 ounces each) heads baby romaine lettuce, leaves separated but kept whole (about 4 cups total)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 350°F. Cut lemon in half crosswise; thinly slice 1 lemon half. Reserve remaining lemon half for another use./nStep 2: Peel away and discard outer layer of each leek, and trim the hairy roots, leaving root ends attached. Place 1 leek on a cutting board with white end of the leek pointing away from you. To remove dark green part of leek, cut it at an angle, then roll the leek 90 degrees to repeat the same cut. Continue rolling and cutting in this manner until the tapered pale green end of leek resembles a sharpened pencil. Discard dark green leek trimmings. Cut leek lengthwise into quarters. Rinse to remove fine grit between each layer, and pat dry. Repeat process with remaining leek./nStep 3: Place leeks in a 3-quart baking dish. Drizzle evenly with 1/4 cup of the oil; sprinkle evenly with salt and pepper to taste; toss to coat. Pour in chicken stock. Drizzle evenly with remaining 1/2 cup oil. Arrange lemon slices over leeks, and scatter with thyme sprigs. Cover baking dish tightly with aluminum foil. Bake in preheated oven until leeks are very tender, about 45 minutes. Remove from oven, and increase oven temperature to 400ºF. Remove and discard foil from baking dish. Remove and discard lemon slices and thyme sprigs. Return leeks to oven, and bake at 400°F until leeks are glazed and golden brown and liquid has evaporated, 1 hour to 1 hour, 15 minutes. Set aside at room temperature until ready to use. Braised Leeks may be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 5 days./nStep 4: Whisk together shallot, lemon juice, vinegar, salt, and pepper in a small bowl. Let stand 10 minutes. Gradually add oil in a slow, steady stream, whisking constantly until emulsified. Whisk in Parmesan cheese, garlic, and lemon zest. Store in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 5 days./nStep 5: Whisk together vinegar and lemon juice in a small bowl. Whisk together canola oil and olive oil in a small measuring cup. Place egg yolk in a medium bowl. Wet a clean kitchen towel, and drape over a medium saucepan to cover; place bowl with egg yolk on top of towel. This will help hold the bowl in place. Whisk egg yolk until pale yellow, 2 to 3 minutes. Add salt and garlic; whisk to combine./nStep 6: Add oil mixture 1 drop at a time, whisking constantly, until oil and egg are emulsified; you will have added 2 or 3 tablespoons of oil mixture. Add 1 tablespoon of the lemon juice mixture, and whisk to combine. Drizzle remaining oil mixture in a slow, steady stream, whisking constantly and stopping when mayonnaise thickens to add remaining lemon juice mixture, until you've added all the oil. Whisk in remaining lemon juice mixture, if there is any. Aïoli may be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 3 days./nStep 7: Rinse anchovies under cold water to remove salt. Place anchovies in a small bowl, and cover with cold water. Let soak until anchovy flesh softens slightly, 20 to 30 minutes. Drain and gently pat anchovies dry. Using a paring knife, cut each anchovy lengthwise into 2 fillets. Gently lift out spines and discard. Stir together anchovy fillets, oil, parsley, and lemon zest in a small bowl. Let stand at room temperature 1 hour./nStep 8: Meanwhile, bring 8 cups water to a boil in a large saucepan over high. Add salt. (The salt helps the egg whites solidify quickly if a shell cracks). Gently add eggs; simmer, undisturbed, for 5 minutes. Meanwhile, fill a medium bowl with ice water; set aside. Remove pan from heat; let eggs stand in water 5 minutes. Remove 1 "tester" egg, and crack it open to see if it's cooked to perfection — white and the outer rim of the yolk should be cooked through, while the innermost portion of yolk should be bright yellow and slightly wet looking. If the yolk is runny and wet looking, let eggs stand in hot water up to 2 additional minutes. Transfer eggs to prepared ice water; let cool completely, about 10 minutes. Peel eggs, and cut into thin slices. Set aside until ready to use./nStep 9: Preheat grill to medium-high (400°F to 450°F). Arrange bread on oiled grates; grill, uncovered, until toasted, 2 to 3 minutes per side. Remove from grill. Rub garlic clove evenly over 1 side of each bread slice./nStep 10: Spread about 2 tablespoons Aïoli over the garlic side of each bread slice. Cut each bread slice in half diagonally, and divide evenly among 6 plates. Cut 4 Braised Leek pieces diagonally into thirds; arrange evenly on top of bread pieces, fanning them out slightly. Reserve remaining leeks for another use. Arrange egg slices evenly on top of leeks. Top each bread piece with 2 anchovy fillets, and drizzle with some of the anchovy marinade. Sprinkle evenly with chives./nStep 11: Toss together lettuce leaves and 3/4 cup Garlic-Parmesan Vinaigrette in a medium bowl. Massage each leaf with vinaigrette to ensure every leaf is dressed evenly. Divide lettuce evenly among plates, and fan out next to the crostini.

Ingredients: 4 ounces fresh lump crabmeat (about 3/4 cup), drained and picked/n1/4 cup panko/n2 scallions, finely chopped/n3 tablespoons mayonnaise/n2 tablespoons finely chopped jalapeño/n3/4 teaspoon paprika/n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt/n1/4 teaspoon celery seeds/n1/4 teaspoon cayenne pepper, or more to taste/n1/3 cup fine yellow or white cornmeal (about 1 1/4 ounces)/n1/3 cup all-purpose flour (about 1 1/2 ounces)/n1 tablespoon light brown sugar/n3/4 teaspoon ground coriander/n3/4 teaspoon kosher salt/n1/2 teaspoon baking powder/n1/2 cup buttermilk/n2 large eggs, beaten/n2 tablespoons vegetable oil/n1/2 cup fresh or thawed frozen yellow corn kernels (about 2 1/4 ounces)/nCooking spray/nFinely chopped fresh cilantro, for garnish
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 400°F. Stir together crabmeat, panko, scallions, mayonnaise, jalapeño, paprika, salt, celery seeds, and cayenne in a small bowl until crabmeat breaks apart into shreds and mixture is evenly combined. Set aside./nStep 2: Whisk together cornmeal, flour, brown sugar, coriander, salt, and baking powder in a medium bowl. Whisk together buttermilk, eggs, and oil in a small bowl. Add buttermilk mixture to cornmeal mixture; whisk until smooth. Stir in corn kernels. Lightly grease (with cooking spray) a 24-cup miniature muffin pan. Divide cornmeal mixture evenly among muffin cups (about 1 tablespoon each). Spoon about 1 1/4 teaspoons deviled crab in center of batter in each cup. Bake in preheated oven until lightly browned and a toothpick inserted in center comes out clean, 12 to 15 minutes./nStep 3: Carefully remove muffins from pan, and place on a serving platter. Sprinkle with chopped cilantro, and serve warm./nStep 4: Deviled crab mixture can be made up to 1 day ahead and stored in an airtight container in refrigerator. Muffins can be baked up to 2 hours ahead and reheated in a 200°F oven until just warm, 3 to 5 minutes./nStep 5: Lively, lemony white.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup chopped fresh mint/n3 tablespoons water/n2 tablespoons sugar/n1/2 cup white-wine vinegar/n2 cloves garlic, minced/n3/4 teaspoon salt/n4 tuna steaks, about 1 inch thick (about 2 pounds in all)/n1 tablespoon olive oil/n1/4 teaspoon fresh-ground black pepper
Steps: Step 1: Put 1/3 cup of the mint in a medium glass or stainless-steel bowl. In a small stainless-steel saucepan, bring the water to a simmer over moderate heat. Add the sugar and stir until completely dissolved. Stir in the vinegar, garlic, and 1/4 teaspoon of the salt. Pour the mixture over the mint in the bowl. Let sit 15 minutes./nStep 2: Light the grill or heat the broiler. Coat the tuna with the oil. Season with the remaining 1/2 teaspoon salt and the pepper. Cook the tuna for 4 minutes. Turn and cook until done to your taste, 3 to 4 minutes longer for medium rare./nStep 3: Strain the mint sauce through a sieve into a sauceboat or serving bowl. Stir in the remaining mint. Pass the sauce with the fish./nStep 4: Fish Alternatives Mackerel and salmon are both full-flavored enough to take on this sauce./nStep 5: Look for the lightest, leanest white you can find; anything else will have a tough time with the mint. Try a Verdicchio-based wine from Italy or a Vinho Verde from Portugal.

Ingredients: 1 cup apple cider vinegar/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n1 tablespoon sugar/n4  shallots (large (about 1/2 pound) thinly sliced crosswise into rings)
Steps: Step 1: In a small saucepan, combine the vinegar, salt and sugar with 1/2 cup of water and simmer over moderate heat until the sugar dissolves. Put the shallots in a small bowl or pint-size jar and pour the vinegar mixture on top. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours before using./nStep 2: The shallots can be refrigerated in the pickling liquid for up to 2 weeks.

Ingredients: 1 pound fresh ricotta/n1 teaspoon finely grated lemon zest plus 3 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1 garlic clove, finely grated/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for brushing and drizzling/n1 cup finely chopped mixed chives, parsley, mint and tarragon, plus more for garnish/nKosher salt/nPepper/n2 baguettes, split lengthwise
Steps: Step 1: In a food processor, puree the ricotta, lemon zest, lemon juice, garlic and the 1/4 cup of olive oil until smooth. Scrape into a medium bowl, stir in the herbs and season generously with salt and pepper./nStep 2: Light a grill. Brush the baguettes with olive oil. Grill over moderately high heat, turning once, until lightly charred, 3 minutes. Drizzle the herbed ricotta with olive oil and garnish with herbs and cracked pepper. Serve with the bread.

Yield: about 10 tablespoons, enough for 4 pounds of meat
Ingredients: 3 tablespoons chili powder/n2 tablespoons garlic powder/n2 tablespoons onion powder/n1 tablespoon ground cumin/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n1 teaspoon cayenne pepper/n2 teaspoons dried oregano/n1 teaspoon sweet paprika/n1 teaspoon black pepper
Steps: Step 1: In a medium bowl, whisk all of the ingredients until combined. Transfer the taco seasoning to an airtight container./nStep 2: The taco seasoning can be stored in an airtight container for up to 6 months./nStep 3: To make 4 servings of taco filling, in a large skillet, heat 2 tablespoons of canola oil. Add 1 pound of ground beef, turkey or chicken and cook over moderately high heat, stirring occasionally, until cooked through, about 8 minutes. Add 2 1/2 tablespoons of the taco seasoning and 1/2 cup of water and simmer until the meat is coated in a light sauce, about 2 minutes.

Ingredients: 8 slices of thick-cut bacon/n1/3 cup packed light brown sugar/nKosher salt/nPepper/n1/3 cup plus 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil/n1 medium fennel bulb—halved, cored and very thinly sliced/n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard/n1 1/2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n1 1/2 tablespoons sherry vinegar/n8 ounces baby spinach (12 cups)/n2 cups lightly packed basil leaves/n4 ounces French feta cheese, crumbled
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 375°. In a large bowl, coat the bacon with the brown sugar and 1/2 teaspoon of pepper. Arrange the bacon in an even layer on a parchment paper–lined baking sheet. Top with another piece of parchment paper and another large baking sheet. Bake for about 25 minutes, until the bacon is lightly browned and the fat is rendered. Remove the top baking sheet and parchment paper. Bake the bacon for about 15 minutes longer, until well browned and nearly crisp. Using tongs, transfer the bacon to a rack to cool and crisp, then coarsely chop./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a large skillet, heat 1 tablespoon of the oil. Add the fennel and a generous pinch each of salt and pepper. Cook over moderately high heat, stirring occasionally, until just softened and lightly browned, about 4 minutes. Transfer to a plate and let cool./nStep 3: In a large serving bowl, whisk the mustard with the lemon juice and vinegar. Gradually whisk in the remaining 1/3 cup of oil until emulsified. Season the dressing with salt and pepper. Add the fennel, spinach and basil to the bowl and toss well. Season with salt and pepper and toss again. Sprinkle the feta and candied bacon on top and serve right away./nStep 4: Minerally Chardonnay.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoons canola oil/n4  eggs (large beaten)/nKosher salt/nPepper/n3 tablespoons unsalted butter/n4 cups alliums, such as onions, shallots, leeks and scallions (finely chopped)/n4  garlic cloves (minced)/n2 tablespoons fresh ginger (minced)/n4 cups white or brown rice (cooked)/n1 tablespoons distilled white vinegar/n2 tablespoons Sriracha/n2 tablespoons mayonnaise/nSliced scallions (for garnish)
Steps: Step 1: In a large nonstick skillet, heat the oil. Add the eggs and season with salt and pepper. Cook the eggs over moderate heat, stirring, until just set, about 2 minutes. Transfer to a cutting board and coarsely chop./nStep 2: Wipe out the skillet and melt the butter in it. Add the alliums and season with salt. Cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until golden and tender, about 12 minutes. Add the garlic and ginger and cook, stirring, for 2 minutes. Add the rice, vinegar and eggs, season with salt and pepper and cook, stirring, until well mixed. Spread the rice evenly in the skillet and cook without stirring until golden and crispy on the bottom, 4 to 5 minutes./nStep 3: Meanwhile, in a small bowl, stir the Sriracha with the mayonnaise. Top the rice with scallions and serve with the Sriracha mayo.

Ingredients: 1 small ancho chile, seeded/n3 tablespoons hazelnuts/nTwo 1/2-inch-thick slices baguette, toasted and torn into 1-inch pieces/n3 tablespoons roasted almonds, preferably Marcona, coarsely chopped/n1 garlic clove, chopped/n2 plum tomatoes—peeled, seeded and coarsely chopped/n1 roasted red pepper from a jar, cut into 1-inch pieces/n1/2 tablespoon sherry vinegar/n1/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for brushing/n1 tablespoon chopped flat-leaf parsley/nSalt and freshly ground black pepper/n16 baby leeks or thick scallions, trimmed
Steps: Step 1: Light a grill. Preheat the oven to 350°. In a small heatproof bowl, cover the ancho with hot tap water and soak until softened, about 15 minutes. Drain./nStep 2: Meanwhile, in a pie plate, toast the hazelnuts in the oven for about 10 minutes, or until fragrant and lightly browned. Let the hazelnuts cool, then transfer them to a kitchen towel and rub them together to remove the skins. Transfer the hazelnuts to a work surface and let cool completely, then coarsely chop./nStep 3: In a food processor, combine the ancho with the hazelnuts, toasted baguette, almonds and garlic and process to a smooth paste. Add the tomatoes, roasted red pepper and vinegar and puree. With the machine on, slowly pour in the 1/4 cup of olive oil and process until blended and smooth. Scrape the romesco sauce into a bowl, stir in the parsley and season with salt and black pepper./nStep 4: Brush the leeks with oil and season with salt and pepper. Grill over high heat until charred all over, about 3 minutes. Serve with the romesco sauce alongside./nStep 5: The romesco sauce can be refrigerated for up to 2 days. Bring to room temperature before serving./nStep 6: To go with these grilled baby leeks, pour Catalonia's (and Spain's) most famous sparkling white wine, Cava. Avinyó's citrusy nonvintage Brut is Mantuano's choice.

Ingredients: 6 garlic cloves, peeled/n1/2 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n1 tablespoon peanut or canola oil/n4 medium onions, thinly sliced lengthwise (about 8 cups)/nKosher salt/nFreshly ground pepper/n1/3 cup sugar/n2/3 cup balsamic vinegar
Steps: Step 1: In a very small saucepan, submerge the garlic in the olive oil and cook over moderate heat until bubbles begin to appear. Reduce the heat to low and cook until the garlic is very soft, about 30 minutes./nStep 2: In a large skillet, heat the oil until shimmering. Add the onions, season with salt and pepper and cook over moderate heat, stirring occasionally, until the onions are soft, about 20 minutes. Add the sugar and cook over moderately low heat, stirring frequently, until the onions look dry, about 10 minutes. Add the vinegar and cook over low heat, stirring occasionally, until the onions are very soft and dry, about 45 minutes./nStep 3: Stir the garlic confit with its oil into the onions and cook for 5 minutes. Serve warm or at room temperature./nStep 4: The marmalade can be refrigerated for up to 2 weeks./nStep 5: Grilled rib eye steak.

Ingredients: ¼ cup dried sea lettuce (about 1/8 ounce)/n2 tablespoons flaky sea salt (such as Maldon)
Steps: Step 1: Toast sea lettuce in a medium skillet over medium, stirring occasionally, until fragrant and crisp, 1 to 2 minutes. Transfer to a mortar and pestle, and grind into a powder. Add salt, and grind to coat evenly. Store in an airtight container at room temperature up to 24 hours.

Ingredients: 1/2 cup packed light brown sugar/n1 tablespoon ground coriander/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n2 teaspoons ground cumin/n2 teaspoons smoked paprika
Steps: Step 1: In a small bowl, whisk all of the ingredients until well combined./nStep 2: The smoky spiced sugar rub can be stored in an airtight container for up to 3 months.

Ingredients: 8 small leeks, root ends trimmed/n6 tablespoons heavy cream/n1/2 cup freshly grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese/nKosher salt/nWhite pepper/nFreshly grated nutmeg
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the broiler. Cut off all but 3 inches of the dark green portion of the leeks. Make a horizontal slice lengthwise from the green ends, stopping at the firm white bulb. Rinse the leeks very well.”/nStep 2: In a pot of salted boiling water, blanch the leeks until just tender, about 8 minutes. Drain and transfer to a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking. Drain very well and pat dry. Halve the leeks lengthwise and arrange cut side up in a 2 1/2-quart gratin dish./nStep 3: In a medium bowl, mix the cream with the cheese and season with salt, white pepper and nutmeg. Spoon the cream mixture over the leeks. Broil 6 inches from the heat for 7 to 8 minutes, until golden and bubbling. Season with salt and white pepper and serve.

Ingredients: 2 tablespoons celery seeds/n2 tablespoons mustard seeds/n1 ½ tablespoons paprika/n1 tablespoon kosher salt/n1 teaspoon black pepper/n½ teaspoon crushed red pepper/n½ teaspoon ground ginger/n1  bay leaf (crushed)
Steps: Step 1: In a spice grinder, combine all of the ingredients and pulse until finely ground. Transfer to a small bowl./nStep 2: The Baltimore-style rub can be stored in an airtight container for up to 3 months.

Ingredients: One 12-ounce sweet potato, peeled and cut into 1⁄2-inch dice/n1⁄4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/n1⁄2 teaspoon paprika/n1⁄4 teaspoon piment d’Espelette/nKosher salt/n4 bone-in chicken thighs with skin/n2 tablespoons canola oil/n4 large shiitake mushrooms, stems discarded and caps halved/n10 garlic cloves, halved/n4 large shallots (6 ounces), cut into thick rings/n1 tablespoon minced fresh lemongrass (inner bulb only)/n1 cup dry white wine/n3 cups low-sodium chicken broth/n1⁄2 cup heavy cream/n1 teaspoon Asian fish sauce/n1 teaspoon Sriracha
Steps: Step 1: Preheat the oven to 400°. On a rimmed baking sheet, toss the diced sweet potato with the olive oil, paprika and piment d’Espelette. Season with salt. Roast the sweet potato for about 10 minutes, stirring halfway, until golden and tender. Reduce the oven temperature to 350°./nStep 2: Meanwhile, season the chicken thighs with salt. In a medium enameled cast-iron casserole, heat the canola oil. Add the chicken and cook over moderately high heat until browned all over, about 7 minutes. Transfer the chicken to a plate. Add the mushrooms, garlic, shallots and lemongrass to the casserole and cook, stirring, for 2 minutes. Add the white wine and bring to a boil. Simmer for 2 minutes, stirring to dissolve any browned bits on the bottom of the casserole. Add the chicken broth, heavy cream, fish sauce and Sriracha./nStep 3: Return the chicken thighs to the casserole and bring to a boil. Cover and braise the chicken in the oven for about 1 hour, until very tender./nStep 4: Spoon the roasted sweet potato into bowls. Top with the chicken thighs and mushroom sauce and serve./nStep 5: The chicken stew can be refrigerated for up to 2 days./nStep 6: Zesty, focused Chablis: 2011 Gilbert Picq

Ingredients: 1/2 cup freshly grated ginger/n1/2 cup sugar/n1 1/2 cups water/n1 ounce chilled verjus (see Note)/n3/4 ounce fresh ginger juice (from a 2-inch piece of grated ginger pressed through a fine strainer)/n3/4 ounce grenadine, preferably homemade/nIce/n1 1/2 ounces chilled club soda
Steps: Step 1: In a small saucepan, combine the ingredients. Bring to a boil, then simmer over low heat until reduced to about 1 3/4 cups. Strain, let cool and refrigerate for up to 5 days./nStep 2: In a mixing glass, combine 1 ounce of the Ginger Syrup (reserve the rest for another use), the verjus, ginger juice, and grenadine. Fill the glass with ice and stir well. Strain into a chilled coupe and stir in the club soda./nStep 3: Verjus, the tart juice pressed from unripe grapes, is available at specialty food stores.

Ingredients: 5 ounces inactive brewer's yeast (such as Twinlab) (about 3/4 cup)/n.50 ounce kosher salt (about 5 teaspoons)/n⅛ ounce gochugaru (about 1 1/2 teaspoons)/n⅛ ounce citric acid (about 1 1/2 teaspoons)
Steps: Step 1: Stir together all ingredients in a medium bowl until combined./nStep 2: Twinlab inactive brewer's yeast can be found at urbannutritioncenter.com./nStep 3: Store spicy yeast salt in an airtight container up to 6 months.

Ingredients: 2 medium beets, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice/n1 cup water/n1/2 cup dry red wine/n1 tablespoon light brown sugar/nKosher salt/n1/4 cup red wine vinegar/n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/n2 tablespoons Dijon mustard/n2 tablespoons chopped tarragon/n1 tablespoon minced shallot/n3/4 cup extra-virgin olive oil/nPepper/n3 cups water/n1 1/2 cups dry white wine/n1 large carrot, diced (1/3 cup)/n1 celery rib, diced (1/3 cup)/n1/2 small yellow onion, diced (1/3 cup)/n3 garlic cloves/n5 flat-leaf parsley sprigs/n3 tarragon sprigs/n1 bay leaf/n1 teaspoon black peppercorns/nKosher salt/n4 pounds small young leeks, trimmed and cleaned (about 8 leeks)/nPepper/n2 tablespoons snipped chives
Steps: Step 1: In a small saucepan, combine the beets with the water, wine, sugar and a 1/4 teaspoon of kosher salt. Bring to a boil over moderate heat, then cover and simmer over low heat until the beets are just tender, about 40 minutes. Uncover and continue cooking until the liquid is reduced to a syrup and the beets are soft, about 15 minutes. Remove from the heat and let cool./nStep 2: In a large bowl, combine the vinegar with the lemon juice, mustard, tarragon and shallot. Slowly whisk in the olive oil until emulsified. Stir in the cooled beets and their liquid, and season with salt and pepper./nStep 3: In a large saucepan, combine the water, wine, carrot, celery, onion, garlic, parsley, tarragon, bay leaf, peppercorns and 1 tablespoon of kosher salt. Bring to a simmer over moderate heat. Nestle the leeks in the liquid, then cover and cook over low heat until the leeks are tender, about 30 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer the leeks, carrots, celery and onion to a large plate; discard the liquid./nStep 4: Spoon half of the beet vinaigrette on a platter, top with the leeks, and season with salt and pepper. Top with the reserved vegetables and chives, and serve with the remaining vinaigrette./nStep 5: The beet vinaigrette can be refrigerated overnight.

Ingredients: Vegetable oil, for frying/n1/3 cup all-purpose flour/n1/3 cup fine cornmeal/n1 1/2 tablespoons cornstarch/n1 teaspoon fine salt, plus more for seasoning/n1 cup buttermilk/n1 large egg/n1 large sweet onion, cut into 1/4-inch-thick rings
Steps: Step 1: In a medium saucepan, heat 1 inch of vegetable oil to 350°. In a shallow bowl, whisk together the flour, fine cornmeal, cornstarch and the 1 teaspoon of salt. In another shallow bowl, whisk the buttermilk with the egg until thoroughly combined./nStep 2: Working in batches, dredge the onion rings in the flour mixture. Dip the rings in the buttermilk mixture, allowing the excess to drip off. Fry the rings until golden brown and crisp, about 1 minute per batch. Drain on paper towels and season with salt. Serve hot./nStep 3: The recipe can be made up to 3 hours ahead. Recrisp before serving.

Ingredients: 1 medium-size red onion (about 8 ounces), shaved on a mandoline into thin, translucent rings/n1 medium-size yellow onion (about 8 ounces), shaved on a mandoline into thin, translucent rings/n½ cup packed roughly chopped fresh flat-leaf parsley (about 1 large bunch)/n1 tablespoon ground sumac (such as Burlap & Barrel)
Steps: Step 1: Toss together onions, parsley, and sumac in a large bowl. Serve alongside kebabs./nStep 2: Shaved onions with sumac and parsley may be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 1 day.

Ingredients: 1 tablespoon neutral oil (such as grapeseed)/n1 large red onion, thinly sliced/n1/2 teaspoon kosher salt/n1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce/n1/2 teaspoon dry sherry/n1 (8-ounce) sheet frozen puff pastry sheet (such as Defour), thawed/nFlour for dusting work surface/n1 (9-ounce) wheel Brie with rind/n1 large egg beaten with 1 tablespoon of water/n1 baguette, thinly sliced/n3 tablespoons unsalted butter
Steps: Step 1: Heat oil in a 10- to 12-inch high-sided skillet over medium-high. Add onion slices; turn to coat in oil. Cook until sizzling, about 3 minutes. Add salt and toss to combine. Cover pan, reduce heat to medium, and cook until onions have collapsed to half their height and a pool of liquid has collected in bottom of skillet, about 8 minutes. Fold onions with a spatula, scraping bottom of pan to ensure they don’t stick or scorch. Cook, stirring every 5 to 6 minutes and reducing heat as necessary to maintain a gentle simmer, until liquid has evaporated, about 18 to 20 minutes. Stir in Worcestershire sauce and sherry. Remove pan from heat and let onions cool until just warm./nStep 2: Preheat oven to 400°F.  Place a piece of parchment paper on work surface and place puff pastry on top. Roll out puff pastry to an even 10-inch square. Transfer pastry to prepared baking sheet./nStep 3: Place Brie in center of pastry. Spoon onion mixture on top of Brie, spreading it evenly on top. Fold 2 opposite corners of pastry together to cover Brie; repeat with remaining 2 corners so Brie is completely encased in pastry. Tuck in any stray edges or corners of pastry as needed, making sure there are no gaps or holes that would let cheese leak out. Brush pastry all over with egg wash./nStep 4: Place baguette slices on a separate baking sheet. Brush tops of slices with melted butter./nStep 5: Bake Brie in preheated oven for about 35 minutes, until pastry is crisp and golden brown. While Brie bakes, toast baguette slices in oven until golden, 10 to 12 minutes. Remove baguette slices and Brie from oven and let cool for 5 minutes before serving.

Ingredients: 6  (about 2 1/2 pounds total) bone-in, skin-on chicken thighs/n2  tablespoons, plus 2 teaspoons olive oil, divided/n2 teaspoons kosher salt, divided/n1 teaspoon black pepper, divided/n1  frozen puff pastry sheet, thawed (from 1 [17.3-ounce] package)/n1  large egg, beaten/n2 tablespoons unsalted butter/n2  medium-size (about 1 pound, 4 ounces total) yellow onions, halved lengthwise and sliced 1/4-inch-thick (4 1/2 cups)/n2  large (6 ounces total) carrots, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch cubes (1 cup)/n¼ cup water/n1 tablespoon minced garlic (from 3 garlic cloves)/n¼ cup dry sherry/n3 tablespoons all-purpose flour, plus more for work surface/n2 cups beef stock/n2 teaspoons chopped fresh thyme, plus more for garnish/n¾ teaspoon chopped fresh rosemary/n4 ounces shredded Gruyère cheese, shredded (1 cup)
Steps: Step 1: Preheat oven to 425°F. Place chicken, 2 teaspoons of the olive oil, 1 teaspoon of the salt, and 1/2 teaspoon of the pepper in a large bowl; toss to coat. Place chicken, skin side up, on a baking sheet lined with aluminum foil. Bake in preheated oven until golden brown and a thermometer inserted into thickest portion of chicken registers 165°F, about 35 minutes. Remove chicken from oven, and let cool at room temperature until chicken is easy to handle, about 10 minutes. Remove and discard skin and bones. Using 2 forks, shred chicken into bite-size pieces; set aside. (You'll have about 3 cups.)/nStep 2: Unfold pastry sheet, and roll into a 9-inch square on a lightly floured work surface. Using a 3-inch round cookie cutter, cut pastry into 7 rounds. Discard excess dough. Place pastry rounds on a parchment paper-lined baking sheet. Brush tops evenly with egg. Bake in preheated oven until pastry is light brown and puffed, about 10 minutes. Remove from oven, and let cool on baking sheet./nStep 3: While pastry rounds are cooling, heat butter and remaining 2 tablespoons olive oil in a 10-inch cast-iron skillet over medium. Add onions; cook, stirring often, until golden brown, 25 to 28 minutes, adjusting heat as needed to prevent burning. Stir in carrots and water; cook, stirring often, until onions are deep golden brown and carrots are tender-crisp, 5 to 6 minutes. Add garlic; cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add sherry, scraping up any browned bits from bottom of skillet using a wooden spoon. Cook, stirring often, until liquid is evaporated, about 45 seconds./nStep 4: Stir in flour; cook, stirring constantly, until flour is light brown and onions become pasty, about 1 minute. Gradually stir in stock, and bring mixture to a simmer over medium. Simmer, stirring often, until mixture thickens, 3 to 5 minutes. Stir in reserved chicken, thyme, rosemary, and remaining 1 teaspoon salt and 1/2 teaspoon pepper. Remove from heat./nStep 5: Nestle puff pastry rounds on top of chicken mixture in skillet. Sprinkle cheese evenly over chicken mixture and puff pastry rounds. Bake at 425°F until cheese is completely melted, 8 to 10 minutes. Remove from oven, and let cool slightly, about 5 minutes. Garnish with additional thyme leaves, and serve.

Ingredients: 3 ounces mixed tender fresh herbs (about 7 loosely packed cups), such as basil, Thai basil, mint, cilantro, and lemon verbena/n3 cups simple syrup
Steps: Step 1: Bring a large pot of water to a boil over high. Arrange a double layer of cheesecloth in a strainer, and place strainer over a medium bowl so that strainer rests a few inches above bottom of bowl; set aside. Prepare an ice bath by filling a large bowl with ice water./nStep 2: Add herbs to boiling water; cook, stirring constantly, 10 to 15 seconds. Using a slotted spoon, transfer blanched herbs to ice bath. Let cool 5 minutes. Drain, gently squeezing out excess liquid, and transfer herbs to a blender. Add simple syrup to blender. Process on high speed until herb mixture is smooth, about 2 minutes. Pour into prepared strainer, and let stand, stirring occasionally without pressing on solids, until all liquid has passed through strainer, about 1 hour. Discard solids./nStep 3: Herb simple syrup may be stored in an airtight container in refrigerator up to 1 week.

Ingredients: 1 pound orecchiette/n⅓ cup extra-virgin olive oil/n¾ pound sweet Italian sausage (loose)/n1  red onion (large thinly sliced)/n15 ounces chickpeas (1 can rinsed and drained)/n1 cup mint leaves (small)/n2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice/nSalt/nPepper/nPlain yogurt (for serving)
Steps: Step 1: In a pot of salted boiling water, cook the orecchiette until al dente. Drain, reserving 3/4 cup of the cooking water./nStep 2: Wipe out the pot and heat the olive oil in it. Add the sausage and cook over moderate heat, breaking up the meat with a wooden spoon, until browned and nearly cooked through, 7 minutes. Add the onion and cook, stirring occasionally, until softened, about 3 minutes. Add the chickpeas, orecchiette and reserved cooking water and toss over moderate heat until the pasta is hot and coated in a light sauce, about 2 minutes. Stir in the mint and lemon juice and season with salt and pepper. Spoon the pasta into bowls and serve with yogurt./nStep 3: Pair this pasta dish with a spice-inflected Barbera d’Alba.
